HEADLINE: Future of Faith Worries Catholic Leaders

SERIES: Searching Its Soul: The American Catholic Church -- Last of four articles.

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS 

 BODY:
It was an awesome scene: nearly 400,000 Catholic teen-agers encamped last August in a Rocky Mountain park to join in sung praise and solemn prayer with Pope John Paul II. Amid this army of young believers, it was hard to imagine that the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, 60 million strong and growing, is fraught with anxiety about its future.
No one imagines that American Catholicism's vast numbers and impressive network of parishes, schools, hospitals, universities and social services will soon disappear. But church leaders increasingly wonder whether the church, even as its ranks increase and it draws new energy from the latest waves of immigrants, is losing its distinctive identity. 
 Enormous public attention has been focused in recent years on disputes over the church's teachings on abortion, divorce and sexual morality, on the arrests of priests for sexually abusing children and on the restriction of the priesthood to males, which the Pope affirmed on Monday in a declaration that among faithful Catholics the matter was no longer open for debate.
Yet the strong feelings stirred by these issues may be hampering the church's response to a less visible but more pervasive problem, what worried leaders inside the church have begun calling a "hollowing out" or "thinning" of Catholicism.
"We are a church at risk," said Marcel J. Dumestre, director of the Institute for Ministry at Loyola University in New Orleans.
There could scarcely be a more dramatic example of what worries such leaders than a finding of a New York Times/CBS News Poll in April: almost two-thirds of American Catholics believe that during Mass, the central sacred ritual of Catholicism, the bread and wine can best be understood as "symbolic reminders of Christ" rather than as actually being changed into Christ's body and blood. Even among the subgroup of Catholics who said they attended Mass every week or almost every week, 51 percent described the rite as strictly symbolic.
For centuries, and especially since the Reformation, the church has insisted upon the actual change of the bread and wine into the "real presence" of Christ as a defining mark of the Mass. This emphasis on "sacramentality," on God's life-giving action through material signs and physical acts -- water, wine, bread, laying on of hands, all mediated by a structured church -- has been the hallmark of the Catholic approach to worship.
No survey question can adequately measure a complex religious belief, but results so much at odds with longstanding doctrine are "certainly an alarm bell," said Archbishop Rembert Weakland of Milwaukee.
 
Parallel With Some Protestants
 Paradoxically, some recent sources of the church's vitality -- especially its encouragement of an active laity and its heightened sensitivity to social problems -- may have contributed to this spiritual drift. A number of Catholic thinkers who endorse those trends worry nonetheless that the Church's mystical element is being lost, eclipsed by a concern with ethical conduct, psychological healing and social service.
At the same time, sociologists of American religion point out that religious groups demanding adherence to clear-cut beliefs and practices have tended to flourish while those refusing to define their boundaries have languished.
Catholicism, in their eyes, is confronting the same quandaries as the mainline Protestant denominations, for whom tolerance and humanitarian social action have become more important than doctrinal boundaries. Their numbers have been declining while those of evangelical and fundamentalist groups have grown.
Yet rigid adherence to traditional doctrine also has a cost: the alienation of Catholics who believe that teachings in areas like divorce and contraception are incompatible with the complexities of their own experience.
 
Membership
Commitment? Yes. But on What?
 "Abortion, absolution, afterlife, AIDS, alcohol abuse, arms control, art, asbestos, astrology, atheism, Auschwitz. . . ." R. Scott Appleby, director of the Cushwa Center for the Study of American Catholicism at the University of Notre Dame, was reading aloud an index of topics that Catholic leaders and organizations had recently addressed. He noted the mix of the spiritual and the social, the pastoral and the political.
"An impressive range of concerns," Professor Appleby summed up in an interview, "that reach into almost every aspect of American culture and public life."
But he also drew attention to "the cracks in the fresco": the decline in Mass attendance, the ebb in financial support from the laity, the disaffection of many women, the shrinking number of priests and especially "the increasing difficulty of socializing young people into a committed Catholicism."
Professor Appleby sees a coming generation of Catholics who periodically turn to the church for psychological support but "with no sense of ownership." A traditional sense of being Catholic, he said, is being "displaced by a more eclectic kind of piety" that is unlikely to fill the pews, the collection baskets and the ranks of priests.
This concern about the loss of Catholic identity, once largely limited to conservatives or Catholics nostalgic for the church of their youth, is now expressed as well by liberals like Archbishop Weakland.
"It is becoming clearer and clearer that committed Catholics are very committed, very involved," the Archbishop said in a recent interview. "And then there are the others. They go to Mass irregularly and they say they are Catholics on a census, but that is about it."
 
New Steps, Old Problems
 Although liberals like Archbishop Weakland and conservative church leaders closer to the Vatican's outlook increasingly recognize the same problem, their contrasting outlooks prevent a concerted response.
Many bishops, for example, hope that confusion or ignorance about Catholic beliefs will be countered by the new catechism. But its appearance in English last Friday was first delayed for more than a year by the Vatican's rejection of a gender-neutral translation and then clouded by criticism of the approved translation's repeated use of "man" and "he" for all humankind.
Similarly, the Pope's declaration on Monday that ruled out even consideration of women's ordination was welcomed by conservatives as a needed clarification of Catholic identity but worried liberals. They fear that the declaration will feed disaffection in a Catholic population that, according to surveys, has long favored ordaining women by a large majority.
"How, as a bishop, am I to deal with the anger and disillusionment which will inevitably result?" Archbishop Weakland asked on Monday in a written response to the Vatican declaration.
 
Institutions
Where to Go Now After Opening Up
 Anxiety is heightened by awareness that the church is undergoing a double transition. From parishes to Catholic universities, lay people are increasingly filling major posts traditionally held by priests and sisters. The next two decades are likely to see a decisive shift in leadership throughout Catholic life from a generation brought up in the certainties of the pre-Second Vatican Council church to one formed during the uncertainties and experimentation of the late 60's and 70's.
Thirty years ago, the only lay people on almost all parish payrolls were janitors, housekeepers and perhaps the organist. Properly religious tasks were the responsibility of priests, except in parochial schools where sisters held sway.
Today, quite apart from the 149,000 lay people who outnumber nuns 10 to 1 as teachers in parish schools, parishes employ 20,000 lay people and sisters to direct religious education, prepare people for baptism and other sacraments, plan liturgies and carry out other pastoral tasks. A few hundred individuals are actually running parishes that no longer have a priest of their own.
Forty percent of these 20,000 parish ministers are sisters, but almost half of these women are over 60 years old. The lay workers who will soon be filling these slots have significantly fewer years of Catholic schooling and of training in specifically religious subjects. And with women constituting 85 percent of the new parish ministers, questions raised by feminists, whether of equal treatment, access to the priesthood or religious language, seem certain to become more pressing.
As long as priests carried out almost all pastoral tasks, bishops, who oversaw seminary training and parish assignments, effectively held the reins. Today parish pastors are choosing the lay ministers, often from among parish volunteers whose training, in turn, may be on-the-job or obtained from graduate programs in theology and pastoral work. For many parishioners this may be invigorating, but it also means a weakening of the church hierarchy's traditional control over practice and belief.
 
Catholic Hospitals
 The problem of maintaining a special identity stretches from the religious knowledge of individual church members to the whole array of Catholic institutions.
The Catholic hospitals, universities and social services dotting most large and medium-sized American cities were established primarily to serve the needs of Catholic immigrant populations. They were supported by money raised by the church and were staffed by people, largely priests and nuns, animated by a shared religious commitment.
But today, in a spirit of community outreach, many of those institutions are as likely to serve non-Catholics as Catholics. They increasingly rely on government money or support from non-Catholic foundations and donors. And they are more and more staffed and led by professionals chosen on the basis of technical skills not religious beliefs.
As a consequence, Catholic leaders are wondering what is apt to make the Catholic hospital of the future different from its public counterpart. Will it, for example, be legally able to bar procedures like abortion that violate Catholic moral principles?
And what will make the Catholic university different from the state or private institution down the road?
 
Eyes on Universities
 In fact, Catholic higher education presents a laboratory case of the conflicts surrounding Catholic identity. Besides wielding considerable influence over the lives of young Catholics attending them, the nation's 235 Catholic colleges and universities are major seedbeds for Catholic thought and places where scholars in fields from literature to economics can plumb the relevance of the church tradition to contemporary culture.
For over two decades, most of these institutions have purposely tried to escape from a religious conformity that Catholic educators believed was stifling intellectual excellence. Faculty members were hired on the basis of academic standards that usually excluded religious considerations. Control was often passed from religious orders to independent lay-run boards. Urban Catholic universities like Georgetown in Washington and Fordham in New York attracted highly diverse student bodies as well as faculties.
In 1990, after years of consultations, the Pope issued "Ex Corde Ecclesiae," a document calling for a renewed emphasis on the religious identity of Catholic higher education. But the effort by a committee of the American bishops' conference to draft "ordinances" applying the document has led to a standoff with Catholic educators, many of whom acknowledge the need to insure their institutions' Catholic identity but also fear that the bishops' involvement may threaten academic freedom and their campuses' eligibility for Government money.
Efforts to bring hiring of theology faculty members or other campus policies under the control of bishops will only stir a backlash, these educators warn, and actually increase the pressure toward secularization.
 
Factions
Several Agendas To Save Church
 The pattern of conflict over Catholic higher education is paralleled in other areas of church life -- from sexual ethics to the priesthood. At least three schools of thought are competing to shape the church's future.
In one camp are conservatives looking to Rome for unambiguous directives concerning church teaching and policy and to Pope John Paul II as a champion of Catholic forcefulness. They want papally approved teaching energetically proclaimed and, wherever possible, directly enforced by bishops and priests.
Against a culture that these conservatives consider profoundly hostile to Catholicism, they seek bulwarks in official texts: for example, the Pope's latest declaration rejecting women's ordination, the new catechism, the 1968 papal encyclical, "Humanae Vitae," affirming the condemnation of contraception, Vatican statements upholding traditional sexual morality or chastising dissenting theologians.
They echo the cry that Catholicism must be "counter-cultural," a term that Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger, the Vatican's overseer of Catholic doctrine, borrowed from 1960's student leftists to signal a sweeping challenge to the materialism, individualism and secularism that they associate with the dominant cultural elites in the West.
The conservatives are also convinced that by imitating the Pope's confidence in the truth of church teaching and his appeal to heroic self-sacrifice the church could recruit candidates for the priesthood and communicate its faith to young people.
The Vatican itself prefers to concentrate on the zones of church life where it can more easily exercise control: the appointment of bishops, the training of seminarians, the teaching of theology in Vatican-accredited degree programs like the one at Catholic University of America, the policies of religious orders of priests and nuns.
Safeguarding a highly loyal core of bishops, clergy and theologians in the United States and elsewhere appears to be the Vatican's priority, even if the immediate cost is fewer priests or isolation from contemporary culture. The church's leaders in Rome want to insure that at least that nucleus will be there when the world comes to its senses.
On the other end of the spectrum are groups of liberal Catholics who worry less about the maintenance of traditional Catholic identity than about goals like opening the priesthood to women, readmitting to active service those priests who have married, revoking the church's condemnation of homosexual relations or supporting radical social and political movements.
As in the Democratic Party, the church's left often resembles a collection of groups seeking recognition for single interests or excluded minorities. It includes the Women's Ordination Conference; Corpus, an association of priests who resigned to marry; Dignity, a group representing Catholic homosexuals, and Pax Christi, an anti-military organization. But the sympathy for one another's causes is general.
For some in this camp, the emergence of a "cafeteria Catholicism" in which individual believers choose whatever doctrines and practices accord with their own experiences or needs and feel little loyalty to church institutions is an almost inevitable reflection of American culture -- and one that does not disturb them.
 
Struggling in the Middle
 Caught between these factions, striving to construct a center that will hold, is a segment of American church leadership that doubts whether the liberal agenda offers a realistic remedy to the pressing question of Catholic identity but also demurs from the conservative tendency to rely heavily on authoritative statements or papal example.
Instead, these leaders argue that Catholic identity must be nurtured among a broad base of Catholics by persuasion, a task that they believe demands flexibly adapting general directives to particular circumstances, encouraging consultation with clergy and laity and living with a wide variety of theological opinion.
The liberals among them generally favor revision of church teachings in areas like birth control, divorce and the ordination of married men or women. The moderate conservatives among them disagree but do not treat the liberals' stance as disloyalty to the church or Pope.
Like any centrist group, this one is subject to withering attacks from both left and right. Many militant liberals suspect that talk about Catholic identity threatens a return to what they view as a narrower Catholicism. For them, assuring the church's well-being demands further relaxing, not reinforcing, the boundaries of Catholic life.
Militant conservatives, on the other hand, believe that the moderates' emphasis on consultation and persuasion means trimming church authority and doctrine to appease feminists, advocates of sexual liberation and the new layers of church employees whom the conservatives consider especially susceptible to intellectual fashions.
The next 10 to 15 years may well determine whether the American Catholic Church survives as a flabby and failing institution, a reduced but militant body or a still-growing and thriving church.
"There has to be a clear articulation of boundaries," said Professor Appleby of Notre Dame. But this must be done, he said, without cutting off Catholicism from "what is good and enduring in contemporary culture."

HEADLINE: The Pyongyang Puzzle

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 31

 BODY:
When North Korea first began playing cat-and-mouse with the Clinton Administration over nuclear inspections, Washington's goal seemed simple: the Communist leaders of one of the world's most unpredictable states could not be permitted to possess a nuclear weapon.
But in the ensuing 18 months, as Washington and its allies have alternately tried to pressure, sweet-talk and threaten the North into giving up its bomb project, reality has set in and the objectives have grown far more complicated. 
 And during the last few days, as the North has raced to pull nuclear fuel out of a reactor in open defiance of a treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons, there are still raging arguments among the allies over what to insist upon, how much risk of confrontation to take and what to settle for.
The problem is that Mr. Clinton's initial goal -- to establish with certainty that the North does not possess a bomb -- is now virtually unattainable. If the North has built one or two bombs, an "if" that stymies intelligence agencies, the chances of finding it soon are next to nil.
So during the last year, the Administration and its allies have subtly shifted their goals. More important than finding one or two weapons made in the past, American officials began saying late last year, is preventing the North from acquiring more. As an inducement, they offered talks on diplomatic and economic relations.
While it would be a bad precedent to pay countries off to observe the terms of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, the Japanese suggest, it would be worse to let North Korea become the first country to abandon the treaty.
And while a nuclear-armed North may be a scary prospect, many in South Korea ask, is it worth risking a second disastrous confrontation on the Korean peninsula in 40 years, especially when the prosperous South has clearly won the economic contest and has so much to lose?
The result has been a muddying of objectives that helps to explain how allied officials can exclaim one week that a solution is in sight, then despair the next week about looming disaster.
"No one is sure exactly what we want, and what we will settle for," a senior Japanese diplomat said the other day. "So no one is quite sure how hard to push."
The North has sensed the confusion, and seems to have capitalized on it skillfully.
Several times now North Korea has changed the terms of the argument. For seven years it barred inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency, despite the fact that it had signed the nonproliferation treaty in 1985. When it finally allowed them in, North Korea entered an argument over whether they had the right to visit two waste dumps detected by United States satellites that might reveal how much plutonium the North possesses.
When that issue seemed likely to bring Security Council action, the Government announced it was withdrawing from the nuclear treaty. This sent Washington scrambling to come up with incentives to keep the North from pulling out, a step that would legally bar all inspectors.
That issue was never resolved. But for more than half a year inspectors were barred from the heavily guarded nuclear complex at Yongbyon anyway, and their monitoring cameras ran out of film and batteries. When they were finally allowed back, in March, they were prevented from taking samples to determine what had happened in the interim.
 
Worry About New Fuel Supply
 A few weeks ago, facing a new threat of economic sanctions, the North switched tactics again. It let the inspectors finish their sampling work in one building while it began unloading fuel from the biggest reactor, a step that would give North Korea the raw material for four or five more bombs and would destroy the best evidence of how much plutonium was diverted in the past.
Suddenly, rather than focus on history, the United States raced to make sure no new fuel is diverted.
The current crisis is focused on the unloading of that fuel, which apparently proceeded at a startling pace over the weekend. Hans Blix, the director of the International Atomic Energy Agency, warned last week that within days the agency "would not be in a position to verify, with any degree of confidence, that all nuclear material" is accounted for, meaning that there was little left to negotiate.
 
The Pace Quickens
 Those accusing the Administration of taking too soft a line say it has simply been strung along: the North is moving flat-out to build a bomb, several officials who served on President George Bush's national security team argue, and is simply playing for time. The "Great Leader" of the North, Kim Il Sung, they say, is as wily now as he was 40 years ago when he took Washington unawares and launched the Korean War.
Evidence to support that view has greatly strengthened recently.
Inspectors say the capacity of the reprocessing plant that produces bomb-grade plutonium has been doubled; United States intelligence officials expect a second test imminently of a North Korea-designed missile that can carry a nuclear weapon.
"For every step we take to slow things down," Leonard Spector of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace said recently, "they take two to speed it up."
But defenders of the keep-talking strategy say what the North wants more than a bomb is to maintain the mystery of whether it can build one. Unless its adversaries are kept in the dark about the program, this theory goes, there is no chance the North will get the economic aid it needs so desperately.
"It comes down to this," said an American military official in Seoul: "If we know that the bomb project is a dud, we'll forget about the North and move on to the next crisis. They get nothing. And if we know it is a success, we go to sanctions. So they want to keep it in-between."
A result of such mind games is that the once-definitive statements from Washington and Seoul about what the world can tolerate now come in many more shades of gray.
"Clearly, the North Koreans want to preserve as much ambiguity about their program as they can," said Han Sung Joo, the patient and soft-spoken South Korean Foreign Minister. "But rather than view this as a question of whether the nuclear program will be open or not, I think we have come to see that the question is how much transparency the North will provide." Somewhere along that scale, he said, "we have to draw a line."
 
'Very Dangerous Point'
 The effort this week is to convince the North that in unloading the fuel and preventing the inspectors from sampling it, they are at the edge of no return. The South Korean President, Kim Young Sam, called President Clinton today, and Mr. Kim's spokesman immediately announced that the two leaders saw the issue reaching a "very dangerous point."
The Security Council, in subdued language aimed at appeasing China, which has consistently opposed sanctions, tried to send the same message in a statement Sunday that "further Security Council consideration will take place" to achieve full compliance by North Korea, a veiled reference to sanctions.
But the North knows that no one wants to go that route -- not China, and certainly not Japan, where the Government is doing everything it can to suppress discussion of the extensive contingency plans it has drawn up to cut off hundreds of millions of dollars in funds to the North, and perhaps take part in a blockade.
North Korea may well turn to the technique that has worked so many times before: offer a little more transparency, just enough to defuse the immediate crisis, and keep building at Yongbyon.

HEADLINE: Effort Is Begun By Dominicans To Seal Border

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DAJABON, Dominican Republic, May 30

 BODY:
The Deputy Secretary of the Armed Forces stomped along a dirt path by the muddy Massacre River, glaring at hundreds of Haitians on the other side sitting under trees or wading out to probe for a place to cross.
Every few dozen yards on the Dominican side of the river was a freshly arrived paratrooper in the black beret of the elite Airborne Brigade, blocking the countless trails worn toward places selling gasoline or other scarce goods. 
 The paratroopers pulled themselves to attention at the approach of the officer, Maj. Gen. Luis Luna Paulino.
"I don't want to see anyone talking to Haitians," the general barked to a pickup truck loaded with new troops. "Anyone talking to Haitians will be out of a job."
For four days now, since shortly after President Joaquin Balaguer met with President Clinton's point man on Haiti, William H. Gray 3d, the general and his men appear to have shut down this once-bustling smuggling center.
It was a remarkable turnabout.
For months, Mr. Balaguer was loath to crack down on the booming smuggling trade, his public reason a fear that increased hardship in Haiti would bring an unwelcome flood of refugees.
With the embargo stepped up a week ago to include everything but food and medical supplies, the porous Dominican border was the weakest point in the international effort to unseat the Haitian military junta that ousted the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in 1991.
But after the hotly disputed Dominican presidential election on May 16, which was marked by widespread accusations of fraud by international observers as well as Dominicans, Mr. Balaguer found himself susceptible to American persuasion.
 
Understanding With the U.S.
 The meeting with Mr. Gray was widely seen here as producing an understanding that the Americans would not make an issue of the election and the Dominicans would cooperate in enforcing the embargo. Mr. Balaguer dispatched General Luna Paulino, the second-ranking official in the armed forces, to the northern sector of the border and another major general, Tomas Fernandez Alarcon, to the southern area.
The Defense Ministry says that half of the army, some 15,000 troops, is on the border, and that the regular border guards, many of whom had been augmenting their meager salaries on the brisk gasoline trade, were transferred out or in some cases arrested.
"Before, the United Nations only called the embargo 'provisional,' " General Luna Paulino explained to a visitor, saying he had been sent here at the end of last week with a new set of orders. "Now our primary target is to stop all the fuel to Haiti. We cannot expose the Dominican Republic to losing international credibility."
But at night, hundreds of Haitians still try to swarm across the river, some now carrying sticks or knives. Groups of the Haitians fight with the soldiers, the general said, while others scatter in different directions trying to fill plastic containers of fuel. Townspeople say a rich Haitian businessman waits on the other side to collect the fuel.
Sealing off a town and the official border crossing here is the easiest part, military officials concede. Most of the frontier is unsettled hill and river country, difficult to patrol, the general said, and his troops are short of vehicles, communications equipment, night vision scopes and even rations. There have been nocturnal encounters with smugglers in the hills, too, including one in which, General Luna Paulino said, he was hit in the arm with a rock.
Given the difficulties -- and the profits to be made -- it is uncertain how effective the effort will be or, indeed, how long it will be pressed.
"It's like a shell game," said a Western diplomat unimpressed with the flurry of activity. "They'll keep it up for a few weeks. There is still stuff getting through at night."
But the army has already collected hundreds of fuel barrels, plastic jugs and ingenious tanks, including hollowed-out automobile, bus and truck seats and a dump truck equipped to hold only a few inches of sand with gasoline concealed below. Some of the houses he has raided in town, the general said, had false walls to hide gasoline tanks.
 
A Blow to Residents
 In the sun-baked market square of Dajabon, residents mourned the economic disaster that had befallen them. In addition to the profit to be made from gasoline smuggling, Haitians were allowed freely over the border twice a week to stock up on supplies, mostly bananas, chickens and eggs. At midday, merchants who came in from the countryside after buying from farmers were glumly reloading their sagging pickup trucks with unsold produce.
"A few days ago you could come into this town until 1 o'clock in the morning and find Haitians smuggling," grumbled Bonifacio Vargas, standing with other Dominicans by huge heaps of unsold bananas. "Now you see nothing."
Maria Tejada agreed. "Now it's completely sealed," she said. "The army has closed everything." Pura Sanchez added angrily: "I have five kids I support selling bananas. No Haitian can come across, and I don't make a single peso. What am I to do?"
Running his hand across his neck like a knife, Ramon Grollon said: "The U.N. is cutting my throat. We have lost all our money. The Devil will take us all."
The Dominican Republic and Haiti uneasily share the Caribbean island of Hispaniola. African slaves revolting against their French masters on the western end of the island in 1804 overran the Spanish-colonized eastern portion. They remained in control until they were ousted in a war of independence in 1844.
In 1937 the Dominican Army massacred thousands of Haitians along the border.
Mr. Balaguer, though, has long enjoyed good relations with Haiti's dictators, and provided refuge in times of trouble. He is also said to detest Father Aristide, who asserted that Haitian workers who cut cane and did other menial jobs in the Dominican Republic were treated like slaves.
"Haiti's best friend is Balaguer," an important Haitian backer of the military coup, Senator Bernard Sansaricq, told the Dominican newspaper El Nacional before the President's about-face on the embargo.
 
Protege of Trujillo
 But Mr. Balaguer, a protege of the late Gen. Rafael Trujillo, who ran the country with an iron hand for 30 years, is even more aware than most Dominicans of the potential of American influence.
He was installed as President with American backing after Washington's military intervention in 1965 and has been in office for 20 of the last 28 years. One of his two losses was negotiated with the American Embassy so Mr. Balaguer's party would retain control of the Senate, which appoints all judges, thus discouraging any unseemly prosecutions.
In this year's election campaign, Mr. Balaguer sought to portray his opponent, Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, as a sort of closet Haitian -- his parents fled the 1937 massacre and he was raised by a Dominican family -- and perhaps even a furtive practitioner of voodoo, who might give the country away to its neighbors.
In the closing days, rumors swept the country that a plan was afoot, backed by France, Canada and the United States, to unite the island. Dominican flags went up on many houses as a nationalist symbol.
His narrow margin -- 30,000 votes among three million cast -- is being challenged by opponents as the product of electoral fraud, and a recount is under way.
At issue, said Juan Bolivar Diaz, a prominent journalist investigating the campaign, spreading out piles of electoral lists and returns, is a pattern in which the identification numbers of about 25 voters per precinct were switched with other names, making them ineligible, coupled with unaccountably high turnouts in some places.
The official election results show seven provinces with returns ranging from 100.36 percent of those eligible to a high of 135.22 percent in Espaillat Province.
"It's clearly visible," said Mr. Bolivar, who was the official pool reporter at the election board for the last two elections. "In our past electoral history, which is full of fraud, I don't think we have any examples where they have left such traces."
But one of Mr. Balaguer's most prominent party supporters, Donald Reid, dismissed such accusations wearily.
"I have been an actor or front-row spectator for more than 30 years, and it's always the same," said Mr. Reid, a member of the legendary Ten Families who control much of the country's wealth. "Whichever party loses, they call fraud."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bank Buying The Building Named for It

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Bankers Trust Building, which takes up the block from 48th to 49th Street on Park Avenue, is no longer that in name only. In a complicated transaction, the bank is buying the part of its headquarters building that it does not already own. The deal should close by late fall.
The bank is exercising an option to buy the property according to a formula based on its fair market value as of Jan 1, 1993. The bank and the owner of the property, Sigmund Sommer Properties, could not agree on an appraisal of the building. 
 On Friday, an arbitration board set the value at $135.4 million. The bank will pay an undisclosed fraction of that amount.
The bank's appraisers, Cushman & Wakefield, had valued the property at $90 million; James Felt Appraising, the Sommer appraiser, put the worth at $180 million.
 
 
First Rights of Refusal
 The difference stemmed as much from the complicated ownership split between land and buildings as it did from different perceptions of the direction of the Manhattan office market. Although the building carries one address, 280 Park Avenue, it is in fact three separate buildings.
In 1968, shortly after the last building was built, Bankers Trust negotiated a favorable long-term lease for about 40 percent of the space. It also had first rights of refusal on space that became available when other tenants left.
Today, Bankers Trust occupies about half of the complex's more than 1.1. million square feet.
In 1979, Bankers Trust bought the land under the east and middle buildings. Eight years later it bought the 30-story building fronting on Park Avenue, from Rose Associates. Sommer retained the land under the western building, and owned both the middle and western building.
 
 
Dueling Appraisers
 Bankers Trust's lease said it signed an agreement to buy the middle and west building in 1988, although the price would not be determined for five years.
People involved in the negotiations said the owner's appraiser viewed the property as though the buildings were vacant and leasable in a real estate market that was moving out of recession, and valued it as though the buildings and land had one owner.
The bank's appraisers took into account that many of the leases, including those held by Bankers Trust, were below the rents that a prime midtown building could now command in an improving market, about $38 a square foot. Also, because Bankers Trust owned the land, the appraisers had argued that the building's value on the open market had been diminished.
 
 
Taking Over Lease in 2013
 If Bankers Trust had decided not to buy the building, it might have owned it eventually anyway. Its lease says it can take it over for the nominal sum of $20 in the year 2013.
"The formula for establishing a price, combined with saving the cost of 21 years of rental, still gave us a significant economic advantage for buying the building now," a Bankers Trust executive said.
Bankers Trust says it has not yet decided whether to take more space in the building as other tenants move or to move any people from the space it rents downtown at Bankers Trust Plaza on Liberty Street.

HEADLINE: City Asks $100 Million for Coliseum Parcel

 BODY:
A day before the start of the trial to determine whether Mortimer B. Zuckerman's $338 million contract to build at the New York Coliseum is valid, the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday formally agreed to offer him half the site.
In an agreement which has still to be accepted by Mr. Zuckerman, he would pay $80 million for half the property and $20 million would come from city subsidies from annual tax payments generated by the project. 
 John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, said terms of the new offer would include a $17 million down payment by the developer and his agreement to start building by April 30, 1995.
Mr. Zuckerman, who signed a contract in 1989 to build a 2.1-million-square-foot retail, office and residential complex on the full Coliseum site at 59th Street and Columbus Circle, has been trying to negotiate a smaller development at a lower price.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
U.S. to Help With Supercomputer Software

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The Department of Energy will soon announce a federally backed effort by Cray Research Inc. and 16 other companies to develop advanced software for supercomputers, the Secretary of Energy, Hazel R. O'Leary, said yesterday.
The program, which will also involve two of the Energy Department's national laboratories, is meant to develop practical business applications for the powerful "massively parallel" supercomputers made by Cray and other American companies, including the Thinking Machines Corporation, which is also taking part. 
 About half the funds for the $50 million program will be Federal money, with Cray Research providing $12 million. The rest will come from the other companies, which have been drawn from the oil, chemical, automotive, pharmaceutical and other industries heavily reliant on powerful computers for research and product design.
Unlike many past Federal programs involving the national labs, in which weapons research sometimes found practical applications for civilian industry, the software effort is being driven by the needs and skills of private business, Mrs. O'Leary said.
"I have invited the private sector, which knows a whole series of applications" for supercomputers, Mrs. O'Leary said, describing the program with a reporter after alluding to it yesterday at a luncheon in Manhattan with security analysts.
 
Labs Seeking Mission
 The software effort comes at a time when the Government's laboratories are seeking a new mission in the post-cold-war era.
Cray is a leader in massively parallel supercomputers, so-called because they use hundreds or even thousands of inexpensive microprocessors harnessed in parallel to achieve vast information-processing power. Such machines have become tools for solving tough problems for scientists and engineers. But for corporate computing customers, a major frustration has been developing software that enables them to use the machines fully to attack practical problems like analyzing seismic data from an oilfield or simulating the inner workings of a combustion chamber in an auto engine.
"The goal is to make these machines sing," Frank Parisi, a spokesman for Cray Research, said.
Mrs. O'Leary said that some of the companies expected to be involved in the effort were Alcoa, Amoco, AT&T, Boeing, Hughes Aircraft and Schlumberger, an oil and gas exploration company. A complete list was not available yesterday because some of the companies had not yet signed final agreements to take part.
In the past, the Department of Energy has been a big customer for supercomputers primarily for the use of its own laboratories.
Two of those, the Los Alamos National Labororatory and the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, will be involved in the software effort.
Larry Smarr, the director of the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois, said there was a need to develop software capable of keeping up with the increasingly powerful hardware produced by computer makers. "There are many problems of national importance that will require supercomputers that are 100 times faster than the ones today," Mr. Smarr said.
The question about the new Energy Department effort, he said, is whether it can be done in an economical way that has applications for the private sector. Too often, in the past, he said, when the Government has become involved in such efforts, there have been few useful results for private business.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Sudan Envoy to Visit African Capitals

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
President Clinton's new special envoy to the Sudan is to visit several African capitals this week as part of a stepped-up American effort to end the Sudanese civil war and to speed the flow of relief to a nation where American officials say millions are threatened with starvation.
As part of her trip, Melissa F. Wells, the special envoy appointed on May 20, plans to urge the Sudanese Government to allow an increased flow of aid to sustain the 2 million people in Sudan's rebellious south and 1.3 million in the Government-controlled north who rely on food aid. 
 American officials admit that their diplomatic efforts are unlikely to end the decades-old conflict between the Islamic Government based in the capital, Khartoum, and the Christian and animist rebels in the south. Nonetheless, these officials say it is important to press ahead with diplomatic efforts because of the magnitude of the crisis there.
"This is just about the most complicated task there is," a State Department official said. "It's more difficult than Somalia."
Malnutrition has reached emergency levels because of a serious drought and because of the Government's spring offensive, which has impeded the flow of relief and forced huge numbers of people in the southern Sudan to abandon their farms.
According to the Agency for International Development, 400,000 of the Sudan's 28 million people have become refugees in neighboring nations as a result of the 11-year-old war, while another 700,000 have been displaced internally. Some officials fear that 280,000 people will starve in the Sudan -- more than the number who died of malnutrition in Somalia.
In addition to visiting Khartoum and the rebel-held South, Ms. Wells plans to go to the four countries that are seeking to broker a peace plan in the Sudan: Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda and Kenya. Those four countries sponsored unsuccessful talks two weeks ago, and no new talks are scheduled until late July.
The main success of those four countries has been in persuading the Sudanese Government and the rebel group, the Sudan People's Liberation Army, to set up corridors to help relief efforts get through.
About the only ray of hope seen by American officials is that the Government may feel pressed to end the war because Government troops have suffered so many casualties and the war has wreaked havoc on the north's economy.
Washington's complaint with the Sudan goes far beyond the Government's spring offensive, which has included bombing of camps with displaced people. The United States is also angry about the Sudanese Government's support of terrorist groups.
Having put the Sudan on its terrorism list, the United States treats Khartoum as a junior member of the rogue states that include Iraq and Iran. American officials say the Sudan has received many of its weapons from China while Iran has financed much of those purchases.
According to Administration officials, Ms. Wells's message to the Sudanese Government will be to stop sheltering terrorist organizations nad to stop human rights abuses.
Ms. Wells, a former Ambassador to Zaire, Mozambique and Guinea-Bissau, is refusing to comment on the Sudan situation until after her trip.

HEADLINE: Japan Is Considering Optical Fiber Network

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 31

 BODY:
The Japanese Government is considering creating a multibillion-dollar communications network to connect every home and business in Japan with optical fibers by the year 2010.
The plan, which was recommended today by the Telecommunications Council, an influential Government advisory board, is expected to be adopted by the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications. It would form the core of Japan's response to similar plans in the United States for a national information infrastructure, sometimes called the information superhighway. As in the United States, most of the actual work would be left to the private sector. 
 Such a network would be costly. The council estimated that bringing fiber to 75 million subscribers by 2010 would cost between $300 billion and $500 billion, depending on the network's sophistication. Laying the cables underground would require an additional $400 billion.
 
N.T.T. Building Network
 The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the nation's main telephone company, is already building a $400 billion nationwide optical network, which it intends to complete by the year 2015. The council's plan would speed that up by five years, although it is unclear how a new timetable could be enforced.
The source of the necessary financing is also not yet clear. But industry and Government officials here have grown increasingly worried that Japan is lagging behind the United States in advanced telecommunications and multimedia.
Japanese companies and consumers have largely stood by while the use of computer networks has mushroomed in the United States and while American telephone and cable companies have begun testing services like video on demand, home shopping and electronic libraries. The American companies are hoping to have fiber optics installed in most of their networks by early in the next decade, years ahead of the Japanese target.
 
Efficiency Is a Goal
 Developing its own information infrastructure would help Japan spawn new industries and make existing industries more efficient as the economy shifts from manufacturing to services. The Telecommunications Council also said the network could help relieve traffic congestion by promoting tele-commuting and providing such services as remote medical checkups to Japan's aging society.
The council recommended that the bulk of the network be built by the private sector, mainly telephone and cable television companies. But the report also suggested that the Government would help by providing tax incentives, low-interest loans and other inducements.
The advisory council also recommended that the Government lead in developing public service uses of the network, for health care and education, for example. This would help finance the network before commercial applications developed.
Analysts say that one reason that Japan has fallen behind is the strictness of telecommunications regulations, which have left Japanese cable television companies undercapitalized and fragmented. Only about 3 percent of households here subscribe to cable services in contrast to 60 percent in the United States.
 
Broadcasting a Separate Fief
 Broadcasting and telecommunications have been considered separate fiefs in Japan, even though new technology allows them to merge. N.T.T. would like to offer video services over its optical fiber network, but there is a concern that it would be powerful enough to wipe out the smaller and weaker cable companies.
The advisory board recommends reviewing regulations and possibly ending these industry distinctions.
Despite a late start, Japan's Government and industry are gearing up for many tests of advanced telephone and cable services. And American companies, notably Time Warner and Tele-Communications Inc. are entering the Japanese market.

HEADLINE: California's Fast-Forward Politics

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 31

 BODY:
Democrats and Republicans will go to the polls on June 7 to nominate candidates in the California Governor's race, but conventional political wisdom and opinion surveys long ago jumped ahead of the primaries and nominated two contenders: Gov. Pete Wilson, the Republican, and State Treasurer Kathleen Brown, the Democrat.
They have been squaring off for the better part of 15 months, and the latest polls show Mr. Wilson pulling closer to Ms. Brown. A single issue is dominating what is probably the most important state election in the country this year: the California economy, which is still struggling to pull out of a recession. Crime is an important secondary issue. 
 The other candidates seeking nomination on June 7 have failed to make close races of the primaries, the first stage of a contest in which voters will not only choose a leader for the most populous and politically potent state but also provide some hints about Presidential prospects in 1996.
The most recent voter surveys, one taken in mid-May by the Field Poll of San Francisco, and the other taken last week by The Los Angeles Times, found a Wilson-Brown contest growing tighter. Even though Ms. Brown spent several months retooling her staff and message while stepping up her campaign pace, Mr. Wilson had pulled to within about 10 percentage points. He had trailed by more than 20 points in the past 15 months.
 
Economy a Wilson Thorn
 But the new polls also indicate that the Governor has serious weaknesses, with more people giving him a "poor" rating than a "good" rating for the job he has done in his four-year term. Most of his detractors blame him for the weakness in the state's economy, while his defenders say he could have done little about the hard hits the state took from the national recession and military cuts.
"This race has all the makings of going down to the wire," said the director of the Field Poll, Mervin Field. "If the primaries seem already settled, the things that the other primary candidates are doing and have done, even if they're out of it, can still impact on Wilson and Brown."
Besides Ms. Brown, a 48-year-old centrist whose father and brother are both former Governors, there are two other Democratic primary candidates. They are Insurance Commissioner John Garamendi, a 49-year-old former State Senator with considerable personal wealth and a bent toward populism, and State Senator Tom Hayden, best remembered as one of the noisiest radicals of the 1960's but more recently, at the age of 54, a surprisingly soft voice for peaceful change.
In the new polls, Mr. Garamendi trails Ms. Brown by about 20 points and Mr. Hayden trails by about 35 points. Those margins have not changed much for months, despite heavy campaign spending by Mr. Garamendi and a number of complimentary reviews by political columnists and analysts for Mr. Hayden.
 
A Lone Republican Challenger
 In the Republican primary, besides Mr. Wilson, whose politics also tend to be centrist, there is only one other candidate. He is Ron Unz, a little known conservative who has made a fortune producing computer software in Silicon Valley and has not hesitated to spend some of it on his campaign. In the new polls, Mr. Unz, who is 32, trails the Governor, who is 60, by almost 20 points.
But by spending heavily on television and by relentlessly assailing the Governor, he has managed to win over about 30 percent of the likely Republican electorate, the polls say.
"When a political unknown wins away one of every three Republicans from a Republican incumbent, it serves notice that the incumbent has some real weakness to deal with," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, an analyst at the Center for Politics and Economics at Claremont Graduate School. "Unz has been hitting Wilson on everything Californians worry most about: the economy, crime, taxes, you name it. He's the best thing that ever happened to Kathleen Brown."
Stung by Mr. Unz's attacks, Mr. Wilson agreed to a radio debate, a risky decision for a front-runner but one he decided would ultimately serve him well. Neither man overpowered the other in the debate, held on Friday, though Mr. Unz showed considerable stage presence and aggressiveness for a beginner. He went at Mr. Wilson again and again on the economy, asserting that he had not instituted enough programs to offset the loss of jobs from industry and military cutbacks.
 
Brown Ignores Opponents
 In a round of three television debates just completed by the Democrats, Ms. Brown concentrated on an all-out attack on Governor Wilson, not her primary opponents. Her opening line at each forum was, "I'm angry at Pete Wilson."
Ms. Brown also managed in the debates to fend off the most damaging blows from her Democratic challengers, though most analysts say Mr. Garamendi and Mr. Hayden scored points when she refused to say why she opposed capital punishment. Mr. Garamendi gave his unqualified support to capital punishment while Mr. Hayden said he supported it under certain circumstances.
Early in her campaign, Ms. Brown often stumbled when sharply questioned, and her basic message seemed at times to be unfocused. Some Democrats grumbled that she seemed to assume that her election was a foregone conclusion, given that her father, Edmund G. (Pat) Brown Sr., served as Governor from 1959 to 1967 and her brother, Edmund G. Brown Jr., served from 1975 to 1983.
She is making no assumptions about success now and takes pains to shape her own image, contending that she is neither as liberal as her father nor as New Age as her brother.
 
Long Days, One Issue
 Two months ago, she hired Clint Reilly, one of the state's top political consultants, to run her campaign. Today, her message is focused -- Pete Wilson, she says, has destroyed the California economy and with it the California dream -- and she campaigns 15 and 20 hours a day.
Mr. Wilson's gains in the latest polls might have been even greater had it not been for Mr. Reilly's work. "He's made the difference," said Ms. Jeffe, the political analyst.
Governor Wilson has taken a classic incumbent approach, relying heavily on state ceremonies, speeches and implementation of various programs to make his political points, and supplemented those activities with television advertising.
Mr. Wilson and Ms. Brown say they plan to spend heavily on television, which is more important in this hugely populous and diverse state than in any other.
At every opportunity, Mr. Wilson meets with police organizations and citizens groups to talk about crime. And he hammers repeatedly on the need for better control of illegal immigration, another issue of major concern in the state. "They keep coming," he says in one of his ads.
But so does the economic issue, and in the end, whatever else is debated, that is the subject that is likely to decide whether Pete Wilson or Kathleen Brown is the next Governor of California.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Looks Ahead to Good Old Days

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, May 31

 BODY:
As Gov. Mario M. Cuomo prepares to run for a fourth term, with his popularity dangerously low, he has been talking a lot about the good old days.
His approach is a politics of nostalgia, Cuomo-style, aimed at reminding voters why they once admired him. He pines for his chronological youth -- for days when jobs were plentiful and trouble on the streets meant fist fights, not guns and drugs. And he talks of his political youth as well: those glorious first two terms when New York's streaking economy and Mr. Cuomo's Presidential prospects made him one of the most popular governors in state history.
"Everybody says stop looking backward, look forward," said the 61-year-old Governor, who will be nominated here Wednesday at the convention of the Democratic State Committee. "But if you take those years '83 through '89, it's hard to separate them from my rationale. Those years were so good you wanted me to be President. I haven't changed." 
 To hear Mr. Cuomo tell it, a relentless recession ate away at his popularity like a persistent cancer, effectively stealing three years of his political life. He does not speak of the possibility that New Yorkers may also have grown weary of his unconsummated flirtations with the Presidency and the Supreme Court, his legalistic combativeness and his lack of an easily identifiable legacy after 12 years in office.
His approval rating dropped 41 percentage points between January 1988 and March 1994, to 36 percent from 77 percent, according to the Marist Institute for Public Opinion.
Now a recovery offers a chance at redemption, a return, if not to the pinnacle of six years ago, at least to a height that history may judge more admiringly.
A fourth election would secure his place among New York's most enduring political figures. If he wins and completes his four-year term, Mr. Cuomo would become the second-longest serving governor in state history, surpassing Nelson A. Rockefeller and trailing only George Clinton, the first governor, who served for 23 years over two periods.
Mr. Cuomo is too smart a politician to express his ambition so egocentrically. Instead, he speaks about the opportunity to finish a mission on behalf of New York that he says was interrupted by the state's fiscal collapse. But clearly, his friends and aides say, Mr. Cuomo's decision to run a fourth time also was motivated by his sense of history and his desire to finish on an ascent.
"In many ways, the decision to run again was a more profound choice for him than whether to run for President," said Meyer S. Frucher, a longtime Cuomo confidant. "He's the kind of political figure who will only run if he has a rationale. And I think he's really looking forward to an upturn, both governmentally and politically."
 
A 'Stronger, Sweeter' State
 At a fund-raiser last month, Mr. Cuomo recounted his last decision to run, in 1990, saying he felt an obligation to use his experience to help the state through the recession.
"Then, when the state is back on the right track, when we get this train on the track moving in the right direction again, back up toward the top of the mountain, then we'll get out," he said.
"The reason I'm running this time is I think that train is just about on the track. I think now we need another push and we're on our way to a society stronger, sweeter, more sensitive, more intelligent than the Empire State ever was."
Mr. Cuomo said in the same speech that he did not want to be remembered simply as a governor who balanced the state's budget during a recession. That task, which has occupied much of his last five years, was completed only through severe spending cuts, tax increases, , heavy borrowing and broken promises.
"I didn't come into government to be an accountant," he said. "If I could produce a balanced budget because the taxes were coming in very nicely and I paid all our bills but didn't take care of the problems of the needy and didn't help the struggling middle class, I would regard that budget as a sort of emblem of my hypocrisy."
 
Staying the Course
 And yet, Mr. Cuomo said in interviews over the weekend that he would propose no grand new social programs in a fourth term.
Instead, Mr. Cuomo said he would continue on the course set in this year's state budget: government investments in high technology and job-creating infrastructure projects; increased spending on education; aid to local governments aimed at helping them reduce property taxes, and cuts in state taxes that are large enough to encourage business expansion without fraying the social safety net.
After winning support this year for reductions in corporate income taxes and hotel taxes and the creation of a tax credit for the working poor, Mr. Cuomo said he would like to lower the state's utilities taxes next year. He is not yet sure the state can afford a major cut in the personal income tax, like the proposal that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman rode to victory in New Jersey last year. (He is also mindful that voters didn't buy the I-made-the-tough-choices argument made by Jim Florio, the incumbent that Mrs. Whitman defeated.)
Mr. Cuomo also said he would spend a lot of time in a fourth term campaigning for a constitutional convention. The state Constitution requires New Yorkers to vote in 1997, 20 years after the last similar referendum, on whether to hold a convention. Mr. Cuomo has come to belief that the only way to win approval of initiatives like public campaign financing and stricter regulation of lobbying is to bypass the Legislature.
Central to Mr. Cuomo's rationale for running this year is the notion that he, like many governors, was an unwitting victim of the recession. He argues that the loss of more than 500,000 jobs from 1989 through 1993 was thrust upon New York by a changing world economy and the fiscal policies of Republican presidents.
 
'Not Future, but Fault'
 "We were hit from behind, not by a New York-bred disaster, but by a national recession," he said.
Much of the 1994 campaign will be spent debating that proposition. At the Republican state convention in Manhattan last week, the party's designated gubernatorial candidate, State Senator George E. Pataki, blamed the shrinkage of the state's job market on Mr. Cuomo's policies on taxation, spending and debt. As he spoke, delegates to the convention chanted: "It's Mario's fault."
Mr. Cuomo said the slogan only proves what he has long said about Republicans, that they campaign negatively. "The best word they could think of was 'fault,' not 'future,' but 'fault,' " he said.
Although many Cuomo aides have a grudging respect for the ticket assembled at the Republican convention last week, Mr. Cuomo plans to take advantage of the opening provided by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's heavy backroom role.
The Governor already has appropriated the analogy drawn by Herbert London, Mr. Pataki's one-time foe and current running mate, that Mr. Pataki is playing Charlie McCarthy to Mr. D'Amato's Edgar Bergen.
"I'm glad they didn't talk about Pinocchio and Geppetto because that would have been ethnic," Mr. Cuomo joked. (Although Mr. Cuomo can, on occasion, make fun of his heritage, his ethnic sensitivity has not waned. When a reporter used the word "vendetta" in a question earlier this year, Mr. Cuomo said he was sure there must be a synonym with a Gaelic derivative.)
 
Not a Pliable Candidate
 The Cuomo campaign also plans to portray Mr. Pataki as an empty suit without either experience nor convictions. Whenever possible, they said, they will attempt to exploit the stature gap they see between Mr. Cuomo and his opponent.
But above all, Cuomo aides said, the campaign's first mission is to reconnect with voters who may consider the Governor a distant presence. A man who excels at raising money and pressing the flesh, Mr. Cuomo dislikes doing both. He would much rather stay home and read or watch CNN and the Discovery Channel.
"We have to remind people that he's a human being who cares about people and the state," said one Cuomo aide, who insisted on anonymity.
The aide said that Mr. Cuomo was not an easy candidate to manage.
"When you ask him to explain why he's running, he wants to write an appellate brief," the aide said. "When you tell him that it will make a big difference if he takes off his jacket, he just doesn't accept that viscerally."
Campaign officials said that Mr. Cuomo's media consultant, David Garth, who has played an active but strictly behind-the-scenes role thus far, was preparing commercials featuring voter-in-the-street testimonials to the Governor that may be aired shortly after the convention.
But Mr. Cuomo's future may depend, as it has so often in the past, on his own eloquence and his ability to relate the past to the future.
"The job simply isn't done," Mr. Cuomo said on CNN's Larry King Live two weeks ago. "I think I can be helpful because of my experience, of my background. Because the job is not done, I want to finish it."

HEADLINE: Homes Sales and Spending Slump in Signs of a Slowing

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
Fresh signs of economic slowing emerged today as new-home sales and personal spending slumped in April after two months of hefty gains, Government figures showed today.
And consumer confidence slipped in May, according to a tabulation by the Conference Board, with seven of nine regions posting declines. New England and the South Atlantic were the exceptions. 
 The latest economic figures, which were generally weaker than expected, reflected to various degrees the twin bites of higher interest rates and higher income taxes, analysts said.
Today's reports followed the Government's recalculation of first-quarter growth on Friday, raising total output in the first quarter to an annual pace of 3 percent, up from an initial estimate of 2.6 percent but far below the 7 percent surge in the final three months of 1993, when a sharp rise in the refinancing of home mortgages greatly swelled household buying power.
The downbeat economic news, a sign of inflation in control, helped the bond market bounce off its lows yesterday but a jump in commodity prices rekindled inflation fears and the market declined, driving interest rates higher. [Page D14.]
"The second quarter is off to a rather poor start," said Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist at HSBC Holdings Inc. in New York. "At a time when the economy needs help from the interest-sensitive sectors to overcome tax increases, the interest-sensitive sectors are a drag."
Exhibit A, many economists contended, is housing. Sales of new one-family homes in April skidded 6.8 percent to an annual rate of 683,000, today's report by the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development showed. Sales fell 16.9 percent in the Northeast, 14.1 percent in the South and 5.7 percent in the West. The Midwest, however, posted a 16.9 percent gain.
"It looks like it's primarily the interest rates," said David F. Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. Although the Federal Reserve began raising short-term interest rates only in February, mortgage rates have been moving up since October and the early benefit of fence-sitters being pushed to act has now all but disappeared.
Legions of first-time buyers, some of whom would presumably have found a home to buy during the winter had it not been for exceptionally harsh weather, now find themselves priced out of the market.
 
Inventory Edges Up
 During April the stock of unsold new homes edged up less than 1 percent, to 302,000, but because of the slower selling pace this inventory would last 5.3 months, up from 4.9 months in March.
The actual number of homes sold, with no annualization or seasonal adjustment, was 66,000 last month, the same as in April 1993, the Department also found. The average sales price eased $200, to $153,900.
Nor did economists find much comfort in the Commerce Department's report showing that personal income rose four-tenths of 1 percent of in April, one-third the average increase for February and March.
They noted that disposable income fell two-tenths of 1 percent, the difference largely ascribed to tax increases that many wealthier households paid in the days approaching April 15.
This drain no doubt contributed to a slight, one-tenth of 1 percent easing in personal spending, which had been a major source of the economy's recent strength.
 
'Tempo Has Changed'
 "Today's report is further evidence that the economy's tempo has changed," commented Robert D. Barr of the United States Chamber of Commerce. "After the frenetic flash dancing of late last year, households are moving to a softer, slower beat."
Not all analysts, however, were disappointed by today's statistics, which also included private-sector surveys of store sales and of purchasing managers in the Chicago area.
Paul Mastroddi, economist at J. P. Morgan, called the decline in home sales "quite muted" and said he found strength -- even price pressures -- in the report on Chicago manufacturing.
He said the bank was staying with its projection of a 6 percent annual growth rate in the economy for the current quarter, one of the most optimistic forecasts.
 
Confidence Slips
 The report on confidence from the Conference Board, a business-sponsored research group in New York, showed its index slipping 4.5 points in May, to 87.6 on a scale designating 1985 as 100.
"Although confidence retreated in May, the current reading continues to be at a fairly reassuring level," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the organization's Conumer Research Center.
Respondents this time were "considerably" less positive in their appraisal of current conditions -- down to 78.9 from 87.1 -- but only "moderately" less optimistic in what they expect over the coming six months -- to 93.5 from 95.4 -- the board reported.

HEADLINE: Herbert Bienstock, 71, Official Who Invested Figures With Flair

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Herbert Bienstock, a former regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics with the Department of Labor, died on Monday at his home in Bayside, Queens.
He was 71 and died of a heart attack, his family said. 
 Mr. Bienstock was principal spokesman on statistics for the Labor Department, covering a region that included New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and the Canal Zone, until he retired in 1979.
 
Spicing Up Reports
 He was known for enlivening the government's monthly Consumer Price Index reports and for making the figures meaningful for consumers. For instance, he urged the public to eat turkeys when their prices dropped and even suggested stuffing them with green peppers when they were a bargain.
"An economic, if not a gastronomical, delight," he said at the time.
Mr. Bienstock told the public what was behind the cost of a steak or a new car, and why buying a chicken (fresh, not frozen) might be a prudent investment.
Mr. Bienstock served as commissioner through nearly two decades, recording the wave of Government spending in the 1960's and the recession that hit New York City in 1970 and held for 10 years.
During his tenure, he became an authority on human resources, employment and the growing problem of youths who could not find jobs.
In 1983, three years after his retirement and a professor of labor and urban values at Queens College, he described teen-age unemployment as at its worst in the city's history.
"We are living through a period of a teen-age employment disaster," he said. "What has it done to the teen-agers and the city? We have created a lost generation."
Throughout his career, Mr. Bienstock combined a social conscience with a love of statistics -- almost, he said, making figures speak for themselves.
But then, he also asked in 1975, "What can you say with figures? It all needs explaining."
Educated in New York City public schools, Mr. Bienstock was graduated from City College in 1945 when he joined the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
He was appointed regional commissioner in 1962. He also was a visiting lecturer and adjunct professor at Yeshiva University, the Hunter College Graduate School of Education, Baruch College, the New School for Social Research, Pace University's Graduate School of Business Administration, and at Cornell University's School of Industrial and Labor Relations. He also was the author of numerous articles dealing with employment.
In 1970, City College awarded Mr. Bienstock the Townsend Harris Medal, for "Outstanding Achievement" in his chosen field. He was a fellow of the American Statistical Association and a member of the board of directors of the National Conference of Christians and Jews Mobilization for Youth.
He also helped found the Hebrew Academy, an elementary school in Bayside.
Mr. Bienstock is survived by his wife, June; a daughter, Ruth Bienstock Anolik, of Penn Valley, Penn.; a son, Joshua, of Fresh Meadows, L.I.; a sister, Clara Schneider, of Bayside; and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
850 Workers At Chrysler Go on Strike

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 31

 BODY:
About 850 salaried workers who design Chrysler cars and trucks walked off the job this morning in a dispute between the auto maker and the United Automobile Workers union over subcontracting work to nonunion workers and companies.
The workers who went on strike earn $16 to $27 an hour as draftsmen, clay modelers, designers and clerical assistants, said David Corless, financial secretary of U.A.W. Local 412 in Warren, Mich. The union, he said, objects to the hiring of nonunion companies to do similar work and to having nonunion workers stand "shoulder to shoulder" with union members at the technical center. 
 Nonunion workers earn about the same salaries, Mr. Corless said, "but the company wants as little as possible to do with pensions, job security pay" and other benefits for which nonunion workers do not qualify. In the last 20 years, Mr. Corless said, the number of workers represented by the union has shrunk from about 1,650 to the current total of 850 as Chrysler has channeled more contracts to the outside.
 
Tentative Agreement Reached

Lee Sechler, a Chrysler spokesman, declined to comment on the dispute.
A second group, of about 400 salaried and some hourly maintenance workers, also employed at Chrysler's technical center in Auburn Hills, Mich., tentatively reached a settlement today. The workers will vote on the proposed contract on Thursday.
Although the three United States auto makers signed new three-year master contracts last fall covering general terms of pay and benefits, each union local must also reach agreement with plant or workplace managers. Reaching local agreements has sometimes proved troublesome, a result of the industry's current boom.
The union believes extra help is needed in factories, but auto makers prefer not to give the work to the union since doing so may mean paying job security benefits when the economy slows down.
 
Complaint About Overtime
 The union, on the other hand, complains that workers are working too much overtime and need help to prevent repetitive-stress injuries and other job-related health problems.
Separately, union negotiators representing 11,500 General Motors Corporation assembly and components workers in Flint, Mich., were scheduled to meet with company representatives to resolve complaints about the speed-up of operations.
G.M. officials, eager to meet strong vehicle demand by retail customers, wants to increase the line speed at its Buick City assembly plant to 72 or 73 vehicles an hour from 67. Buick City assembles the Buick LeSabre, Park Avenue and Oldsmobile 88 sedans. The union wants to add 300 to 500 new workers to handle the load.
G.M. workers in Flint, members of U.A.W. Local 599, voted 6,220 to 1,022 last week to strike if a settlement was not reached.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Midwest Dry Spell Causes Rally in Corn and Soybeans

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Dry weather in the Midwest touched off a rally in corn and soybean futures prices yesterday that pulled other commodity prices upward, reviving inflation fears. Precious metals, coffee, cocoa and crude oil all gained, while livestock and meat futures ended mixed.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 4.54 points, to 235.42. Many financial experts consider the index an early inflation indicator. 
 A similar broad-based commodities rally collapsed last week when rain fell in the Midwest, where most of the country's corn and soybeans are grown.
David Rothberg, a commodities analyst at Friedberg Mercantile Group in Toronto, said the roiling prices signaled an underlying strength in the market.
"This kind of volatility, this kind of itchiness, is typical of a bull market," he said.
 
Little Rainfall in Midwest
 Most corn and soybean contracts rose their permitted daily limits on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders returned from the long weekend to reports of little rainfall in the Midwest and forecasts for mostly dry weather this week.
After the close of trading, the Agriculture Department reported 79 percent of the corn crop was in good to excellent condition as of Sunday. Twenty percent was fair and 1 percent poor.
Soybean planting was 78 percent complete as of Sunday, the Department of Agriculture said in the weekly report.
Wheat for July delivery rose 9 1/2 cents, to $3.27 1/2 a bushel; July corn rose the 12-cent limit, to $2.78 3/4 a bushel; July oats rose 4 3/4 cents, to $1.25 1/4 a bushel; July soybeans rose 27 cents, to $7.01 a bushel.
Inflation jitters drove precious metals higher on the Commodity Exchange in New York. June gold rose $2.40, to $387.10 a troy ounce; July silver climbed 7.5 cents, to $5.55 a troy ounce.
On the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, unroasted coffee beans for July delivery surged 4.7 cents, to $1.26 a pound; July cocoa beans rose $52, to $1,388 a ton.
 
Crude Oil Prices Rise
 Refined products led crude oil higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange as the June gasoline and heating oil contracts expired in typically volatile fashion.
Crude oil rose 28 cents, to $18.31 a barrel; June heating oil surged 1.33 cents, to 49.71 cents a gallon; June unleaded gasoline climbed 1.09 cents, to 53.30 cents a gallon; July natural gas rose 7.5 cents, to $1.917 for 1,000 cubic feet.
In livestock trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, June live cattle rose 0.80 cent, to 66.27 cents a pound; August feeder cattle fell 0.65 cent, to 73.95 cents a pound; June live hogs rose 0.08 cent, to 47.60 cents a pound; July frozen pork bellies fell 0.32 cent, to 41.50 cents a pound.
