HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against Yen On Trade-Talks Optimism

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen and most other major currencies yesterday, buoyed by optimism that the United States and Japan will make progress in trade negotiations set to resume this week.
United States officials will begin talks in Tokyo today on insurance services, a spokeswoman for the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said yesterday. Talks on autos and auto parts are scheduled to start in Washington this week, she said. 
 "The dollar's fate depends on whether the trade talks with Japan are successful," said Karl Halligan, a trader at ING Capital Markets. "That's what everyone is waiting to see."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 104.75 yen, up from 104.30 yen on Friday. Currency markets in London and New York were closed Monday for holidays and post-holiday trading was light as many market participants extended their holiday weekend.
 
Bearishness in Europe
 The dollar also rose after the Bundesbank canceled a bond offering for the second time in one week, prompting a selloff in Germany and other European government debt markets as well. Traders said the trend might spread to other mark-based investments if such bearishness continued, depressing the German currency further. The dollar rose yesterday to 1.6467 marks from 1.6466 marks on Friday.
The New Zealand dollar rallied yesterday after the Government said it expected a surplus of $422 million in the fiscal year ending June 30, the first in 16 years. The New Zealand dollar rose to 59.49 United States cents in late trading today, its highest level since April 1991. It was quoted at 58.84 cents in New York on Friday.
Higher commodity prices also helped the New Zealand, Australian and Canadian dollars gain yesterday. Those currencies often rise alongside commodities because raw materials account for large proportions of the countries' exports.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodity prices jumped 4.54 points, to 235.42 yesterday, driven by higher soybean, corn and coffee prices. The index rose to a three-and-a-half-year high of 239.20 on May 24.
The index is a closely watched inflation measure and its increase prompted talk that the Federal Reserve would again raise short-term interest rates. But traders said the market had not yet focused on such a move by the Fed's policy-making committee, which is scheduled to meet July 5 and 6.
The British pound was quoted at $1.5110 late yesterday, up from $1.5105 late Friday. The dollar rose to 5.6310 French francs from 5.6163 francs, and strengthened to 1.4037 Swiss francs from 1.4020 francs. The dollar rose to 1,593 Italian lire yesterday from 1,589 lire on Friday.

HEADLINE: Ukraine: Not for the Fainthearted

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
S. C. Johnson & Son Inc., the $3 billion family-owned company that makes clothes, floor wax, furniture cleaners, bug killers and air fresheners, has traditionally been challenged by new frontiers.
When the company opened a plant in Britain 80 years ago, it was one of the first American corporations to go abroad. At the end of the cold war, it trailblazed again -- this time into the uncertain precincts of Ukraine. 
 Doing business amid the political and economic turmoil here is not for the fainthearted. Only Johnson Wax, as the company is popularly known; Tambrands, which makes Tampax; some cigarette companies, and Pepsi-Cola have ventured from the West into this intriguing market of 52 million people.
Johnson Wax's experience since late in 1990 -- when the company started to make and bottle detergents and furniture polish in a renovated corner of a ramshackle factory on the outskirts of Kiev -- helps explain the reluctance of other consumer-products companies to jump in.
A few months after Ukraine joined Russia and Belarus in leaving the crumbling Soviet Union, it introduced a coupon currency to replace the ruble. In relatively short order, the coupons became all but worthless. By late last year, inflation had reached about 100 percent a month, from almost zero two years before. A fierce credit squeeze by the Government left wholesalers little money to buy Johnson's products. And a Government that initially promised to create a friendly environment for Western investors became encrusted with old-style -- many say, corrupt -- former Communists.
Last year, Johnson Wax halved its production from that of 1992. And almost half of 1993's 10 million bottles that came off the assembly line had to be sold in Russia, where the economy, however turbulent, is far stronger than Ukraine's.
But Johnson Wax had been prepared for the long haul, said Franck Benhamou, 34, the general manager of S. C. Johnson in Kiev. Unlike Tambrands, which had to import new machinery, Johnson had to bring in less and was able to spruce up some existing Ukrainian equipment. So far, the company has invested less than $10 million. The original target remains the same: the entire, vast market of the former Soviet Union.
"We're building a brand, we're building a work force and we're building a factory," Mr. Benhamou said, showing off a large, airy and freshly painted building where production takes place. "This will enable us to be a competitor. The problem is not knowing what is going to happen. If it takes off, we will be in a good position."
The key to keeping going in Ukraine is to stay nimble, Mr. Benhamou said. Until early in 1993, the plant could not keep up with demand, especially for a laundry detergent, Hello; a liquid starch, Jubilee, and a pre-spotter for clothes, Bioshout. Ukrainians love to starch their clothes, even their bed sheets. These products sell for the equivalent of $1 in a country where industrial wages run $150 a month or less.
"We could sell everything we made and more," Mr. Benhamou said of the 20 million bottles of detergent and other products produced in 1992. "There was money in the country, we barely had a sales department -- there was no need to sell. People were lining up to buy it."
One enthusiastic customer, Olga Stepanovich, a 22-year-old newlywed, elaborated. "The local washing powders are too rough for silks and wools," she said as she searched the shelves in a store here for Hello. "We used to send our sweaters and blouses to the dry cleaners, but dry cleaning has become so expensive."
Mrs. Stepanovich said she could not easily find the detergent in the stores anymore.
The reason is a Government credit squeeze. Johnson demanded payment in advance from wholesalers, in order to insure payment in a volatile credit market and protect itself against inflation.
But after March 1993, the wholesalers found it almost impossible to get credit. Johnson could no longer rely on its regular wholesalers, and new ones were yet to emerge.
 
Blessings in Deep Disguise
 Yet, the slide in Ukrainian sales proved to be less of a blow than it might have been. Johnson had already started selling in Russia, not so much to find new customers but to earn rubles it could use to buy raw ingredients there. About 80 percent of ingredients in the detergent, as well as the plastic used in making the bottles, come from Russia.
"When Ukraine exited the ruble zone, all of a sudden we couldn't buy raw material," Mr. Benhamou said, alluding to Ukraine's coupon currency. "We had been buying raw materials in Russia, but to continue to do so we had to quickly generate sales in Russia."
An overhaul of the poorly maintained plant Johnson acquired in 1990 has just begun. Aluminum window frames are replacing rusted metal ones. Smaller, more powerful engines to turn the detergent-mining vats are being imported. Western floors are replacing broken concrete.
The overhaul was delayed when Johnson's local partner, Ukrbytkhim, which makes shampoo and detergent, failed to live up to an agreement that it would move out of the building. Only after pushing the case to the highest reaches of the Ukrainian Government has Johnson won a three-year battle for control of the building, Mr. Benhamou said.
The plant's original work force of 700 has been whittled down to 300, with the departing local partner taking many of the workers. For those remaining, initial nervousness about working for a Western company has subsided.
"They thought we'd leave and then they'd be sent to Siberia," Mr. Benhamou said.
A major attraction for Western manufacturers here is low wages. Johnson would like to raise the pay of some workers above the monthly $150 that the best get, but a 92 percent tax rate on earned income above $150 makes it impossible to do so, Mr. Benhamou said.
Thefts, endemic at state enterprises where workers make up for low salaries by taking products, barely occurs at Johnson Wax, Mr. Benhamou said. Early instances were dealt with by dismissals.
 
Phones Work Now
 Some improvements in everyday life make the difficulty of doing business here a little easier. To make an overseas telephone call took two days several years ago. Now they can be made on the spot. And there are more flights in and out of the country.
But unpredictability prevails. In the last six months, the Ukrainian Government has raised or lowered the value-added tax rate three times. Now there are worries that the Government might impose an excise tax on supplies coming across the border from Russia. And still another currency is expected, prompting further headaches.
In the long run, Mr. Benhamou said, it is the gritty preparation that Johnson Wax has put into Ukraine that will determine success.
"How much money does the competition have to spend three years down the road to reach our level is the question," he said. "If they have to spend much more money than we have to match us, it was a good bet."

HEADLINE: Japan's Jobless Rate

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 31

 BODY:
Japan's unemployment rate stood at a seasonally adjusted 2.8 percent in April, down one-tenth of a percentage point from March, the Government announced today. The number of unemployed people totaled 1.94 million in April, up 23.6 percent from a year earlier but below the 2.08 million people reported in March. Japan's unemployment rate would be higher if calculated by United States or European methods. In Japan, people working more than one hour in the last week of the month and all members of the armed forces are counted as employed.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
The First Spoleto Without Menotti

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C., May 29

 BODY:
"A fake festival," Gian Carlo Menotti called it from afar on the CBS program "Sunday Morning." Odd, but the real thing seemed to be happening in the teeming streets right outside my hotel window here as the city was awakening to the fifth day of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A.
Mr. Menotti, who founded the event in 1977 and guided it through 17 seasons, is, of course, entitled to his bias. And the current season, which runs through next Sunday, might not have been to his liking in any case. But he was not speaking from firsthand experience. In fact, Mr. Menotti has had no contact with the festival or the city of Charleston since he resigned as artistic director in October after a protracted series of squabbles, which need no further rehearsal here. 
 "We've had no communication from him," said Joseph P. Riley Jr., the Mayor of Charleston, who was one of Mr. Menotti's staunchest allies through the time of troubles.
What seems remarkable to a first-time visitor to the festival is how quickly and well it has picked up the pieces. Even before Mr. Menotti's departure, it had announced that because of an accumulated $1 million deficit, the season would be cut back from 17 days to 12 this year, and offer many fewer events.
Milton Rhodes, the former director of the American Council for the Arts in New York, became the general manager of Spoleto in November and wiped the programming slate clean. Mr. Rhodes, who took over the council in 1985 in a state of near-bankruptcy and built it back up, also determined to put the festival on sound financial footing.
And to do so, the 49-year-old Mr. Rhodes, who was born in North Charleston and knows the social and economic terrain, did some smooth talking. He persuaded creditors to write off $400,000 of debt, including $130,000 owed to the Westminster Choir College and $97,000 owed to the city.
"I told them if they wanted the festival to continue, they would have to forgive the debt," he said. "We needed the money to keep from going under. It was as simple as that." He negotiated a loan from the state to cover the remaining $600,000 deficit.
The loss of the festival would have been an economic blow to the area in the best of times. "It has an economic impact of $73 million on the state and a $43 million impact on the region," said Mayor Riley, who is running for Governor. The festival, he added, has been largely responsible for the restoration of the old parts of the city and the revitalization of the downtown area.
In addition, a loss of the festival just now would be doubly awkward, since the city is about to lose the Charleston Naval Base as part of the base closings announced in Washington last year. (There is talk of a threat to the Charleston Air Force Base, but Mayor Riley dismisses the possibility.)
There is also the matter of prestige. BMW, the German auto maker, is about to open a $350 million plant near Spartanburg, S.C., and both Mr. Rhodes and Mayor Riley argue that the festival's presence in the state was a crucial factor in the choice of location. Indeed, in a nice symbiosis, BMW sponsored one of the two opera productions this year, "Fidelio," and Mr. Rhodes said he hoped to persuade the company eventually to pick up the entire opera tab.
One way or another, Mr. Rhodes seems to have accomplished Phase 1 of his plan, which was simply to mount a festival this year and make it work. He pieced together a triumvirate of artistic directors with past ties to the festival: Spiros Argiris, a symphonic and operatic conductor; Joseph Flummerfelt, the choral conductor, and Charles Wadsworth, the pianist and chamber-music specialist. He filled the 12 days with almost as many events as were presented last year, and he reported on Saturday that the day before had been the biggest in the festival's history in terms of ticket sales. He also expanded the festival's educational programs.
Phase 2 is to begin long-range planning and settle on the programming for next season. Mr. Rhodes does not yet know whether a full 17 days will again be possible (as the hotel owners and other vendors in the city fondly hope), but he said he was giving the idea "a strong look."
Phase 3, he said, involves long-term financial planning for future solvency. Here, Mr. Rhodes carries over some perspective from his last job.
"We haven't yet found a mechanism in this country for long-range financing in the arts," he said. "Generally, the management is good, but we're still scraping for every penny. And every five years or so the ox lands in the ditch because we have no ongoing base of support except our own."
For the moment, the Spoleto ox seems to be back on course and moving resolutely forward, but Mr. Rhodes is not ready to make any grand claims. "I don't have any idea how any of these plans are going to turn out," he said, "but I feel good about Phase 1."
As well he might. He has already achieved some much-needed peace, quiet and stability, and in a setting that has already proved fruitful under propitious circumstances, prosperity may well be the next step.
 
A Multi-media Message
 One of the more unusual happenings at the festival this year is "Box Conspiracy: An Interactive Sho," a multimedia musical comedy by George Coates, with a score by Marc Ream. Communications technology is its subject and its reason for being. As it shows the ultimately baleful effects of an imagined 5,000-channel interactive cable system (thus one of the many meanings of "box") on the life of a family, it celebrates some of the same technology by surrounding live actors with computer-generated effects amounting in some instances to virtual reality.
The play itself hardly transcends sitcom level and, as such, goes on far too long. Viewers, fitted out with 3D glasses and subjected to a relentless electronic rhythm track, are made to feel constrained in a box of their own, and the fascination of all the gimmickry quickly gives way to sensory overload.
Yet every so often on Sunday afternoon the music jolted the slumping viewer bolt upright. Not that it was ever profound or always well wrought, but it was superbly rendered. Of the three live players, Sheldon Born, a saxophonist, stood out. More impressive still were two of the singers, Susan Fatma Volkan and, especially, Raz Kennedy. Mr. Kennedy, who has worked with Bobby McFerrin, sang, wailed, almost yodeled at times, with an unfailing musicality that riveted the attention.
Anomalously, perhaps, one listener harked back to Friday evening, when a previously unknown tenor, Johan Botha, had brought the desultory "Fidelio" production to life in an instant by dint of sheer vocal prowess. Mr. Botha cut an unprepossessing figure onstage and lacked much in subtlety, but he sang the demanding role of Florestan with easy strength, unforced plangency and considerable tonal beauty.
Both productions had gone to considerable lengths to create drama, or at least distraction, yet once the power of real, accomplished vocalization took hold, everything else fell from view. Amid a few lost hours, it was good to be reminded, not once but twice, how much drama is inherent in the oldest, if not simplest, musical medium of all. We hear it so seldom nowadays.

HEADLINE: In America;
Time to Act on Haiti

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
A few years ago when I was on an assignment in Haiti, a man took me to the back of his pickup truck and pointed to two young children. They were sitting in the bed of the truck and both were shivering, although the evening was quite warm. It was obvious that they were ill.
The man said the children were his and he begged me to smuggle them into the United States, where they would be safe and "grow strong." After listening to me explain how that was impossible, the man quietly said thank you, and with an expression of absolute despair, climbed into the cab of the truck and drove away. 
There was nothing unusual about the condition of the children in the truck, or the plight of their father. Hunger, disease, poverty and ignorance are staples of life in Haiti, a place where centuries of exploitation have thrown the vast majority of the people into a thoroughly wretched existence.
In the two and a half years since President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was ousted in a coup, the misery has only intensified. The combination of ferocious political repression unleashed by the coup leaders and the international sanctions that were supposed to drive them from power have made a terrible situation worse.
If the United States is going to intervene militarily in Haiti, it should do so soon. Prolonging the sanctions (even the new, improved version), when they are causing such hardship for ordinary Haitians while at the same time having so little impact on the renegade Government, is both cruel and indefensible.
President Clinton has spelled out why he feels the United States has a special interest in Haiti, and why the use of force to restore President Aristide is being considered. Haiti is "in our backyard," Mr. Clinton said, and it is the only country in the Western Hemisphere in which the military has seized power from an elected leader. Haiti and Cuba are the only two countries in the hemisphere that are not democratic.
President Clinton also noted that if democracy was not restored to Haiti, the United States at some point would face an enormous surge of new refugees seeking to settle here. (Keeping those refugees out has been the cornerstone of American policy to date.) Other points of special interest, according to Mr. Clinton, include the thousands of Americans who live in Haiti and the one million Haitian-Americans who live here. Finally, there is the fact that Haiti has become a staging area for drug shipments to the United States.
Mr. Clinton did not mention the important role the United States Government has played in the exploitation of the Haitian people. This has occurred through U.S. Government support -- both direct and covert -- for a series of repressive regimes, and through the long-term exploitation of cheap Haitian labor by American businesses. The U.S. has an interest in acknowledging those abuses, and in making the effort to act as a friend rather than an oppressor of the Haitian people.
The military in Haiti believes it has won its battle of the wills with the United States. "Sometimes," said an American diplomat, "the military leaders believe we were never serious about restoring Aristide, and other times they think we may have been serious but lacked the will. Either way they have felt triumphant."
Almost no one, in or out of the Clinton Administration, believes that the sanctions alone will drive the military leaders from power. Actually it is wrong to call them military leaders -- they are thugs, a band of murderers, rapists, terrorists and drug dealers who have all but demolished the fragile democratic infrastructure that was in place at the time of Father Aristide's election in December 1990.
A report on Haiti published last March by the U.S. Army War College said, "We have seriously misread the Haitian military and its allies, ascribing to them a degree of reasonableness and flexibility that does not exist."
President Clinton cannot bluff the leaders of the coup in Haiti. And he should not continue the added misery of the sanctions indefinitely. If the United States is going to lead an invasion, then the time to move is near. Nothing less than a genuine threat of force will dislodge the coup.

HEADLINE: Invade Haiti? A Sure Way To Make a Bad Policy Worse

BYLINE: By Brent Scowcroft and Eric D. K. Melby; Brent Scowcroft, national security adviser to Gerald R. Ford and George Bush, is president of the Forum for International Policy, a foundation. Eric D. K. Melby, a National Security Council staff member in the Bush Administration, is a senior associate at the Forum.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The United States is in danger of making a bad situation in Haiti even worse. We seem to be laying the groundwork for military intervention, which would get us into a quagmire.
If the Administration orders an invasion to restore President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, it will be making a grave mistake. There are better ways to help the democratic process. 
 Even if, given our superior forces, Father Aristide were back in office within a few days, in the long run an occupation would immerse us in the morass of Haitian nation-building -- a futile exercise, surely. Haiti has struggled unsuccessfuly with this task for nearly two centuries.
The Clinton Administration inherited a Bush Administration policy toward Haiti that was dead in the water. Its own approach has also been flawed. It has mistakenly embraced Father Aristide, who has shown no flexibility. It has tightened economic sanctions, which will increase the regime's black-market profits and the misery of the Haitian people. This, in turn, will increase the number of refugees, threatening to make the proposed offshore processing of them an insurmountable task.
When it becomes clear that the new policies will not work, the Administration, if we understand its hints, will resort to invasion.
Even if Father Aristide were returned to office behind the bayonets of a multinational force sponsored by the United Nations or the U.S., what then? The Haitian military and its paramilitary allies would fade out of sight to undertake guerrilla activities against the occupying force.
An occupation would not be the clean operation that some interventionists imagine, even with our overwhelming power; we could expect casualties and humiliations reminiscent of those in Somalia.
We might even succeed in uniting the disparate Haitian political forces against us. We would be dragged into settling their differences, but predictably could not satisfy various factions; in the end, we would wind up scapegoats.
Additionally, unilateral intervention would stir up long-standing anti-interventionist sentiment in the Southern Hemisphere.
In short, returning Father Aristide to Port-au-Prince would be the beginning, not the end, of Washington's problems. He would have to be sustained in power -- we would have to protect his life -- at least through the end of his term, in December 1995. (Or longer, according to his calculations. He maintains that his term was interrupted when he was deposed in December 1991, eight months after he took office and a year after he was elected.) And given Father Aristide's tendencies, once in power he might negate our attempts to sow the seeds of democracy in Haiti.
Our brief invasions of Grenada and Panama provide no justification for overrunning Haiti. In both cases, our goals were limited and involved no nation-building. Even the House, on May 24, approved a resolution opposing military intervention.
There is a better approach. The White House ought to drop Father Aristide permanently. Hardly a democrat, he is part of the problem, not the solution. Although he is the product of an election, his authoritarian behavior while in office briefly does not augur well for democracy. Moreover, despite the Administration's embrace of Father Aristide, he has bitten the hand that has been trying to feed him by refusing to compromise with his opponents.
Instead, together with the Organization of American States we should press for negotiations with Haiti's military regime. Our object would be to start building a democratic process, beginning with a new presidential election as soon as suitable procedures could be put in place.
This would require several things: the departure of today's military leaders from power; barring Father Aristide from returning (other democrats can be found to support); international observers for proper elections; dismantling all paramilitary organizations, and a multinational effort to professionalize the Haitian military and police.
To put pressure on the military leaders to negotiate a transfer of power, we should continue the tough sanctions against them personally: no international recognition, no traveling abroad, no access to their frozen financial and property assets overseas.
Although the international sanctions against Haiti's leaders themselves should continue, the trade sanctions against Haiti should be lifted: they punish innocent people and add to their misery, including forcing them into boats to flee to the U.S., only to be turned back. In any case, all the sanctions since 1991 have been ineffective; instead of coercing the military into accepting the return of Father Aristide, they are providing black-market profits to the military and its allies.
We should be encouraging the private sector in the U.S. to resume economic operations in Haiti, a major source of income for the impoverished Haitians.
Ending our support for Father Aristide should induce the military leaders to cooperate with us, because they would no longer have to fear for their lives if he returned: we would be offering them a face-saving way out. It would help break the deadlock while relieving the Haitians' economic hardship, which has gained us nothing.
Those contemplating direct involvement in nation-building ought to hark back to our occupation of Haiti from 1914 to 1933. When we arrived, we encountered no vestige of democracy; when we departed, we left none. An invasion today would very likely lead to the same result.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
The Nurse Paradigm

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN 

 BODY:
An apple a day keeps the nurse away? Don't worry, you'll get used to the idea.
Because one of the most revolutionary parts of health care reform in America is bound to be the burgeoning role that nurses will play, including providing many of the services that were once confined to physicians. Their new prominence will benefit patients -- and raise some questions about the importance of tender loving care and the economic value of medical services. 
 Exhibit A in what the president of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York City calls "a major paradigm shift" is that hospital's decision to give its nurse practitioners admitting privileges, further blurring the line between what doctors do and what nurses can.
This shift is apparent in many areas of the medical center, from the geriatric floor where Shelly Dubin is overseeing the treatment of a group of elderly patients to the primary care clinic in which Lisa Henderson is diagnosing childhood ear infections and prescribing antibiotics. Neither likes to be called doctor, because they aren't. They have seen the future, and in it nurse practitioners can order diagnostic tests, immunize and deliver babies, perform physicals, now even admit patients to the hospital.
Like a corporation that doesn't work, medicine -- or health care, as those dedicated to reform prefer to call it -- is being forced to change because of dissatisfaction from both within and without. Physicians will still be involved in specialty treatment of serious medical conditions, as they are today, but nurses may well step into the primary care and preventive medicine breach. Some say that they've been surreptitiously providing such care for years, along with the caring some patients complain doctors lack.
One issue surrounding an expanded role for nurses is whether it will save money or become an opportunity for long-overdue salary increases. Since studies show that nurses spend more time with patients, savings may be eroded by fewer patient visits per day -- or realized at the cost of the humane treatment some find such a signal part of nursing. And since nurses are one of the largest groups of female professionals in the nation, using them to cut costs raises troubling questions about equal pay standards, particularly if they are providing services once provided by doctors.
"I won't frame this as an economic argument," said Martha Orr, executive director of the New York State Nurses Association. "Nurses have long been under-recognized and under-appreciated, economically and otherwise, and that should change. But quality of service is where we should put the emphasis. And we can provide all kinds of care in a more humane and a cost-effective way."
Dr. William T. Speck, the president of Columbia-Presbyterian, says that in his hospital, which is both a prominent teaching and research center and the health care nucleus of a sprawling urban area, giving nurse practitioners more authority simply made good sense.
For years doctors and nurses played a hierarchical game in which nurses could only suggest treatment that only a doctor could give. ("Doctor, it appears that the patient is dead" is one of the bitter little examples nurses use to illustrate this dance of deference.) But more recently nurse practitioners have been providing a range of medical services, both in rural areas and in inner-city hospitals, like Columbia-Presbyterian, where there simply were not enough primary care providers -- or enough interest in poor patients -- to go around.
"It was always clear that the nurses knew as much about some things as the doctors, and more about others," said Dr. Susan Spear, the medical director of community health services for Columbia-Presbyterian. "But they were artificially prevented from doing all they could for patients."
That simply won't do anymore. While the use of nurses and nurse practitioners in growing areas of patient care will require some adjustment for patients and doctors and some thoughtful resolution of salary issues, it is clearly the future of health care in a system that must be reconfigured around needs, not job titles. To watch the nurse practitioners at Columbia-Presbyterian go about their appointed rounds is to see the necessary being done competently by the qualified. And if some patients call them doctor -- well, they'll learn to say nurse soon enough.

HEADLINE: Fed Did Right in Raising Interest Rates

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Fed's Latest Mistake" by Sam Nakagama (Op-Ed, May 19): 
 We must hope Mr. Nakagama is wrong in his belief that the Federal Reserve Board erred in raising short-term interest rates half a percentage point May 17. I believe he is.
Granted that the economy is not growing as fast as some estimates of its performance would have us believe, but it is expanding at a pretty high rate. Judged by the coincident indicators, which are more sensitive and timely than the gross domestic product figures, it looks to be growing at around 3.5 percent a year, even a bit faster.
That is, of course, a catch-up rate, and needs, one way or another, to be moderated to a speed that can be continued for an extended period without exceeding the practical limits of capacity and becoming seriously inflationary.
It is pretty obvious that the Fed was trying to slow growth to a sustainable pace, without counterproductive increases in borrowing costs, perhaps even without having the mythical "wealth effect" of which Mr. Nakagama speaks. And the Fed may well have done it. Is it not interesting and relevant in this connection that, after what the Fed did, long-term borrowing costs dropped and the stock market went up?
Mr. Nakagama also refers to the 1950's, and in this case, too, sees the Fed as having made bad mistakes. Agreed, there were mistakes in the 50's, but they were the opposite, as I saw them then and still see them, of what Mr. Nakagama sees. In my view, what the Fed did on May 17 was designed to avoid precisely the mistakes that it made in the mid-50's. Because it failed to act firmly enough in 1955-56, it had to act more severely in 1957, and in doing so tripped off the 1957-58 downturn.
Having taken over as chairman of the Eisenhower Administration Council of Economic Advisers in December 1956, I felt particularly victimized by the severe tightening of credit that occurred in mid-1957. And Bill Martin, who was chairman of the Fed at the time, later stated in testimony before Congress that he thought the downturn might have been avoided if policy had been firmer in 1955-56.
Another way to look at the May 17 events is to consider what the Fed's other options were -- it could do nothing or it could ease monetary and credit conditions. It is hard for me to believe that the consequences of taking either of these other directions of policy would have been anything but seriously damaging.
Finally, it is interesting in judging the wisdom of what the Fed did, though not conclusive, that the President and all his people were happy with what happened. They had reason to be.
 
RAYMOND J. SAULNIER
Chestertown, Md., May 20, 1994

HEADLINE: Shelby C. Davis, Envoy and Philanthropist, 85

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Shelby Cullom Davis, a New York investment banker, philanthropist and former United States Ambassador to Switzerland, died on Thursday at his house in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 85 and lived in Tarrytown, N.Y.
He suffered a brief illness, his family said. 
 At his death he was the head of Shelby Cullom Davis & Company, a firm specializing in insurance securities that he founded in 1947 with $100,000. Last year it reported $848 million in capital. He was also chairman and treasurer of a foundation bearing his name, whose disbursements go chiefly to higher education and to research on public policy and economics.
In 1964 he presented a check for $5.3 million to Princeton University, his alma mater, to support its history department. He endowed Princeton's Center for Historic Studies, several chairs of history there, chairs at Wellesley College, and professorships of free enterprise at Wellesley and at the Cullom-Davis Library at Bradley University in honor of his parents. Other beneficiaries included the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.
He served as the American envoy in Bern under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford from 1969 to 1975. He was a past chairman of the Heritage Foundation, a former governor of the Society of Mayflower Descendants and president of the Sons of the Revolution.
Mr. Davis was born in Peoria, Ill. He graduated from Princeton in 1930 and earned a master's degree at Columbia University in 1931 and a doctorate in political science at the University of Geneva in 1934. He worked as a European correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System in Geneva and as an economist before joining the staff of Thomas E. Dewey.
He advised on economics when Mr. Dewey ran for president as the Republican candidate in 1940 and again in 1944. With Mr. Dewey as Governor of New York, he served as First Deputy Superintendent of Insurance from 1944 to 1947.
He became a member of the New York Stock Exchange in 1941 and for many years was the managing partner of the firm bearing his name. He was its chairman at the time of his death.
Mr. Davis is survived by his wife of 62 years, Kathryn Wasserman Davis; a son, Shelby M. C., of Manhattan; a daughter, Diana D. Spencer of Wellesley, Mass., and eight grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 2, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary yesterday about Shelby Cullom Davis, a New York investment banker, philanthropist and former United States Ambassador to Switzerland, misstated the date of his death in some editions. It was Thursday, May 26, not Sunday.

HEADLINE: North Korea's Dangerous Lurch

 BODY:
Enough is enough. North Korea has responded to the United States' patient and hopeful diplomacy with recalcitrance and provocative nuclear maneuvering. The recalcitrance was tolerable when talks were inching toward progress. But now the North is rushing to unload spent fuel from its nuclear reactor while delaying talks. If that is a negotiating tactic, it is one that the North Koreans must abandon immediately as deal-breaking brinkmanship.
The U.S. has been right to hold out for a negotiated nuclear-free Korean Peninsula. But North Korea seems intent on demonstrating that patient diplomacy will elicit only duplicity and defiance. It if intends to send some other message, it must do so quickly or else it may leave the U.S. no recourse but to seek economic sanctions and prepare for any military reactions. 
 The U.S., in an effort to woo North Korea away from building nuclear bombs, has been offering to resume high-level talks promptly. But last week the North spurned immediate talks and rushed instead to remove spent fuel rods from its nuclear reactor at Yongbyon at a rate far faster than anticipated.
That could very shortly make it impossible for inspectors to take or segregate the 300 samples they seek from the full complement of 8,000 fuel rods. Those samples would allow inspectors to determine how much spent fuel North Korea has diverted in the past and whether that was enough to build two nuclear bombs, as some intelligence suggests. Without samples to provide a clear accounting of the North's nuclear past, diplomacy to assure a nuclear-free Korea may falter and the world may turn in frustration to economic sanctions that Pyongyang itself warns could lead to war.
North Korea's rush to remove the spent fuel rods from the reactor raises two concerns. One is that by unloading the fuel rods without segregating some for future assay, it could be trying to keep inspectors from learning about its nuclear past. That past includes a 100-day period in 1989 when the reactor was shut down and some spent fuel was diverted -- two bombs' worth by one worst-case estimate. The assays would help the inspectors determine how long and at what power the reactor was operating and thus how much spent fuel it should have produced. The assays could also help determine whether any of the original fuel rods were replaced; the plutonium extracted from them could end up in bombs.
A second, even greater, concern is that the spent fuel now being removed will itself be diverted to bomb-making, giving North Korea enough material from this batch of fuel to make perhaps four or five bombs. At the moment inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency see no sign of that. But as long as the spent fuel remains at Yongbyon, inspectors will need access to assure that no diversion occurs. So far the North has permitted that access.
North Korea has long sought a resumption of high-level bilateral talks with the United States in an effort to gain diplomatic recognition and increased trade and investment. But Washington has set two critical conditions for holding the talks. The North has thus far satisfied one condition by allowing inspectors and cameras to monitor the current removal of fuel rods to prevent diversion to weapons programs and allowing them to complete work it interrupted in March -- work that would verify that it has not diverted any spent fuel or reprocessed plutonium in the past year.
But North Korea is dangerously close to making it impossible to meet the second condition -- that nothing be done to preclude analyses that could determine whether fuel was diverted earlier, particularly in the suspect 1989 period. Indeed, when Washington tried to schedule the high-level talks for this week, the North proposed a later date and accelerated removal of the fuel rods without setting any aside for later sampling.
Time is running out for the kind of diplomacy the U.S. has pursued. If the North stays on its present course, by week's end the world will face an unpalatable choice: Live with the possibility that North Korea may have diverted two bombs' worth of plutonium in the past, or move to sanctions. Pyongyang should recognize that the Clinton Administration and its South Korean allies will be under enormous pressure to impose sanctions, even if that leads the North to bar inspectors and make more bombs.
This time, in playing brinkmanship North Korea has gone too far. If it wants to avoid deepening its isolation, it has a way out: Stop removing nuclear fuel and resume talks.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 2, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a diagram yesterday explaining the extraction of plutonium from nuclear fuel rods referred incorrectly in some editions to the country suspected of diverting plutonium from its nuclear power program to make weapons. It is North Korea, not South Korea.

HEADLINE: U.N. Lists Four Nations at Risk Because of Wide Income Gaps

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 1

 BODY:
Egypt, South Africa, Nigeria and Brazil are among countries now in danger of joining the world's list of failed states because of wide income gaps between sections of their populations, a new United Nations report warns. Disastrous social upheavals and explosions could result, it says.
The warning comes in the United Nations Development Program's annual Human Development Report, a widely respected work that seeks to measure the development progress each country is making, not in terms of increasing its overall wealth but in how it uses that wealth to improve the longevity and literacy of its people and reduce poverty. The report does this by compiling a Human Development Index that compares different regions and ethnic groups. 
 "The Human Development Index holds a mirror up to society, forcing policy makers to take note of disturbing disparities between various regions, various ethnic groups and various income classes," said Mahbub ul Haq, a Pakistani economist and former Minister of Finance and Planning, who prepares the report. "Timely action can forestall a gathering storm."
The report traditionally reflects the present interest among development specialists in improving the lives of individuals so they have more options rather than building up a country's aggregate wealth through huge industrial investments.
This means channeling resources to the people who most need them, especially women and the poor. It also implies a degree of democracy to prevent development aid and investment from being concentrated in politically powerful areas.
But an attempt several years ago to include an index of human freedom in the report was suppressed by developing countries who feared they would lose aid if their ranking in that index was low. The writers of the report are now reintroducing a somewhat similar concept, however, by saying countries that do not distribute wealth fairly may fail.
 
Lowest Quality of Life
 Among developing countries, the development index puts Barbados, Hong Kong and Cyprus at the top in promoting life expectancy, education and income, and Guinea, Burkina Faso and Afghanistan at the bottom.
Among developed nations, Canada, Switzerland and Japan are at the top, with the United States in eighth place. Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan have the lowest quality of life.
On Egypt, the report notes "disturbing contrasts" between rural Upper Egypt and Cairo province. While Cairo, measured as a separate state, would rank 69th in the world for human development, or just behind Turkey, Upper Egypt would stand in 125th place, below Cameroon. Upper Egypt has less than half the literacy rate of Cairo, while the average life expectancy is six years lower and incomes are 45 percent lower.
Despite the advent of democracy in South Africa, the report says the white and black sections of the population are not just two different peoples but "almost two different worlds." If white South Africa were a separate country it would rank 24th in the world in terms of human development while black South Africa would be in 123d place, just above Congo.
"The major challenge for policy makers will be to provoke social integration without provoking racial violence," the report says.
Disparities among Nigeria's 19 states are described as "amongst the worst in the world." The index puts the state of Bendel ahead of a progressive country like Sri Lanka while the state of Borno ranks lower than any country in the world, with an average life expectancy of 40 years and only 12 percent of its adult population literate.
In Brazil, the report highlights the discrepancy in living standards between the more prosperous south and the impoverished northeast, where life expectancy is 17 years shorter, adult literacy 33 percent lower and average incomes 40 percent lower.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing in May Posted 9th Straight Gain

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Manufacturing activity grew in May as production increased for the ninth consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.
The association said that of the 20 industries in the manufacturing sector, 18 reported stronger business than in April, the largest number to report gains since March 1990. 
 "Generally, the tone of the economic numbers is quite solid," said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "It's the kind of strength that leads to more orders, more employment, more production and more growth."
The purchasing managers' group said its overall index held at 57.7 percent in May, the same as in April. A reading above 50 percent indicates manufacturing is generally expanding; one below 50 indicates a decline.
The association's employment index surged to 52 last month, from 50.8 in April -- the second consecutive gain and the highest level since December 1988.
 
Prices Rise on Broad Front
 The association, based in Tempe, Ariz., said the robust activity had caused prices to rise across the board for manufacturers, intensifying fears of inflation and initially causing bond yields to rise and stocks to fall. The markets, however, ended with gains.
Economists said prices were rising for the commodities that manufacturers use to make their goods, rather than for consumer goods.
"I think the inflation story is a future story," Mr. Jones said. "We're not getting as much on the inflation side as we normally would in this stage of a rebound."
The group's report is scrutinized because manufacturing accounts for about one-fifth of the economy and the report provides the first reading of how the economy performed in the previous month. The first Government look will come tomorrow in the May unemployment report.
While the recovery has been picking up, the impact of four interest rate increases from the Federal Reserve this year is starting to be felt. Lending and mortgage rates have increased, slowing construction and home buying. Construction spending, which is especially sensitive to interest-rate changes, eased in April to one-third of the pace in March, the Commerce Department reported.
The department said new construction projects rose at an annual rate of six-tenths of 1 percent in April following a revised 1.9 percent increase in March. It said that spending on privately financed construction projects -- homes, apartment buildings, offices and hotels -- rose 1.7 percent in the month, compared with a rise of 2.9 percent in March.
Public construction, like highways and public housing, fell by a surprising 2.5 percent in April following a decline of 1 percent in March.
"There's still quite a bit of momentum in the economy," said David Wyss of DRI/McGraw-Hill Inc., an economic research company in Lexington, Mass., "but higher interest rates are beginning to take a toll and by the second half we will see some slowing."

HEADLINE: Jamaica to Let U.S. Anchor Ship Off Coast

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
Jamaica agreed today to let the United States anchor ships in its waters so American officials can hold shipboard hearings to determine whether fleeing Haitians qualify for refugee status.
The Jamaican decision represents a diplomatic victory for the Clinton Administration, which promised last month to provide individual hearings for Haitian boat people rather than forcibly send them back without hearings. Later, the Administration realized it did not have a suitable place to conduct such hearings. 
 The Clinton Administration has been eager to find processing centers in third countries because fleeing Haitians who are processed in the United States often remain for years even if their asylum applications are rejected because Federal courts can permit them to stay until their appeals are exhausted.
The Administration has been under pressure to set up the shipboard processing as soon as possible because it has been in the embarrassing position of continuing to summarily repatriate Haitians without interviews even though President Clinton announced on May 8 that he was abandoning this policy.
[The United States Coast Guard returned 63 fleeing Haitians to Port-au-Prince Wednesday, the third group repatriated in a week, Reuters reported. That brought to 1,439 the number of refugees brought back to their homeland since Washington said it would halt the practice.]
 
Ship Heads for Kingston
 After the United States and Jamaica announced their agreement, Administration officials said they hoped to have a large American ship anchored in Kingston harbor within several days to begin interviewing Haitian emigrants.
"They'd like to start this at the beginning of next week," said Barbara Francis, the United States spokeswoman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which is working with the Clinton Administration on setting up the processing.
The plan is for a 1,000-bed Navy hospital ship to arrive in Jamaica this week so it can begin processing what American officials expect to be a steady stream of fleeing Haitians. In light of a recent United Nations decision to tighten the trade embargo against Haiti, Administration officials fear an accelerating exodus.
About 300 Americans will work on the hospital ship, including Immigration and Naturalization Service officials who will conduct hearings and Navy personnel who run the ship.
In addition, about 10 employees of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees will work on the ship to provide training for the American hearing officers and will counsel the Haitian applicants.
 
U.S. to Cover All Costs
 Christine Shelly, a State Department spokeswoman, said the United States will cover all costs connected to the shipboard processing.
Jamaica has not asked Washington for any payment for allowing American ships to anchor in its waters, but Jamaican officials have conveyed their displeasure that the Clinton Administration has not appointed an Ambassador to Jamaica and is cutting economic aid to the island.
Under the Administration's plan, Coast Guard cutters will pick up Haitian boat people in the Caribbean and take them to Kingston Harbor. Haitians who are found to have a well-founded fear of persecution in their homeland will be transported to the United States, or perhaps another country. Those whose claim of persecution is declared to be not well-founded will be taken back to Haiti.
"We would hope they would go not only to the U.S., but that other countries would step forward to accept some of them," an Administration official said concerning those granted asylum.
 
Hope for Turks and Caicos
 United States officials say they still hope that the Turks and Caicos Islands, a British-ruled group of small islands off the Bahamas, will agree to allow Washington to set up processing centers there.
The legislative council of those islands is scheduled to meet on Friday to consider Washington's request.
Turks and Caicos officials have offered the United States an uninhabited island, but Washington is concerned about the lack of docking facilities and potable water on the island.
The United States sent a second ship to Jamaica today. That ship, a leased, 700-bed Ukrainian cruise ship, will be anchored in Kingston to handle the spillover from the Navy hospital ship, or it will be anchored off the Turks and Caicos Islands, officials said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Haitian Files Suit
 A Haitian refugee who was chopped with a machete and left for dead in her homeland filed a $30 million lawsuit in Brooklyn yesterday against a far-right political group in Haiti.
The refugee, Alerte Belance, who now lives in Newark, N.J., sued the Haitian Front of Advancement and Progress in Federal Court for an attack last fall that cost her a right arm and left her with deep gashes on her neck and across her face.
Her suit is based on a ruling that allows some victims of human rights abuses committed abroad to seek redress in an American court.

HEADLINE: U.S. Stocks End Steady Amid Inflation Anxiety

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stocks dropped sharply in Europe overnight and on Wall Street in the morning yesterday, but United States stocks recovered strongly by the closing gavel as an unusual and confusing confluence of inflation anxieties swept through American, European and Japanese stock and bond markets.
What is unquestionably clear is that international stock traders are becoming increasingly worried. Like their counterparts in America, they seem to growing more concerned about inflation because of the convergence of an ebullient American economy, a surprisingly resurgent Europe and a recession-racked Japan that seems to be showing unexpected strength. 
 The Financial Times 100 index in London dropped 1.3 percent, and the French CAC-40 index fell 2.47 percent; the German DAX index rose slightly, up .09 percent.
Even Japan, locked in a three-year recession, saw bond yields soar, but without setting records, after better-than-expected industrial production figures surprised analysts. The Nikkei index of 225 issues rose slightly, up 0.38 percent.
 
 
Deadlock for the Dow
 In the end, however, deadlock was the word, at least for now. The major American stock indexes barely moved. After falling more than 26 points shortly after 10 A.M., the Dow Jones industrial average zigzagged the rest of the day before recovering to 3,760.83, up 2.46 points.
The other indexes wandered, too, before ending barely higher. After falling more than 2.50 points, the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 1.12 points, to 457.63. The Nasdaq composite index fell as much as 4.50 points before recovering to 735.52, up 0.33 point.
Blue chips like International Paper and Chevron rose on no immediate news. Semiconductor companies like Intel and big banks like Citicorp also rose on no immediate news. But U S Surgical gained 2 3/4, to 21 3/4, on takeover speculation, and IDB Communications fell 7 3/8, 7 1/8, over a dispute with its auditors. IDB Communications was the most active stock yesterday as 32.5 million of its shares changed hands.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was near normal at 278.5 million shares, about 7 percent below this year's average of 300 million shares. The near-normal day followed six consecutive sessions of below-average trading volume.
 
 
'It Just Got Worse'
 As in recent months, a falling bond market has been driving down the stock market. "We walked in this morning and found most of the European bond markets down and then it just got worse," said Chris Madell, head of Government bond trading at First Chicago Capital Markets.
In the end, bonds recovered, too. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.39 percent from 7.43 percent the day before.
For the American side of the markets, the immediate downdraft for stocks and bonds came from a closely watched index that implied that United States factory activity, and possibly inflation, was still growing.
The National Association of Purchasing Management index was unchanged in May but showed the economy expanding for the ninth straight month, despite recent economic data that suggested the possibility of a slowdown.
But at the same time traders noticed that the daily Commodity Research Bureau index was falling convincingly throughout the day on weakness in futures contracts for silver, coffee, lumber and live cattle. The index had been sparking inflation concerns recently as it rose in response to fears about a possible drought involving soybeans and other agricultural products.
As American traders struggled with these conflicting reports, European and Japanese bond markets were trading sharply down on inflation concerns. Germany, Europe's largest economy, appeared to be rising out of recession faster than analysts expected, with industrial production up 4.1 percent from a year earlier.
But a rare public disagreement by members of the policy council of the Bundesbank confused traders about the central bank's inflation-fighting strategy. German bond yields soared to a 17-month high.
 
 
German Money Supply
 "The story I heard was that there was also increasing concern about German money-supply growth, which has been pretty high," Fred Leiner, fixed-income market strategist at Continental Bank, said. That would mean that the Bundesbank would hesitate to cut German interest rates further, maintaining downward pressure on United States bonds and the dollar.

HEADLINE: Cape Town Journal;
In Land of Smokers, Mandela Heads Resistance

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, June 1

 BODY:
South Africans smoke in crowded elevators. They smoke on television. There are nursery schools where teachers smoke in the classroom.
Iraj Aedian, an anti-smoking economist at the University of Cape Town, recently walked into the maternity ward of a private hospital and was horrified to find a crowd of visitors puffing happily among the newborn. 
 But as of last week there is one place they do not smoke. In the Cabinet room of President Nelson Mandela's Government, the ashtrays have been banished, and even the chain-smoking former President, now Vice President, F. W. de Klerk, is obliged to step outside to assuage his craving.
The Cabinet room is the first beachhead in what Dr. Nkosazana Zuma, Mr. Mandela's new Minister of Health, promises will be a concerted battle for the hearts and lungs of the nation.
Dr. Zuma's assault on the smoking habit is not the highest priority of the new post-apartheid Government, or even of her own ministry -- the promise of free health care for poor children is her first job -- but it reflects a readiness in the new Government to take on powerful interests in areas not confined to the social ravages of apartheid.
In an interview, Dr. Zuma, a 45-year-old physician, said she would push for the conversion of smoke-congested workplaces and public buildings to smoke-free zones, a ban on the tobacco advertising and a steep increase in the cigarette excise tax.
Last week she issued regulations requiring health warnings in cigarette advertisements.
Her crusade will pit her against the well-connected domestic cigarette industry, a prospect Dr. Zuma anticipates with the unruffled determination of a woman new to Government but accustomed to political resistance. By gentle persistence, she helped persuade the reluctant, male-dominated hierarchy of the African National Congress to advocate the legalization of abortion, when many leaders were afraid of arousing the election-time hostility of conservative Christians and tribal chiefs.
As an AIDS researcher, she has promoted sex education and condom distribution in rural areas where these were considered radical innovations.
Dr. Zuma said that overturning the country's strict abortion laws and promoting awareness of AIDS would also be among her goals as Health Minister, assuring that she will not want for exercise of her political muscles.
At first glance her alarm about smoking might seem exaggerated. About 30 percent of adults over age 16 smoke, similar to England and the United States. But the overall number is low because few black women -- 5 to 7 percent -- smoke, and that is changing, encouraged by cigarette advertisements that increasingly aim at black women.
The pattern in countries like South Africa is that as rural dwellers move to the city, as traditional taboos break down and income levels rise, men smoke more and women join the smoking fraternity.
Among the mixed-race South Africans known as "coloreds," who are a bit more affluent and urban than blacks, 55 percent of men and 36 percent of women now smoke. They also have one of the highest rates of death from lung cancer of any community in the world.
"Our colored community unfortunately represents the future unless legislative action is taken now," said Yussuf Saloojee, director of the National Council Against Smoking.
Except among health-conscious whites, smoking has been steadily growing, abetted by a culture that has long treated tobacco as a harmless and stylish vice.
Until February, the law placed no age limit on the buying of cigarettes.
Two years ago smoking was banned on domestic airline flights, but smoke-free zones are still regarded as a novelty in public buildings.
At about 75 cents a pack, cigarettes are cheap, and according to Mr. Saloojee, the taxes are lower than any place except a few of the tobacco-growing states in America.
Although state television has stopped cigarette advertising, commercials on radio and in movie theaters portray smoking as a glamorous, cosmopolitan and -- the ultimate cachet -- American thing to do.
Articles about the dangers of smoking are rare in the South African press, which is heavily dependent on cigarette advertising revenues.
"The extent of awareness is abysmal," said Mr. Aedian, the economist. "In Canada and the United States, it's taken a great deal of continuous education to convince people that smoking is bad. That doesn't exist here. We just cannot afford spending that much on public education."
The South African tobacco industry has parried past attacks by pointing to the largely black work force -- 50,000, according to the Tobacco Exchange, an industry group -- employed in harvesting on the tobacco plantations and in the assembly lines of cigarette factories.
The cigarette industry here is dominated by the influential Rembrandt Group, a conglomerate that controls gold mines, banks and insurance companies. Together with large tobacco growers and allies in the powerful farm lobby, the cigarette makers have cultivated a smoker-friendly Government.
"The tobacco companies lobbied my colleagues just as hard as they could," said Rina Venter, Dr. Zuma's predecessor as Health Minister. "They came forward with very expensive documents, well prepared to prove that cigarette smoking is not harmful to your health."
With support from Mr. de Klerk, Mrs. Venter won the first modest restrictions last year, including a 16-year age limit on cigarette purchases and a provision allowing local officials to declare no-smoking areas in public buildings. But she said more far-reaching proposals stood no chance at the time.
Dr. Zuma starts out with the advantage of an African National Congress policy that is strongly anti-smoking, and with the sympathy of the new President.
President Mandela, an anti-smoking lobbyist said approvingly, "does not allow anyone to come within 20 feet of him with a cigarette."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious-Metal Prices Drop As Commodity Index Falls

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Precious metals fell yesterday as a decline in the Commodity Research Bureau's index suggested that prices for basic commodities might not be a source of renewed inflation.
The C.R.B. index of 21 commodity prices, a widely watched gauge of inflation, fell 1.61, to 233.84, ending a two-day rally that on Tuesday brought the index to its second-highest close since October 1990. Declines in copper, lumber and livestock helped push the index lower. 
 The drop in commodities pushed gold, silver and platinum lower and allowed bond prices, another sensitive gauge of inflation, to rise for the first time in five trading sessions.
"These are short-term fears" caused by a recent rise in soybean prices, said Daniel Weissman, head precious metals trader with MTB Bank in New York. "If inflation were in the air, gold should trade much higher. The market is saying none of this means anything.
 
Gold Contract Down
 Gold for August delivery, the most active futures contract, fell as low as $383.50 an ounce, closing $3.70 lower at $386.30 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. July silver fell 20 cents, its largest drop in almost two months, to $5.35 an ounce. July platinum fell $3.80, to $400.40 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Meanwhile, July copper fell 2.75 cent, to $1.010 a pound on the Comex.
While the C.R.B. index is respected, other indexes, like the Goldman Sachs Commodity Index, offer a more accurate view of whether changes in commodity prices will bring inflation to the economy, many analysts say.
The C.R.B. index gives equal weight to all components, from platinum to orange juice. The Goldman Sachs index weighs each for their relative effect on consumer prices. Energy prices account for 14 percent of the C.R.B. index. They are 48 percent of the Goldman index. Late yesterday, the Goldman Sachs index was unchanged at 2268.91.
 
Cattle Prices Fall the Limit
 On other commodity markets, cattle prices fell their daily trading limit before recovering on concern about weak demand from retailers.
June live cattle for August delivery fell 1.50 cent, to 63.775 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. August feeder cattle also fell its limit, dropping 1.50 cent, to 72.45 cents a pound.
Traders are concerned that retailers bought much of the beef to restock shelves following Memorial Day and will not order much more for Father's Day.
Elsewhere, lumber prices fell from a two-month high amid concerns whether rising interest rates would dampen housing demand. July lumber fell $10, the daily trading limit, to $387.70 for $1,000 board feet on the Merc. On Tuesday, lumber rose to its highest price since late March.

HEADLINE: Rich Saudi Bails Out Disney Unit

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 1

 BODY:
A Saudi prince who provided cash to Citicorp at a crucial time in its restructuring has agreed to acquire a major stake in Euro Disneyland, the struggling French theme park, and to provide $100 million to build a convention center considered crucial to the park's survival, the parent Walt Disney Company said today.
Under the agreement, Prince Walid bin Talal, a nephew of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, will acquire 13 percent to 24 percent ownership in Euro Disney, through a stock rights offering. 
 The offering will increase the number of shares in Euro Disney to 770 million from 170 million now. With it, the Prince's investment in the company is expected to total between $400 million and $500 million.
 
Deal With Park's Creditors
 The rights offering is part of a financial restructuring between Euro Disney and its creditors that is expected to put the theme park, critically short of cash, back on its feet. Walt Disney, based in Burbank, Calif., will subscribe to 49 percent of the new rights, in proportion to its current stake in Euro Disney, and the public will be offered 51 percent.
United Saudi Commercial Bank, of which Prince Walid is chairman, has agreed to act as a backup underwriter with the three banks leading the syndicate group that is underwriting the 51 percent to be sold to the public. The offering is expected to be completed by July.
The Prince, who is 37, gained international prominence early in 1991, when he became the largest shareholder in Citicorp, investing nearly $800 million when the New York bank holding company's shares were depressed by problems from bad real estate loans. He later sold large numbers of those shares for nearly two and a half times what he paid.
 
Two Sources of Equity
 Under the new agreement, Prince Walid can buy shares both from the Walt Disney Company and the syndicate group. He can buy up to 1.9 billion francs -- $338 million -- worth of shares that are not acquired by the syndicate group. If that quantity of shares is not available to him, the Walt Disney Company will sell him Euro Disney shares worth up to one billion francs -- $177.8 million -- at the issue price. The Prince has agreed to limit his total investment in Euro Disney to half of the Walt Disney Company's shareholdings.
His investment is a major vote of confidence for the Euro Disney venture, which has been losing money since it opened in April 1992. Hurt by the European recession, bad weather, cultural differences and high start-up costs, the park has failed to attract European visitors in numbers as great as it had expected.
Euro Disney has announced an operating loss of $183.9 million for the first half of the 1994 fiscal year, with revenue declining 12.4 percent, to $276 million.
The Walt Disney Company's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, said in a statement today: "This significant investment and financing commitment by Prince al-Walid means that there is a strong, sophisticated new partner who shares our view of Euro Disney's future and whose involvement enhances Disney's major contribution to the Euro Disney financial restructuring package."
The restructuring plan includes debt payment forgiveness and deferral of principal payments that will provide breathing room to Euro Disney to continue operations. The parent company is also making concessions, including waiving royalty and management fees for five years and reducing the amount in succeeding years.
 
Decision Is Hailed
 Industry analysts applauded the Prince's investment, saying that it would be good for all involved, especially the Walt Disney Company, which has been widely criticized for mishandling the European venture.
"It's good for Disney in the sense that it lessens Disney's equity ownership in Euro Disney, which in turn will be beneficial to the company's earnings, reducing the amount it will absorb from Euro Disney's losses," said Richard P. Simon of Goldman, Sachs.
The Prince also agreed to a three-year financial commitment of $100 million to build a convention center near the park, which is situated 20 miles east of Paris. The convention center is seen as vital to drawing new visitors to the park and hotels during the midweek and off-season periods.
Prince Walid heads a multibillion-dollar business empire that includes banking, travel, real estate, broadcasting and supermarkets.
The Prince could not be reached for comment today. A receptionist at the office of Faissal M. Fahad, his Prince's lawyer in San Francisco, said that Mr. Fahad was traveling in Saudi Arabia and that no one would be available to comment on the Euro Disney investment.
But in a statement released by the Walt Disney Company, Prince Walid said: "I believe the long-term prospects for Euro Disney are bright. The quality of what has been constructed at Euro Disneyland Paris makes me optimistic about its future. Becoming a partner in the Euro Disney project is consistent with my strategy to invest significant amounts of capital in association with superior management teams around the world."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New Fund Raises $1 Billion For Investment Plan in Asia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
While Asian stock markets have been plummeting and tepid investor demand led the Tiger Management Corporation to cancel plans for an investment fund in emerging economies, the American International Group has raised more than $1 billion for a fund to invest in large infrastructure projects in Asia.
With an illustrious history that began in Shanghai in 1919, American International is seen by corporate America as something of a "China hand," and is the most internationally minded of American insurance companies. Its links to China and other Asian countries are more than just historical. American International is a well-established insurer in many Asian markets, including China, where other companies are struggling to enter. 
 The new fund, called the A.I.G. Asian Infrastructure Fund, will make large, long-term investments in projects for developing energy, transportation, electric power and petrochemicals. It will be managed by two former executives from the World Bank: Moeen A. Qureshi, formerly the bank's second ranking officer who also served as interim Prime Minister of Pakistan last year, and Donald C. Roth, the bank's former treasurer. Mr. Qureshi left the World Bank in 1991 and Mr. Roth in 1992. They became founders in 1992 of the Emerging Markets Corporation, an investment fund.
The familiarity of Mr. Qureshi and Mr. Roth with many government officials, local businesses and other financiers, whose cooperation is essential for long-term infrastructure projects, helped the fund attract twice the $500 million target it set when fund-raising started in late 1993. By late May, when the fund was closed to new investors, it had nearly two dozen institutional investors and $1.08 billion.
Officials at American International and the new fund were unavailable to comment, but people familiar with the fund said its investors included various agencies of the Singapore Government with $250 million, as well as American International itself with $100 million.
Although the growth potential of emerging countries in Asia is attractive to outside investors, many of them have a hard time finding outlets for their funds because local stocks are often thinly traded and cannot readily absorb large blocks of capital. In addition, there is the risk of highly volatile markets, as shown by the steep market declines this year of 20 percent in Hong Kong, 23 percent in Malaysia, 19 percent in Thailand and 16 percent in Indonesia.
 
 
'Not Yet Developed Enough'
 "In these markets it is hard to find enough publicly trade stocks to invest large amounts of money," John A. Griffin, president of Tiger Management, said last year when he announced plans for Tiger's emerging markets fund. "You could readily invest $100 million in a power plant or container port in China, but to buy $100 million of stock is impossible. Their capital markets are not yet developed enough."
Despite the appeal of investing in large projects, not all funds embracing that idea have been able to attract money from investors. Tiger Management canceled plans for a $1 billion fund to invest in Asia and other markets when it was unable to raise more than $250 million. Other investment funds similar to that of A.I.G. include the Asian Infrastructure Fund, sponsored by Peregrine Investment Holdings, Hong Kong, whose clients include Soros Fund Management and some American pension funds.
Mr. Qureshi started at the World Bank as a loan officer. In his 30 years at the bank, he worked in many different jobs before leaving in 1991 as a senior vice president and No. 2 ranking officer. When he was named interim Prime Minister of Pakistan, Mr. Qureshi earned high marks for economic reforms that elected Government officials had been unable to achieve, such as taxing large rural landowners and curbing Government spending.
Mr. Roth spent more than 20 years at Merrill Lynch & Company, where he was an investment banker in Europe, Asia and the Middle East, before joining the World Bank as its treasurer in 1988.
