HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE ASKS GLOBAL SANCTIONS ON NORTH KOREANS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration called today for global economic sanctions against North Korea after international inspectors said the North Koreans had destroyed evidence of whether they had diverted material for a nuclear bomb.
The Administration's move marked a new -- and potentially dangerous -- phase of Washington's confrontation with North Korea over its nuclear program. North Korea has threatened to attack South Korea if sanctions are imposed. 
 Washington's decision to seek the sanctions follows more than a year of on-again, off-again talks in which American officials have sought to coax North Korea to agree to strict controls on its nuclear program.
"They have triggered this, not the United States or anyone else," President Clinton told reporters in Rome today. "I just don't think we can walk away from this."
But even as the Administration vowed to seek sanctions, key elements of its plan remained unclear, including whether China would go along and what steps North Korea would have to take to end any sanctions that might be imposed.
Administration officials said the sanctions needed to be painful enough to induce the North Koreans to reconsider the decision to proceed with their nuclear weapons program while leaving open the possibility of a diplomatic solution.
An Administration official, who asked not to be identified, said one plan that has been promoted by Robert Gallucci, the Administration's top official on policy toward North Korea, has two main elements: calling on other countries to refrain from arms purchases or deliveries, and seeking a cut-off in the $600 million to $1.6 billion in annual remittances sent back to the country by North Koreans living in Japan.
Other possible measures include suspending North Korea's membership in international organizations, cutting off technical assistance and banning non-commercial airline flights. The most Draconian measure would be a full-scale trade embargo, which would ban oil shipments. But the general view among officials is that such a measure would go beyond what China and other Asian countries are willing to accept.
Senior Administration officials declined to explain their sanctions plan, saying that Mr. Gallucci planned to discuss the proposed measures with South Korean and Japanese officials on Friday. One official said, however, that Washington was still in the process of hammering out its position.
China's position is important because it wields a veto in the United Nations Security Council, supplies oil and food to North Korea and has a long border with North Korea. Although the Administration has sought to justify its decision to award most-favored-nation trading status to China by saying Beijing's cooperation is needed in dealing with North Korea, it is still unclear whether China in fact would support sanctions.
In Beijing today, China warned against increasing the confrontation with North Korea. "At this time, we do not favor the resort to means that might sharpen the confrontation," said Shen Guofang, Foreign Ministry spokesman, in a news conference.
Russia also urged the Administration to move slowly. In Moscow, President Boris N. Yeltsin said a Russian-proposed international conference should be convened before sanctions are imposed.
"Today, when no decision has been taken on calling an international conference, it is too early to talk about sanctions," Mr. Yeltsin said.
But Administration officials said that Russia is much less of an obstacle to sanctions than China and that Russian diplomats at the United Nations have been generally cooperative on the question.
 
Other Options Exist
 Even if the Security Council refused to support sanctions, there are some measures that Washington and its allies could take on their own, such as persuading Japan to cut off financial transfers.
North Korea's threats to retaliate if sanctions are imposed are another worry. Echoing its bellicose warnings that sanctions could be an act of war, the North Korean Foreign Minister, Kim Yong Nam, sent a letter on Saturday to the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, warning that sanctions would "bring devastating consequences, menacing peace in Asia and the rest of the world."
The Pentagon said today that there were no indications that North Korea, which has concentrated much of its 1.2 million-member military close to South Korea, was about to attack. As a precaution, the Pentagon has already shipped Patriot antimissile systems and additional spare parts and other supplies to the area.
American military officials said the aircraft carrier Independence would leave Japan on Friday for a major exercise near Hawaii. Because of the heightened tensions, military officials were thinking about keeping the Independence west of Midway Island so that it could steam toward Korea if a crisis developed.
Another way the North Koreans could retaliate is by withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and rejecting all constraints on its nuclear program. Despite its dispute with the International Atomic Energy Agency, North Korea has continued to allow monitors to visit its nuclear site to determine that it is not being used to build up a nuclear arsenal.
At issue is North Korea's refusal to permit international inspectors to examine 300 of the 8,000 fuel rods in its nuclear reactor in order to determine how much plutonium might have diverted in past years.
The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that North Korea diverted enough plutonium for one or two bombs after it shut down its nuclear reactor in 1989 and that there is a "better than even" chance it has actually developed one or two nuclear weapons.
North Korea has denied this. But in recent weeks the North Koreans began furiously pulling out fuel rods from the reactor at Yongbyon and dumping them indiscriminately into a cooling pond.
Today, Hans Blix, the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, sent a letter to Mr. Boutros-Ghali noting that the North Koreans had removed so many rods that they had made it impossible for the agency to conduct its measurements.
 
Need for Cooperation
 Mr. Blix wrote that the agency's ability to determine whether plutonium was diverted "has been seriously eroded because of the discharge of the core."
"The situation resulting from the core discharge is irreversible," Mr. Blix added.
But Mr. Blix also suggested that there were other ways for the agency to reconstruct the history of the reactor and to try to determine whether plutonium had been diverted.
"For the agency to be able to verify non-diversion" by the North Koreans, Mr. Blix wrote, "it is essential for the agency to have access to all safeguards, relevant information and locations. To achieve that, a paramount requirement is the full cooperation" of North Korea.
One way of gaining additional information would be to send inspectors to two nuclear waste sites at Yongbyon. But the North Koreans have steadfastly refused to give international monitors access to the sites.
Mr. Blix is traveling to the United Nations to meet with the Security Council on Friday, United Nations officials said.
With North Korea rejecting Washington's earlier conciliatory overture, the matter has become a hot issue for Mr. Clinton, who is being criticized for what some say is a vacillating foreign policy.
Some American officials say the Administration was obliged to seek sanctions to maintain its credibility. But a comprehensive analysis prepared by American intelligence agencies last year said it was unlikely that sanctions would induce North Korea to abandon its nuclear program.
 
Building Second Reactor
 North Korea has been working hard to construct a second, larger reactor and to expand its ability to reprocess plutonium. The fuel that it is now being removed from its reactor is enough to build four or five bombs.
North Korea's population is inured to economic deprivation. Some trading partners that provide oil for arms, like Iran, are unlikely to be swayed by a United Nations call to action.
A key question is what exactly the Administration hopes to achieve through sanctions. If they were imposed, would North Korea have to help the atomic energy agency determine whether plutonium had been diverted to get them lifted? Would it need to do more, such as halting the construction of its second reactor and the expansion of its nuclear reprocessing ability?
Would the Security Council agree to a gradual toughening of sanctions and, if so, over what time frame?
"The objective is to have North Korea reconsider its position and find it in its interest to move back to negotiations and settle this matter," a senior Administration official said.

HEADLINE: Haitian Migrants Settle In, Looking Back

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

 BODY:
In a turquoise cottage in Miami's Little Haiti, Meriente Auguste riffled through photographs of the family left behind when she fled home on a tumbledown boat. She pulled out two snapshots, one of her father, one of her teen-age sister. Hands crossed over their chests, they both lay in open coffins.
"They died because of me," said Ms. Auguste, 23, who left Haiti in 1991, won political asylum last fall and now irons blouses for a living. "My father was shot because I escaped, and my sister died of sorrow the day of his funeral." 
 Two thousand miles north and a universe away, Patricia Reiher Francis conducted business in four languages in La Petite Boutique, her bookstore in Cambria Heights, Queens. In 1958, after her wealthy father angered President Francois Duvalier, her family gave up their butler, their cook and the rest of their elite island life. They took not a leaky boat, but an airplane into exile. It was the very beginning of the Haitian exodus.
Between the flight of Ms. Francis and that of Ms. Auguste lies the story of the Haitian Diaspora. Spanning nearly four decades, it is a complex tale often distorted by the monolithic image of the Haitian boat people.
That image -- of poor, illiterate, disease-carrying people -- has lent an animus to the debate over Haitian refugees that many Haitian-Americans find unsettling. The debate gained new urgency this week when Jamaica agreed to let the United States conduct shipboard immigration interviews in its waters, raising the prospect of another wave of refugees.
"It's insulting to be so unwanted; all this talk about Haitians descending on this country as if they were a plague," said Roger Biamby, director of human services at the Pierre Toussaint Haitian-Catholic Center in Miami. "It's not like we haven't proved ourselves."
Numbering about 450,000, Haitian-Americans are a small, entrenched immigrant group, concentrated in the New York and Miami metropolitan areas. They include not only migrant workers in Homestead, Fla., but wealthy doctors on Long Island, not only taxi drivers in Manhattan but college professors in Washington. Most came by plane.
Four in 10 have at least some college education; one in 10 has less than an eighth-grade education. About 5.7 percent of the nation's Haitian households -- 5,300 -- collect welfare benefits, compared with 5.2 percent of households generally, according to an analysis of 1990 Census data.
Marc Abraham, an elfin 37-year-old Long Island resident, is far more representative than the gaunt refugees who beseech Sister Ruth Podesta for rice and beans in Miami. The son of a carpenter and a hotel maid, Mr. Abraham teaches math at Erasmus Hall High School in Flatbush, Brooklyn, and moonlights at La Guardia Community College. He also runs a typically hodgepodge immigrant business, a car service that sells commercial insurance and produces educational videos in Haitian Creole.
 
Plenty of Problems
 "I think Americans see Haitians as a desperate people instead of a decent people who struggle," Mr. Abraham said. "I have to understand that hostility, I guess, to take it off my heart. I mean, this country has enough problems without ours too."
Indeed, the most recent Haitian refugees have faced their share of problems -- high unemployment and rampant crime in Little Haiti -- as have second-generation Haitian-Americans in New York City who cannot find their way out of the ghetto.
"My feeling is that there is coming to be a bifurcation in the community," said Alex Stepick, director of the Immigration and Ethnicity Institute at Florida International University. "There are those living out the American immigrant dream and those who, succumbing to anti-Haitian and racist prejudice, are merging into the underclass."
 
The Diaspora
To Flatbush And Beyond
 Every wave of migration from Haiti has come during political turmoil there, but economic malaise always accompanies such turmoil. So it is often difficult to distinguish political from economic migrants. .
Some Haitian emigres went to Harlem in the 1920's. But the migration from Haiti started in earnest when Francois Duvalier took power in 1957. The first Haitians to leave were dissident politicians, and then came middle-class professionals and finally tradespeople. Like other immigrants before them, most headed for New York City.
They confronted what Michel Laguerre, a Haitian-American anthropologist, calls their "triple minority status," as blacks, foreigners and non-English speakers. Coming from the elite of a black nation, it was a rude shock for people like Mr. Biamby's father, Ernst, a former army colonel.
Colonel Biamby fled after plotting and failing to assassinate Duvalier. A career military officer with no experience in the civilian world, he took a job stabbing litter at the 1964 World's Fair in Queens. His wife sewed in a garment factory. His son, then 16, washed dishes at a Times Square restaurant, eventually putting himself through a doctoral program in political science.
 
Newspapers and Radio
 Thousands of Haitians were working their way out of menial jobs at the same time. They started newspapers and radio programs, churches, credit associations and social clubs. They established a quiet presence in Brooklyn that remains to this day, with the latest arrivals selling cloves and djondjon, or dried mushrooms, on Church Avenue.
Most Haitians settled first in Flatbush, Crown Heights and Bedford-Stuyvesant, working in garment factories, hotels and restaurants. But those who could moved to Queens and the suburbs, commuting to hospital emergency rooms and law practices in Brooklyn for work. . As their children grew, they became fluent in the lexicon of New York, in the P.S.'s and the IRT.
Estelle Dubuission, 64, like many, never stopped missing her hometown, Lascahobas. In fact, she mortgaged her home in Canarsie, spent the limits on her credit cards and organized fund-raising events to give the town an ambulance and a child-care center. Her children, meanwhile, grew up to become an electrical engineer, an architect and an X-ray technician.
"They were born and raised here," she said. "They are crazy about Haiti, but this is their home."
 
Miami Connection
Under the Palms, The Roots Remain
 Until 1977, Brooklyn was the quiet heart of Haitian America. Between 1977 and 1981, 60,000 Haitian boat people landed in South Florida. And just like that, the nerve center of the Haitian Diaspora moved south, to a community of stucco cottages and mom-and-pop businesses anointed Little Haiti.
From its birth, Miami's Haitian community was different. Haitians had melted into New York's black neighborhoods, into the vastness of the city. But in Miami, their presence was felt immediately. Their arrival was controversial, their numbers greater relative to the total population. They were younger and poorer. And they remained so tied to their homeland that the ins and outs of Haitian politics quickly became a local story on Miami's television newscasts.
"In New York you can forget for a few minutes that you were born in Haiti and get on with your life," said Alwyn McCalla, 32, who runs a money-transfer office in Little Haiti. "But in Miami, forget about it. You live, breathe and eat your Haitian roots."
In the early 1980's, thousands of Haitian doctors, teachers, social workers and entrepreneurs moved from New York to Miami. Restaurants serving conch and goat and record shops blaring Haitian merengue sprang up on 54th Street and Northeast Second Avenue. Before long, there was a 24-hour Creole-language radio station.
 
Prejudice in Miami
 By the 1990 Census, Haitians represented about 6 percent of the city's population, concentrated in Little Haiti. They were only 1.5 percent of New York City, spread throughout the five boroughs. Miami's Haitians were more provincial and less educated than New York's; nearly half had less than an eighth-grade education.
In Miami, "the anti-Haitian prejudice was much stronger," Professor Stepick said.
When he moved from New York, Leslie Prudent, an assistant elementary school principal, was startled by the antipathy. Students told him to "go back to the banana boat." Teachers referred to problem students as "Haitians" regardless of background. Tennis players dropped their jaws when they watched Mr. Prudent, a former tennis coach at Hunter College, destroy his opponents on the court.
"They'd be in shock, like, 'I didn't know the boat people played,' " Mr. Prudent said.
Much of the antagonism sprang from the way the Miami Haitians arrived, some literally washing up on beaches. The tension was increased by the Federal Government's effort to keep out more. In 1981, President Reagan ordered Coast Guard cutters to stop Haitians at sea. In the next 10 years, only 28 of the 22,716 intercepted were admitted into the United States.
 
Jailed if Caught
 Those who made it through the blockade were usually jailed if caught. Cuban refugees, in contrast, were welcomed as heroes. The Haitians felt embattled, and it did not help that some Miami blacks resented their entrepreneurial success and their appeal to employers as eager workers accepting low pay for long hours.
"Every day I get calls saying, 'Fedy, we need some Haitians,' " said Fedy Bieux-Brierre, administrator of a City of Miami office in Little Haiti. "The Haitian workers don't look at the clock."
While tensions existed between black Americans and West Indians in New York -- Haitians used to be called "French fries" in Harlem -- the antagonism was closer to the surface in Miami.
"I'll never forget the time I met this Afro-American in the supermarket," Mr. Prudent said. "He heard my accent and said, 'You're not a brother. You're a cousin.' "
 
Trouble Time
Frustrations And Failures
 By the second generation, when the accents fade, however, Haitian-Americans are, for all intents and purposes, black Americans, as acknowledged by the black leaders who champion their cause on a national level.
They face the same hurdles. And some evidence suggests that the adult children of Haitian immigrants are floundering.
In New York, only about 7 percent of Haitian-born immigrants collect welfare benefits, compared with 9 percent of the general population. But, in contrast, at least a quarter of adult, second-generation Haitians receive welfare, according to an analysis of the 1990 Census. That, however, is a small number: only about 1,000 household heads.
 
Sharing Resources
 Haitian immigrants, who do not believe in welfare, consider this a negative example of Americanization. In Haiti, families, even people from the same town, are supposed to share their resources. "It's a Creole saying: 'If there is food for two, there's food for three,' " said Chantal Morrisse, a hotel maid.
Still, while some Haitian-Americans have derailed their parents' dreams, some have realized them. About half the Haitians in New York have some college education, and 4 percent have advanced degrees. About a third of New York's Haitians now live in the suburbs, particularly Long Island, Rockland County, and in northern New Jersey.
The Haitian Enterprise Association in New York counts several thousand Haitian-owned businesses. Haitian Doctors Abroad, which gathered 500 physicians for a convention in Orlando, Fla., last year, counts several thousand medical doctors.
 
Recent Troubles
 From the beginning, Little Haiti in Miami was a healthy, bustling neighborhood. There are no empty storefronts, and no homeless people on the streets. But lately it has known some troubles.
Most recently, with many businesses dependent on trade with Haiti, its commercial vibrancy has been dimmed by the international embargo against Haiti's military regime. Unemployment is high, about 30 percent. Once a safe neighborhood, Little Haiti now has the highest crime rate in Miami.
Ms. Auguste, however, still finds it peaceful.
As a teen-ager in Haiti, Ms. Auguste, daughter of a tailor, helped run a literacy program. Infuriated by soldiers who disrupted classes, she threw herself into politics with a fervent belief that President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was Haiti's savior. Shortly after he was overthrown, Ms. Auguste was jailed, then fled. Her father was murdered by thugs in retribution, she said.
 
A Pink Toyota
 Accepting her story, the United States allowed Ms. Auguste to start a new life. Now she commutes every morning to a garment factory in Hialeah, where she earns about $200 a week. Working overtime, she has saved enough money to make her first big purchase: a pale pink, used Toyota Tercel with a big red heart on the front bumper. She has every intention of returning to Haiti as soon as it is safer there, she said.
But so did many other Haitians, political exiles and economic migrants alike, who fled before her. They ended up forming the Diaspora, with roots now too deep to be unearthed.
"Sometimes I have a desire to go back, but there's nothing to go back to," said Rodrigue Charles, 35, an immigration agent and former Peace Corps volunteer in Africa. "All the Haitians I grew up with are either in Canada, France or the U.S."

LENGTH: 1133 words

HEADLINE: CUOMO, BEGINNING BID FOR 4TH TERM, ASSAILS THE G.O.P.

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, June 2

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo kicked off his campaign for a fourth four-year term today with a speech that included a list of accomplishments, an acknowledgement that he had not reached all his goals, and a broad attack on Republicans, both in New York and elsewhere, for practicing the politics of division.
On the closing day of the State Democratic Convention, Mr. Cuomo and his running mate, Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine, left the direct assaults on their probable Republican opponents, State Senator George E. Pataki and Elizabeth P. McCaughey, to a parade of surrogates. When it was Mr. Cuomo's turn, he used his meandering 50-minute acceptance speech to draw numerous substantive and political distinctions between the Democratic and Republican tickets. 
 "Stan and I are different because we weren't picked by some boss," he said, referring to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who played a major role in assembling the Republican ticket. "Let me tell you something. I may hit a sour note from time to time. But understand this. The words and ideas that come out of my mouth are mine. No one else's. I will have no boss but the people of the state of New York."
That theme echoed throughout the convention, where the Democrats nominated a ticket heavy with incumbents and outlined a strategy for what is expected to be Mr. Cuomo's toughest campaign since his first, in 1982. They made clear that they would not let Mr. Pataki, an unknown quantity in most of the state, define himself alone. But the intensity of their attacks suggested the concern Democratic strategists have about Mr. Cuomo's prospects this year.
Today's speakers took every opportunity to depict Mr. Pataki as a political creation of Mr. D'Amato. They characterized him as a man of malleable convictions who had made a career out of opposing initiatives rather than proposing solutions.
The chairman of the Democratic National Committee, David Wilhelm, referred to him as "D'Amato light." New York City's Public Advocate, Mark Green, asked, "Are we going to let Al's pals run the state?"
While Mr. Cuomo did not acknowledge Mr. Pataki by name, he painted the campaign as a struggle between positivism and negativism. "Where would I be, Mario Cuomo, if the negativists who mocked my parents and called them dagos had been in charge of the state of New York or any other important government?" he asked.
He also sought to link New York's Republicans to the national party's caustic 1992 convention in Houston and Republican leaders' past efforts to portray New York as a pariah of liberal politics. "I believe we Democrats seem today to know this state better, to appreciate it more, to love it more than our opponents," he said. "Maybe it is the negativism that has infected our adversaries."
Mr. Cuomo clearly viewed today's address as critical to his re-election. He rehearsed twice in the Buffalo Convention Center to become comfortable with the Teleprompter. To make sure he was rested, he stayed overnight at a Buffalo airport hotel, breaking his practice of sleeping in the Executive Mansion in Albany whenever possible. And his aides made sure the convention hall was packed with 3,000 placard-waving fans, a stark contrast to the half-empty hall on Wednesday.
With the exception of Mr. Lundine, who was nominated without opposition today, the rest of the Democratic ticket was put together on Wednesday. It includes United States Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell and State Comptroller H. Carl McCall.
Mr. McCall used his acceptance speech today to level a direct attack on his Republican opponent, Herbert London, the 1990 Conservative Party nominee for governor. After losing to Mr. Pataki in the gubernatorial balloting at last week's Republican convention, Mr. London accepted the party's nomination as comptroller in an arrangement aimed at winning Conservative support for Mr. Pataki.
"Herb London doesn't want to be comptroller," said Mr. McCall, who hopes to become the first black candidate to win statewide office in New York. "He wants to use it to advance his far, far-right-wing agenda."
 
No Woman on Ticket
 Heading into the Sept. 13 primary, the Democratic ticket remains without a woman while the Republican ticket has two -- Ms. McCaughey and Bernadette Castro, who is running for Senate. Mr. Cuomo seemed to acknowledge that contrast in his speech today by listing virtually every woman he had appointed to office.
One Democratic woman, Karen S. Burstein, a former Family Court judge in Brooklyn, plans to try to run a primary campaign against Mr. Koppell, as does the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes. To get on the ballot, they must collect 15,000 valid signatures on nominating petitions during a five-week period this summer. The Rev. Al Sharpton also will go the petition route in an attempt to challenge Mr. Moynihan.
On the Republican side, Mr. Pataki still may face a primary challenge from Richard M. Rosenbaum, a former state Republican chairman. And some Conservative Party leaders hope to keep Mr. Pataki from receiving their party's endorsement at its convention in Albany on Saturday, a move that would tarnish the gloss of Republican-Conservative unity created at the Republican convention.
Mr. Cuomo begins the campaign with more than $4.5 million, far more than Mr. Pataki. Mr. Wilhelm pledged today to give the State Democratic Committee $1 million from a June 27 Democratic National Committee fund-raiser in Manhattan that will feature President Clinton.
 
Formidable Obstacles
 But even the Democratic delegates and strategists here acknowledged that Mr. Cuomo faces formidable obstacles. A restless electorate demonstrated its impatience last year by ousting incumbent Democratic chief executives in New Jersey and New York City. And after a bruising recession, Mr. Cuomo's approval rating rests near its lowest point.
The Governor and his advisers maintain that he has an admirable record but has failed to sell it. He catalogued his accomplishments, ranging from a large personal income tax cut to the country's first mandatory seat-belt law to significant increases in funds for education.
"The speech was lengthy because it began the process of communicating a substantial series of accomplishments that have lost their immediacy," said the New York City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi.
Mr. Cuomo's media consultant, David Garth, agreed, saying that even he had been surprised to learn what the Governor had done. He blamed the news media for not fully reporting the Cuomo record. "The people who report the media don't stop at the rest stations on the state highway because if they did, they'd tell you that 22 of the 26 of the Thruway restaurants and stops have been rebuilt," he said. "It boggles the mind."

HEADLINE: School Chiefs Say Teachers Face Layoffs

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

 BODY:
Superintendents in New York City's 32 school districts say they will be forced to lay off hundreds of teachers under the Giuliani administration's proposed city budget.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has said the budget cuts he proposed for the Board of Education would cut bureaucratic fat without directly affecting classrooms. But several superintendents, who have been meeting in recent weeks to discuss the cuts, said they could not balance their budgets without dismissing teachers, assistant principals, guidance counselors, teacher's aides and others. 
 The superintendents say that the damage that the budget cuts would do has been overshadowed in the last two months by the Mayor's dispute with Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines over the size of the school bureaucracy. That exchange became so heated that the Chancellor threatened to resign, but ultimately he agreed to the Mayor's demand that 2,500 jobs be cut at school headquarters. Several, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they felt the Chancellor had failed to properly highlight the losses in classrooms.
In interviews they said the $358 million in cuts planned for the $7.5 billion budget would be the deepest in several years.
"The Mayor has said, 'Cut $358 million from the schools without hurting children,' " said Dr. Arthur Greenberg, superintendent of District 25 in Queens. "And I want to tell you that that is just not possible."
The superintendents, joined by members of community school boards, school union officials and educational advocates, have begun preparing protests, letter-writing drives and phone campaigns to persuade the City Council to restore some of the money when it votes on the budget.
Mr. Giuliani's aides and officials at the Financial Control Board, speaking in interviews yesterday, said the superintendents were attempting to exaggerate the severity of the cuts and said the projections of mass layoffs were alarmist.
"We've heard the Board of Ed cry wolf on a number of occasions," said Abraham M. Lackman, the city budget director. "It's not unusual that as the City Council considers the budget, that the Board of Education will seek to protect its spending."
The Board of Education's central budget office recently sent a memo to the superintendents that outlined two potential budgets, one that projected cuts of $100 million and one with cuts of $200 million. The memo apportioned the cuts by enrollment in each district and asked the superintendents how they would accommodate the two possibilities.
By yesterday, only 24 of the 32 superintendents had responded, but even their partial reports underlined the scope of the cutbacks contemplated. Under the $100 million cut, the 24 superintendents said they would lay off 368 classroom teachers, 87 assistant principals, and 1,200 guidance counselors, classroom aides and other employees. Under the $200 million cut, the 24 superintendents said they would lay off 837 teachers, 183 assistant principals, and 2,250 other school employees.
"The Mayor's goal was not to have any cuts in the classrooms, and the Chancellor has agreed," said Marcelino Rodriguez, superintendent in Manhattan's District 4, which includes East Harlem. "But a cut of this size is going to hit classrooms anyway."
The 32 superintendents administer the city's 830 elementary and middle schools; similar cuts were likely in the 160 high schools, school officials said.
Mr. Giuliani's budget was presented May 10 to the City Council. The Council plans to vote on it late next week, said Thomas L. McMahon, director of the Council's finance division. Unlike other large school systems around the country, the New York City schools are not fiscally independent: state aid and city financing come through City Hall.
Mr. McMahon said that the magnitude of the cuts being asked of the school system this year surpasses any of the five previous budgets that he has worked on since he assumed his position in 1989, especially since more than 20,000 new students enter the system each year.
"Given the register growth, which drives a whole series of new needs, these cuts are more dramatic," he said.
 
Cortines Criticized
 Several superintendents said Mr. Cortines has appeared unwilling to confront the Mayor since his public disagreement with Mr. Giuliani on April 9 over cuts to the bureaucracy and the appointment of a City Hall-based fiscal monitor. Mr. Cortines remained in his job only after intervention by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The Chancellor's spokesman, John Beckman, disputed the view of these superintendents. "If anything, the Chancellor has been the lone voice about the effect of the proposed cuts on the schools," Mr. Beckman said. "What is needed is a bigger chorus."
Because simultaneous negotiations are underway at City Hall and in Albany, where the Legislature has not yet determined how much state aid New York City will receive, few numbers in the debate are firm.
Anxious over the continuing uncertainties, the superintendents and many community school board presidents met on May 16 with Mr. Cortines, Carol A. Gresser, the board president, and Leonard Hellenbrand, the board's budget director, requesting information about the cuts they should expect.
 
Budgets Explained
 Three days later, Mr. Hellenbrand sent the memo projecting the two budget scenarios.
Explaining how he arrived at the two scenarios, Mr. Hellenbrand said that Mr. Cortines had already identified about $60 million to $70 million in administrative cuts at board headquarters. Through further economy moves, accounting devices, and negotiation with City Hall, Mr. Hellenbrand said he believed the board could reduce the cuts necessary at the community district level to $200 million, hence the first scenario. City Hall is likely to pass on to the schools about $100 million in state education aid, Mr. Hellenbrand said, and for that reason, he asked the superintendents to explain how they would respond to budget cuts of $100 million.
The superintendents' tactics for accommodating the $100 million cut would vary considerably. Superintendent Anthony Alvarado said he would accommodate the $2.2 million cut that the $100 million citywide reduction would bring in his District 2, which includes most of lower Manhattan, by laying off five assistant principals, seven district office employees, four guidance counselors, 56 school aides and 13 teachers.
Superintendent William Casey said that the $100 million cut would mean a $2.1 million loss to Brooklyn's District 15, which includes the Park Slope and Sunset Park sections. He said that, in order to avoid increasing class sizes, he would eliminate 30 assistant principals, 19 guidance counselors, 33 secretaries, 123 school aides and 15 school guards.
"The Board of Education, more than any other agency, is extremely adept at creating artifice," said Allen J. Proctor, the executive director of the Financial Control Board. "You're seeing a familiar part of the budget choreography."

HEADLINE: Doubting Sanctions, Aristide Urges U.S. Action on Haiti

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
In the strongest statement he has made in favor of military intervention, the exiled Haitian President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, said today that he doubted that economic sanctions could restore him to office and urged "action to get rid of the thugs" who overthrew him.
In an interview in his Washington apartment, Father Aristide repeated his concern that the Haitian Constitution would not allow him to formally invite foreign military intervention. But the Haitian leader said the United States should be "moving toward a surgical action" to remove Haiti's military leadership that he said would succeed in a few hours. 
 Asked if sanctions could force the military to relinquish power, Father Aristide said, "If we really want to save lives, something else should be done now." Referring to the United States intervention in Panama in 1989 to remove the military dictator Manuel Noriega, he added: "Haiti is not the first case. When things were like that in another country, something was done. Why not in Haiti?"
Father Aristide's comments came as part of a growing debate in the United States over statements by President Clinton that military action should not be ruled out to force an end to Haiti's political crisis.
 
Taken by Surprise?
 But his statements appeared to take some advisers by surprise. Moments before the Haitian leader spoke in the interview, one close American adviser, Burton Wides, suggested that the emphasis on the diplomacy around Haiti should be aggressively closing loopholes in the international sanctions before any foreign intervention is considered. It was not clear whether the Haitian leader had expressed his views on military action directly to Clinton Administration officials.
Until now, Father Aristide's position on foreign intervention has been widely perceived as ambivalent, with many in the Clinton Administration expressing concern that he would either not fully support military intervention before the fact, or would quickly condemn it once he was returned to office.
But while he endorsed the idea of foreign military action, Father Aristide, who was overthrown in a coup in September 1991, expressed strong opposition to any plan that would involve any long-term foreign occupation.
The debate over United States intervention has often centered around the question of how long the American presence would be required after Father Aristide's restoration to power.
 
Four Point Plan
 "The action could be a surgical move to remove the thugs within hours," Father Aristide said of the kind of intervention he would support. "Once we do that, we could have the international community in the country within the framework of agreements we have already signed. Not in the framework of a military intervention."
Outlining his ideas as a four-point plan that would begin with the military action, Father Aristide said international military trainers called for under an agreement negotiated last July in New York should be sent to Haiti immediately after any intervention.
Their role, he said, would be to separate the country's police from its army, and to begin retraining both forces, as foreseen under last year's aborted settlement plan. Almost immediately after that effort begins, Father Aristide said that he should be returned to Haiti, and that international development assistance should be begun on a huge scale to help push national reconciliation.
Father Aristide sought to reassure those who have said he would quickly turn against the United States if he were returned to office through an American intervention. "We are talking about interests, mutual interests," he said. "Not feelings.
"If I could do it alone, I would. If the United States could do it alone, they would. But we have to go together."
At the same time as he was urging the Clinton Administration to take decisive action to restore him to office, Father Aristide renewed criticisms of its handling of Haitian boat people.
 
Bitterness Over Refugees
 Speaking of the announcement this week that Jamaica would allow American ships to process Haitian refugees in its harbors before deciding whether they would be returned to Haiti, Father Aristide expressed bitterness that many of those fleeing his country would be "returned to a house on fire."
"In terms of their statements, yes, they are saying there is a change," he said of the Clinton Administration's handling of Haitian refugees. "In terms of the implementation, no."
The Clinton Administration announced today that it was adding 35 more Haitians, many of them members of the government, to the list of 600 Haitian military personnel and other coup leaders whose assets in the United States have been frozen.
Those added to the list today include Haiti's newly appointed President, Emile Jonassaint, as well as Finance Minister Rigaud Duplain and Foreign Minister Charles David. Also added were the wife and three children of the head of Haiti's military, Raoul Cedras, as well as the children of several other military leaders.

HEADLINE: Study Warns of Growing Underclass of the Unskilled

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Opening a wide door for changes in labor law but then hesitating to walk through it, the Labor and Commerce Departments issued a joint report today, detailing shifts in the American workplace but delaying any recommendations to deal with them for months.
The report details the development of an underclass of low-paid and unskilled workers unable to compete in a complex marketplace. The changes come against the backdrop of an increasingly adversarial climate between management and labor while America is slipping behind other industrialized nations in wages and benefits, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said at a news conference. 
 The report, by a commission that Prof. John T. Dunlop of Harvard University led, is the first important salvo in the Clinton Administration's battle to change and update labor laws. It offers the closest scrutiny of American labor practices since World War II.
But after a year of study, the report's authors stopped short of proposing a plan for change. One person who has followed the committee's work said the members had had a series of disagreements over how new laws would affect unions, businesses and leading industries.
Mr. Reich spoke of the polarization of the American workplace and the need to find solutions that suit both workers and their managers. He painted a bleak picture of an economy destined to spiral downward unless growing imbalances between those sectors are corrected.
"A society divided between the haves and the have-nots or the well-educated and the poorly educated can not be a stable society over time," he said. He said sharp inequalities between the well-educated, well-paid workers and those at the bottom of the pay scale "spells a breakdown somewhere down the line."
Those remarks and the report's conclusion that "a healthy society cannot long continue along the path the U.S. is moving," seemed to signal a move to increase Federal involvement in worker-management relations. But without a blueprint for that involvement, all sides seemed inclined to take a cautious public stance.
Responses to the findings were measured. Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association for Manufacturers, praised the focus on excessive litigation and global competitive pressures. But he cautioned that in places, the report tended to generalize and imply "a more negative labor relations environment than is justified."
 
Women in Dire Straits
 The Women's Legal Defense Fund said the report underscored the need to close the gaps "that leave so many working women in dire economic straits." In fact, the report found a declining gap in the earnings of men and women. The more troubling statistics, it said, pertain to a "stagnation in the gap between white and nonwhite workers."
An unrelated study released today by the Center for National Policy, a research group, came to the same conclusion. It showed that the median pay for women increased 9.2 percent over the last decade while many of the relatively well-paid jobs traditionally held by men had disappeared, to be replaced by low-paying jobs. As a result, pay for men overall declined by about 5 percent.
The scope of possible recommendations could not be broader. Professor Dunlop, a former Labor Secretary, said no existing law was "sacred." Instead, the next six months promise a broad, though to some extent hidden debate. Dr. Dunlop has a reputation as a tough-minded, behind-closed-doors deal maker who has little patience with public dialogue.
These were among the other problems the commission found:
*Falling real earnings for less-educated and less-skilled workers.
*Stagnant growth of earnings for more-skilled employees.
*High levels of occupational injuries.
*Lack of health insurance and other fringe benefits for many workers.
*An increased proportion of young male workers in prison.
*High rates of joblessness for the unskilled.
Most chilling of all, however, was a brief notation at the end of the second chapter which warned of "a large, growing population for whom illegal activity is more attractive than legitimate work."
Sprinkled throughout the findings are indications that workers, not their employers, may have the most to gain. An anthem of cooperation, collaboration and mutual benefit even seeped into the Commerce Department. Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, who often advocates big business positions and was a former lobbyist for some of the nation's largest corporations, took the day off and skipped the presentation.

HEADLINE: 9 Florida Hotels Blacking Out A TV Station's Crime Reports

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 2

 BODY:
Some of South Florida's larger hotels have decided to screen out the newscasts of a local television station because of its zealous coverage of crime news.
The hotel owners, already dismayed by several highly publicized killings of tourists in Florida last year, say they are angry with what they call the sensational style of the television station, WSVN (Channel 7), a Fox affiliate. 
 "It is a continuous barrage of the body bags on the street and the blood coming out of them," said one hotelier, Don Lefton, who said he would block WSVN's newscasts from the seven hotels owned or operated by Continental Companies, of which he is vice chairman. The hotels, which include the Bonaventure in the Fort Lauderdale area, the Grand Bay in Miami and the Pier House in Key West, have a total of more than 2,200 rooms.
Charles Folds, a spokesman for WSVN, said the station was simply giving aggressive coverage to an important local issue. "I'm out in the community, and the No. 1 concern of our viewers is crime," he said.
 
No Effect on Ratings
 Mr. Folds added that while the blackout might shield tourists from some crime news, it would have no effect on WSVN's programming. "We are not going to censor the news to placate them," he said.
Shutting out WSVN will also have no effect on ratings by the Nielsen service; hotels are not counted in its audience surveys. Nevertheless, some hotel owners see the blackout as a small way to aid Miami's reputation among tourists.
About a month ago, Victor Farkas, the owner of the Thunderbird and the Chateau-by-the-Sea hotels in Miami Beach, blocked all of WSVN's programming from his hotels' 340 rooms. "I didn't want to expose my guests to every gruesome detail of every murder that happens in the neighborhood," he said. "It's certainly bad for tourism, it's certainly bad for the local economy and certainly bad for the general atmosphere."
Robert S. Peck, a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union in Washington, said, "It's a disturbing trend where those who have a captive audience can prevent people from having access to the news." While Mr. Peck, who tracks censorship issues, said he had heard of hotels weeding out "steamy" movies, "I've never heard it aimed at the news."
Constitutionally, however, the Miami blackout is not a problem, he added, "because the hotels are not the government."
 
Just the News
 Mr. Lefton said, "I welcome people to report the news, but to adopt a pattern of continuous sensationalism is doing our community a disservice."
Mr. Lefton said his company's decision to begin blacking out the broadcasts came soon after correspondence with WSVN failed to bring any change in the newscasts. His plan is to block just the news, not other shows, "as quick as can be done."
The blackout by the nine hotels has not been widely embraced by tourism officials here, said Mayco Villafana, spokesman for the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau, who pointed out that the city's three other English-language news stations regularly broadcast crime reports.

HEADLINE: Coliseum: Something for Everyone (Maybe)

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
On the surface, the deal reached this week to sell half of the New York Coliseum site to the developer Mortimer B. Zuckerman has something for everyone. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, for the first time since it put the Coliseum on the market nine years ago, has cash to show for its efforts: a nonrefundable down payment of $17 million from Mr. Zuckerman.
The Giuliani administration, which had pressured the M.T.A. to complete a deal with Mr. Zuckerman, now has the prospect of a new development to show that the economy is rebounding, 3,700 potential construction jobs and $12 million to $14 million in tax revenues, assuming the project is built. 
 And Mr. Zuckerman and his development company, Boston Properties, have managed to cut the potential outlay to $80 million from $338 million without defaulting on a $33.8 million line of credit.
Beyond that, the benefits for all parties in the tangled transaction remain to be seen, and many questions still loom about how good a deal the city and the M.T.A. received, and whether Mr. Zuckerman has already made money from it.
 
Focus on 'Fair Value'
 "The major focus all along has been on getting fair value," said Peter E. Stangl, chairman of the M.T.A. board, which approved the agreement yesterday. "We got the best deal under the circumstances. The deal was finally done because Boston Properties met our terms."
But in fact, the main points of the deal were largely those that Mr. Zuckerman had been pushing for months: a substantially reduced price and a smaller project on half the original site. And some City Council members, like Ronnie Eldridge and Kenneth K. Fisher, have questioned the prudence of pushing a deal through just to get the project moving.
Although the city and the M.T.A. have commissioned appraisals of the site to justify the price, real estate experts say appraisals are not reliable indicators of a property's value at a time when the market is improving, as it is doing now.
"The more sales and development projects you have, the closer you can get to a worthwhile appraisal," said Paul N. Fox, director of valuation services at Jones Lang Wootton, an international real estate brokerage company. "A strong market greatly increase reliability. We're moving closer to that point, but we're not there yet."
Indeed, Mr. Stangl has acknowledged that the most beneficial situation might have been a fresh start that would have allowed the M.T.A. to rent the office building and exhibition hall while holding back on a sale until the real estate market improved.
That would have required that the M.T.A. and the city to force Mr. Zuckerman's hand, close on the existing $338 million contract and risk losing the lawsuit that Mr. Zuckerman filed in April contesting the validity of the contract.
As the June 1 trial date drew near, Mr. Stangl said, M.T.A. lawyers were less absolute in their conviction that the lawsuit could be won.
 
$100 Million for Half the Site
 The M.T.A. will get $100 million for half of the site it owns at 59th Street and Columbus Circle, leaving the transit agency with the office building to rent and sell when the market improves. The money, M.T.A. officials said, will go for subway improvements.
Additional concessions included the requirement that Mr. Zuckerman pay $6 million for garage repairs and the $2.5 million cost of separating the office building from the exhibition hall. Assuming the one-million-square-foot office and retail project turns a profit, the M.T.A. will get a 20-percent equity interest.
Instead of a letter of credit, which was used as security for the former contract, Mr. Zuckerman wrote a check yesterday for the $17 million nonrefundable down payment required by the M.T.A.
Yesterday, after agreeing to terms of the deal, Mr. Zuckerman's representatives talked mostly in terms of concessions.
"I'm not exactly euphoric," said Edward Linde, Mr. Zuckerman's partner in the transaction for the past nine years. "It's going to be tough." But he added, "We wouldn't be doing it if we didn't think it could be done." Mr. Linde was speaking for Boston Properties because Mr. Zuckerman was traveling overseas.
But critics of the transaction, including Ms. Eldridge, remain skeptical. They say that when the benefits package is tallied -- $11 million in tax benefits from the Industrial Development Agency as well as half-ownership in the Coliseum garage -- it increases the value of his deal with the M.T.A.
Other questions remain over whether Boston Properties has already made money on the Coliseum deal as a result of the compensation it received from Salomon Brothers -- $95 million -- when the investment banking company pulled out as equity partner in 1987.
 
No Profit, Zuckerman Says
 Mr. Zuckerman has asserted that he and his partners made no profit from the Salomon payment because of the huge costs of keeping the project afloat without the benefit of a development deal.
"We have spent in excess of $100 million," said Mr. Linde, reiterating what Mr. Zuckerman has said about the Salomon Brothers payments.
Mr. Linde said the banking company paid $54 million when it left the deal and a total of $41 million to reimburse Boston Properties for predevelopment costs the developers incurred while still partners.
"Over the history of our relationship there were times when we would write checks and times when they would make payments," he said.
Mr. Linde said the costs, which the Salomon Brothers payments helped to cover, included a series of architectural and engineering designs, legal fees and the cost of canceling orders for materials like steel and marble.
Some real estate experts agree with Boston Properties that it faces a difficult task in seeing the project through.
When asked to analyze the transaction recently, Stephen B. Siegel, president of Edward S. Gordon, a real estate brokerage company, said that Mr. Zuckerman's deal was hard to justify, using the current office market as a measuring stick.
"Because there are so few projects, there are few ways of making comparisons in development deals," said Mr. Siegel. But he noted that Mr. Zuckerman was taking a risk that the market would improve. And in fact, he said that to make a profit Mr. Zuckerman would have to charge rent higher than what is now the top of the market, about $40 to $50 a square foot.
From the perspective of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his aides, there is no down side to the deal, even though the city is putting up $20 million to complete the deal. The money comes from the projected tax revenues that the city expects to receive from the project. Mr. Giuliani said that waiting for the market to recover to at the Coliseum was not beneficial.

HEADLINE: Kudlow Takes Securities Job

 BODY:
Lawrence A. Kudlow, who resigned three months ago as chief economist and senior managing director at Bear, Stearns & Company to deal with a drug and alcohol problem, rejoined the brokerage community yesterday as a consultant to Montgomery Securities.
Mr. Kudlow, who is 46, resigned on March 3 after eight years with Bear, Stearns. There were rumors at the time of his resignation that he was forced out because his substance abuse problem had caused him to miss an important meeting with clients. 
 Mr. Kudlow later acknowledged in an interview that he had a problem with drugs and alcohol and had been in a rehabilitation program for 15 months. But he said he had missed the meeting because he was sick, not because he had suffered a relapse.
Scarcely a month after leaving Bear, Stearns, Mr. Kudlow was named economics editor of National Review magazine. He is also a television commentator with CNBC.
In his new job, Mr. Kudlow will hold a "regular series of meetings" with Montgomery's clients, said Kent Logan, director of institutional sales at the firm. Mr. Logan said he expected that Mr. Kudlow would spend "a few days a quarter" working for Montgomery.
Montgomery, an investment bank and brokerage house based in San Francisco that specializes in four industry sectors, had never before employed an economist or investment portfolio strategist.
When asked about Mr. Kudlow's substance-abuse problem, Mr. Logan said, "To the best of our knowledge he is cured."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Japanese Stocks Show Life As Economy Gains Strength

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 2

 BODY:
Japan's stock market appears poised to break out of its long slump and surge to its highest level in more than two years, according to a growing number of analysts and investors.
The Nikkei index of 225 issues is now at its highest level since September and has risen 20.6 percent this year. The index closed today at 21,009, down a mere 44.11 points, after four days of gains. 
 Twice last year, in the spring and in September, the Nikkei index moved close to the 21,500 mark it approached in March 1992. But in both cases, the market fell back as the glimmer of an economic recovery proved to be a mere mirage.
But now there is an evolving consensus that the recovery is for real this time and that Japan's long, bleak recession is finally coming to an end. That view was buttressed this week by the release of several economic indicators that pointed, at least tepidly, in a positive direction.
"Fears of deja vu are misplaced," said Kathy Matsui, chief strategist in Japan for Goldman, Sachs & Company, who thinks the Nikkei average will gradually climb as high as 24,000. "You've got a very different economy now."
And even if the market undergoes a short-term correction now, analysts contend it will eventually rise as high as 25,000, signaling an end to the bear market that has persisted since prices started falling in 1990. But while that would be a jump of 43.5 percent for the year, the market will still be far below the Nikkei's high of 38,915.87 at the end of 1989.
Last year, any hope of economic recovery was dashed by the sharp rise of the Japanese yen, which severely hurt Japan's export-oriented automobile and electronics companies. But now the United States, which let the yen strengthen against the dollar to put pressure on Japan in trade talks, is worried about the impact of a weakening dollar on American financial markets. It is unlikely, then, that the yen will rise as sharply this year as it did last year, if it rises at all.
The strong United States economy is also helping Japan, pulling in Japanese exports despite the fact that the strong yen has made Japanese products less competitive.
To be sure, no one expects a robust recovery in Japan. Most predictions are that economic growth this year will be below 1 percent. And some of the economic indicators that have buoyed the market this week look positive only because they are less negative than what have come before.
Corporate profits for the fiscal year that ended in March, for example, were down about 18 percent, but that was less than expected, said Jeff Bahrenburg, Japanese equity strategist for Merrill Lynch in Tokyo.
And companies and research groups are forecasting that profits will rise this year after four consecutive years of decline -- not because sales will increase but only because corporate cost-cutting and restructuring will begin to take effect.
Housing starts, however, were strong in April and the unemployment rate fell to 2.8 percent from 2.9 percent in March. There are some signs that consumer spending is picking up and hopes that an income-tax cut this year will help encourage more spending.
Weak as these portents might be, stock markets tend to move in advance of economic recovery. And a momentum can build as investors fear being left behind as the train departs the station. "Little hints are enough to bring all the cash that's bottled up on the sidelines into the market," Mr. Bahrenburg said.
The key to sustaining the rally, then, will be whether Japanese investors truly jump into the market.
So far, the market has been driven upward by foreign investors, who view the Japanese market as one where bargains can still be found.
But Japanese institutional investors, wary of being burned again by a false recovery, have been more cautious. This week, many of them finally began buying, helping fuel the rally. But in the last two days, selling has balanced buying so that the Nikkei has moved only moderately, despite the fact that trading volumes have been unusually heavy.
In general, Japanese executives and Government officials are cautious about saying the economic recovery is at hand. Less than 1 percent of executives at large companies surveyed recently by Keidanren, a Japanese business organization, said that the economy had already hit bottom and that prospects were bright.
Any setback in economic statistics, then, could derail the market rally. And there are other threats ahead: The Government is unstable, and the yen is still hurting companies.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Post Increases For 2d Day

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices climbed yesterday for a second day and yields fell to a two-week low amid signs that the economy's expansion is slowing, reducing the pressure for higher interest rates.
The Treasury's 30-year bond gained 15/32 , while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 7.35 percent, from 7.39 percent on Wednesday. 
 Bond prices rose after the Commerce Department said factory orders in April fell one-tenth of 1 percent. Also yesterday, the Labor Department reported that the latest four-week average of state unemployment claims rose to its highest level since mid-February.
"The economic indicators that have come out lately look weak," said David Rossmiller, head of $2.5 billion in fixed-income investments at BT Global Investment Management.
The economy "isn't moving as fast as it was" in the last six months, said Sterling Russell, president of Olympus Capital Management, a money management firm in Las Vegas, Nev.
"There's a pretty good chance we'll see a rally in the next two to three months that will push bond yields under 7 percent, or to at least 7 percent," Mr. Russell said. That's because investors may become convinced that inflation, which erodes the value of bonds and other fixed-income securities, is not increasing.
The yield on two-year notes was 5.90 percent, down from 5.97 percent on Wednesday. The note yielded 144 basis points less than the 30-year bond, up two basis points from yesterday. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
'Have to Be Cautious'
 Bonds didn't rally more because traders and investors were leery of making big bets before the release today of the May jobs report, a closely watched economic indicator. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News forecast an increase of 289,000 jobs in the month, compared with a rise of 267,000 jobs in April.
"You have to be cautious" about buying Treasuries just hours before the report, said Robert G. Smith 3d, executive vice president at the Smith Affiliated Capital Corporation, a New York-based firm with $1.25 billion in fixed-income investments.
Smith Affiliated has 10 percent to 20 percent of its funds invested in cash. "We've rarely run with a cash position above 5 percent," Mr. Smith said. "We're ready to go with more investments" once economic indicators signal slower growth.
That may be starting to happen. The nation's retailers yesterday reported slower sales in May than in April, according to the Bloomberg Composite Same-Store Sales Index. The index rose 2.65 percent last month, compared with a 4.51 percent rise a month earlier. As a result, yields could make a run at 7 percent, Mr. Smith said.
Treasury bonds are also benefiting from the recent rout in bond markets across Europe, tied to speculation that the Bundesbank and other European central banks will not lower interest rates again soon to spur economic growth. Some investors are swapping European bonds for United States debt securities.
Italian bond yields, for example, rose to their highest level since August. The benchmark 10-year Italian Government bond yield rose as much as five basis points to 9 percent. French bond prices also fell, pushing the yield on the benchmark 10-year French bond to 7.52 percent from 7.48 percent yesterday.
The three-year note rose 6/32 to 10022/32 , a yield of 6.24 percent.
Among intermediate notes, the five-year note rose 1/4, to 10011/32 , a yield of 6.67 percent. The 10-year note rose 13/32 , to 10110/32 , a yield of 7.06 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Broad Advance As Bond Pricesa Rise in U.S.

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday as Treasury bonds gained for a second day.
"People think there's money coming back home from abroad," said James McGroarty, managing director at Athena Global Investments, a Greenwich, Conn., money manager with $400 million of assets. "That sentiment helped the dollar gain." 
 The dollar was also bolstered by optimism about today's Government report on May employment and concerns about rising tensions between the United States and North Korea, traders said.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6537 German marks, up from 1.6469 marks on Wednesday. It rose to 104.85 Japanese yen from 104.50 yen.
Bonds rose, pulling the dollar higher, after Government reports suggested that the American economy was not growing fast enough to fuel inflation, the bond market's nemesis.
Most European bond markets tumbled, meantime, amid persistent speculation that the German central bank will no longer be cutting interest rates to stimulate economic growth. The rise in American bonds and the slump in European bonds convinced many traders that investors are returning to the United States.
"The whole argument for a weaker dollar has been based on the notion that capital is moving out of the U.S.," Mr. McGroarty said. "That looks like it might be changing now." The dollar had fallen as much as 10 percent against the yen and 6 percent against the mark this year as American stocks and bonds declined.
Worsening relations between the United States and North Korea also helped the dollar gain, traders said. President Clinton sent his sternest message yet to the North Koreans, saying the United Nations must discuss imposing sanctions on North Korea for breaking the nuclear nonproliferation treaty.
The dollar often gains in times of global turmoil as investors seek a haven for their investments. The yen often suffers most when tensions in Korea escalate because Japan is close to the Korean peninsula.
"North Korea is something you have to keep your eye on all the time," said Jim Raphael, a trader at NatWest USA Bancorp in Jersey City. "The dollar could pop a lot higher against the yen if we wake up to a crisis there one morning."
Other traders said they were skeptical that the dollar's gains would last. The key for many is how the dollar reacts to today's monthly jobs report, considered one of the broadest assessments of economic strength.
"I wouldn't read too much into the dollar's gains," said Steve Geovanis, managing director of foreign exchange at Merrill Lynch. "We have to wait and see if people are impressed by the employment report."

HEADLINE: Trump Pays Bridgeport a Visit To Promote Theme Park Plan

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 2

 BODY:
The developer Donald Trump came to this economically depressed city today to promote his proposal to build a $350 million amusement park and seaport village here.
As outlined by Mr. Trump and his associates, the project would include a seasonal theme park featuring rides and amusements; a year-round seaport village with specialty shops, restaurants and entertainment and a waterfront terminal for cruise ships, high-speed ferries and trade show ships. 
 Mr. Trump told business and political leaders that Trump Park would create about 3,000 full- and part-time jobs and generate millions in tax revenues.
"The magnificence of the park will make Bridgeport a world-class destination," Mr. Trump said.
The project is far from a certainty. Before construction can begin, Mr. Trump must win several approvals, including environmental permits and approval from the Bridgeport Port Authority.
He hopes to build the project on 100 acres of land located along the eastern portion of Bridgeport Harbor. The land includes Pleasure Beach, the site of a former amusement park that once attracted thousands of visitors from throughout the Northeast, and an old industrial site once occupied by Carpenter Steel Corporation.
The city currently owns Pleasure Beach, which makes up about 40 percent of the 100 acres. The remaining 60 percent is privately owned. Under the Trump proposal, the city would acquire the private land through eminent domain and then convey it to Mr. Trump. The Trump organization and the city's Parks Board would enter into a long-term lease for the Pleasure Beach area.
Mr. Trump said that Bridgeport, an impoverished city plagued by crime, was chosen as the site for the theme park because of its location and because an extensive amount of waterfront property is available for development.
"If this site were properly developed, I believe it could be absolutely spectacular," Mr. Trump said.
Mr. Trump, the developer of the Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City, spent months last year trying to build support for a casino in Bridgeport. Connecticut does not allow casino gambling, with the exception of the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe's Foxwoods casino in Ledyard.
He said today that his theme park proposal does not hinge on an expansion of gambling in Connecticut.
"This has nothing to do with the casinos," he said. "This is a separate plan. If casinos should happen in Connecticut, we'd be involved, but not here."
Mr. Trump said he plans to provide all of the financing for the project, using no public money.
The project has enjoyed widespread support from Bridgeport business leaders since it was proposed two months ago.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
For Democrats, Too Smooth a Polish?

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, June 2

 BODY:
A week after a Republican state convention that was filled with accusations of backroom arm-twisting, skulduggery and last-minute deals, the Democratic convention that ended today was a tightly scripted, downright civil affair virtually devoid of drama.
Yet for all their messy maneuvering, the Republicans emerged from their convention energized by the sense that, amid strife, they had chosen the best ticket possible: one that would appeal to moderates and conservatives, women and people angry with incumbents. 
 Among the Democrats, conversely, there were concerns today that despite their smoothly polished process, they had perhaps done too much to protect incumbents and had missed opportunities to infuse their campaign with fresh faces and ideas.
"The Republican convention looked like something out of a movie about Huey Long," said an aide to one Democratic state official. "But on the flip side, when you talk to local Democratic leaders they're worried that, after 12 years, they can't defend Mario Cuomo and this ticket in the hinterland."
Most notably, the two-day convention ended with no guarantee that the Democrats would have a woman on their statewide ticket, although Karen Burstein, a candidate for attorney general, says she will circulate nominating petitions to get on the Democratic primary ballot.
"That's a concern," said Representative Thomas J. Manton. "There has been a tendency among women, perhaps because of past grievances, to vote for women."
Indeed, the Democrats seemed intent on compensating for their lack of female candidates by featuring women on the podium. The keynote address was by former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, three women nominated Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell, and Representative Nita M. Lowey was the honorary convention chairwoman on the second day.
The Democrats also studiously avoided controversy and name-calling. When District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn fell short of gaining a ballot spot for attorney general by a mere handful of votes, some suggested that last-minute pressure had caused some of his supporters to defect. But not Mr. Hynes. "I've been a prosecutor too long to believe in conspiracy theories," he said.
To some, an odd role reversal seemed at work: Democrats are supposed to air their fights in public while Republicans are expected to run rigidly choreographed conventions -- a political fact of life that Mr. Cuomo took note of today.
When heckled by a man just as he began his acceptance speech, Mr. Cuomo said: "This is a Democratic convention. If you don't have one or two incidents like this, they begin to think you're Republican."
 
Dealing With the Media
 A repeated refrain today was that if voters only knew more of Mr. Cuomo's accomplishments, they would certainly re-elect him. That was also the message of a workshop for Democrats led by the Governor's chief strategist, David Garth.
As is his fashion, Mr. Garth, who engineered Rudolph W. Giuliani's victory in last year's New York City mayoral election, used the forum to do two things: criticize the media while trying to implant campaign messages with the very reporters he was attacking.
He told the Democrats that reporters "sometimes qualify to be human" and dislike having "to unscrew their rear ends from a chair." He complained of a tendency in the media to get "lost in the immediacy of events" while ignoring substantive issues. And intermittently he ticked off some of what he considered Mr. Cuomo's legacy: better rest stops on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, economic development zones in blighted cities, billions of dollars in infrastructure improvements. "The basic problem is we don't know what he has done," Mr. Garth said.
In his stream-of-consciousness manner, Mr. Garth offered other pointers: do lots of commercials, use cable television as much as possible, never reveal strategy to reporters and don't be afraid to confront your candidate's weaknesses head on.
And he warned against lying to reporters. "I don't believe it's smart to lie, not because of any heavy moral principles, God knows, but because they can catch you," he said. "If I had a guarantee I'd never see that reporter again, FINE!"
 
A Shortened Anecdote
 Governor Cuomo is known for breaking the ice with a funny anecdote, but on Monday night he almost got himself into hot water with one of his favorite stories.
In an appearance with the Rev. Al Sharpton before black ministers at a Baptist church here, Mr. Cuomo opened his speech with a well-worn tale about the first time he was introduced to President Ronald Reagan. As Mr. Cuomo tells it, the friend was about to make the introduction when Mr. Reagan cocked his head, smiled and said: "You don't have to introduce us. I know Lee Iacocca well."
As usual, the story got a hearty laugh. But Mr. Cuomo had deftly left out one potentially embarrassing detail: the "friend" who attempting the introduction was Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the three-term incumbent whom Mr. Sharpton hopes to challenge in the Democratic primary.
 
A Time for Nostalgia
 As any dealer in mementos knows, nostalgia can sell well, but sometimes what's best is what's new. At the Mario Cuomo memorabilia table at the convention, there was a little of both this week.
Among the more popular items at the table run by the Democratic State Committee was a $15 recording of Mr. Cuomo's address at the 1984 Democratic National Convention, a speech that overnight launched him as a Presidential contender.
Barbara Wayne, a Democratic volunteer, said workers found the recordings, marked "collector's item," in two dusty boxes in the basement of party headquarters in Albany.
An even hotter item was one that had nothing to do with the Governor: a $10 button in the shape of the President's oval office, emblazoned with the words, "Clinton '92."
"I only had 25 and they sold out in half an hour," Ms. Wayne said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Josephine Moy Hong, 93, Dies; Volunteer and a G.O.P. Leader

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Josephine Moy Hong, active in Chinese-American affairs and Republican Party politics, died on Sunday in Flushing Hospital. She was 93 and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens.
She suffered a brief illness, her family said. 
 Mrs. Hong was born in Boston but spent much of her childhood in southern China, where her father moved when she was 8 years old to help develop the mining industry.
She returned to the United States in 1917 and studied economics and psychology at the University of Chicago and New York University. In 1923 she married Louis Fong Sui Hong, who was instrumental in expanding operations in Asia for the National City Bank of New York. The family went to live at Shanghai's International Settlement, an enclave of foreigners guarded by Western forces, when the Japan invaded China in 1937. Mrs. Hong tended to the wounded and sick while under bombardments.
Back in the United States in 1939, she organized a group of Chinese volunteers to raise funds for war refugees in New York. After Pearl Harbor, she served as a director of the National Board of the American Women's Voluntary Service and as chairman of its Chinese unit in New York.
In the decades since, she held leading positions in the Chinese Women's Benevolent Association, the Institute of Chinese Culture, the Chinese Cultural Renaissance Society and the Asian American Assembly, among others.
She turned to Republican Party politics in the 1960's and was vice president of the New York State Republican Heritage Groups Council.
She was inducted as a Life Member of the Republican Party in 1979. In 1982, President Ronald Reagan named her to his Peace Corps Advisory Council.
Mrs. Hong is survived by three sons; Alfred of Jamaica Estates, Robert of Syosset, L.I., and Morris of Fresh Meadows, Queens; a daughter, Virginia Wei of Princeton, N.J.; a brother, Herbert Moy of Chicago; a sister, Mae Wu of Berkeley, Calif.; 10 grandchildren, and 11 great-grandchildren.
