HEADLINE: Iraq Played 'Catch Me if You Can.' North Korea Says, 'What if You Do?'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT used to be that the world's great powers worried that some renegade country -- Saddam Hussein's Iraq, for instance -- might sneak a nuclear bomb past the prying eyes of international monitors and spy satellites.
Then came North Korea, which has presented a whole new threat to the guardians of nuclear nonproliferation. North Korea is not simply trying to cheat. It is ripping up the rule book and challenging the world to do something about it. 
 It is the first nuclear crisis of the post-cold war world: At a time when the old rules of international order have been cast aside and entire nations have been ripped apart by ethnic strife, North Korea has stalled, thwarted or otherwise defied international nuclear inspectors and ignored warnings, coaxing and threats from Washington.
Last week an ominous new threshold was crossed when the United Nations' nuclear watchdog agency formally concluded that it could no longer determine whether spent fuel removed by North Korea after its nuclear reactor at Yongbyon was shut down in 1989 had been diverted to a secret weapons program. If unchallenged, North Korea's recalcitrance could destroy the credibility of the 1970 Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, the world's principal tool for preventing the spread of nuclear weapons.
"It is the first time that a country first signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, worked to develop nuclear weapons while a member and then openly defied the demands of international inspectors," said Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, a Washington-based research institute.
 
Attention, Libyans
 Clinton Administration officials acknowledge as much, and say that is one reason President Clinton announced last week that the United States would try to mobilize support for global economic sanctions. The aim is not just to persuade North Korea to abandon its bomb program, which Washington fears could trigger an arms race in Asia. It is also to send signals to Libya, Iraq, Iran and other potential nuclear powers that they cannot ignore the controls that the treaty imposes on them.
"We have made no secret of our concerns about the nuclear intention of such countries as Libya, Iraq, Iran," said Robert Gallucci, the Clinton Administration's point man on the North Korea question. "All three of these countries are nonproliferation treaty members."
The stakes are so high, the officials say, that the pressure of sanctions is necessary even though the North Koreans say their imposition would be an act of war. But it remains unclear whether China will support sanctions in the United Nations Security Council, which sanctions might be approved and what the North Koreans would have to do to get them lifted.
The nonproliferation treaty, which comes up for renewal in 1995, codified this basic bargain: Major nuclear powers -- the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain, which joined the treaty in 1970 -- would keep their nuclear arsenals. France and China agreed to join the treaty in 1991. Non-nuclear nations joining the agreement would receive assistance in developing nuclear energy for peaceful uses. In return, they would promise not to develop nuclear weapons. The arrangement would be monitored by inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency.
From the start, the treaty had its limitations. One major problem was that some emerging nuclear powers simply refused to be part of the deal.
India and Pakistan, at odds over Kashmir and deeply distrustful of each other's intentions, never signed the accord and are assumed to have small nuclear arsenals. During the summer of 1990, American intelligence agencies became concerned that south Asia might become a nuclear flashpoint and issued a classified warning that there was a "50-50" chance of a new Indian-Pakistan war.
Concerned that the two nations will soon escalate their arms race by fielding new surface-to-surface missiles, the Clinton Administration has launched a diplomatic effort to cap their nuclear weapons programs. But Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State, was rebuffed when he sought to press the Administration's initiative during a recent trip to the area.
Israel, which has a small nuclear arsenal, also has not signed the treaty. That has been a worry, not because the United States believes Israel may launch a nuclear strike, but because it fears that Arab nations will cite Israel's stance to justify their own bomb programs.
A second major problem was making sure nobody cheated.
Iraq's ability to elude the agency's inspectors, in particular, was a black stain on the accord. Iraq signed the treaty and allowed inspectors to visit its reactors. Then it mounted a secret program to make highly enriched uranium for nuclear weapons, using an antiquated technology pioneered decades ago by the United States.
The full extent of Iraq's nuclear efforts became clear only after the Persian Gulf war, when defectors made their way out of Iraq. While some of Iraq's nuclear installations were bombed and United Nations inspectors dismantled others after the conflict, Iraq still has the scientists it needs to rebuild its nuclear-bomb program and could do so if sanctions were lifted and the United Nations inspections ceased.
Since the gulf war, the atomic energy agency has become more vigilant -- and with good reason. Iran has signed the nonproliferation treaty, but American officials believe that it is determined to develop nuclear weapons.
They say Iran is probably a decade or more away from building a bomb, but it could make faster strides if it managed to acquire nuclear material and scientists from the former Soviet Union and North Korea. Iran has important ties with North Korea, selling it oil in return for missiles and other weapons.
Libya, which has also signed the nonproliferation treaty, is farther behind. But it, too, has the money to buy bomb ingredients or scientific expertise.
International inspectors have also been keeping a watchful eye on Algeria, which purchased a small reactor from China and has also joined the nonproliferation treaty.
 
Foot-Dragging
 This is not to say that there have not been some successes. South Africa is the most notable case. Rather than hand over its nuclear weapons to a new black-majority government, the departing government of President F. W. de Klerk joined the nonproliferation treaty and dismantled its nuclear arsenal.
But that success has been overshadowed by the growing crisis in East Asia, where the atomic energy agency's new vigilance and the North Koreans' determination to have the bomb are producing a dangerous political standoff.
Like Iraq, North Korea seems to have calculated that the nonproliferation treaty would be a way to keep the West happy while it sought to develop nuclear arms.
North Korea joined the agreement in 1985 but dragged its feet on completing the technical agreement that covers inspections of its sites.
Meanwhile, its nuclear program continued apace. In 1989, it shut down its five-megawatt reactor at Yongbyon for three months. During that period, the Central Intelligence Agency believes, it removed enough plutonium for one or two nuclear bombs.
More recently, it has been working intensively on a second, larger reactor and expanding its plutonium-reprocessing capability. Pyongyang's decision last month to begin removing fuel from the Yongbyon reactor will give it enough plutonium to build four or five bombs once the fuel is reprocessed.
All of which has raised the stakes for the Clinton Administration, already under fire for a vacillating foreign policy. "I just don't think we can walk away from this," Mr. Clinton said in Rome last week.

GRAPHIC: Photos: In 1991, a U.N. inspection team in Iraq worked near the debris of equipment that enriched uranium for bomb fuel, above. Then, the issue was proving that a nation had broken international rules. Now, the question is what to do when a nation tears up the rule book. At top, the first atomic bomb explosion in 1945. (United Nations Photo)

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Pick a Number, Any Number . . .

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
THE economy is growing a lot faster than expected. Or maybe it is growing much more slowly than thought.
Or maybe the numbers are just messed up. 
 There is something for everyone in the economic statistics from Washington. And never was that clearer, or perhaps we mean less clear, than it was Friday.
First, the good news. The unemployment rate dropped from 6.4 percent in April to 6 percent in May, far below any forecast. The report, President Clinton was quick to say, "clearly supports the wisdom of the economic strategy we have been following."
Unfortunately, there was more. The Government also said that just 191,000 new jobs were created last month, a lot fewer than anyone had expected. If that's right, the economy is weaker than thought.
How can such clearly incompatible figures coexist? The answer is that they are based on different surveys, each with its own inaccuracies. The unemployment figure comes from a household survey, which asks people whether they worked in the previous week and whether they were looking for work. The number of jobs comes from a survey of employers. Add in seasonal adjustments that probably are flawed, and the numbers could mean anything.
If nothing else, the numbers produced wild times for bond traders. If the economy is as strong as the 6 percent figure indicates, then inflation fears are likely to be rekindled and the Federal Reserve is likely to try to push up interest rates even more than it already has. So when the 6 percent headline flashed on news tickers, everybody wanted to sell bonds. Prices plunged, and the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds rose from around 7.3 percent to over 7.4 percent.
But within a few minutes, sentiment began to turn as the report on job totals came in. Bond prices rose, and by the end of the day the yield, which falls as prices rise, was back down to 7.26 percent.
All of which proved only that those who rely on quick readings of complicated and flawed economic reports can lose a lot of money very quickly.
And where is the economy really going?
Wait a bit. The Government will have more numbers this week, including figures on inflation and on how much money Americans are borrowing.
Maybe the new set of numbers will make some sense. But don't bet on it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
On the Internet, Dissidents' Shots Heard 'Round the World

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
POLITICAL dissidents of all nationalities are discovering a homeland in the worldwide web of computer networks known as cyberspace.
Five years ago today, Chinese dissidents used facsimile machines to call world attention to the Government's violent crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. Today, many human rights activists are exploring an even more powerful medium, the computer web called the Internet, as a way of defying censorship. 
 Human-rights organizations have been embracing electronic mail as a means of communicating with their members around the world. And just last week, Human Rights Watch, Amnesty International, the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights and the writers group PEN were among the groups that met in New York to explore the possibility of establishing a human rights communications system over the Internet.
"As more and more people have access to the Internet, it will be practically impossible for governments to ban something," said Siobhan Dowd, who is the program director of the Freedom to Write committee of PEN.
There are places on earth that the Internet cannot reach, and in countries where the flow of information is no problem, copyright laws sometimes are. But already, the writings of dissidents and political prisoners are circulating on the Internet, which connects more than 20 million people worldwide.
An unusual library opened its electronic doors two weeks ago with a catalogue that so far consists entirely of excerpts from two books banned in the authors' home countries. "I was 16 when the Cultural Revolution broke out in 1966," one of them begins.
These words from the autobiographical manuscript "Searching for the Truth," by the Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng, along with excerpts from the book "This Earth of Mankind," by the Indonesian novelist and dissident Pramoedya Ananta Toer, are the first in what could become a global repository of banned and censored writing, distributed freely over the Internet. Some of the work of Esmail Fassih, an Iranian diarist, is to go on line this week.
None of the authors have access to the Internet, as far as anyone in cyberspace can tell. There are no Internet host computers in Beijing, where Mr. Wei, having been imprisoned for years and finally released, was recently placed under house arrest after speaking to Western journalists about human rights in China. Nor is Mr. Toer on line in Indonesia, where he has been barred from leaving the country and his activities are said to be closely monitored. But the new electronic library, which is called the Digital Freedom Net, demonstrates the Internet's power in opening pathways around government censors.
The Digital Freedom Net was established by Howard Jonas, whose company, International Discount Telecommunications of Hackensack, N.J., provides long-distance telephone and Internet service to businesses. The excerpts on the network are accessible to anyone in the world with a personal computer, a modem, a telephone line and a way to tap into the Internet.
Compared with the uncoordinated, small-scale use of facsimile machines by dissidents in China and the former Soviet Union, the rapidly growing Internet holds the promise of great speed and scope.
Messages travel from one Internet site to another, even around the world, in seconds. It is as easy to post messages to thousands, or even hundreds of thousands, of users as it is to send a single fax. Once retrieved, it can be passed on to other computer networks or by more conventional means. And because information travels in "packets" of data that are typically scattered and reassembled at the receiving site, it is much harder to intercept or trace messages.
"The notion of using the Internet to transcend international boundaries that have been used to suppress information is a very visionary one," said Gara LaMarche, associate director of the Human Rights Watch, an international human rights monitoring organization based in New York.
But Ms. Dowd of PEN, and others, have practical concerns about the Digital Freedom Net, including the mechanism for deciding which works would be included, and the fact that most censored publications require translation. Not the least of Ms. Dowd's concerns is rights and royalties. "Putting things up on the Internet without getting copyright permission wouldn't be right," she said. "We are a writers group, after all."
Ms. Dowd cited as an example Salman Rushdie's novel "Satanic Verses," which was banned in several Islamic countries but published commercially elsewhere. "Putting it up freely on the Internet could take away the market," she said.
Before posting the excerpts from "The Earth of Mankind," the Digital Freedom Net received permission from Mr. Toer's publisher, William Morrow in New York. But Mr. Wei's manuscript, which was has never been formally published, was made available to the Hackensack computer by the Index on Censorship, a London-based group that had printed the excerpts in the organization's magazine -- without the writer's authorization but on the assumption that he had permitted the manuscript to be smuggled out of China in order to share it with the world.
Still, skeptics wonder about the practical reach of Internet communication, since the computers capable of tapping into it are concentrated in North America and Europe.
"If something is banned in Bangladesh, putting it on the Internet wouldn't help because most people in Bangladesh don't have computers," Ms. Dowd said.
But Mr. Jonas, the network's founder, said: "It's the business leaders and intellectual groups in universities, where opinion is made, where people in those countries have access to the Internet. The information will get through, unless a government is willing to close down every school and every business that has an Internet account."
John S. Quarterman, an Internet consultant and author in Austin, Tex., said approximately 60 countries and territories have Internet connections capable of tapping directly into the Digital Freedom Net, which is known as a "gopher" site. Gopher is a navigational tool for streamlining the search for information on the Internet.
But dozens of other countries without such sophisticated Internet capabilities can gain indirect access to the information, which can be relayed by the less complicated system of electronic mail. Mr. Quarterman says more than 40 million computer users worldwide can exchange E-mail. Using his computer keyboard to explore the Internet's backwaters, Mr. Quarterman found only one site in Africa between Cairo and Cape Town, and no sites in Iran. In all of China he has found only one, a commercial venture in Shanghai.
"Networking is subversive, and that's why the Chinese don't want it," Mr. Quarterman said.
But he added that there might be some electronic exchange across the Chinese border -- "given the changing political tide and economic conditions, especially Hong Kong." He also noted that Internet traffic into and out of Vietnam has surged since the United States lifted its trade embargo.
The Digital Freedom Net goes beyond basic electronic mail by storing files that can be read, copied and printed. (The Internet address is "gopher.iia.org" for those with the gopher tool.)
There is no charge beyond the user's own Internet fees, and Mr. Jonas said all material posted to the library would be selected by reputable human rights groups.
Mr. Jonas, who is 37 years old, said his company was donating the computer space and phone lines, and that many of his employees were volunteering their time, often well into the night, to maintain the library. "We wanted to use technology to do something great," he said, "like eliminate censorship."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: 'Last Rain Forest:' Timber vs. a Culture -- A special report.;
In Isolation, Papua New Guinea Falls Prey to Foreign Bulldozers

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea

 BODY:
Hidden in the lush vastness of the rain forests of Papua New Guinea, there is a land that time forgot. It is a place so untouched by the outside world that many of the forest-dwellers here still wear bird feathers and grass skirts, use shells and pigs' teeth for money and remember not-so-distant relatives who celebrated victories over their tribal enemies by eating them.
Papua New Guinea has been described by conservationists as the last rain forest, and it is not much of an exaggeration. This remote Pacific country is carpeted by some of the last extensive stretches of pristine tropical forest anywhere. 
 But even the "last rain forest" is now in danger. The forests of Papua New Guinea -- and a way of life they have sheltered since the Stone Age -- are threatened by a stampede of foreign loggers desperate for new sources of tropical timber. Environmentalists say the timber with commercial value here could be felled within a generation, possibly within a decade.
 "They use the bulldozer to make a road to bring the trees down to the sea, and they come right through our land," said Vincent Mutumutu, pointing to the new logging road that stretches down the mountain behind his village, a huge brown scar slicing through the dense 100-foot-high canopy of walnut and Borneo mahogany trees. "The loggers do not think about the life of the people here."
Mr. Mutumutu does not know exactly how old he is. All he knows is that he was born before "the big fight," otherwise known as World War II, the only event that linked the people of these majestic forests to the modern world.
But if Mr. Mutumutu and his neighbors lost track of the 20th century, it is fast catching up to them. Late last year, a bulldozer owned by a foreign logging company came crashing into Mr. Mutumutu's tiny farm of banana trees and watermelon vines, destroying the only source of income for his family of 16.
"I do not know what I will do now," said Mr. Mutumutu, adjusting and readjusting his lap-lap, the ragged piece of cloth tied around his waist, the only item of clothing that he has ever worn or, for that matter, ever needed.
 
The Land
Viewing Trees In Different Ways
 Eighty percent of Papua New Guinea is covered by trees -- 145,000 square miles of tropical forest, nearly equal to the size of California, spread across an archipelago of 600 islands at the point near the equator where Southeast Asia spills into the South Pacific. The western half of main island is occupied by Irian Jaya, a province of Indonesia.
With only four million people, Papua New Guinea is among the most sparsely populated countries, and many of the tribes have been isolated from their neighbors for centuries.
This is a paradise for linguists, since there are more than 700 distinct languages, a fifth of the languages known on earth. Pidgin English is the national language, and the expression "happy noon" is a national greeting.
The loggers see a paradise of a different sort. The forests are thick with hardwood trees, including walnut, mahogany and pine, and the logging companies describe a resource worth billions of dollars in a world market starved for tropical timber.
 
Malaysian Logging Companies
 The largest foreign logging companies operating here come from Malaysia, which has already sacrificed much of its own rain forest to rapacious logging.
Evidence of the loggers' work is increasingly easy to find. Some logged areas here resemble moonscapes, with so much of the vegetation and topsoil stripped away that the forests may never grow back. Conservation groups warn that the loss of such massive tropical forests could affect climatic patterns elsewhere in the Pacific.
Rare species of plants and animals have been put in danger; the variety of wildlife is among the most diverse on earth, including the world's largest butterfly and 38 of the 43 species of birds of paradise. Also endangered are some of the world's most ancient tribal cultures.
"This is a battle that pits people wearing loinclothes and bird feathers against fast-talking, fast-moving foreign loggers," said Tim Neville, the Forests Minister and the nemesis of the Malaysian loggers.
Max Henderson, an Australian-born environmentalist who has lived in Papua New Guinea for 30 years, says the loggers are engaged in a "magnificent con."
"The loggers turn up on a beach with a handful of money," he said, "and tell these gullible landowners, 'I'm here to help you if you let me just take down a few of these old trees.' And they leave the landowners with nothing."
 
Tribes Paid Fraction of Value
 Figures compiled by the Forests Ministry seem to support the charge. Government figures show that nearly $500 million worth of logs was shipped out last year. The payment to the tribes that actually own the forests was less than $15 million.
Loggers insist that no one is being cheated. They say their industry is creating wealth for a backward people whose wretched living conditions have always been ignored by their own Government.
"Our industry has a lot of contributions to make," said Francis Tiong, general manager of the largest of the Malaysian logging firms, Rimbunan Hijau, which translates from the Malay as Beautiful Forest.
"In remote rural areas of the country, we build roads, community halls, churches, schools, government offices," Mr. Tiong said.
But as they rake in huge profits, the loggers are creating for themselves a reputation for corruption and violence. The industry's critics say they have been the targets of death threats, or worse. Mr. Neville, the Forests Minister, says that since he announced a crackdown on foreign logging, he has twice been confronted by gun-wielding attackers. "My bloody neck has been on the line," he said.
 
The Logging Industry
The Social Battles Seem Very Uneven
 Only a few years ago, most foreign loggers did not want to do business in Papua New Guinea. It was not worth the trouble.
The terrain -- wide, raging rivers, jagged mountains, plunging valleys -- is treacherous, which helps explain why this former British and German colony was one of the last places in the Pacific to be conquered by European explorers.
The Germans were forced out during World War I, with the League of Nations handing control over to Australia, which also took over the British mandate. Papua New Guinea was granted full independence in 1975.
The terrain makes logging difficult, often impossible. Worse for the loggers, the laws in Papua New Guinea give ownership of the forests to the people who live in them, not to the Government, a situation that requires separate timber contracts for even the smallest tracts of forest.
But the loggers' attention turned back to Papua New Guinea in the 1980's, as Malaysia and other heavily forested countries in Southeast Asia and the Pacific barred the export of raw logs, hoping to preserve what was left of their ravaged woodlands. The result has been a rush of loggers into Papua New Guinea, one of the few countries that still permits the export of raw logs. (Papua New Guinea does not have the large sawmills needed to process the logs itself.)
 
Timber Prices Spur Cutting
 The pace of logging here has exploded along with prices on world markets. The price for the wood from a single tree of tropical hardwood has jumped from about $225 in the mid-1980's to nearly $600 today.
The amount of wood exported from Papua New Guinea has quadrupled since 1980, when 642,000 cubic meters of logs left the country. In 1992, 2 million cubic meters of logs was exported. The exports grew last year by more than a third, to 2.7 million cubic meters, equal to about 3 million trees, with most of the logs bound for wood-processing plants in Japan.
If the environmental stakes were not so high, the negotiations over lumber rights might be comical, with loggers venturing hundreds of miles into the dense forests to wave money at villages of illiterate, nearly naked forest-dwellers.
"These are bush people," said Helen Pilon, a social worker here whose job requires her to take daylong hikes into the jungle to explain the concept of logging rights to remote tribal villages. "They live in bush houses, with no power, with pit toilets, using dogs' teeth for money. For many of these people, the first time they ever see an outsider is when they meet a logger."
 
$24 a Tree to Villagers
 Honest loggers acknowledge that native villagers are easily cheated, and that tribes often sell their rights to millions of dollars' worth of trees for a pittance. The Government estimates that a village will receive about $24 for every tree taken from its forest, while the logging company will sell the tree for nearly $600 -- of which at least a third is profit.
A report prepared for the Government last year by an outside consultant found that "the customary landowners whose forests were logged have received nothing of substantial benefit -- indeed, have suffered long-term harm" as their forests are devastated.
While there are no exact Government estimates on the amount of deforestation, environmental groups say that even their most optimistic calculations show that the forests with commercial value will be gone within 20 years.
Mr. Henderson, the environmentalist, recently warned a local audience that "for those of you with new babies, there will be no accessible forests left by the time they are 21."
 
A Typical Village
The False Promise Of Development
 The people of the village of Sembam, whose ancestors survived in the forest for centuries with little but rock-sharpened spears and a hunger-inspired aptitude for hunting, thought that they would be rich by now.
They own thousands of acres of dense rain forest along the eastern coast of the island of New Britain, the largest of Papua New Guinea's offshore islands. In 1991 they sold off the rights to the forests -- trees that had sprouted in the time of their great-great-grandparents -- to a Malaysian-controlled logging company, Bismark Industries, in exchange for what the villagers say were promises of wealth and development.
But three years later, there is little development and no wealth, at least not among the villagers. And their ancestral home in the forest is being torn apart.
In the surrounding forests, the squawking chatter of flocks of hornbills and kingfishers is drowned out by the grinding buzz of chainsaws and the massive thud of hardwood trees striking the moist earth. Where once there had been dense vegetation, there is now a barren vista dotted with lonely tree stumps.
 
Topsoil Has Washed Away
 Without the trees to hold it in place, the topsoil has washed away, replaced by a gritty scarlet-colored mud that smears the rags that clothe most of the village children. The runoff has polluted nearby creeks once used for drinking water.
"We had nothing before the loggers come, and I think maybe we will have nothing when the loggers go home," said Nicholas Pius, 29, a cocoa farmer, digging his toes into the gooey mud on the path outside his family's home, a straw-roofed one-room wooden hut without running water or electricity. "Maybe when the loggers go, we will have nothing, because the forests will be gone."
A year and a half after the logging began, villagers say, each of them has received only 50 kina -- equivalent to $57, or slightly more than $14,000 for the entire village of about 250 people -- even though Bismark estimates that it has already removed about $3 million worth of timber.
A Methodist preacher in the village, Pastor Pendrick Libai, said the 50-kina payments had been distributed in April, and that most of the money had been spent within days. Much of it went for what are considered luxuries here, including canned meat and alcohol.
"I see a few men get drunk," he said. "Some people in the village are angry about the way that they have been treated by the loggers, but they have no guts to speak out. These people are new to the outside world. They have a fear of outsiders. They do not know how to complain."
 
Pacts Fulfilled, Manager Says
 Bismark insists that it has done nothing wrong. Tatsuo Fujino, the company's business manager, said the company had lived up to "every condition of our contract."
He said that while details of the logging agreement with the village were confidential, he could disclose that "much more" than 100,000 kina, or about $114,000, had been put into bank accounts under the control of the village elders.
"We recommended that they keep the money in the bank," he said.
Asked why most of the villagers had seen so little of the money despite their wretched living conditions, Mr. Fujino said that was not his business.
"I am not in a position to say this is fair or not fair," he said. "My duty is to follow to the agreement."
The contract, he acknowledged, also called for the logging company to build a new schoolhouse, three new first-aid stations and a permanent bridge. But so far only the school has been built, and it is a rickety open-air structure with only two classrooms and housing for two teachers. Mr. Fujino said the first-aid posts and the bridge would eventually be built.
 
The Consequences
How Corruption Can Bring Murder
 For years, the Government ignored its responsibility to police the logging industry. To understand how that happened, it takes only a quick trip -- and few visitors want anything more -- to the capital, Port Moresby.
Most of this country is lush with virgin forests, but Port Moresby is a dusty, dirty, charmless city so dangerous that a family's wealth is measured by the amount of barbed wire that rings its home.
Along every rutted road there is evidence of the inability of the nation's leaders to carry out even the most basic functions of government.
"This place makes the worst American city look like a picnic," said a Western diplomat, whose backyard is bordered with interlocking strands of razor wire and patrolled by a mean-spirited guard dog.
Gangs known locally as rascals, mostly unemployed young men who come here looking for work, roam the streets looking for victims. There are no reliable crime statistics, but murder and gang rape are common.
In 1989 a Government commission found that the logging industry was "out of control," both because of Government incompetence and because so many Government officials had been paid off by the logging companies. The report likened the loggers to "robber barons -- bribing politicians and leaders, creating social disharmony and ignoring laws."
 
Chief Investigator Attacked
 After the results of the investigation became known, the chief investigator, Tos Barnett, a judge, was attacked in the streets of the capital. The gang of unidentified men screamed, "Kill him! Kill him!" as they stabbed him with sharpened screwdrivers.
"I had stab wounds to my lungs, chest, legs, buttocks -- wherever they could stab me," Mr. Barnett said. He has suggested that the attack was organized either by logging interests or by politicians implicated by the investigation.
Mr. Neville, the Forests Minister, is widely admired among conservationists, and his appointment is the reason for the Government's new willingness to confront the loggers.
His national forestry plan, announced in increments over the last two years, would ban the export of logs and compel loggers to guarantee that they were involved in sustainable logging, and he appears to have the support of the Prime Minister Paias Wingti.
But Mr. Neville has also come under threat. Once, when he was driving from a Port Moresby hotel, he was confronted by a group of men wearing face masks and carrying pistols.
"They jumped out from the side and smashed in the windshield of the car," he said. "I put my foot on the accelerator and tore through them."
 
Had to Flee His House
 Two days later, several men drove up to the gate of his house at night with rifles. "Luckily the gate next door was open, and I went racing down my neighbor's driveway," he said. The car sped away.
"I was born in this country, and I've never, ever had any experiences like this before," he said. Mr. Barnett has occasionally sent his family out of the country to Australia for their safety.
Mr. Tiong, the Malaysian logger, said that allegations linking the foreign logging companies to violence were "ridiculous" and that death threats were "not our Malaysian culture."
He said that the Malaysians, like other foreign loggers, were living up to their contracts with landowning tribes, and that the tribes were eager to make deals, since the logging companies offered them their first chance for any sort of development.
"The resources in this country are owned by the landowners, and they have to decide for themselves whether they are happy," he said. "We think they are happy."
 
A Novel Approach
How One Village Learned to Benefit
 Ankle deep in thick red mud as he hikes beneath a canopy of trees so dense that no sunlight strikes the soil, George Metpes, 31, the tribal chief in the village of Arabam, leads an expedition into the heart of one of the world's last great rain forests.
As he goes, he explains how he hopes to save this isolated stretch of forest from the law of supply and demand.
Arabam is one of a handful of villages involved in sustainable-logging programs, in which local villagers chop down trees themselves but leave enough standing so the forest can grow back quickly.
The program is the brainchild of Mr. Henderson, the environmentalist. His organization, the Pacific Heritage Foundation, is trying to encourage local tribes not to give up their only resource to foreigners who care only about quick profits.
In the project with Mr. Metpes's village on New Britain island, several villagers are put to work for about $6 a day, a good wage, chopping down trees and then processing them into boards, which are shipped to a chain of English hardware shops that sell only "environmentally sensitive" lumber.
 
Preserving the Canopy
 The idea, explains Gary Thomas, a British forester who is overseeing the project for the foundation, is to preserve the thick canopy of trees, which provides the shade and moisture needed for the trees to grow back quickly. "Here, we can take the trees and still preserve the canopy," he said.
The difference between areas of sustainable forestry and clear-cutting is stark. Even where trees have been removed, there is still shade and the cool damp of the rain forest. Lizards scamper across the mud. The deep-throated hornbills and blue-eyed cockatoos are still in full voice here.
The problem for Mr. Metpes is that the money from this project does not match the money he would receive from foreign loggers if the village agreed to allow the clear-cutting of the forest. The tribal chief said that after a lifetime of deprivation, many of the older villagers want as much money as possible, even if that means the loss of the forest forever.
"It is always a struggle," he explained sadly. "Many of these people want fast money. Some of them have been so poor all of their lives that they have never eaten tinned meat. And that's what they tell me. They say that they want tinned meat before they die."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 5, 1994

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 3679 words

HEADLINE: Derailment On Wall Street -- A special report.;
Fallen Bond Trader Sees Himself As an Outsider and a Scapegoat

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR with DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

 BODY:
From the time he left a small town in Ohio to make his way through M.I.T., Harvard Business School and three Wall Street firms, Orlando Joseph Jett was the ultimate outsider, a fierce individualist who made few close friends and drove himself hard. And since mid-April, when Kidder, Peabody & Company accused him of orchestrating a $350 million fraud and dismissed him, placing him at the center of one of Wall Street's biggest scandals, Mr. Jett has been more isolated than ever.
For the first time since that scandal unfolded, Mr. Jett, 36, is speaking out about himself, his upbringing, his career on Wall Street and his ordeal at Kidder. Only months ago, he was Kidder's employee of the year -- a star trader who earned a $9 million bonus in 1993. Now he is unemployed, and under investigation by the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan and the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 Many have speculated about how that fall took place. Mr. Jett offers no single answer. But in a four-hour interview with him last week, he kept returning to what it was like to be a black man in a largely white society, and how that has affected his career and his life. Some of his most biting stories underscored how even after he had gained entree into blue-chip institutions like the Ford Motor Company and Kidder, he still saw himself as invisible to others who counted.
Initially, the notion of a certain degree of invisibility appealed to him. He talked, for example, of the lure of Wall Street as a place where he would be judged not by the color of his skin, but by the amount of money he could make. "The government bond market is exquisitely objective," he said. "It cares nothing about a person's race, color or creed. Trading was the perfect job."
But he was reminded again and again that it was not entirely the case.
"It was sort of fascinating," he said, recalling how visiting Kidder salespeople sought to congratulate him after his promotion to chief of Kidder's government bond desk. He recounted how they would walk up to a colleague to offer congratulations, rather than to Mr. Jett himself. "It never entered their minds that I could possibly be Joe Jett," he said.
Mr. Jett craved recognition, and tried harder and harder to achieve the performance that would bring it. In the end, however, it was that performance -- the exceptional, but apparently phantom, profits he managed to show on the trading desk -- that brought about his downfall at Kidder.
Even as Mr. Jett reasserted his innocence in the interview at the office of his public relations adviser, a person outside of Kidder who is familiar with the investigations said Mr. Jett's scheme was something far larger than that described in Kidder's accusations.
According to this account, in the month before Mr. Jett was dismissed, his fictitious trades soared to a stunning $600 billion for March. But instead of concluding any of these trades, this person said, Mr. Jett rolled them over into new trades and counted the nonexistent profits as real.
 
 
A Huge Pyramid Scheme
 The person familiar with the investigations said the trading records and interviews with Kidder staff showed that Mr. Jett had engaged in a huge pyramid scheme involving nonexistent trades and ever-larger phantom profits. A month before his dismissal, his scheme had grown so huge that it was threatening to spiral out of control and this ultimately led to his downfall, this person said.
With the current investigations, Mr. Jett's lawyers would not allow him to discuss his trading in an interiew. Nonetheless, Mr. Jett disputed Kidder's charges against him and reasserted his belief that he has done nothing wrong. "I have to fight because I am innocent," he said. "I won't let them railroad me."
In the weeks since Kidder embarrassed itself and stunned the financial world by charging that Mr. Jett had outwitted its controls and auditing systems, the firm has recognized $350 million in losses that it has attributed to Mr. Jett and has opened itself to armies of outside investigators.
Mr. Jett, meanwhile, has assembled a team of lawyers -- including Kenneth E. Warner, a civil lawyer, Lewis D. Lowenfels, a securities specialist, and Gustave H. Newman, a criminal lawyer who recently represented Robert A. Altman in the B.C.C.I. case -- to free money from his Kidder accounts and to defend against any possible legal charges, though none have yet been filed.
 
 
Doing What He Was Told
 People familiar with Mr. Jett's situation contend that he was merely recording his trades the way he was told by his bosses to make Kidder's books look better for the benefit of prospective buyers and Kidder's parent company, the General Electric Company.
A Kidder spokesman has called this accusation "preposterous" and "defamatory."
 Mr. Jett's legal strategy has already borne some fruit: on Friday evening, Kidder gave Mr. Jett $138,181 from his deferred compensation account, though he is still seeking the remainder of the more than $8 million that he had in other Kidder accounts.
Even though Mr. Jett is now having his say, he says he feels that with General Electric and Kidder against him, he is facing a juggernaut. "After what has been done to me there is no room for truth," he said, shaking his head. "They've depicted me as a despicable character. The words have been twisted, and the truth turned merrily on its head."
 
A Midwest Upbringing
Brains and Brawn Of a Professed Nerd
 Sitting in the Third Avenue office of the public relations adviser, George Sard, Mr. Jett described last week his middle-class Midwest upbringing, the attraction of Wall Street and his ill-fated career at Kidder. Mr. Jett, dressed in a dark suit with a faint chalk stripe and a white shirt with a yellow-and-blue patterned tie and gold cuff links, sat with a military bearing, formal and composed, eager to tell his story. Although he is only 5 feet 7 inches tall, he is powerfully built, the result of years of bodybuilding.
During the interview, Mr. Jett sought to dispel the image of himself as a ruthless Gordon Gekko willing to do anything -- even cheat -- to make money or beat his rivals. In tones measured and sad at times, angry and scornful at others, he portrayed himself as a driven, dedicated employee who tried to light a fire under a lackluster trading department, made enemies along the way and wound up a scapegoat at least in part because he is black.
He described how as the son of a conservative black small-business man, he grew up a fan of Richard Nixon, worked in Ronald Reagan's 1980 Presidential campaign and disdained affirmative action programs so much that he refused to identify his race on his application to the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.
 Mr. Jett, who grew up in Wickliffe, Ohio, 14 miles northeast of Cleveland, arrived on Wall Street with the kind of background that seemed made for success. His mother, a science teacher, and his father, who sold insurance, stressed education and discipline to their three children. "My Dad pulled us out of team sports; he felt it was a trap," he said. "If we didn't get good grades, we were punished. When we did something wrong, he'd take a belt to us."
Mr. Jett's father, James, 64, who said he learned of the accusations against his son on the evening news, said, "We have every bit of confidence that this system works and we want the process to go forward."
"You don't get shook up just because someone is accusing your child," he said. "But when he is vilified and when his character is assassinated, when you have a Judge Thomas situation, when high-tech lynching is starting to occur, you get shook up."
Although he worked a paper route from about the age of 8, and as a dishwasher and cook at a steak house during high school, Joseph Jett was also an avid reader and a mathematics whiz who liked beating his older sister and brother at the flash cards his parents quizzed them on hour after hour.
"There's a beauty to math," Mr. Jett noted. "It's logical. It adheres to rules always."
Nancy Vieburg, a childhood friend who knew Mr. Jett through high school, shared his interest in math and science and has stayed in touch with Mr. Jett.
"It was not a real popular thing to be a brain in our high school," she said. "There was a point when he realized, it's a good thing to be smart."
 
No Money in Philosophy
 Even better than math, Mr. Jett said, was philosophy. But he said his father talked him out of majoring in philosophy by showing him the newspaper and saying, "Show me the help-wanted ads that say 'Philosopher.' "
 So Mr. Jett headed for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1976, where he earned bachelor's and master's degrees in chemical engineering, and later to Harvard Business School.
Even before he moved east, however, it was clear to Mr. Jett that he did not fit in, even with many of his fellow black students. Not only was he a professed nerd who did not speak black slang, but he sometimes seemed to go out of his way to challenge other blacks.
He tells the story, for example, of the time in the ninth grade, when he walked onto the basketball court in a local park and stole the ball. As he tells it, he climbed up on a bench and told the players, "It's time that we as a people stop making baskets and start making A's."
"I got beat up," he added, laughing.
Even when he attended a program for minority engineers at the University of Dayton in the 11th grade, he did not blend in. He recounts how the group had to take two I.Q. tests on the second day of class, a standard one and one that had racial bias removed.
"The psychologist told the class that all of them except one did poorly on the standard test, and that all except one did better on the racially corrected test," Mr. Jett said. "She identified me to the class."
 
 
Building Character and Body
 Mr. Jett says he developed a certain strength of character partly from his father and partly from the fact that he was picked on. To defend himself, he began lifting weights.
While college and graduate school were liberating experiences, socially and intellectually, Mr. Jett said, he found the working world by turns indifferent, stifling and, at times, hostile.
 
 
From Orlando to Joseph
 After graduating from M.I.T., he went to work for the General Electric plastics division in Selkirk in upstate New York. At General Electric, Mr. Jett abandoned his first name, Orlando, in favor of his middle name. "Orlando would never be called back," he said. "Joseph would be called back almost immediately."
It was also at General Electric that Mr. Jett, who wound up with far less responsibility than he wanted, decided that people skilled in management and marketing, not engineers, would be running things in the new corporate world. Since techies, as he put it, would "always be order takers," he decided to get an M.B.A.
Although he said he intended to return to General Electric, Mr. Jett was drawn at Harvard to students who had worked on Wall Street -- "They had the drive and the energy" -- and he got his first taste of trading in a summer job at Ford Motor, where he was part of the group that managed the company's short-term cash.
 
Rough Start in Finance
Personality Clashes At 3 Wall St. Firms
 Mr. Jett was determined to make his mark on Wall Street, but his initial experiences there were not encouraging.
His first job after graduating from Harvard was as a trainee and then as a junior trader at Morgan Stanley. He said he alienated colleagues and supervisors by turning "loud and brash" in an effort to fit in with other traders. After less than two years, he was laid off.
When he landed a second job, at CS First Boston, after being unemployed for six months, Mr. Jett said he was careful to present a new persona. "I felt I simply could not allow a personality," he said. "I became very dry. My God, did I become a dry, quiet, dull person."
Former colleagues at First Boston said Mr. Jett was dismissed in early 1991, partly for poor performance and partly for inflating his resume, including overstating his experience at Morgan Stanley. But he said he was let go after the firm discovered he was looking for work at Kidder.
Mr. Jett said that he had a "handshake agreement" to join Kidder in early 1991, but that the deal fell apart after he lost his job at First Boston. Six months later, Mr. Jett landed a job as a bond trader on Kidder's government desk.
But within six months, Mr. Jett said, he was in danger of failing again and losing what he considered "the dream job." Despite a regimen of 12-hour days and much study at home after hours, Mr. Jett received a warning at year-end that he would have to become more profitable or face dismissal, according to two people familiar with his record. His bonus that year was $5,000 -- a pittance by Wall Street standards and practically an invitation to start looking for work elsewhere.
 
 
Driven to Success
 At the time, Mr. Jett was living in a 400-square-foot, $700-a-month apartment on West 54th Street in Manhattan. To punish himself for his failure at First Boston and his poor work at Kidder, he deprived himself, he said, of "every comfort." Mr. Jett said he removed his furniture and began sleeping on the floor. He said he was more determined than ever to prove himself.
In 1992, his fortunes suddenly improved. He not only made lots of money trading, but he attracted the attention of Edward A. Cerullo, the powerful head of fixed-income trading at Kidder. That year, Mr. Jett took home a $2 million bonus.
By March 1993, Mr. Jett had become such a big star that Mr. Cerullo decided to hand him the government trading desk, where he suddenly had enormous authority and 32 people reporting to him.
"I was asked to remake the government desk," he said. "It required doing things that were emotionally hard for people to do."
Mr. Jett said he dismissed four people and clashed often with Kidder's sales force.
People familiar with the investigation into his trades, however, said that he also stepped up the unusual trading strategy that would ultimately end his rapid rise.
 
Kidder's New Star
A Midas Touch, Or So It Seemed
 Descriptions of what Mr. Jett's defenders say he did differ by 180 degrees from what Kidder and outside investigators say they have found. His defenders say he developed a highly profitable means for trading Government bonds, while critics contend that the strategy was a complete fraud, a stratagem for covering up a wretched trading record that piled up $100 million in losses.
Good government bond traders, former traders said, usually have revenues of $10 million to $30 million a year. But in 1993, Mr. Jett's profits began exceeding $10 million a month. Mr. Jett had invented a technique, it appeared to his supervisors, that turned a modest money maker into a powerful money machine, just as other young traders like Michael Vranos and Joseph W. Cherner had done at Kidder in recent years.
 
 
Firm Eager to Show Profits
 There also was a sense that Kidder executives might not have looked too closely at Mr. Jett's trading because he was suddenly posting big profits at a firm eager to impress its owner, General Electric, which had been threatening to sell Kidder.
As word of his success spread, other traders at Kidder and elsewhere on Wall Street were full of curiosity about Mr. Jett's trades.
Mr. Jett declined to comment on his technique or his exchanges with fellow traders. People familiar with his trading, however, said that he was executing a high volume of transactions, called forwards -- which are nothing more than instructions to the back office to get securities ready for settlement for a particular day -- and recording the anticipated earnings as current profits.
He apparently started small. In May 1993, Mr. Jett was trading about $3 billion a month, not an unusual amount for government bonds, a person familiar with the Kidder investigations said.
 
Trading Quickly Soars
 By the end of 1993, Mr. Jett's trading had soared and his system had apparently earned profits of more than $200 million for the year. He was paid a $9 million bonus and given a coveted chairman's award.
Every January, Kidder honors its top performers at a management conference. In January 1993, Mr. Jett attended the conference in Orlando, Fla., as a member of a task force on recruiting minorities. The experience made Mr. Jett -- who opposes affirmative action -- more determined than ever, he said, to earn a place at the gathering based on his performance.
"I did not want to be viewed as an affirmative action case," he said. "With affirmative action, all of a sudden, the expectation of lower standards was being codified."
His 1993 performance clearly seemed to have earned him the spot at the convention. At this year's conference in January, as he stood on the podium to accept the chairman's award, Mr. Jett said he was proud to be there based on his trading performance.
Although people who later described the speech recalled Mr. Jett comparing trading on Wall Street to war, he said he used the analogy only to describe how everyone at Kidder needed to work together.
 "I told them a story about my father in Korea," Mr. Jett said. "My dad was a sergeant. His troop was Hispanics, blacks, and rednecks from the deep South. When they landed, they set aside their differences and set about destroying the enemy. What I said was, 'At Kidder, we had to unite and work together.' "
 
No Camaraderie at Kidder
 Mr. Jett now says he never felt any camaraderie at Kidder. He seemed almost flabbergasted at the notion that he and Mr. Cerullo had a personal relationship. He said when he went on a ski trip to Mr. Cerullo's Aspen vacation home earlier this year, it was all business.
There soon were more pressing concerns. In the first few months of this year, as Mr. Jett's trading volume increased, the computer system had difficulty keeping up, a person familiar with the Kidder investigation said.
Kidder's computer specialists were stunned when they saw the scale of Mr. Jett's ostensible trades and noticed that none of the trades ever led to any actual securities changing hands, two people familiar with the events said. If the trades were never consummated, where had the hundreds of millions in profits booked by Mr. Jett come from?
As the computer people were joined by accountants, Mr. Cerullo and other top executives, the alarm grew. Mr. Jett's profits had been booked but the underlying trades were apparently never completed. Two or three days before a trade was to be completed, Mr. Jett rolled the trades over but kept the profits on the books, the person familiar with the investigation said.
And as his phantom profits accumulated, Mr. Jett executed larger and larger trades to keep the scheme afloat, the person said. He also used numerous trading variations to make his accounting maneuvers look like real trades.
 
A Lonely Fall
Shock and Denial As Scandal Unfolds
 The allegations contrast sharply with defense theories that portray Mr. Jett as someone who implemented sophisticated, highly lucrative trading techniques with the knowledge of profit-hungry superiors. His lawyers declined to discuss the substance of Mr. Jett's side of the story.
"There is a lot more here than meets the eye and has already been disclosed publicly," said Mr. Lowenfels, the securities lawyer on Mr. Jett's legal team.
By the time Kidder stopped the trades in April and summoned Mr. Jett to a meeting with top executives where he was questioned, about $250 billion in fictitious trades was still on the company's computers.
The volume of fake trades was so large that Kidder personnel initially suspected Mr. Jett must have had help. But the firm now believes, people familiar with the inquiry said, that Mr. Jett probably acted alone and was able to take advantage of a peculiarity in the computer system.
 
 
Helped by Technology
 "They had this great, superduper automated system that helped Jett create these positions by typing in a couple of numbers," one of the people familiar with the inquiry said.
By early April, Kidder knew it had a problem. Early in the week of April 11, Kidder alerted John F. Welch Jr., the chairman and chief executive of General Electric, that the problem could affect Kidder's bottom line. At that point, Kidder contacted the S.E.C. and New York Stock Exchange, alerting regulators that it expected a major loss of capital.
On Thursday, April 14, Mr. Jett was summoned to the meeting with Mr. Cerullo and other top Kidder executives. He denied that he had done anything wrong, offering various explanations. At the end of the meeting, he walked out the door of Kidder for what was probably the last time.
 
 
A $210 Million Charge
 On Sunday, April 17, Mr. Cerullo sent Mr. Jett a curt letter telling him that he had been dismissed. Later that evening, General Electric issued a press release saying that it would have to reduce after-tax earnings by $210 million because Mr. Jett had inflated his trading profits. Kidder also froze the $8 million that Mr. Jett had left behind in three personal accounts at the firm.
Although Kidder released some funds to Mr. Jett on Friday, he is still concerned that he will need more to pay his lawyers and his public relations firm.
Despite his fears, the former Kidder trader can find humor in the bizarre turn his life has taken. For example, Mr. Jett noted what happened a day after Kidder accused him of making phantom trades.
"That Monday I woke up in a daze," he said. "I got dressed in a suit as if I was going to work. When I got downstairs and opened the door," Mr. Jett said, stepping back and imitating a man in the glare of sudden lights, "there was a network television crew.
"And you know what," he said, laughing. "They let me walk right by. At that point the media didn't know I was black. So they let me walk right by."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. IN VIRGINIA NOMINATES NORTH FOR SENATE SEAT

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RICHMOND, June 4

 BODY:
Forsaking appeals from Ronald Reagan in March and other party heroes, the Virginia Republican Party today nominated Oliver L. North for the United States Senate, setting the stage for one of the year's most unpredictable and acrimonious contests.
Mr. North won 55 percent of the vote at the party's state convention, to 45 percent for James C. Miller, an economist and a budget director in President Reagan's Administration. 
 A triumphant Mr. North took to the podium to the theme from "Rocky," and, borrowing from President Clinton's anthem after the New Hampshire primary in 1992, proclaimed himself "the real comeback kid."
Then he put the White House on notice. "Today, we send the Clintons and their cronies a simple but unmistakable message," said Mr. North, as his wife, Betsy, looked on beside him. "This is our Government, you stole it, and we are going to take it back." He ridiculed the White House as teeming with "20-something kids with an earring and an axe to grind."
With balloon drops, blaring bands and a huge American flag behind the stage, the Richmond Coliseum was transformed into the site of a grand spectacle. Party officials said the event drew nearly 15,000 delegates, more than any political gathering in American history and close to three times the number who were at the party's national convention in 1992.
But the celebratory air and outward unity were little more than a red, white and blue facade. With his conviction, later overturned, on felony charges for his role in the Iran-contra affair, Mr. North has emerged as one of the most polarizing figures in modern American politics. To his admirers, he is a brave patriot, while to his detractors, he is a duplicitous criminal.
Mr. North's candidacy -- even before his nomination here today -- had thrust the state's Republicans into turmoil just a year after the party's jubilation over seizing the governorship for the first time in 12 years. Many delegates here vowed to follow the lead of Senator John W. Warner and oppose Mr. North in November. But others accused the state's senior Senator of disloyalty after he threw his support this week to the likely independent candidacy of J. Marshall Coleman. "Dump Warner" buttons were a popular item on the convention floor.
 
Conservative Support
 Well beyond Virginia, national party officials fear that Mr. North is such a divisive candidate that he could deprive the party of what appeared to be a clear shot at defeating the Democratic incumbent, Senator Charles S. Robb, the onetime war hero who has been tarnished in the last few years by several embarrassing disclosures about his private life. The race is of such national interest that even former President Reagan, for whom Mr. North served on the staff of the National Security Council, thrust himself into the fray in mid-March by writing that he was "getting pretty steamed about the statements coming from Oliver North." Mr. Reagan protested Mr. North's saying that he had lied to Congress under Mr. Reagan's orders. Mr. North later said the statements for which Mr. Reagan called him a liar had been intentionally misrepresented in the press.
Mr. North's nomination was also an important demonstration of the growing potency of Christian conservatives, who form the core of his support and who have come to dominate several state Republican organizations this year. In fact, the religious conservatives proved to be a far more powerful force at the convention, which can be swayed by small but motivated groups, than they have historically been in the state as a whole. That was why it probably would have been far more difficult for Mr. North to win the nomination had there been an open primary, like the Democrats will hold on June 14.
With Mr. North expected to face Mr. Robb, who has clung to a wide lead over his opponents in that primary, the main event is likely to be between two former marines whose negative ratings are among the highest of any candidates running for Federal office this year. Both candidates have engendered such opposition in their own parties that they will probably be challenged by party members running as independents in November.
Former Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, a Democrat who has feuded with Mr. Robb for years, is poised to run, as is Mr. Coleman, a Republican and former State Attorney General. With so many candidates, it would be virtually impossible to rate anyone as a front-runner. The winner would need only 26 percent of the vote. Mr. Wilder, for one, would be buoyed by his support among blacks, while Mr. North could depend on his strength with conservative Christians.
In an odd scene typical of the changing and twisted alliances in the race, supporters of Mr. Wilder set up a booth here to collect signatures on a nominating petition to put him on the ballot as an independent. They managed to get dozens of signatures before being booted out by angry partisans.
 
Ultimate Outsider
 With his conservative positions and national celebrity, the 50-year-old Mr. North appears to be seeking the mantle of Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina. He has built his career -- and personal fortune -- on criticizing Congress, the body that excoriated him during the Iran-contra hearings in 1987. Despite his own service in the White House, Mr. North is portraying himself as the ultimate outsider, a theme he emphasized in his vigorous speech before the voting.
Much of Mr. North's message was devoted to demeaning the press, and he singled out Ted Koppel, the host of the ABC News program "Nightline" who harshly questioned the candidate's truthfulness. At one point today, Mr. North lumped Mr. Koppel with his other favorite foes, referring to "Clinton, Congress, Koppel and above all, Chuck -- we'll beat 'em all like a dozen eggs."
Mr. North had long been viewed as the favorite to win the Republican nomination. But his forces viewed Mr. Miller as a serious threat because of his support from major figures wanting to stop Mr. North. In addition, the quirky nature of voting at the state convention only added to the uncertainty over the outcome.
Any Virginia Republican could become a delegate if they paid a $45 registration fee. The party set the overall delegate vote for each county, weighted to favor counties that cast more votes for Republicans in the 1992 and 1993 elections. Both camps spent months courting delegates with phone calls, mailings and personal appeals up to the last moment.
Though the system varied by county, most delegates filled out a paper ballot. Then, in a process similar to that of a national party convention, each district announced how many votes it had cast for each candidate.
A balding, rotund figure, Mr. Miller offers little of the rhetorical flourishes or charisma of his opponent. But in his plain-spoken appeal, he repeated his campaign theme that while he is as conservative as Mr. North, polls show that he would have a better chance to beat Mr. Robb.
Mr. Miller choose his words carefully to avoid inflaming Mr. North's backers. But scattered boos erupted when Mr. Miller raised the notion that a North victory would cost Republicans the seat.
"If we Virginia Republicans nominate a candidate who loses to Chuck Robb, Democrats from Hollywood to Manhattan would insist that Americans don't mind if politicians break promises, raise taxes and promote bigger government," he declared. The message, he added, would be that no one in Virginia "would care about integrity and honor."
Such warnings were what left Mr. Miller's supporters shaken after the voting today. Barbara Comstock, a Miller delegate from Fairfax County, in the Washington suburbs, said it would be hard for her to vote for Mr. North in November. "It's going to be a real hard sell," she said of Mr. North. "With North, it's like Bill Clinton. People either like him or they don't, and the negatives are way too high."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. George Allen of Virginia, right, joins Oliver L. North after Mr. North won the Republican nomination for the Senate from Virginia. Delegates at the party's convention chose him over James C. Miller. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. 26)

HEADLINE: Turkey, Hurt By Iraq Curbs, Requests Help

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey

 BODY:
Turkey is pressing the United States and other Western and Arab allies for relief from the hardships that the United Nations embargo on Iraq imposes on its crisis-ridden economy.
At the same time, sentiment is growing against the continued use of Turkish territory for an international operation on behalf of Kurds in northern Iraq. 
 The Government of Prime Minister Tansu Ciller is seeking approval for a tentative agreement it reached with Iraq in April to conduct what it calls a "rescue operation" to reopen for repair the pipeline from the Kirkuk oilfields in Iraq to the Turkish port of Yumurtalik on the Mediterranean.
Under the agreement, Turkey would be allowed to buy for domestic use the 12 million barrels of crude oil that have been in the 616-mile pipeline since the embargo was imposed after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in 1990 and would reimburse Iraq with food and medicine.
 
Pipeline 'Going to Rot'
 "Let us save the pipeline," President Suleyman Demirel said in an interview. "It is going to rot."
Western diplomats expressed sympathy but emphasized that their governments were in varying degrees reluctant to breach the embargo.
Ozdem Sanberk, the second-in-command in the Turkish Foreign Ministry, negotiated the deal in Baghdad. He emphasized in an interview that the deal had not yet been signed. He said 3.8 million barrels of the oil in the pipeline belonged to Turkey, having been paid for before the sanctions. Turkey, he said, has rejected Iraqi demands to export the oil and stands firm against transferring money to Iraq.
Mr. Demirel said Turkey would stick with the coalition that defeated President Saddam Hussein in the 1991 Persian Gulf war. "We are not going to make a deal with Saddam," he said.
 
Heavy Losses for Turkey
 Mr. Demirel said the war and embargo had cost Turkey $15 billion to $20 billion, of which it had been compensated "three or four billion" by "our friends in the gulf."
Iraq was one of the country's most important trading partners before the war. Turkey is still owed about $2 billion for construction projects. He said Turkey had also lost the $600 million or $700 million a year that it collected for the use of the pipeline.
Most sensitive, perhaps, has been the effect of the cutoff in Iraqi trade in southeastern Turkey, where the Turkish military is conducting a war against the Kurdish Workers Party.
Mr. Demirel also spoke of what he called the political and social problems caused by the operation to aid Kurds in northern Iraq. Northern Iraq, like southeastern Turkey, is largely populated by Kurds, who have struggled since the breakup of the Ottoman Empire for national recognition, which Turkey, Iraq and Iran have all denied. Mr. Demirel said he and many Turks feared the consequences of the de facto detachment of northern Iraq from Iraqi control.
"We are very sensitive about that," Mr. Demirel said. "The protection of these people should not result in a Kurdish state. Our mercy, our humanitarian feelings should not create something we don't like."
The Speaker of Turkey's Parliament, Husamettin Cindoruk, who is considered a contender for prime minister, said Parliament would accept the operation for another six months when it expires June 30 "if the Government insists." He added, "But it will be the last time."

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
Gyula Horn, Recycled Communist, to Lead Hungary

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, June 4

 BODY:
After a stunning comeback in elections last weekend, Hungary's victorious Socialist Party today designated its leader, Gyula Horn, a tough politician with deep roots in the Communist era, as its choice for Prime Minister.
The vote by the former Communist party assures that Mr. Horn, 61, will become Hungary's next Prime Minister after a new Parliament convenes in early July. The Socialists captured 209 of 386 parliamentary seats in the final voting last Sunday, with most attributing the result to discontent with free-market policies. 
 A heavy smoker who understands English but does not speak it in public, Mr. Horn (his first name is pronounced JOO-la) transformed himself in the final years of Communist rule from a party apparatchik into a Western-leaning foreign policy expert. Yet Hungarian analysts say he retains the characteristics that made him successful within the Communist party structure: a certain ruthlessness and adroitness in outwitting his opponents.
 
'The Political Fox'
 "In the 60's and 70's, Horn was not among the reformers," Laszlo Lengyel, a political scientist, wrote in a recent article about the party leader, which bore the title "The Political Fox."
"It was in the Nemeth Government that Horn stopped being an apparatchik and became a professional foreign policy player," he wrote. Mr. Horn served as Foreign Minister in Prime Minister Miklos Nemeth's Government, which governed from 1989 to 1990.
In the weeks before Parliament convenes, Mr. Horn is talking with the Alliance of Free Democrats, heavy losers in the elections, about the possibility of forming a coalition.
Because the Socialists won an outright majority of parliamentary seats, they do not need the Free Democrats, a party born from the anti-Communist opposition of the 1980's, to govern. There are wide doubts about how sincere Mr. Horn is in his offer of a coalition, though few believe that the Socialists would turn the clock back by reinstating Communist policies.
"Horn is giving the offer, but he's trying to get them to reject it," said Andrew Arato, a professor from the New School in New York who is a visiting scholar at the Central European University. "The Socialists need something that looks like a coalition, but it is not clear whether they want a real one."
 
Publicity Maneuver
 Today Mr. Horn sounded more conciliatory toward the Free Democrats. At a news conference after the party congress, he said the Socialists were willing to give the Free Democrats more posts in the Government than their vote totals would earn them.
He also said the economic programs of the two parties were close and that he hoped "very strongly" that the Free Democrats would join in serious talks on a coalition.
Nonetheless, Mr. Horn seemed to show some of his old cunning this week by maneuvering his potential partners into an awkward situation. Mr. Horn told the Free Democrats he wanted to change a meeting site from neutral territory to his own party headquarters because too many journalists would congregate at the known meeting place.
The Socialists tipped off the press, and a phalanx of cameras recorded the Democrats' paying homage to the victorious Mr. Horn at the former headquarters of the Budapest Communist Party. "It was a childish trick," said one Free Democrat.
 
With the Communists in '56
 Born in Budapest on July 5, 1932, Mr. Horn was one of seven children brought up in poverty and political violence. His father was arrested by the Nazis because of his membership in the Communist party and killed on his way to a concentration camp.
Mr. Horn wound his way into the highest party echelons over three decades of obedience to the party norms.
A promising student, Mr. Horn was sent by the Communist Party to an accounting school in Rostov, Russia. On his return to Hungary he joined the Finance Ministry. He took the side of the Communist authorities during the failed 1956 uprising, joining an auxiliary police unit assigned to guarding bridges.
In the 1960's, he was posted as a junior diplomat in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, where he learned Serbo-Croatian, and in Sofia, Bulgaria. In 1969 he began his climb within the Communist Party's department of Foreign Affairs. He joined the Foreign Ministry as Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs in 1985 and was appointed Foreign Minister four years later.
He took the unorthodox route of promoting relations with countries that had previously been off-limits. "He was a realpolitik politician," said one of his close friends, Jozsef Gyorke, who was Hungary's Ambassador in London in 1989. "He thought it was an ostrich-like position to ignore Israel, South Africa and South Korea. Whether we liked them or not, they existed."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gyula Horn, who has recently worn a neck brace because of an injury suffered in a car crash. (Associated Press)
