HEADLINE: Clinton Says That North Korea Can Still Avoid U.N. Sanctions

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTSMOUTH, England, June 4

 BODY:
Trying to ease the confrontation with North Korea over nuclear inspections, President Clinton said today that North Korea could still take action to avoid economic sanctions.
The President's remarks, at a joint news conference with Prime Minister John Major prior to the D-Day commemorations, came a day after North Korea said it would regard sanctions as a declaration of war. 
 The President did not specify what steps he expected the North Korean Government to take to avoid sanctions, other than presumably opening up its nuclear sites for whatever inspections can still be carried out. And he insisted that North Korea's defiance "made it virtually imperative" that the Security Council take up the question of sanctions.
The United States, Japan and South Korea have concluded that North Korea's refusal to allow inspectors of the International Atomic Energy Agency to examine a nuclear reactor to see if spent fuel has been diverted to its weapons program is a sure sign that it is developing nuclear weapons.
 
Joint Statement on Sanctions
 Ending two days of talks today in Washington, officials from the three nations said in a joint statement that the United Nations should "urgently consider an appropriate response, including sanctions." It is not yet clear whether China or Russia, both of which have veto power as permanent members of the Security Council, would support such a move.
Japan, which greatly fears the specter of nuclear weapons in Asia, has signaled that it might consider imposing economic sanctions even without a United Nations vote. Japan is an important source of hard currency for North Korea.
The growing confrontation has been a preoccupying cloud, though not a very large one, over Mr. Clinton's second trip to Europe as President, which includes a visit to England, where he was a Rhodes scholar at Oxford.
On Friday, the head of the United Nations nuclear monitoring agency told the Security Council that North Korea had already removed most of the fuel rods from the reactor in dispute at Yongbyon, including the 300 rods considered critical to determining whether weapons-grade plutonium has been diverted in the past.
 
U.S. Offers Way Out
 In his remarks today, President Clinton sought to give North Korea some room to back away from the dispute.
"There's still time for North Korea to avoid sanctions actually taking effect if we can work out something on the nuclear inspectors," he said. "I think that clearly sanctions are not any sort of act of war and should not be seen as such. All we want them to do is keep their word, and we're going to try to give them chances to do it."
South Korea, meanwhile, made a point of declaring that it was prepared to repulse any military attack from the north. South Korean Government officials met in Seoul to set up a task force to assess national readiness.
President Kim Young Sam, traveling in Russia, told reporters, "We and the United States are fully prepared and have enough military power ready to meet any emergencies." He said that "round-the-clock surveillance on the North's movements" was under way.

GRAPHIC: Photo: North Korea's Ambassador to Beijing, Chu Chang Jun, declared yesterday that North Korea could survive any sanctions imposed. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: China Tries to Blot Out Memories of 1989

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 4

 BODY:
China deployed security forces against its dissidents today and interrupted international news broadcasts to prevent commemoration of the fifth anniversary of the 1989 military attack on the Tiananmen Square democracy movement.
In anticipation of the anniversary, security agencies had put scores of dissidents under house arrest or close surveillance, a tactic most recently used during Secretary of State Warren Christopher's visit in March. 
 At dawn today, Tiananmen Square was ringed by security agents in plainclothes and in uniform, some dozing in their cars and others scanning the 99-acre expanse with binoculars. The security men seemed to outnumber the early-morning strollers, kite-fliers and shadow boxers out for their daily exercise.
 
Blocking Televised Images
 The authorities also threw a cordon of police officers around the university district in northwestern Beijing, a wellspring of the 1989 protests. Public events were canceled, and hotels were instructed to unplug their satellite connections to Cable News Network.
Even in housing compounds reserved for foreign diplomats, journalists and business executives, the authorities interrupted satellite television service whenever Western networks broadcast images of the 1989 protests in news reports of the anniversary.
Gladdened by President Clinton's decision last week to stop linking China's human rights performance to its $30 billion in exports to America, Communist Party leaders are hoping to pass the anniversary weekend without incident.
The past five years have been defined by the crackdown -- a tank and machine assault on unarmed civilian protesters who had laid siege to the Chinese capital, put up a "Goddess of Democracy" and refused to disperse in the face of a martial-law decree. Hundreds died and many more were wounded during the night of June 3 and the early morning hours of June 4, 1989.
After the killings, thousands of students and workers who took part in the movement were rounded up and imprisoned. Others fled overseas. International condemnation of the crackdown led to nearly three years of economic sanctions and political isolation for China as it pursued a policy of wide repression of dissent.
 
China's Determined Normalcy
 Today the national flags of China and Cambodia lined the Avenue of Eternal Peace, which crosses Tiananmen Square, in honor of a state visit by King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia. In a gesture underlining China's goal to convey a determined normalcy, President Jiang Zemin ceremoniously greeted the King on the square on Friday.
During the ceremony, King Sihanouk laid a wreath at the Monument to the People's Heroes at the center of Tiananmen Square -- the same spot that served as the headquarters of student democracy campaigners who occupied the square in 1989.
Despite the security clampdown today, some expressions of defiance broke through.
 
Reminiscences by Computer
 Using international computer networks easily accessible in China, Chinese students and professionals on several continents published an electronic file of personal reminiscences of the night of June 3-4. Hundreds of people in China have access to the computer network, which is used at universities, Government ministries and foreign companies.
One Chinese student recalled the experience of being run down by a tank on the Avenue of Eternal Peace west of Tiananmen Square. The driver, possibly blinded by a cloud of tear gas, rushed the students as they stood on the side of the avenue.
"Since I was in the front row, I found no way to run," the student wrote in the electronic file. "I was bumped onto the ground. I thought, 'It's all over!' "
"When I came to," he continued, "I sat up. I could not move my left thigh. It's lying on the ground, strangely shaped. . . By my side, there were seven to 10 mashed bodies, too terrible to look at."
In another act of commemoration that got past the attempts at a news blackout, a People's University philosophy professor who is under house arrest, Ding Zilin, was able to inform news agencies that she and her husband, Jiang Peikun, observed a three-day fast in memory of their 17-year-old son, who was felled by an army bullet on the night of June 3, 1989.
 
A Call to End Repression
 In a letter to the National People's Congress, she implored the country's leaders to reflect on the age and the innocence of the students who died.
Speaking of her own son, she asked, "Is he not even allowed to have on untainted spot in which his spirit can rest?"
Professors Ding and Jiang were among the seven intellectuals who signed a petition in March calling on Communist Party leaders to end political repression, a call that the leadership answered with a greater clampdown.
An Asian diplomat who was touring Tiananmen Square today by car so he could report back to his Government stopped a reporter on a bicycle to remark, "There are not going to be any more protest movements in China until after Deng Xiaoping dies."
Mr. Deng, China's 89-year-old paramount leader, has refused to reconsider an official Government verdict that branded the demonstrations as "counter-revolutionary rebellion."
Repression in China today is also related to anxiety in the Communist Party hierarchy over inflation, growing unemployment, corruption and crime, which are threatening to undermine national stability and therefore party rule.
Tonight, as the anniversary ended, the only comment from a pedicab driver seeking a fare near the square was, "For us Chinese, how pitiful is this history."

HEADLINE: Papandreou Barks Less This Time

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATHENS

 BODY:
When Andreas Papandreou was Prime Minister through most of the 1980's, he made Greece the odd man out in the Atlantic and European alliances.
With his anti-Western Socialist oratory and friendships with people like Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who imposed martial law on Poland, Mr. Papandreou seemed to go out of his way to offend fellow NATO members and the European Community. 
 The United States was his particular target, and Washington responded by cooling its long friendship with Greece. Although Mr. Papandreou had spent more than 20 years in the United States and had become a citizen, served in the Navy in World War II, taught at many universities and served as chairman of the economics department at the University of California at Berkeley, he was not invited to Washington during his eight years in office.
 
Concern in the West
 When a convincing election victory of his Pan-Hellenic Socialist Movement returned him to office last October, after four years of the conservative Government of Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis, concern ran high in Western capitals.
But Mr. Papandreou has established himself in Western eyes as a better ally and better European. "It's the dog that didn't bark," a senior Western diplomat said.
Mr. Papandreou's first official visit to Washington, in April, crowned Greece's readmittance to full partnership. His meeting with President Clinton produced no progress on issues of mutual concern -- Greece's embargo on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, its warm relations with ostracized Serbia and Turkey's continued occupation of northern Cyprus -- but an informed official said that the two leaders enjoyed getting acquainted, and Mr. Papandreou emphasized his pleasant memories of the United States.
"He was anxious to draw a line under that period," the official said, recalling Mr. Papandreou's earlier Prime Ministership.
 
Critique From Opponents
 In Athens, Mr. Papandreou's opponents write off the visit as a failure because he did not win American support for demands that Macedonia change its name, which Greeks consider their exclusive property, nor did he win stronger American support of Greece's position regarding Turkey.
Greek politics remain intensely personal. An old-fashioned political spoils system has led to widespread replacements of senior civil servants and top managers in the large state sector of industry.
And just as Mr. Mitsotakis began court action against Mr. Papandreou, charging misdeeds and corruption in office (a court acquitted him), Mr. Papandreou has retaliated. Mr. Mitsotakis stands accused of misappropriating antiquities for his private collection, tapping opponents' telephones and corruption.
But there is little debate on issues of state. Mr. Papandreou has inherited the rundown economy he passed on to Mr. Mitsotakis. Under his Government, which spends more and privatizes less than the previous one, the national debt has risen to more than 150 percent of the gross national product. Under the rules of the European Union, which is Greece's main source of economic support, indebtedness must not exceed 60 percent of G.N.P.
The Government has not spelled out an economic program, and because of its own poor economic record, the New Democracy Party, which formerly ran the country, has not stimulated much public debate.
From the right and the left, surprisingly, criticism strikes a similar note. It concentrates on inaction, owing partly to Mr. Papandreou's age, 75, and frail health. "All ministries seem to be at a standstill," said Virginia Tsouderou, Deputy Foreign Minister in the Mitsotakis Government. "It's an orchestra without a maestro."
"The country is tired of the old faces. There is a disgust with all politicians. We also didn't inspire the people," she said.
Leonidas Kyrkos, who for many years led the anti-Moscow wing of the split Communist Party, said: "What Andreas started, Mitsotakis completed. Now there is more disillusionment. It is not like Papandreou I. The people are extremely tired and have turned their back on politics."

HEADLINE: GIULIANI IS MOVING TO LIMIT AWARDS WHEN CITY IS SUED

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
With juries finding New York City's pockets nearly bottomless, the Giuliani administration is moving to make it harder for people to sue the city.
This year, the city estimates it will pay out $262 million to settle lawsuits and other claims, a figure that has doubled in seven years. That amount could be cut by a third, officials reckon, if Albany enacts a package of proposals that would put such cases in the hands of judges rather than juries and would limit awards for pain and suffering. 
 But opposition has been swift and furious among personal-injury lawyers, whose fees would be cut in the process, and from consumer-protection groups, who say the city should not balance its budget at the expense of those it has injured.
Many efforts by earlier administrations to curtail awards were unsuccessful. This time, proponents see several factors making action more likely: anti-lawyer sentiment, the city's budget difficulties, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's support for one major change, the switch from jury trials.
"As we get beyond the budget, tort reform will be one of the administration's three or four major objectives for the summer and the fall," said Forrest R. Taylor, a spokesman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Among the proposals are a medical-expense threshold of $5,000 before a person can ask for damages based on pain and suffering and a cap of $250,000 on such damages.
Paul A. Crotty, the Corporation Counsel, said 39 other states, including New Jersey and Pennsylvania, had adopted similar and even more restrictive liability laws against public entities.
Other proposals include barring anyone who is injured while committing a felony from suing the city. The city also wants to make owners of commercial buildings and apartment houses maintain sidewalks and also share legal responsibility for costly slip-and-fall cases.
Compensation for lawyers would drop, too: as award dollars rose, the percentage of a lawyer's fees would shrink. That has been the compensation schedule for private and public medical-malpractice cases statewide since the Legislature approved the change in 1985. In other cases, lawyers typically collect about 33 percent of an award, regardless of the size.
Budget planners estimate that if all the proposals were adopted, the city would immediately save $87 million in 1995. But anticipating that only some will survive, they have figured $45 million in savings in the 1995 budget.
Critics of the proposals challenge the notion that lawsuits filed against the city deserve exemptions not available to private defendants. But Mr. Crotty said the system was so out of hand that it was draining money from services like parks and libraries, which benefit the public as a whole but have a combined budget of less than the fund to settle lawsuits.
But the city has been vulnerable to higher verdicts than either private defendants or even New York State. Russell F. Moran of The New York Jury Verdict Reporter, who studied verdicts in civil cases from 1987 to 1993, found that when New York jurors delivered a verdict against a private defendant, the average award was nearly $1.5 million. When the defendant was New York City, that average rose to $2.6 million. (Jury verdicts are often reduced on appeal.)
The discrepancy between awards against the city and those against the state is equally striking. While city lawsuits are heard by juries, lawsuits involving the state are decided by a judge. From 1987 to 1993, Mr. Moran said, a judge's average award against the state for a knee injury came to $175,271. But city juries considering similar lawsuits gave plaintiffs an average of $442,536.
The drumbeats for and against the measures are just beginning. Assemblywoman Helene E. Weinstein, a Brooklyn Democrat who heads the Assembly's Judiciary Committee, has already expressed the Assembly's traditional resistance, while State Senator James J. Lack, a Suffolk County Republican who is her equally influential Senate counterpart, supports some of the proposals.
But enthusiasm for the package does not necessarily rise and fall along party lines. Senator Lack has introduced a bill similar to one proposed this year by Governor Cuomo: that city cases be heard by a judge, not a jury. That is how lawsuits against New York State have been conducted since 1929.
"The cities shouldn't be discriminated against," said Victor A. Kovner, who, as the Dinkins administration's Corporation Counsel, campaigned unsuccessfully for similar measures. "If someone is hit by a city car, why should they be treated differently than someone hit by a state car?"
Those favoring a switch to judges say that those trials move more swiftly than jury trials, and that judges are less susceptible to heart-wrenching pleas for additional compensation for pain and suffering.
And having judges hear the cases, proponents say, will bring a consistency to the awards, which now vary wildly depending on the borough. In a study for The New York Law Journal that looked at a decade of personal-injury verdicts against the city as well as private defendants, The New York Jury Verdict Reporter found, for example, that a Bronx jury puts the value of a herniated disc at $740,000, while the same injury in Queens goes for the comparatively bargain-basement price of $502,000.
But to plaintiffs' lawyers, the move to trials by judge signals the beginning of the end. The actions of a city should be judged by its citizenry, they contend.
Assemblywoman Weinstein said that rather than depriving a plaintiff of the right to a jury trial, the city would do better to support changes in the jury system proposed this year. Under the proposals, professionals and business owners would be compelled to do their jury duty, and the pro-plaintiff bent of some juries might be altered. "The city might not find itself facing only jurors who are out to get the city," she said.
 
Re-evaluating Pain
 The proposals that provoke the most anger from trial lawyers and consumer groups are the caps on damages for pain and suffering. In contrast to straightforward damages like medical expenses and lost wages, pain and suffering is a broad category with fuzzy edges.
"To a large extent, pain and suffering is a make-believe injury," said Mr. Crotty, the city's Corporation Counsel, who went to Albany last month to promote the proposals. "It is more attributable to the lawyer's ingenuity than anything else."
But Pamela Gilbert of Public Citizen, the national consumer group founded by Ralph Nader, called such initiatives "harsh and heartless and mean-spirited." Often, she said, awards for pain and suffering are more important to the plaintiff than awards for economic losses.
Under the Mayor's plan, she said, a corporate executive would get more money than someone with the same injury who was poor or elderly. Although an elderly man and the executive might get the same maximum of $250,000 for pain and suffering, the executive's total verdict would be higher because he would be reimbursed for his lost wages.
"You're balancing the budget on the backs of the most devastated people," she said.
In the same vein, said Stephan H. Peskin, the president of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, the requirement that a plaintiff have at least $5,000 in medical expenses before seeking damages for pain and suffering shut out many people.
And the city could be doing a lot more to prevent injuries, some lawyers say. "There are gaps between the platform and the train at the Union Square station," Mr. Peskin said. "But how many times do people have to get injured there before the transit system fixes it?"
 
Incentives Toward Prevention
 But unlike the cattle-prod effect that big judgments have against, say, automobile manufacturers, city agencies that are sued do not have the same incentive to clean up their act -- to repair potholes and sidewalks, or to train police officers not to use excessive force.
Part of the reason is that the money to settle lawsuits -- $220 million last year, up from $120 million in 1987 -- comes out of a general judgments fund, not from the budget of the agency that is challenged. Mr. Crotty said he and city budget planners had begun talking about having the agencies themselves administer judgment funds. Lawyers have also been resistant to the Mayor's plan to trim their fees. Personal-injury lawyers are paid only when a verdict or a settlement is reached, when they typically collect a third of the award. But in 1985, the Legislature changed the collection schedule for medical malpractice cases so that the percentage of the fee would decline as the award rose.
Many lawyers saw the new fee schedule as a disincentive to take shaky or small-judgment cases. In 1985, there were 653 cases brought against the city's doctors, hospitals and clinics, according to the New York City Law Department. But by 1993, that number had dropped to 411.
"We get the same telephone calls from clients now as then about what is happening to them in city hospitals," said Philip M. Damashek, a prominent plaintiffs' lawyer. "We feel sorry for them. But we can't help everyone where we can't receive a fee to stay in business for the months and years that it takes to pursue a case against the city."
Now the city wants to extend the same graduated scale to all cases against it. For judgments of more than $1.25 million, for example, legal fees would fall to 10 percent.
While the city's campaign for change is still in the early stages, some predict that in these lean and mean times the Mayor may prevail on at least some fronts. Peter L. Zimroth, a Corporation Counsel during the Koch administration, wished his Republican counterpart well.
"The initiatives are very important for the long-term health of the city," he said. "These cases punish the poorest people in the city because that's who the money gets taken away from."

HEADLINE: Despite Incentives to Stay, Mastercard Plans Move to Suburbs

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Less than a year after Mastercard International said it would stay in Manhattan, it is considering moving most of its 450 New York employees to the suburbs.
No announcement is to be made until the annual board meeting on July 15. But the huge credit-card association has looked at nine office buildings in White Plains, and in Stamford, Conn. It has also shown nearly a dozen potential sublet tenants, including two big financial-services concerns, through the nine floors it has leased at Burlington House, 1345 Avenue of the Americas, at 55th Street. Mastercard had planned to begin moving into Burlington House next May. 
 Mastercard would probably retain the top two floors and keep about 90 employees in New York.
An internal memo dated May 12 and faxed to The New York Times by an angry employee on Friday projected Mastercard's cost of staying in New York City at $505 million in the next 22 years. A move to the suburbs, it said, would save at least $241 million, probably closer to $273 million.
Mastercard estimates that 33 percent of its employees would leave if it moved to White Plains, according to the memo. A move to Stamford would cause 39 percent to leave, it says.
No employee would talk on the record, citing fear of retribution. But many say they are furious. "We bought a house, and several of our colleagues bought Manhattan co-ops," said the wife of one senior manager. "How can they expect my husband to trade an hour's train ride for a 100-mile car commute?" Her husband is job-hunting, she said.
H. Eugene Lockhart, who took over Mastercard's presidency when Alex W. (Pete) Hart left in February, said he had been working closely with an employee support group to see how he could reduce attrition figures from the projected levels.
F. David Brangaccio, the senior vice president who generated the employee memo, said Mastercard would offer a generous relocation and home-resale program.
Mastercard would lose the tax breaks New York City gave it to stay. But those totaled only $2 million in 20 years at Mastercard's current staffing level, and a maximum of $8 million if it doubled its work force.
Lower rents in suburbia would more than make up that cost. Real-estate brokers say prestigious space that costs nearly $40 a square foot annually in Manhattan costs less than $20 in Westchester or Stamford.
"Combine that with lower taxes and utility rates, and they'll save a fortune," one real estate broker said.
Mastercard would probably be able to sublet its Manhattan space at a profit. Real-estate brokers say Mastercard got an excellent deal at Burlington House, with annual rents in the range of $30 to $40 a square foot, with an ample period of free rent, and with the landlord paying nearly $60 a square foot to customize the space.
One clear loser if Mastercard moves is the New York economy. A year ago, the Dinkins administration estimated that retaining Mastercard would yield $81 million from taxes and related business expenses in 20 years. If Mastercard doubled its staff to 900, the boon was estimated at $176 million.
"Mastercard hasn't said they are moving," said Catie Marshall, a spokeswoman for the New York City Economic Development Corporation. "So as far as we're concerned, we still have a deal."

HEADLINE: Competition and Telecommunications

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "AT&T, MCI, Sprint: Cozy Competitors" (Viewpoints, May 22), Kenneth G. Robinson would have us believe that the long-distance business isn't competitive and that the best hope for long-distance customers is competition from local phone companies.
Mr. Robinson wants us to believe that the regional Bell operating companies, currently limited to local service, would bring down long-distance prices if only they could get into that business. He has trouble coming to grips with the fact that long-distance prices have been falling and local rates have been rising since the businesses were separated 10 years ago. 
 Long-distance service is competitive, and local service is a monopoly. Have you ever tried switching local service companies? Don't bother. But 16 million consumers, an average of 44,000 a day, switched long-distance carriers in 1992. And there are plenty of long-distance companies to choose from: 420 in all.
A 1993 study by the Stanford University economist Robert Hall found that inflation-adjusted revenue per minute for the largest carriers fell by 66 percent between 1985 and 1992. After a long period of price cuts, recent years have seen some increases in basic long-distance rates. But long-distance companies have been offering bigger and bigger discounts. Mr. Robinson argues that when one long-distance company raises its price for selected services, the others tend to follow. But the same trend applies when one company lowers its prices.
The bottom line is that allowing the regional Bell operators into long distance before establishing competition in local service would have serious negative consequences for the American economy and American consumers.
 
RAY MARSHALL
Austin, Tex., May 24
 
The writer, Labor Secretary in the Carter Administration, is a consultant to the Competitive Long Distance Coalition.

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Honda Accord Station Wagon;
Good for People, But Not for Bureaus

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
TWO of my lesser charms, or so says my wife, are that I am a pack rat and that I am occasionally lazy. As usual, she is half right.
It is true that the last thing I threw away was a water bill from 1959. But I am lazy on more than just an occasional basis, a fact reflected by the bottles and cans that fill one of the rooms in our basement. 
 My town requires recycling, so the plastic liters and tin cans pile up, awaiting a trip to the machines that go kachunk-kachunk and spill out a pitiful amount of change for all the time one needs to spend.
On the other hand, when Honda comes up with a new series of its Accord station wagon -- the second in Accord's history -- and when that wagon appears in the driveway, it is a good time to circle the flagons.
So I loaded those bags of bottles and cans into the maroon test vehicle, a rounded and fairly wonderful example of today's Japanese intrusion into the American automobile scene.
Intrusion is not right, of course, since all of the Accord wagons are built in America, and the Accord has been one of the more popular export models to Japan and Europe.
The $21,720 test car, with front-wheel drive and four doors, like all new Accord wagons, had blackout trim around its windows, and was a fully loaded model. For '94, the wagon is available in two levels, LX and EX, and both have 2.2-liter four-cylinder engines with four valves per cylinder.
There is a difference, though. The LX makes do with 130 horsepower, while the EX -- with a different valve configuration -- puts out 145 horses. Dual air bags are standard, and both wagons meet the 1997 Federal standard for side-impact protection. Anti-lock brakes are standard on the EX and optional on the LX, which has a base sticker price of $18,180.
The tester rode on 15-inch wheels and had bumpers that should suffer no damage from a five-mile-per-hour thump. Up front, the sloping hood leads to a body that is far more rounded than in the past, with a narrow grille, a black air dam and body-colored bumpers that blend well into the station wagon's body.
A remote entry system is standard on the EX, as are most of the niceties, the only option being an $87 set of floor mats. Also standard are power door locks, power side view mirrors and a rear windshield wiper and washer.
Inside, there was gray cloth and vinyl, nicely done as always. Unfortunately, and especially at the price, power seat adjustments were missing as they generally are on Hondas, although there was an electrical adjustment for lumbar support.
In back, and surprising given the vehicle's relatively small size, there was good room. In fact, the Accord delivers well on its promise of five-passenger family value. Headroom is not great, mind you, but the station wagon does offer both reasonable comfort and carrying capacity.
For the driver, there is a dead pedal for the left foot, and a four-spoke vinyl steering wheel with cruise control buttons between the two right spokes. The two main gauges are a 140-mile-an-hour speedometer and an 8,000 r.p.m. tachometer, with other gauges for the temperature of the engine and the amount of gasoline in the tank.
A toll-change bin is off to the left of the steering wheel, handy as usual.
Less useful is the ashtray (my notes say "dumb") in front of the shifter, whose lever works the standard five-speed manual. Also in the center console is a covered dual cup holder, but the interior designers might as well not have bothered. It is too small, barely holding a can or a cup.
Otherwise, the interior is well done, nicely finished and with grab handles for everyone but the driver. Adjustable seatbelt mounts are convenient, and there is a lighted mirror in the passenger's sun visor, always an indication of luxo-thought on the part of a car's designers.
The passenger air bag is mounted in the top of the dash, and that allows for a glove box underneath, although it winds up being a narrow bin.
Outside, the heavy hood has to be lifted manually and propped up on a rod. In the case of the EX, the sideways mounted engine utilizes Honda's VTEC technology, which varies the lift and duration of the valve opening to make the car's power plant a freer breather.
On the road, the Accord wagon is much of what you want it to be, although the tires sound sharply with every expansion joint. Nevertheless, the car is tight and quiet, a compact and capable hauler that feels a lot like its sedan counterpart.
Unlike a sedan, though, the wagon offers a great deal of room behind its one-piece hatch, which rises on gas struts. Liftover is at bumper level, and the 60-40 split rear seats fold flat with the push of a button.
The rear wheel housings do intrude, and that is unfortunate. Also, the roundness that makes the new Accord wagon so attractive does have its drawbacks. You can't carry bureaus or other square stuff, and if that is part of your plan, then you will do better to look elsewhere.
On the other hand, if you have a basement full of bottles, the Accord is just your meat. In my case, too, the wagon full of containers brought me return deposits of $10.10 -- and my wife now thinks I am a can-do guy.
 
INSIDE TRACK: Honda's '94 Accord wagon is sleek, quick and easy to park. It is small and economical, but some active families may find that its lack of girth pinches more than pennies.

HEADLINE: Beyond Supermarkets: A Shopper's Guide

SERIES: Less Than Super: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
SITTING in a building in Park Slope, labeling blood oranges with stickers declaring them organically grown, Marsha Lindesay is making a grocery-political statement. So are Willie Jackson, a self-described "low-budget person" pushing a shopping cart through a warehouse hard by the Hudson in Harlem, and Anthony Liveridge, so passionate a devotee of the city's Greenmarkets that he actually tends to use the words "shopping" and "pleasant" in the same sentence.
New Yorkers love a tirade, especially about something as basic as food shopping: how crowded their supermarkets are, how messy they are, and above all, the prices they charge. And still they shop there, largely because the stores are so close by, but also because they feel they have no choice. 
 Yet each in his or her own way, Ms. Lindesay, Mr. Jackson and Mr. Liveridge -- along with many thousands of compatriots -- have declared that they do, in fact, have food-shopper's free will, that they are prisoners of the supermarkets no more.
Granted, New York, cramped and vertical New York, doesn't have much in the way of the super-supermarkets and Brobdignagian discount price clubs that the supermarket industry, eager to befriend the American consumer, has been building around the country in recent years. But throughout the city, in forms that have evolved according to the peculiar geography and psychology of New York, a growing network of alternatives does exist. (Admittedly, most don't sell everything; they are not about to put the supermarket industry out of business.)
There are food co-ops, where membership fees and volunteer labor buy democracy and organic (and often bargain-priced) groceries. There are the Greenmarkets, where the produce is farm fresh and the ethos is farm friendly. There are city versions of discount warehouses, where prices on many items are lower than in the neighborhood supermarket or specialty food stores. And there are ways of shopping without setting foot in anybody's store: over the telephone, from stores that have specialized in this kind of service for years, and from farms just getting into the business.
All of these alternatives are a response to New Yorkers' almost primordial unhappiness about their supermarkets, a feeling underscored by a New York Times computer analysis of regulatory and industry data, as well as an informal survey of markets in five city neighborhoods.
The analysis, published last week, found that many city dwellers lack the choice, comfort and variety that big chain stores can offer. Such stores are concentrated in the wealthiest neighborhoods, primarily the Upper East and West Sides, while stores in poor neighborhoods tend to be small and less well-stocked. And many city stores have a lack of creature comforts and modern technology; only half had electronic scanners, and many had aisles blocked by cartons. More than half the city's supermarkets failed state health inspections on the first round.
To the supermarket industry, the alternatives are not much to reckon with, said Howard Tisch, president of the Metropolitan Food Council, a trade organization.
"They are a competitive factor, but I don't think it's anything that's going to threaten the long-term viability of the industry," he said. Asked about the alternatives' generally consumer-friendly nature, he added: "Our stores certainly try to do that, too."
All of the alternatives share some basic business tenets: lowering prices by eliminating the middleman, and giving people a feeling that their wishes can call the shots.
And then there is the usual city-dwellers' willingness to go out of the way for things that people in most places take for granted.
"It's so pleasant to come here, for the people," said Mr. Liveridge, who traveled to the West 57th Street Greenmarket from his home on the Upper East Side. "They add flavor, character even, to the vegetables."
 
THE CO-OPS: TAKING 'CONTROL OVER THE FOOD SUPPLY'
 Back in 1973, when people talked a lot about acquiring what Joe Holtz calls "control over the food supply," not to mention saving money, Mr. Holtz and a dozen of his neighbors took over a community-center closet and formed the Park Slope Food Co-op. Today, when people talk even more about saving money, the co-op is more than 5,000 members strong and spills across more than 5,000 square feet in its own buildings at 782 Union Street.
They may sound like relics of the 60's, but food co-ops are thriving, and growing, as alternatives to supermarket shopping in the 90's. The National Cooperative Business Association says requests for informational books and videos it publishes have surged this year, with 1,000 through May, compared with 1,500 for all of last year.
"In hard economic times, co-operatives tend to grow," said Leta Mach, the association's spokeswoman, noting that while many co-ops begun in the 60's failed later, the recent incarnations are more businesslike.
At the Park Slope co-op, everything still seems to be done in the collective spirit. Mr. Holtz, though he looks like the person in command, is actually one of six co-managers. Shoppers are the workers are the managers.
The vegetarians predominate, and spanking clean produce, much of it organic, is clearly a priority, but the co-op also carries such supermarket standards as chick-
en, Kix cereal and a shelf full of Pepperidge Farm
cookies. There is no red meat, though, and no diapers. Members can request certain items, but in this super-democratic system, the others have to vote to carry them. (Steak has not come up yet, but Soy Boy Not Dogs won in a landslide.)
Prices on most items are fairly low, though organic produce is almost always more expensive than supermarket produce. The food is labeled with one price -- essentially what it costs wholesale -- and a 20 percent markup is added to most items at the checkout aisle.
On a recent visit, a bag of Terra Chips, the potato-chip alternative that usually retails for $4 and up, cost $2.81. A five-pound bag of Eastern potatoes was $1.76, compared with an average of $2.09 in Manhattan stores in The Times's informal survey, and $1.43 for stores outside Manhattan.
The co-op has paid workers, but by and large it is the members who make the show go. In addition to paying a $100 deposit for inventory and other capital expenses, they must perform about three hours of service every four weeks, from checking identification cards at the entrance (only members are welcome) to mopping floors to watching toddlers in the store's child-care center. The penalty for skipping a shift is two makeup shifts. In the last few years, membership has grown an average of 17 percent annually, Mr. Holtz said, while sales have expanded by 20 percent, to an annual $7.2 million.
Among the members working the other day was Ms. Lindesay, who lives in East Flatbush. She was part of a team assigned to label blood oranges with stickers declaring them organically grown.
"I don't shop there," Ms. Lindesay said of her neighborhood. "I can't get white cheddar cheese there, or all the cheeses you can get here."
All co-ops start small; some stay that way. Beth Steinberg, a mother of two who lives in Boerum Hill, founded a co-op of her own with five neighbors six years ago. They order and share a minimum of $350 worth of food, paying wholesale prices, from a Pennsylvania company.
"We're trying to keep it fairly mellow," Ms. Steinberg said. "I tell people to try to organize one on their own blocks."
One organization, the Hudson Valley Federation of Food Cooperatives, reachable at (914) 473-5400, offers advice on how to set up food co-ops and can refer people to existing ones near them. Bruce Meltzer, the company's marketing director, said about 60 percent of its food is sold to co-ops similar to Ms. Steinberg's, also known as buying clubs; the minimum order is $400. In a bow to technology, the company will send free software to anyone who wants to scan price lists and place orders by computer. Additional information is available from the National Cooperative Business Association in Washington, at(800) 636-6222.
 
THE WAREHOUSES: ALMOST WHOLESALE
 About 35 miles east of midtown Manhattan, in Westbury, L.I., stands the gleaming Price Club discount warehouse, where shoppers load their carts with behemoth cans of tuna, entire cases of soft drinks and 10-pound bags of onions displayed minimalistically across 110,000 square feet.
This is what America has lots of, New York's suburbs have a smattering of and the city lacks entirely: the vast warehouse stores that offer deep discounts on many foods, as long as you're willing to buy 24 bottles of ketchup at once.
But while zoning restrictions, corporate uncertainty and local opposition, not to mention an endemic lack of space, have kept such sprawling alternatives out of the city for now, a couple of local permutations have sprung up in the last couple of years.
One is By Choice, visible to drivers ricocheting off the West Side Highway at 125th Street, and pedestrians trekking westward to the river edge of West 133d Street.
Dodge the people and cars veering across the unregulated intersection of the store's parking lot and the parkway ramp. Grab a chest-high shopping cart and enter the friendly fray that is the creation of Joe Fedele, a veteran of the supermarket industry who has decided that bringing meat, produce, dairy and other groceries directly to the people is the only way to play ball. With a team of financial advisers behind him, Mr. Fedele opened his doors in February.
"Nobody likes me," Mr. Fedele said of the mainstream supermarket industry, whose prices he says he undercuts by at least 40 percent. "Distributors don't like me, and supermarkets don't like me."
By Choice occupies 43,000 feet of cavernous warehouse in the old 125th Street meat district, and, along with a winking mechanical cow, it features a vast refrigerated section, where customers can borrow hooded sweatshirts against the 37-degree cold and where everything from cheese to chicken to Smithfield ham is stacked, economy size, on industrial metal shelves.
By Choice is not Zabar's in bulk. While Mr. Fedele says he tries to stock goods that will appeal to the broad range of customers he hopes to attract, and while he is planning to add more prepared foods, foodie amenities are not his strongest suit.
"We're picking up yuppies from 125th Street down, and middle-class blacks from 125th Street up, and Dominicans from the same area," Mr. Fedele said. "But you never know how to carry every product to satisfy every ethnic mix. You have to go from the gourmet coffees to the Bustelo coffees."
And he acknowledges that he has had problems attracting some elements of the public: "Most people hear we're on 125th Street, and they freak," he says.
But ask shoppers about price and they seem genuinely thrilled.
"The prices are really good, and I'm a low-budget person," said Willie Jackson, a father of two who lives on West 162d Street.
And by and large, the prices do seem considerably lower than at local supermarkets. For example, a pound of Ronzoni spaghetti cost 89 cents, less than the Upper West Side average of $1.03 in the informal market survey; ground chuck was $1.59 a pound, compared with an Upper West Side average of $2.29; a quart of milk was 55 cents, compared with an average of 90 cents on the Upper West Side. And lobsters, which weren't included in the survey, were an inexpensive $3.99 a pound.
But a 13-ounce can of Maxwell House coffee cost $2.59, higher per ounce than the Upper West Side average of $2.91 for a 16-ounce can.
Partly in an effort to overcome his 125th Street problem, Mr. Fedele has a plan to refine his concept and sell his groceries via a combination of the information superhighway and city streets: He hopes to build a database of Manhattan customers, who will be able to place orders by computer or fax and have everything delivered that night. All that, he admits, is far in the future.
A considerably more rarified rendition of the warehouse concept is tucked along a row of art galleries and specialty shops on Wooster Street in SoHo: the Gourmet Garage, less a supermarket substitute than a 2,000-square-foot heaven for the New Yorker who wants his Morbier, and his discount, too.
"In the 90's, people don't want to change their life style, just pay less for it," says John Gottfried, one of three partners who started the store 18 months ago.
In a sense, the Gourmet Garage owes its existence and its insurgent identity to Dean & DeLuca, the temple of downtown gourmet grocery on Broadway at Prince Street.
For the last 17 years, Mr. Gottfried and partners have run a wholesale restaurant-supply business, Metropolitan Agribusiness Limited, that provides produce for restaurants like Le Cirque. One of their clients (although no longer) was Dean & DeLuca, a few steps east in SoHo. One day, one of the partners realized it would be a simple matter to stock their own store and undercut the markup, and the Gourmet Garage was born. These days, store workers, from Mr. Gottfried on down, leap at the chance to recite the price differentials between, say, their white truffle butter ($4 for a two-ounce container) and the identical brand sold at Dean & DeLuca ($5 for two ounces).
Within the next two years, the partners are planning to open five more Gourmet Garages on the Upper West and Upper East Sides; next month, the original will be moving into a 5,000-square-foot space, also in SoHo. Last month, they sold their East 91st Street branch to Eli Zabar, their landlord, who has renamed it Eli's Vinegar Factory.
While the Gourmet Garage offers downtown-area discounts on jugs of extra-virgin olive oil, homemade pesto pizzas, frozen drug-free chickens from California and slabs of imported Parmesan, it remains higher on many items than Zabar's. There, Port Salut cheese was $3.98 a pound last week, compared with $5.50 at Gourmet Garage; a box of Twinings Darjeeling teabags was $2.29, versus $2.50 at Gourmet Garage.
The other day at Gourmet Garage, the tomatoes, which Mr. Gottfried insisted had ripened on their Florida stems, were summer red and $2.50 a pound, and the shoppers interviewd declared themselves happy.
"It's very convenient, and it's do-it-yourself," said Neil Layne, who works as a furniture restorer nearby. "I don't like having to go to Dean & DeLuca and ask for everything."
He selected a loaf of bread and scooped some green and black olives from a barrel waiting for people like him to wander by.
Dean & DeLuca, meanwhile, seems rather amused by the competition. "It's basically a retail store," scoffs Michael McGovern, the assistant manager. "Last time I was in there, they had lemons at 50 cents each. Ours were better, and three for a dollar."
 
THE GREENMARKETS: FARM FRESH AND FRIENDLY
 Most of the week, Sheffield Plaza is an unremarkable, mostly concrete afterthought at the corner of Ninth Avenue and 57th Street. But on Wednesdays and Saturdays, starting at about 8 A.M., the corner is transformed into an agricultural showcase, with Rome apples and morels competing with almond tarts and leafy green lamb's-quarters for shoppers' attention and money.
The Sheffield Plaza market, opened in 1987, is part of a growing and evolving Greenmarket empire that is an eloquent expression of New Yorkers' yearning for something better when it comes to food shopping.
Today there are 19 markets in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, with many of the newer ones in poorer neighborhoods (and one more scheduled to open this summer on Park Avenue near 115th Street). Greenmarket officials say some have doubled their daily attendance in the last two years. At the biggest, in Union Square, attendance has grown from 12,000 in 1992 to 20,000 this year.
The Sheffield Place market has the wholesome atmosphere of a country fair, and many of the little human dramas a city will provide. There is the strawberry farmer whose wife got a taste of city life and left him to drive a taxicab. There is the orchard owner who befriended one of the homeless people who frequent the plaza day and night, and ultimately put him on his apple-picking payroll.
And there is astonishing shopper loyalty, with tales of long treks made in search of the right bread, and farmers' cold winter days made bearable by donated cups of hot tea, and conversations interrupted by customers who can't stop themselves from endorsing, loud and clear, a particular farmer's mesclun.
"We get lovely fresh things here that you can't get in the supermarket," said Elaine Eklof, a music teacher who travels from Riverdale on Saturday mornings. "It's more appetizing, and it kind of has a European flavor, shopping like this."
There was even someone doing the reverse commute: Kathryn Shipman, a former New Yorker who drove in from Bayonne, N.J., to buy one of Charlie Rhodes's apple pies, baked for him by one of his rural neighbors in Highland, N.Y.
The whole urban-rural minuet doesn't always mean bargains. A price survey conducted last year by the Greenmarket organization found substantial savings on some products, like corn (31 percent cheaper than a supermarket average) and apples (29 percent). But it also found that some items cost more, like tomatoes (12 percent) and potatoes (10 percent).
The city's Greenmarkets are also being used to encourage better nutrition among poor families. People enrolled in the Federal nutrition program for women, infants and children can receive $20 a year in farmers' market coupons, which can be redeemed only for fruits and vegetables, not baked goods or jams, said Robert A. Lewis, who supervises the program for the State Department of Agriculture and Markets. Many farmers also accept food stamps, and give people tips on how to cook what they buy, Mr. Lewis said.
To build upon that, a nonprofit organization called Public Market Partners has been trying to set up farmers' markets in low-income neighborhoods. The first opened last July, at 162d Street and the Grand Concourse in the South Bronx, and the 115th Street market is to open next month, said Hillary Baum, the group's president.
"We saw it as an opportunity to attract farmers to the South Bronx," she said. "They were less reluctant to come once they knew about the coupons."
 
SPECIAL DELIVERY: JUST STAY HOME
 And then there are those New Yorkers whose solution to the supermarket problem is simply to stay home.
Through a program known as Community Supported Agriculture, one farmer in the upstate town of Claverack divides his produce among about 400 families, 175 of them in the city or just outside. It began when Jonathan Hilton, the former administrator of the city's Anthroposophical Society, which is dedicated to the work of the Austrian philosopher Rudolf Steiner, met Jean-Paul Cortens, a farmer who shared his ideal of city dwellers having a close relationship with growers.
The first season was five years ago, with 55 families participating, and now there are 175 families. "It provides a real human connection with the source of your food," Mr. Hilton said.
Every spring, Mr. Cortens collects payments of $250 each from the city families. Starting in June and continuing through the autumn, he pays them back with produce he drives to the Church of ST. Paul and St. Andrew at 86th Street and West End Avenue on Thursday afternoons.
Other farmers participate in the program as well; information is available at (800) 516-7797.
Another source, one that requires no prepayment, is the American Family Farm, which sells mostly New York and Connecticut-grown products. By calling the 2-year-old Amenia, N.Y., company at (800) NY-FARMS, New Yorkers can arrange for delivery of bottled milk and other dairy products, fresh and frozen meat, poultry and game, seasonal produce and condiments to their doors. The company delivers in Manhattan three days a week for a $4.75 fee (the minimum order is $25). Prices are definitely higher than you'd pay at a supermarket: $1.89 a quart for skim or whole milk, plus a $1 bottle deposit.
The farms and Greenmarkets, of course, offer only certain kinds of groceries. The ultimate escape can be found at the old-line Upper East Side markets that will do virtually all your shopping for you.
One such store is the 62-year-old Gentile's Market at 1045 Madison Avenue, at 80th Street, where about 350 people have accounts and call in their requests. There is no charge for delivery, but Anthony Gentile, the third generation of his family in the business, estimates prices are about 15 percent higher than in the supermarket.
"You would spend $85 in a supermarket for what costs $100 here, but it's an animal farm in there," said Mr. Gentile (preferably pronounced jen-TEA-lay or jen-TEAL, but often mispronounced JEN-tile by New Yorkers). "We'll get customers calling us sometimes from their boats at 7:30 in the morning, saying I'm coming in, can you send up this or that?" One customer calls from California, asking Mr. Gentile to Federal Express him cookies he can't find on the Coast.
When Mr. Gentile was growing up (he is now 43), nearly every corner had its version of the "box grocery" business. Now they are few and far between. Two others are Butterfield Market, at 1114 Lexington Avenue, near 78th Street, and Paradise Market, nearby at 1081 Lexington Avenue and 1100 Madison, near 83d.
"People like service," said Alan Obsatz, a co-owner of Butterfield, "and that's what we cater to."
Those customers, however, do know the value of a dollar. "If they're not satisfied, they let us know," Mr. Gentile said. "We have people who bring us back half a melon."

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE BEAK OF THE FINCH: A Story of Evolution in Our Time, by Jonathan Weiner. (Knopf, $25.) A fascinating look over the shoulders of biologists who watched natural selection in motion over some 20 years in finch populations.
 
BONE BY BONE: Stories, by Gary Krist. (Harcourt Brace, $19.95.) Fictions that draw, with engaging observation, the daily activities of ordinary people learning to swim in hot water.
 
THE CONFIRMATION MESS: Cleaning Up the Federal Appointments Process, by Stephen L. Carter. (Basic Books, $21.) A law professor argues cogently that the Federal confirmation process has become a monster, grotesquely unfair to nominees of both right and left.
 
D-DAY, JUNE 6, 1944: The Climactic Battle of World War II, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) What was done by and to the Allied forces (40,000 men, 5,000 ships, 3,500 vehicles) in the awesome invasion of Normandy 50 years ago, with many accounts from the grunt's-eye level; by a distinguished biographer of Eisenhower.
 
EDITH WHARTON: An Extraordinary Life, by Eleanor Dwight. (Abrams, $39.95.) This life of the novelist in whose work architecture serves virtually as a language lays special emphasis on the houses and gardens Wharton inhabited and carefully made her own; copious illustrations.
 
LEAN AND MEAN: The Changing Landscape of Corporate Power in the Age of Flexibility, by Bennett Harrison. (Basic Books, $25.) An economist's polemic against analysts who see small, efficient businesses as the models for social organization in a world of rapid change.
 
MASTERS OF AMERICAN SCULPTURE: The Figurative Tradition From the American Renaissance to the Millennium, by Donald Martin Reynolds. (Abbeville, $67.50.) A clear, readable art historian's guide, handsomely illustrated, to modern American figurative sculpture.
 
SCHOOL FOR THE BLIND, by Dennis McFarland. (Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) A deft, affecting novel whose aging protagonist retires in the vain hope that he can plan the outcome of life and decline slowly, affably toward its end.
 
SHOT IN THE HEART, by Mikal Gilmore. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Fifteen years after Norman Mailer's "Executioner's Song," Gary Gilmore's youngest brother reclaims his own life in this highly personal account of his family.
 
SPECIAL TASKS: The Memoirs of an Unwanted Witness -- A Soviet Spymaster, by Pavel Sudoplatov and Anatoly Sudoplatov with Jerrold L. Schecter and Leona P. Schecter. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A valuable book, sometimes to be read with a little skepticism, about Stalin's terror apparatus by a man who served it, written with the help of his son and two journalists.
 
A WAY IN THE WORLD, by V.S. Naipaul. (Knopf, $23.) A brilliant, probing autobiographical meditation on empire and inheritance, made of complementary narratives about characters from the author to Sir Walter Raleigh.

 CORRECTION:
An entry in the "And Bear in Mind" listing on June 5 about "D-Day, June 6, 1944," by Stephen E. Ambrose, misstated the numbers of men and vehicles landed by the Allies on the first day of the invasion of Normandy. Scholars' estimates vary, but Mr. Ambrose believes there were about 175,000 men; his estimate for vehicles of all kinds, from bicycles to tanks, is 50,000.

HEADLINE: 50 Years After D-Day, an Aircraft Industry Remade

BYLINE: By PATRICK J. LYONS 

 BODY:
AS Allied commanders prepared to retake Europe, Asia and the Pacific from the Fascist powers five decades ago, the first place they knew they had to win was in the air. The German blitzkrieg, Pearl Harbor, the Battle of Britain and Midway all demonstrated that air power, a side show in World War I, was crucial to victory in World War II.
Aviation captured the imagination of American generals, inventors, industrialists and the public alike in those dark war years, in a way few industries have, before or since. Aircraft went from being expensive toys to weapons of liberty overnight. Schoolchildren avidly studied recognition silhouettes and knew the names and strengths of dozens of planes. Pioneers of flight like Glenn Curtiss, Jack Northrop and Glenn Martin found themselves at the helm of burgeoning empires. And almost anyone who knew something about planes -- mechanic, stunt pilot, engineer, factory foreman -- could start a company and hope for a Government contract. 
 By D-Day, 50 years ago tomorrow, American factories were turning out about 250 warplanes a day, compared with 10 a day in 1938, the year before the war began in Europe. By war's end, the United States had built 300,000 aircraft, and the aviation industry was the biggest in the country by dollar volume of output.
This prodigious production was instrumental in sweeping the Axis air forces from the battlefield by the summer of 1944. Indeed, only with such air superiority could Allied commanders allow the biggest invasion fleet ever assembled to set forth toward Normandy.
But while plane manufacturers helped win the war -- and a big place in the wartime economy -- many found the peace that followed to be a dangerous time.
Aviation had already proved itself an industry of booms and slumps. After World War I, the War Department canceled aircraft contracts so abruptly that the industry shrank by 90 percent in less than a year, and many producers were forced into mergers or receivership. Civil aviation was just catching on when the stock market collapsed in 1929, causing more consolidation.
When it was clear the tide in World War II had turned, twice-burned aviation veterans started planning for peace, and persuaded the Federal Government to cut back a little more gradually this time around. Some companies went under anyway, some made fortunes or lost them pursuing civilian markets, some followed advancing technology into helicopters, missiles and space hardware, and some made a living out of the smaller but still substantial military market. But few made it as far as 1970, let alone 1994, without changes in name, ownership, management or focus -- or all four.
The end of the cold war triggered yet another round of consolidation, which culminated in Northrop's purchase of Grumman this spring. Widespread layoffs in the industry even claimed the jobs at Douglas Aircraft of a son and grandson of Donald Douglas, founder of the company, by then a division of McDonnell Douglas. Today, almost all the famous, romantic names from the skies of D-Day are drastically altered or gone.
The industry has changed in many other ways as well. Military airframe construction -- putting a plane together from components made in-house or by others -- is now a low-volume business with a handful of very expensive planes built each year, and the companies that remain often work together. Two survivors -- Boeing and McDonnell Douglas -- still have significant civil aircraft programs, though McDonnell is hard pressed to make any money at it. Two others -- the combinations of Northrop, Grumman and Vought and of Lockheed and Convair -- do business almost exclusively with The Customer, as those in the industry often refer to the various arms of the Federal Government, and with friendly governments overseas.
The chart below traces in simplified form the fates of the major prime contractors for military aircraft from World War II to today, highlighting important mergers and some famous planes along the way.
For simplicity, the chart draws a distinction between airplanes and helicopters and concentrates on planes, because helicopters played a negligible role in World War II. From a business point of view the distinction is less meaningful now. And the chart for the most part ignores the growing role and interconnectedness of subcontractors. But it gives a broad picture of the drastic depopulation of military aviation, in waves, since D-Day.

HEADLINE: Whither the Mob? 12 Defendants Plead Poverty and Ask Court for Lawyers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, June 4

 BODY:
In what experts on organized crime are citing as evidence of the Mafia's decline here, 12 of 24 men recently arraigned on racketeering charges declared themselves indigent and accepted court-appointed lawyers.
 "This says to me it isn't much of a mob anymore," said Fred Martens, executive director of the Pennsylvania Crime Commission, which monitors organized crime. "The mob isn't taking care of its underlings the way it used to. In the old days, if a mobster got arrested, the mob took care of his legal fees and his family if he went to jail. The crime family really isn't a family in Philadelphia anymore." 
Mafia families are having trouble all over the country, said Alan Ellis, a former president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers who practices in Philadelphia and San Diego.
 "The Government keeps saying they have smashed the mob, and lawyers who represent organized-crime figures have privately told me that the prosecutors are telling the truth," Mr. Ellis said. "Lawyers who once made a steady diet of this type of work are having to diversify."
 
A Leader and His Lawyer
 On March 17, Federal agents arrested virtually all of Philadelphia's top mobsters, including John Stanfa, described as the mob's leader here, and Salvatore Avena, a former deputy state attorney general who was Mr. Stanfa's lawyer. Prosecutors say that Mr. Avena was also Mr. Stanfa's adviser on mob business, including the planning of murders.
 Mr. Stanfa, Mr. Avena and 10 other defendants retained their own lawyers. All have said that they are not guilty. Their trials will probably not be held until next year.
 The other defendants, among them men who said they were a short-order cook, a deli owner and an unemployed handyman, accepted court-appointed lawyers.
 
Underbosses and Soldiers
 Joel M. Friedman, chief of the Organized Crime Division of the United States Attorney's Office here, described these defendants as a cross section of the local mob, ranging from underbosses to Mafia soldiers to associate members.
 Mr. Friedman, who has won dozens of convictions in two other major racketeering cases against the local Mafia since 1980, sees the declarations of indigency as a sign that his work is paying off, although he suggests that some defendants may have money hidden away. Judges examined the affidavits and questioned the defendants about their finances, but did not formally investigate their accuracy, Mr. Friedman said.
 The defendants were charged with racketeering-related crimes, including murder, kidnapping, extortion and arson. Three have cooperated with the Government; one has pleaded guilty and awaits sentencing.
 The primary evidence in the case came from nearly 1,800 hours of conversations that Federal agents secretly recorded in Mr. Avena's law office in Camden, N.J. In 30 months of surveillance, prosecutors say, mob members spoke openly about their activities, apparently assuming that agents would be unable to secure court authorization to put listening devices in a lawyer's office.
 Anticipating a challenge based on attorney-client privilege, prosecutors recently gave the defense attorneys 8,000 legal documents and transcripts of some of the recorded conversations supporting their investigation.
 
'He Wasn't in Any Mob'
 Hope C. Lefeber, a court-appointed lawyer, said her client, Gary Tavella, who owns a deli, did not fit popular Mafia stereotypes. "My client may have hung out with mobsters, but he wasn't in any mob," Ms. Lefeber said. "He worked hard, long hours in his deli and rehabbing houses. This guy doesn't have any money."
 Ms. Lefeber will be paid the court's standard rate of $40 an hour for preparing the case and $60 an hour in court -- less than a third of what several lawyers say are the going rates for a criminal defense here.
 Ms. Lefeber has practiced criminal law for 15 years and represented a Mafia member in a previous racketeering case, but not all lawyers who accept court appointments have that much experience. Court-appointed lawyers also face strict limits on defense expenses, including the hiring of expert witnesses and investigators.
 Crime of the sort that the Government said these defendants practiced does not pay very much, Ms. Lefeber said. "This mob case does not involve drugs, where the money is," she said. "It's about extortion and bookmaking, and that's chicken feed."
 
A Brief Kidnapping
 Prosecutors charged Mr. Tavella, 35, with four counts of racketeering, involving among other things the brief kidnapping of a rival mobster's associate, who has since fled to Italy. If convicted on all counts, Mr. Tavella faces up to $1 million in fines and 65 years in prison. Ms. Lefeber said a kidnapping charge involving the same incident was dismissed in a state court last year at a trial in which Mr. Tavella was convicted on a related charge of gun possession and sentenced to probation.
 Prosecutors said they charged Mr. Tavella after recording him discussing details of the kidnapping in Mr. Avena's office.
 Jeffrey M. Lindy, an Assistant United States Attorney here from 1989 to 1992, was appointed to represent Thomas Rebbie, 65, who listed his occupation as unemployed handyman. Mr. Rebbie, described as a mob associate, was charged with two counts of conspiracy, involving a murder and an attempted murder. He has agreed to testify against the other defendants, and Mr. Lindy has negotiated a plea agreement, whose terms have not been disclosed.
 "As his attorney, I can say absolutely that he qualifies for a court-appointed attorney," Mr. Lindy said. "He's done odd jobs for a very long time, and he doesn't have any finances."
 Mr. Friedman of the United States Attorney's Office said the indigent defendants were not just hangers-on but career criminals. Still, he acknowledged, "To the extent that one credits their affidavits of indigency, one would have to conclude that they were less than successful in their careers."

An article on June 5 about the fi nancial difficulties of Mafia defend ants in Philadelphia misstated the locations of the practice of Alan Ellis, a former president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, who spoke about the situa tion. He practices in Philadelphia and in Mill Valley, Calif., not in San Diego. Mr. Ellis pointed out the error in a letter that reached The Times on Monday.

HEADLINE: Two L.I. Film Festivals Enjoying New Stature

BYLINE: By MARJORIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
FILM makers are looking over their shoulders, panning and focusing on Long Island.
The Long Island Film Festival, opening tomorrow at the Cinema Arts Center in Huntington, may be an appetizer for the feast beginning on Oct. 19 at the Hamptons International Film Festival, said Christopher Cooke, director of the Suffolk County Motion Picture-TV Bureau and Office of Cultural Affairs. 
 With a fraction of the Hamptons budget and no direct relation to each other, the festivals promote the cinema as an art form, independent and student film makers and the industry on the Island.
Interest in filming on Long Island heightened in 1979, when New York City became a costly and complicated site to film, Mr. Cooke said. Other states formed film commissions, and Suffolk County created its under the Office of Economic Development, as an advisory board to offer regional resources to increase film and television activity.
"By 1987," Mr. Cooke said, "just after the filming of 'Wall Street' on Long Island, the Island saw its biggest boom, earning nearly $60 million from the film industry."
The chairman of the commission, Thomas J. Junor, said the county was spending $8,000 this year on the Long Island festival, double the budget of last year.
The diversity of locations -- choice scenery, open spaces and historic buildings -- add up to making Long Island ideal for the industry, he added. Warner Brothers is considering Westbury Gardens as a setting for scenes in "Batman 3," and "Moon of Honor," an independent feature by Schofield Films is before the cameras in Montauk with Edie Falco of Northport.
"By showing our support," Mr. Junor said, "we are saying to the young film makers, 'We have an industry here that can use your talent.' "
The commission is now joined by the new Long Island Film and TV Foundation to be a co-sponsor of the festival and promote year-round seminars, workshops and fund-raising events.
Mr. Cooke added: "Many of the New York film schools are producing film makers willing to do projects on a shoestring, because they can't wait to break into the system. It's become an epidemic, because there have been enough successes."
A major role model for independent film makers on the Island is Hal Hartley of Lindenhurst, who in 1991 made a low-budget film, "Simple Men," that received critical praise. In 1985, Mr. Hartley entered a short in the Long Island festival, and this year his "Amateur" was one of two American independent works shown at the Directors' Fortnight in Cannes.
Mr. Cooke said the original one-night Suffolk Film Festival was intended to be a showcase for film students, mostly from Long Island. "It has been an 11-year p.r. campaign to promote Suffolk County as a user-friendly place for the film industry, which has shown a consistently supportive, positive economic impact," he said. The event is broadening its base by changing its name to the Long Island Film Festival.
"Changing a name this year opens up the festival and also points to the importance of the independent film, as opposed to the studio film," Vic Skolnick, co-owner of the Cinema Arts Center, said. "It reflects the extended programming and is a regional showcase for new innovative works from the U.S. and, in some cases, international independent film makers."
The films to be screened represent the "Best of Fest," Mr. Cooke said, including tomorrow night's "River of Grass" by Kelly Reichardt, which was shown this year at the Sundance Festival. The Berlin International Film Festival in February presented "Criminal," directed by David Jacobson, a black-and-white "road movie" to be screened from tomorrow through Thursday night in Huntington. The film makers will lead discussions after the evening screenings.
Last October, the first Hamptons International Film Festival had a $500,000 budget and attracted 14,000 viewers to see 80 films, including features and shorts from 13 countries, in five days. Stephen Spielberg and Martin Scorcese participated in seminars.
"The Hamptons International Film Festival is poised to be a world-class festival," said Peter Glatzer, a festival organizer formerly at the Independent Feature Project in New York City and the new executive director at the Hampton series.
Many film festivals have begun in the last decade. The Hamptons "raison d'etre," the artistic director, Darryl Macdonald, said, is its educational commitment. "We heavily promote new film makers by educational programs, including $25,000 in scholarships. We are looking to the future and seeding the film-production scene for new talent to emerge."
More than 200 film makers submitted entries to the Long Island festival this year. Just the finalists -- more than 20 shorts and 8 features -- will be shown. There are three locations, Theater 3 in Port Jefferson, Guild Hall in East Hampton and the Cinema Arts Center.
"This year we have some of the highest quality films showing," said Myrna Gordon, who was a co-founder of the Village Cinema in Port Jefferson in 1986 and is a co-producer of the festival.
"By high quality, I mean in terms of production value, acting integrity, story line and artistic creativity. 'No Man's Land,' a short by Craig Shepherd, is a perfect example. These are our future film makers, the next wave."
For young film makers, successful shorts can be calling cards for features. In Europe shorts enjoy a larger market. They are commonly screened before feature films.
Mr. Shepherd, of Port Jefferson Station, is a graduate student at the New York University Film School. His short will be screened Wednesday at 9:45 P.M. and Thursday at 3:15 in Huntington. "It is a highly authentic period piece set in the 1930's, down to the costuming and vintage cars," Ms. Gordon said.
"The Suffolk Film Commission and the people of the Port Jefferson community were unbelievably generous," Mr. Shepherd said. "The Mayor shut down Main Street for six hours one Sunday for filming."
"The Last Good Breath," a short by Kimberly Ane Pierce of Port Washington, a student at ColumbiaUniversity, drew on inspiration from a trip to Japan. While filming at the Sands Point Preserve, she used an abandoned beach at Plum Point to portray a war-torn setting. The film is mythical, an irreconcilable love affair based on not only images and metaphors, but also on emotional overtones set by music and photography, Ms. Pierce said.
Bob Gosse of Lindenhurst grew up working on films with Mr. Hartley, his cousin. Mr. Gosse, who graduated in 1986 from the film school at the State University at Purchase College, was a co-founder in 1991 of the Shooting Gallery, with Larry Meistritch, a college friend.
"The Shooting Gallery is alternative space for low-budget film makers to work," Mr. Gosse said. "We have grown out of our original building and are temporarily located in Greenwich Village. But we are in the process of acquiring a larger building one that was Andy Warhol's former space."
"Handgun," a feature showing tomorrow through Thursday in Hungtin is produced by Mr. Gosse, written by Whitney Ransick and stars Treat Williams. It was shown at the Santa Barbara, Calif., International Film Festival this year. " 'Handgun' was filmed in Long Island City, where we try to create a never-world landscape to mirror the action-heist genre of the early 1970's films."
The independent film maker and the film industry have taken root on the Island. "It's a fertile field," Mr. Skolnick said. "It acts as a magnet where distributors are locating the new talent."
