HEADLINE: Efforts Revive River But Not Mohawk Life

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HOGANSBURG, N.Y.

 BODY:
The St. Lawrence River is clearer than it has been in years. Unsightly sores caused by chemicals have all but disappeared from the bellies and backs of catfish and bass taken from the river.
As Francis Jock, a Mohawk fisherman and environmental researcher, sped away from the bank in a small boat to check his nets, he listed other indicators of the river's improving condition. "The eagles and the hawks have come back," said Mr. Jock, who has spent all of his 52 years along the river's edge. "I see mink and otter again. And the fish -- they are plentiful, like when I was a child." 
 Here at the northernmost tip of New York, where the St. Lawrence River forms the boundaries of three nations -- the United States, Canada and the 28,000-acre Akwesasne Mohawk nation -- the costliest and most extensive toxic waste cleanup undertaken in the United States by private companies is beginning. The scientific and administrative lessons learned here are likely to be applied to similarly complex contamination problems in the Hudson River, the Great Lakes, San Francisco Bay, the Chesapeake Bay and the San Pedro Channel off Los Angeles, the Environmental Protection Agency said.
 
Zeroing In on a Pollutant
 The decontaminating of this busy stretch of the St. Lawrence River, which could eventually cost $500 million, is beginning to yield promising results because of several factors. The first is that PCB's, the contaminant of most concern, were banned in 1978, effectively shutting off the largest source of pollution in the river.
A second decisive action was passage of the Federal Superfund law in 1980 and an equivalent law in 1982 in New York State, which gave government regulators broad authority to compel the biggest polluters, three aluminum manufacturing plants, to pay for the PCB cleanup. PCB's, or polychlorinated biphenyls, are compounds that were used in many industrial products and processes, like the manufacture of inks and the insulation of electrical equipment.
A third factor was a decision by the tribe, the state and the Federal Government to concentrate on cleaning up a single chemical offender -- PCB's -- and not to spend years removing every pollutant. "If we had to investigate and remove every contaminant we found along a stretch of river, then we would have gotten into a situation where we would have spent decades defining the problem and done nothing to address it," said Lisa Carson, who since 1990 has managed the cleanup for the E.P.A.
The fourth decision was to leave some mildly contaminated sediments in the river instead of stirring them up with dredges.
But even as the St. Lawrence is one of the rare success stories in clearing a region of nasty wastes, almost nobody connected with the project is satisfied. State and Federal officials say PCB's are only part of the St. Lawrence's ecological problems.
Industrial executives complain that state and Federal cleanup rules are making them waste a lot of money that might be better spent on other environmental risks in the area.
Among the 9,000 Mohawks who live on the banks of the St. Lawrence, pollution has produced a wearying despair. "This stuff got into everything connected with this river," Mr. Jock said recently over the whine of his outboard engine. "It's been there a generation already. It's going to take a generation, maybe two, maybe three generations to get out. What will this do to the fish, to the animals? What will this do to our children? No matter how much money is spent, nobody has those answers."
 
Physical and Spiritual Source
 For nearly three centuries, Mohawks have lived on the St. Lawrence's high bluffs 80 miles down river from its source, Lake Ontario. Until the last three decades, the river had provided a bounty of fish and pelts. It is also a central symbol of Mohawk culture and religious life. According to the tribe's creation legend, otter, mink, beaver and muskrat helped establish the world on the shell of a snapping turtle.
In the 1960's, Mr. Jock and other Mohawk fishermen began to find that most of the catfish, carp and trout in their nets were marked by open sores. Some other species of fish they caught were twisted into hideous shapes. Otter and mink, they said, had vanished.
In the late 1970's, scientists from Cornell University who were looking into environmental problems in the region, told the state and the tribe that one cause of the deformities might be the PCB's. The authorities from New York State and the Federal Government investigated and confirmed that PCB's, through the food chain, had infiltrated the tissues of nearly every living creature in the region. Doctors even found elevated levels of PCB's in the breast milk of nursing Mohawks.
The source of the contamination was traced to the three aluminum manufacturing plants, owned by General Motors, Reynolds Metals and the Aluminum Company of America. All three companies had used PCB's to insulate and operate metal-making equipment because they are heat-resistant and nearly indestructible.
But the companies, like hundreds of other manufacturers around the country, disposed of thousands of pounds of PCB's in the nearest river -- in this case the St. Lawrence and several of its tributaries. Barrels of PCB-contaminated waste were also placed in poorly constructed pits and the chemical seeped into the river.
 
Early Federal Cleanup Site
 In 1983, the General Motors plant became one of the first sites in the country designated for cleanup under the Federal Superfund law, which had been passed three years earlier. In the following years, New York and the Federal Government split the responsibility for overseeing the cleaning of wastes from the two other plants, with the state managing the waste dumped on land and the E.P.A. managing the cleanup of PCB's contaminating the river's sediments.
Pressed by the tribe, the state and General Motors also took responsibility for protecting the health of the Mohawks and other people who fished in the river.
In the late 1980's, General Motors financed a study by the New York Department of Health to determine the level of PCB's in the breast milk of 97 nursing Mohawks. GM sponsored the study after other laboratory studies clearly showed that PCB's caused cancer in rodents and appeared to be related to an array of other effects in animals, including neurological disorders and growth abnormalities. Because of that, New York has been warning people for over a decade not to eat fish caught in the river.
The latest results indicate that people are heeding the warning not to eat fish from PCB-contaminated waters. According to Dr. Edward Fitzgerald, a state physician, a recent study showed that the levels of PCB's in the breast milk of nursing Mohawk mothers were the same or even lower than the PCB levels in a group of women from the region who rarely if ever ate fish from the river.
The study has been expanded to include the children and the male relatives of the women. Dr. Kelley Brix, a state researcher, said in an interview that the adults and the children exhibited no signs of having been affected by contamination from PCB's or other chlorinated chemicals detected in the region.
Whether exposure to PCB's from eating fish is a substantial hazard to people is a subject of fierce scientific disagreement. Most studies of human health, looking at factory workers exposed to significantly higher levels of the compounds, have not detected any strong association with unusual numbers of cancers. The Federal Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry in Atlanta is studying Indians, members of minorities and anglers in the Great Lakes region exposed to PCB-contaminated fish to determine whether the chemical can cause subtler health problems, like low birth weights, liver abnormalities and learning disorders.
 
Upsetting a Way of Life
 But such results have provided scant comfort to Mohawks, about 9,000 of whom now live on both sides of the St. Lawrence. Perhaps nowhere else in the United States has a community's culture -- from its diet to how families earn their livings -- been so disrupted by pollution.
PCB contamination essentially put the river off limits to all but occasional recreational fishing and hunting. Almost overnight, commercial fishing and guiding, once one of the tribe's most vibrant cottage industries, was destroyed. Many families turned to smuggling liquor, cigarettes and drugs across the river to Canada, tribal officials said.
Mohawk families that used to eat fish almost daily do so rarely now. Even community fish fries use store-bought fish. "Nobody eats fish anymore," said Gale Rourke, the second oldest of 10 children who said her family used to eat fish almost every night. "Now, maybe we have one dinner of fish a year."
Red meat and fast food have become mainstays of the Mohawk diet and contribute to the tribe's high rates of heart disease, obesity, diabetes and cynicism, said Dr. Benson Kelly, the Mohawk medical director.
Kenneth L. Jock, the Mohawk environmental director, said tribal leaders were unsure whether such changes in the reservation's economy and culture will ever be reversed, even if the river becomes clean enough to support a fishing and guiding industry again. "Everything has changed so quickly," Mr. Jock said. "The cost to our traditions has been very high. Our children think fish come from the supermarket instead of their father's net."

HEADLINE: Resolving a Crisis: Can Haiti Emulate South Africa?

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 5

 BODY:
They have both been governed for generations by rigid caste systems, South Africa's based solely on race, Haiti's driven by both money and skin color. Both countries have long been riven by political violence. And both have been the objects of strong international pressure for change.
But since Nelson Mandela rose to the presidency of South Africa, successfully negotiating a democratic end to the system of apartheid that choked his nation, Haitians have been watching, some envious and many fearful, wondering if this is where the similarities between their two countries end. 
 With the United States now openly pondering military action to return Haiti's elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to office, speculation among Haitians is rife over whether their country, which is perhaps as divided along class and political lines as any in the world, can muster the maturity and cohesiveness to forge a working democracy.
 
Drawing the Parallels
 No one has been more conscious of the comparisons with South Africa than Father Aristide himself. During an interview last week that lasted nearly two hours, almost every subject the exiled Father Aristide touched on brought him back to the example of Mr. Mandela and South Africa.
"President Mandela is the incarnation of the capacity to move toward reconciliation," said Father Aristide, who last month attended the inauguration of Mr. Mandela, who replaced F. W. de Klerk as President of South Africa. "But when I saw former President de Klerk, I congratulated him too, and said 'I wish we could find someone in Haiti to act the way you have.' "
But if some in Haiti's tiny elite are cheered by Father Aristide's pronouncements -- which these days are often peppered with words like "reconciliation" and calls for respect for the law -- it is clear that most of them are not. Many Haitians say that a lasting settlement of this country's long-running political crisis will be difficult to achieve, whether through intervention or negotiation, precisely because of the differences between Haiti and South Africa.
Father Aristide, many say, lacks both the organizational support and the reassuring wisdom of Mr. Mandela, both of which would be helpful in calming fears and striking workable compromises.
And Haiti's elite, long accustomed to monopolizing the country's tiny economic pie, has never learned the benefits of sacrifice or the meaning of the greater good.
"When we look at our society we find that we are lacking at both ends," said Jean-Claude Desgranges, a politically active Haitian physician.
"It is not just that Aristide does not have the maturity of Mandela, but Aristide is surrounded by a folkloric movement, Lavalas, that is poorly structured," he said, referring to the grass roots political movement whose most unifying element is Father Aristide's personal charisma.
"On the other side," he continued. "we have an archaic and mercantile bourgeoisie that has never understood the stakes for our country or the need to have a new social pact."
 
A Bad Mix
 For Haiti, many fear, the combination of the two -- a priest-president who before his overthrow in September 1991 seemed to relish the language of class warfare, and an elite that has never been willing to pay taxes or establish even minimal social services for the poor -- still seems highly explosive.
Father Aristide's standing with the Haitian masses is, if anything, as hallowed as that of Mr. Mandela. But while the South African leader has earned the grudging respect, if not love, of many in his country's white minority, for those who live a life of wealth and ease in this hemisphere's most wretched country, Father Aristide's name still conjures images of chaos and revenge.
International human rights experts say that this is largely undeserved. If the Haitian President has a long history of incendiary language, and often made provocative statements during his nearly eight months in office, human rights abuses and political violence both declined during his tenure. Since his overthrow, meanwhile, Haiti has been the scene of repeated and unpunished killings by army-sponsored thugs.
 
Few Friends Come Forward
 Still, Father Aristide's efforts at reconciliation have been seen by many here as half-hearted, at best. From the middle class, which feeds at the trough of a corrupt government, to the cream of the elite, which pulls almost all the economic strings here, fear and hatred of the exiled leader runs deep.
One of the surest signs of this is the fact that many of the paramilitary militias that have formed here in recent months are peopled not only by the easy-to-hire poor, but by the sons of the wealthy, for whom obtaining automatic weapons has become as standard as stocking up on gasoline to beat an international embargo.
"If it is true that Aristide is no Mandela, it is unfortunately true that there are no de Klerks here too," said one Haitian businessman who is one of the rare members of the elite to support Father Aristide's return. "Among my peers there is no vision. The people are driven either by fear or opportunism, and when it comes to political solutions, they will welcome anything but Aristide, even our destruction."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

CLEANING UP THE ST. LAWRENCE RIVER
At the northernmost tip of New York, where the St. Lawrence River forms the boundaries of three nations -- the United States, Canada and the 28,000-acre Akwesasne Mohawk nation -- the costliest and most extensive toxic waste cleanup undertaken in the United States by private companies is beginning. The scientific and administrative lessons learned there are likely to be applied to similarly complex contamination problems in the Hudson River, the Great Lakes, San Francisco Bay, the Chesapeake Bay and the San Pedro Channel off Los Angeles, the Environmental Protection Agency said. B8. 

NEW YORK CITY
 
BLACK HOUSEHOLDS SHOW INCOME GAINS
Driven by striking gains in the 1980's among working wives and immigrants, the median income of black households in Queens has surpassed that of whites. A fresh analysis of 1990 census results found that the economic progress by blacks in Queens, New York City's quintessential middle-class borough, was built largely on a traditional foundation of family solidarity. Married couples, whether born here or abroad, typically made the greatest strides. A1.
 
ARSONIST SETS TRAP, FIRE OFFICIALS SAY
Firefighters responding to a blaze in lower Manhattan yesterday found oil on the stairs in the building and on the fire escape ladder, and Fire Department officials said the aim was to deliberately injure firefighters. Seventeen were hurt in the fire, including one seriously. B3.
 
BOWING OUT AFTER 5 ADMINISTRATIONS
After serving in five administrations as director of the Mayor's Voluntary Action Center, Winifred Brown, 71, is retiring. The city's mayors, past and present, agree she made government run a little more smoothly. B2.
 
A PARK THAT IS NOT YET A PARK
Look at a map of Manhattan. See that inviting, leafy strip of green along the Hudson? No, not Riverside Park. Lower. Say, from Battery Park City to 59th Street. Don't see it? That is because it is not there. Except in an ad now cruising the city aboard the subway. B3.
 
GRADUATES HEAR GIULIANI PRAISE STATEN I.
Addressing the graduating class of the College of Staten Island, Mayor Giuliani extolled some of the borough's favorite sons and praised the section of the city that many considered crucial to his mayoral victory last year. B2.

A grocery store owner in Boerum Hill in Brooklyn was shot and critically wounded when he tried to shield his 18-month-old son from an armed robber, the police said. They said the gunman fled without any money. B3.

GLOVES ARE OFF IN NEW JERSEY
Republican primaries in two Congressional districts at opposite ends of New Jersey are drawing most of the attention as voters prepare to pick their candidates for scores of county and local races as well as for the United States Senate and the state's 13 Congressional seats. B6.

The long battle over New York State's $33 billion budget appeared near its end as legislators reviewed two chunks of a plan that calls for almost half a billion dollars in tax cuts, mostly for business, and programs to fix schools and build stadiums around the state. B5.
 
2 HOSPITALIZED WITH VIRULENT INFECTION
A virulent form of strep throat, similar to the kind that killed 11 people in Britain this year, has hospitalized two residents of Norwalk, Conn. The cases are the first reported in the United States this year, but officials said there was no reason to fear a widespread outbreak. B5.
 
WILDLIFE IN A BACKYARD HABITAT
Edward Drozdowski has turned his two-and-a-half-acre yard into a virtual wildlife park, with 50 pigeons, 40 birdhouses, 3 ponds and an assortment of rabbits, squirrels, frogs, snakes, geese, doves and ducks. He is among more than 13,000 participants across the country in the National Wildlife Federation's backyard wildlife habitat program. B6.

HEADLINE: Inflation Is Viewed As Stable

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
Top officials at the nation's central bank have concluded that growth in the American economy has slackened slightly and that inflation is under control, making further interest rate increases much less likely in the coming weeks.
Three of the Federal Reserve Board's five governors said they did not believe that unemployment had dropped to an alarming extent, given contradictory information on hiring that the Labor Department released on Friday along with an announcement that unemployment had fallen to 6 percent in May from 6.4 percent in April. 
 The Federal Reserve has already raised short-term interest rates by a total of 1.25 percentage points in four stages in the last four months. As a result, the interest rates that Americans pay on their mortgages, credit cards and small-business loans have climbed.
The Federal Reserve has long regarded steep drops in unemployment as one of the two or three clearest signals of an overheating economy and future inflation if the drops come when unemployment is already low.
 
 
The Economic Panorama
 In separate interviews on other topics on Friday and Saturday, the three governors said they regarded the fall in the unemployment rate in the context of other recent announcements -- like a slight fall in consumer spending and slowing sales of new cars -- and in light of other employment information released on Friday that suggested the fall in the unemployment rate might not be reliable. "We actually had a mixed week in terms of statistics -- I don't think anyone is alarmed," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, one of the governors.
The overall pattern of recent economic indicators clearly points to a slowing of economic growth and reduced risk of inflation, said Edward W. Kelley Jr., another Fed governor. "Recent data do seem to imply that is what is going on now -- it does not surprise me and does not disturb me," he said.
John P. LaWare, the third governor, noted that personal consumption spending and new factory orders have ebbed slightly and the leading economic indicators are unchanged. "They don't look like runaways to me," he said.
Such sentiments make it much less likely that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates, though this can never be absolutely certain, particularly if economic indicators in coming weeks show unexpected strength.
 
An Eye on Wages
 Mr. LaWare was more cautious than Mr. Lindsey and Mr. Kelley, warning that he would be watching these indicators closely and would be particularly attentive to any sign that wages were beginning to rise quickly enough to feed inflation.
"I don't have any real feel for what this second quarter is going to look like," Mr. LaWare said.
The Federal Reserve might also raise rates if Alan Greenspan, its chairman and most influential voice on monetary policy, decides that the fall in unemployment is worrisome. But a hallmark of Mr. Greenspan's tenure at the central bank has been his reluctance to respond to any single economic indicator, especially if it is inconsistent with other indicators.
Joseph R. Coyne, the Federal Reserve's press secretary, said on Friday that Mr. Greenspan would not comment on the unemployment figures or the economy. But he is understood to share the view that prospects for inflation are less ominous than they appeared earlier this spring.
Clinton Administration officials have a policy of not commenting on the Federal Reserve or short-term interest rates, but are likely to welcome the cautious words of the central bank's top officials. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen has said that he urged Mr. Greenspan on May 15 to signal that interest rates would stop rising after the next increase.
The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates by half a percentage point two days later while issuing a statement indicating that it had "substantially" finished its current round of rate increases. But the statement also included a sentence hinting that the Fed might move again if it thought subsequent economic indicators required a response from the central bank.
The rough consensus has been that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates again soon. But some economists, like David C. Munro at High Frequency Economics, a New York consulting company, have predicted that the Fed would increase rates as soon as last Friday or in the next few days.
Two Democrats on the Senate Banking Committee, Senator Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland and Senator Jim Sasser of Virginia, have strongly criticized the Federal Reserve for being too quick to think that the economy is in danger of overheating. They have warned that the higher interest rates might needlessly choke off economic growth.
None of the governors interviewed expressed concern that a current leveling off or slight slowing in economic growth might turn into another recession. They also contended that the last four interest rate increases were appropriate, particularly given the fall in the unemployment rate.
"I think that the 6 percent is proof that we probably did the right thing to raise rates earlier this year," Mr. Lindsey said. "I'm sure glad we did it."
 
Looking at Long-Term Rates
 Five presidents of Federal Reserve regional banks join the five governors in voting on interest-rate policy at meetings roughly once every eight weeks, and their views are less clear on whether economic growth is leveling off. In general, the regional bank presidents have tended this spring to pay more attention to long-term interest rates as a sign of whether the Federal Reserve is doing a good job fighting inflation.
Expectations of future inflation tend to push up long-term interest rates. Investors become less willing to lend money for long periods when they fear that inflation will erode the value of the money they are eventually repaid.
Though long-term interest rates remain well above last winter's levels, they have fallen by a third of a percentage point from their peak three weeks ago, suggesting that the regional Fed presidents may be a little less worried than before.
Mr. Kelley and Mr. Lindsey both have reputations within the Federal Reserve as ranking members most willing to raise interest rates early to forestall inflation. Mr. LaWare, the Federal Reserve's top expert on banking issues, has a reputation as a centrist.
 
Gauging 'Natural' Unemployment
 Federal Reserve officials have traditionally worried when unemployment falls very low because this could signal that employers would be forced to start offering higher wages to attract workers. This, in turn, could feed inflation.
Economists at the Federal Reserve and elsewhere have long assumed that a certain percentage of the nation's working-age adults will always be unemployed because they are in the process of changing jobs or have no skills that are sought. No one agrees on this percentage, which is known as the natural rate of unemployment, but the assumption has been that inflation would begin to rise if the unemployment rate dropped through this level.
Stuart E. Weiner, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo., attracted attention when he estimated the natural rate to be 6.75 percent in a Viewpoints article in the Business section of The New York Times on May 29. Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, estimated two weeks ago that the natural rate was between 5.9 and 6.3 percent.
Mr. Kelley, Mr. LaWare and Mr. Lindsey all said that they thought Mr. Weiner had picked too high a figure. Mr. Lindsey said he estimated an unemployment rate of 6.4 percent was neutral with respect to inflation but that even 6 percent might not be a problem.
"It's not like it's a toggle switch," setting off inflation as soon as unemployment falls below the natural rate, he said.
Mr. Kelley agreed. The American labor force is increasingly segmented, with some skills in short supply while others are not. As a result, he said, the overall unemployment rate is not very informative.
"The best approach may be to think of labor capacity utilization as a range of values with inflationary pressures that begin modestly at some point and then intensify progressively as unemployment shrinks," Mr. Kelley said.
Mr. LaWare expressed concern that past estimates of inflation-causing levels of unemployment may no longer be valid because the Labor Department has revised the questions that it asks in surveys to determine how many people do not have jobs and wish they did.
"They've been playing around with this unemployment number anyway," Mr. LaWare said, "so it's hard to pin it down."

HEADLINE: North Korea's Motives Baffle U.S. and the South

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 5

 BODY:
For America's allies in Asia, the imagery is a bit eerie. As President Clinton observes the 50th anniversary of D-Day, leaders across the Pacific are struggling once again to understand the motives of an 82-year-old dictator who seems to have stepped out of the grainy newsreels of another conflict and may be lurching toward a last, desperate confrontation with his old enemies.
Few believe that North Korea's President, Kim Il Sung, will deliberately reopen the Korean War 41 years after it ended. Far too much has changed since his invasion of South Korea took Seoul and the Truman Administration by complete surprise, and this time, Mr. Kim knows, China and Russia would not come to his aid. 
 But few predicted that Mr. Kim would carry his defiance of the United Nations over inspection of North Korea's nuclear complex this far. And the events of the last few days have cast doubt on the central assumption in dealing with North Korea: that the North's xenophobic leaders, desperate to prop up a sinking economy and to preserve their authoritarian Government, are willing to trade the country's nuclear bomb project for the right package of economic benefits.
 
'Somebody Miscalculated'
 "Somebody miscalculated," said a senior Japanese official who has been deeply involved in the issue. "Either it was us or it was him."
North Korea's outright rejection of the United Nations' insistence that it fully open its nuclear sites to inspection continued today. In a statement carried by the state-run news agency, the Government said: "We do not want confrontation. But we do not have the intention to meet an unjustifiable demand under continued pressure and cannot tolerate our sovereignty's being encroached upon."
It again accused the United States of orchestrating a campaign "to stifle our socialist system" and repeated its threats to abandon the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, which would end what little oversight of the nuclear program now exists.
A senior aide to President Kim Young Sam of South Korea, who is traveling in Uzbekistan, said his country was now "determined to impose sanctions against North Korea" through the United Nations.
But he said a balance had to be struck between sanctions that would make Mr. Kim "pay attention" and those that could lead to war. He said South Korea believed that China would not actively oppose sanctions, but in Washington discussions among the allies continued today about the possibility of setting a deadline for North Korea as a way of helping bring China aboard.
Perhaps no authoritarian Government has been as thoroughly psychoanalyzed and dissected over the last four decades, with less satisfying results, as the one run by Mr. Kim and by his son and the heir apparent, Kim Jong Il.
 
Few Convincing Explanations
 Years after North Korean agents assassinated half of the South Korean Cabinet and blew up a South Korean airliner, there are few convincing explanations about what the North hoped to achieve.
And this weekend there was little consensus about how seriously to take the North's warning, in a meandering statement on Friday night, that "economic sanctions would be regarded as a declaration of war."
The uncertainty about the North's endgame has revived the arguments over whether sanctions are vital if the United Nations is to retain any credibility after repeated warnings, or just a futile gesture that will do nothing to stop the nuclear project. The fear is that sanctions, no matter how carefully calibrated, would simply reinforce the North's longstanding fear that it is surrounded by hostile powers.
The Kims say so little in public, and are so sealed off even from North Korea's own closed and stratified society, that any effort to crawl into their heads is almost bound to fail. But many Korea analysts argue that the country's governing clique is haunted by the fall of East Germany.
That theory seemed to be sustained two years ago when reporters and business executives touring the North were bombarded with convoluted theories about why similar events could never happen in the Communist paradise of North Korea.
 
The Economic Situation
 The numbers, of course, suggest a very different story: South Korea, which once looked like the basket case of Asia, now has an economy 15 times the size of the North's. Every year since 1989, North Korea's gross domestic product has shrunk. Recent defectors, whose stories are sometimes enhanced by South Korea's intelligence agencies, report growing food shortages, occasional riots and continued repression.
The dire economic straits are what led many in the Bush and Clinton Administrations to believe that the bomb was a bargaining chip, a view supported by the North's grand plans for free trade zones, new factories and joint ventures with the Japanese.
But there has always been a minority view, one that seems more credible now, that the bomb -- or the ambiguity over whether one exists -- is less useful as a chip than as an insurance policy against German-style unification.
"The bomb," Andrew Mack, a Korea expert at the Australian National University, wrote recently, "offers the North a relatively low-cost strategic equalizer against its many enemies, and forces the rest of the world to take it seriously."
Mr. Mack's view seemed to be echoed in studies last year by the Central Intelligence Agency and its South Korean counterpart. Both concluded that no amount of negotiation would convince the North to abandon its nuclear project -- but also that sanctions would not prove effective.
 
North Is Isolated Already
 The North has survived for so long on so little, many experts say, that deprivation alone cannot seriously weaken the Government.
"How do you isolate the world's most isolated country?" a top adviser to the South Korean President asked a few months ago. "The truth is, it can't be done."
One complication in measuring the likely impact of economic sanctions is that North Korea publishes virtually no economic statistics. But estimates by American and South Korean intelligence agencies, and anecdotal accounts from recent visitors and defectors, make clear that the economy's slide has turned into a plummet.
According to South Korean estimates, North Korea's gross domestic product declined 5.2 percent in 1991, 7.6 percent in 1992 and, by most accounts, even faster last year. More than half of the country's factories are believed to be idle. Grain production was cut by at least a third, because of a particularly poor harvest.
After years of denying that economic troubles exist, the North conceded last December that it needed a drastic new approach. Kim Il Sung publicly abandoned his commitment to the heavy industry symbols of a Stalinist economy, announcing three new priorities: agriculture, light industry and foreign trade.
 
Three Main Trade Partners
 The last category, the one most susceptible to sanctions, accounted for only $2.4 billion last year, mostly with three countries: China, Japan and Russia. But the statistics do not take into account barter between North Koreans and ethnic Koreans across the Chinese border, and that would be virtually impossible to stop, even under strict sanctions.
Mr. Kim's public commitment to an economy that would improve everyday life led many South Korean and American officials to say the country was ready to make a deal. In fact, they said, a concession could be used to bolster the position of Kim Jong Il, who is 52 and a far deeper mystery than his father.
"If Kim Jong Il can finish off the nuclear problem, then he could do anything he wants," Koo Bon Tai, the director general of South Korea's Office of South-North Dialogue, said a few months ago. "They may not be giving away much."
Mr. Koo and other experts have argued that investment and aid, rather than sanctions, would be the fastest way to undercut the North's Government. With foreign money will come foreign ideas, they said, and while few predicted that satellite television dishes would spring up as they have in Beijing -- televisions are almost impossible to find in North Korea -- greater prosperity could spur the rise of "pragmatists" in the North Korean Government.
 
Decision-Making Structure
 "Even an autocratic country like North Korea may not have a very monolithic decision-making structure," Han Sung Joo, the South Korean Foreign Minister, said earlier this year. "There are interests we can appeal to."
This week the advocates of taking a soft line are in retreat. No one knows if the decision to defy the International Atomic Energy Agency was made by Mr. Kim himself, or was a result of a bureaucratic misreading of how far the agency could be pushed. But now, a senior American official in Asia said Saturday, the situation "is radically changed."
"Everyone senses that the North went over some invisible line when they destroyed the record of what they had done in the past with the nuclear fuel, and now they can't call it back," the official said.
But it seems likely that the natural instincts of South Korean and American officials -- not to push too hard, not to risk too much in dealing with the Kims -- will begin to kick in soon.
In the South's mind, the titanic struggle between the two Koreas is essentially over, and Seoul has won. The elder Mr. Kim, they point out, cannot live forever. No one wants the expense of reunification very soon, anyway. And despite their neighbor's hard-line words, few South Koreans seem fearful that Mr. Kim would actually use a nuclear weapon if it had one. Compared with the huge number of conventional weapons the North aims at South Korea, one or two atomic warheads seem like a marginal increase in the threat.
"Our biggest worry," one official in Seoul said, "is not to start a panic."

HEADLINE: Legislators' Agreement on Tax Cuts May End State Budget Impasse

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 5

 BODY:
The long battle over the state's $33 billion budget appeared near its end tonight as legislators reviewed two chunks of a new budget plan that calls for almost half a billion dollars in tax cuts, mostly for business, and programs to fix schools and improve stadiums around the state.
The budget was 66 days late tonight and legislative aides said the deal was not yet complete. But in a sign that negotiations were nearly over, the leaders of the Senate and Assembly unveiled for legislators their agreements on tax cuts and capital projects, including a $24 million aquatic center on Long Island and $103 million for other sports facilities. 
 The leaders expected to complete the review on Monday and begin voting immediately on the entire budget, which is fattened this election year with a $1.5 billion surplus. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said the budget as inexcusably late, but saw it as a sign that the state was on the economic rebound.
 
'It Is a Relief'
 "It is a return to the pre-recession direction of the state," he said in a telephone interview tonight from the Executive Mansion. "After all the pain of the last three years, it is a relief to be getting back tax cuts and investment."
In the agreement, the value of the tax cuts was portrayed as $476 million by the Republican-controlled Senate, but $450 million by the Democratic-controlled Assembly. The difference, aides said, did not alter the substance of the cuts, the largest of which is a three-year phaseout of the 15 percent surcharge on corporate taxes.
The surcharge, instituted during the recession in 1990, will drop to 10 percent later this year, to 5 percent in 1995 and will be eliminated in 1996. Most smaller businesses are expected to save a few hundred dollars a year, but giant corporations could save $100,000 or more.
 
Tax Credit for Families
 The package also includes a tax credit for families that earn less than $25,000 a year. The credit, phased in over four years, would be 7.5 percent of an existing Federal tax credit this year, 10 percent in 1995, 15 percent in 1996 and 20 percent thereafter. That means a family of four earning $11,000 would save $110 this year and $500 in 1997, according to Assembly esimtates.
Also included is the repeal this year of the state's 5 percent portion of the 19.25 percent sales tax on hotel rooms renting for over $100 a night, and of the 10-cent tax on every quart of motor oil.
The capital budget was $5.7 billion, $322 million more than what the Governor requested when he presented his budget in January. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Manhattan, said the plan includes an new initiative of $62 million for repairs on schools around the state. Of that, $42 million will be slated for New York City schools, though the city cannot use any of the money to close its $2.3 billion gap.
Though Mr. Cuomo had ridiculed the project as too elaborate, the budget includes a $24 million aquatic center in Hempstead, L.I. It also calls for $25 million for Crossroads Arena in Buffalo, $43 million for stadiums in Rochester and Syracuse and roughly $8 million to upgrade eight minor league stadiums.
On Monday, legislators are expected to take up state aid to localities, school aid, fingerprinting for welfare recipients and debt reform.

HEADLINE: New York City Striving to Lure Corporations And New Jobs

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
In recent years, New York City has been so desperate to hold on to companies already in the city that it handed out hundreds of millions of dollars in tax incentives to stem the corporate diaspora.
But now, with clear signs emerging that the local economy is finally on the mend, City Hall is looking outward, trying to lure companies prowling for a new home. 
 That is not an impossible dream, contends Clay Lifflander, appointed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to run the city's Economic Development Corporation, a quasi-independent agency responsible for improving the city's business climate and providing help to local companies.
 
Talking to Companies
 "We've started talking to several companies, including a big foreign food firm, about coming here," Mr. Lifflander said in an interview. "They didn't laugh at us."
Mr. Lifflander argues that the city has been on the defensive in fighting for business for so long that it appeared to concede the war was lost even before it started. "It created an atmosphere of defeat," he said. "You cannot win every retention battle, so if there's no effort to do some corporate attraction, you just end up with the perception that the city is a perennial loser."
Given the high costs and other difficulties of doing business in New York City, dozens of state and local governments both in nearby suburbs and around the country have kept busy dangling offers in front of New York companies. The latest to hear the siren song may be Mastercard International, which, despite previous tax breaks from the city, is considering relocating 450 jobs to the suburbs. It has recently looked at several office buildings in White Plains in Westchester County and in Stamford, Conn.
 
'Beauty Contest'
 City Hall does not plan to respond by going out of its way to "create dislocations" in other cities, Mr. Lifflander said, but once a company elsewhere has indicated it wants to move, "New York should be in the beauty contest -- we want a chance to make our pitch."
That is a familiar complaint these days. Echoing Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, who has similarly contended that high taxes and intrusive regulations were driving businesses out of her state, Mr. Lifflander said, "Our message is that New York City is open for business again."
In particular, the Giuliani administration believes it can attract overseas companies seeking a strong location to enter the North American market. It also wants to lure information-oriented companies in search of well-educated employees, and, outside Manhattan, large specialty retailers that have found it difficult to enter the city because of zoning restrictions.
Backing up those claims is evidence the local economic outlook has been improving for more than a year. After losing more than 340,000 jobs in the 1989-92 downturn, the city has gained back at least 50,000 private-sector jobs since the economy hit bottom at the end of 1992. More than 10,000 new jobs were added in the first three months of the year, the largest quarterly gain in six years.
Last month, according to figures released on Friday by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, New York State added 23,000 jobs, many of them in the city. Unemployment in New York City dropped to 8.4 percent in May, down from 9.5 percent in April and 10.8 percent at the beginning of 1994.
But analysts note that the cyclical upswing is more a response to a general economic expansion across the nation than to any specific local government actions. And some critics argue that the Giuliani administration's effort to attract companies from other areas runs counter to the latest thinking about the best ways to foster local economic development.
 
'Worse Than Most'
 "The landscape is littered with the wreckage of traditional economic development policies aimed at making deals with well-known companies," said Charles F. Sabel, a visiting professor at Columbia University who normally teaches at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "New York has been worse than most."
Mr. Sabel, a specialist in local and regional economic development, said the most innovative state and local governments have largely abandoned the chase for companies on the loose. Instead, they are focusing on providing specialized services to closely related businesses and helping support on-the-job training to develop the work-related skills of local residents.
Just as Grand Rapids, Mich., has followed this strategy to stimulate development of its office-furniture industry, Mr. Sabel suggested, New York City should be working on ways to help, say, the fashion industry react more quickly and become more competitive.
Giuliani administration officials respond that they too are interested in what is being called the third wave of economic development strategies. The newer approach follows the first wave of "smokestack chasing" aimed at attracting branch plants, and a second wave of government-run efforts mostly directed at small business. City Hall, for example, may provide modest incentives for an effort by the business-sponsored New York City Partnership to create a center for computer software companies in an underused office building in downtown Manhattan.
To give added muscle to the city's new development strategy, Mr. Lifflander, 31, a former investment banker, has reorganized the relatively modest-sized agency into a more streamlined operation. He created new divisions for business attraction and retention, property management and financing while eliminating and consolidating other operations.
The Economic Development Corporation, which does not operate under Civil Service restrictions, cut 25 positions but added 22 others, leaving the agency with 204 employees, Mr. Lifflander said. Some people were squeezed out, but most others are staying to perform in new roles.
 
Seed Capital
 The new financing unit, which replaces a small direct-lending program, will aim to magnify the effect of the city's limited funds. It will provide $10 million in seed capital for a privately managed venture-capital operation that officials hope to see generate as much as $135 million to support young businesses.
Support for New York City's effort to attract new companies comes from a surprising source, Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania, which spends more money on economic development programs than any other state. "New York City is still a unique place to do business," Governor Casey said in a recent interview. "They've got a good story to tell."

HEADLINE: Can E-Mail Cachet = jpmorgan@park.ave?

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
In late 1990, Alain Pinel Realtors Inc. of Saratoga, Calif., plunged into the electronic age with a vengeance. Employees were given personal computers, and when the company joined the Internet, the global web of computer networks, each worker was assigned an electronic-mail address.
Even in the real estate company's Silicon Valley home, however, the initial reaction to those addresses -- listed on business cards, and thus the outward sign of its high-tech move -- was lukewarm at best. Some agents complained that the arcane computer language -- like jones@apr.com, for example -- looked like messy typographical errors. Potential customers were puzzled. 
 In the last six months or so, those attitudes have changed markedly, said Helen Pastorino, president of the real estate agency.
"We were ridiculed before as being weird or nerdy," Ms. Pastorino said. "But now, our E-mail address is seen as being progressive and with it."
For American business, from big corporations to one-person consulting firms, the electronic-mail address is becoming not just a tool but a status symbol. The person who has one -- or better yet, several -- is instantly regarded as a card-carrying member of the information age, wired for the 90's, not some economic mastodon longing for a three-martini lunch.
But not all network addresses are equal. To the cognoscenti of cyberspace, there is a strict pecking order, all plainly visible in the alphabet soup of letters and punctuation that go into a particular electronic-mail address.
"Your Net address says volumes about who you are, about what community you hang in, and whether you're a cybersnob or a cyberhick," said Paul Saffo, a director of the Institute for the Future, a research organization in Menlo Park, Calif.
More is at stake than impressing colleagues and rivals in the corporate trenches. A rudimentary knowledge of the varied, sprawling realm of computer networks -- known as cyberspace or the Net -- promises to be a useful skill in the job market, especially as the American economy becomes increasingly dependent on information-based products and services. The Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration is preparing a course for next year on the "marketspace," as distinguished from the marketplace, based on the view that products, services, market transactions and business communication will increasingly occur in cyberspace.
"Soon, you will be regarded as a pretty lousy manager if you are not conversant with the electronic world," Jeffrey F. Rayport, an assistant professor at the Harvard business school, said. "And people who live on the Net signal it to each other by having an E-mail address."
To be sure, the social cachet of an electronic-mail address did not start in the business community and extends well beyond it. One sign of the times is "E-Mail Addresses of the Rich and Famous," a compendium of the cyberspace whereabouts of more than 900 people, published last month. The paperback, from the Addison-Wesley Publishing Company, lists people like Bill Clinton (President@Whitehouse.gov), whose network locations are well-known, and Toni Morrison, the novelist, whose electronic addresses are not.
 
'Cold Mailing' on the Network
 The book has rankled some computer-network veterans who say it violates cyberspace etiquette by publicizing the electronic-mail addresses of others. Yet even the rich and famous sometimes benefit from "cold mailing" -- a chance encounter with a stranger on a computer network.
Rush Limbaugh, the conservative commentator, whose network address is in the new book, was married two weeks ago to Marta Fitzgerald. Where did they meet? On Compuserve, a large commercial network.
Yet business people, not celebrities, account for most of the growth on the Net lately. The business use of electronic mail within companies has been common for years, but more and more companies are getting wired to the outside.
It is estimated that 20 million people worldwide are now linked on the Net, which began in 1969 as a Defense Department network intended to survive nuclear attack. Today, the Net is a generic term for some 20,000 computer networks, both noncommercial ones linking government agencies, research labs and universities and commercial networks and on-line services like Prodigy, Compuserve and America Online.
 
Cyberspace Population Boom
 Most of the 20 million participants are Americans, even as the population of cyberspace increases by 15 percent a month, estimates Martha Williams, a professor of information sciences at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. The current fivefold-a-year growth rate will inevitably slow, but a couple of hundred million people worldwide are expected to be on computer networks in five years. These days, most of the conscripts, Ms. Williams says, are from the private sector.
And they are being introduced to the byzantine rituals often associated with the use and display of the calling card of the information age: the electronic-mail address.
In high-tech communities, a network address is all but a requirement for membership these days, both in America and, increasingly, abroad. Not having one can mean ostracism. "If you don't have an E-mail address you're not worth talking to," said Robin Saxby, president of Advanced RISC Machines Ltd., a computer chip maker in Cambridge, England.
How to tell a prestigious address from a pedestrian one? Look to the right of the @ sign in an electronic-mail address. It is called the "domain," and it indicates where the mailbox is. Typically, this will be an organization, a company, a university or a commercial network service.
For example, Jane Doe, who works for Widget Enterprises Inc., might have the address: jdoe@widget.com. The domain is usually broken up into subdomains, each separated by a period. The .com is an abbreviation meaning the mailbox is in a commercial organization; others include .edu for education institutions, .gov for government bodies and .net for networking organizations.
In the cyberspace pecking order, bragging rights go to the person whose address is "closer to the Net." For example, one of this reporter's electronic-mail addresses is slohr@aol.com. This is an address at a commercial service, America Online -- that is, a conduit into the Net open to anyone willing to pay the monthly fees. It is not exclusive and not as "close to the Net" as Jane Doe, whose link to the Net is through the technologically with-it company that employs her, Widget Enterprises.
But real status belongs to those very few people whose domain name is their last name -- a direct connection to the Net, the closest anyone can get. Mark Seiden, a computer consultant in Belmont, Calif., who has a sophisticated link to the Internet through a powerful computer at home, is one of the few. His electronic-mail address: MIS@seiden.com.
"It's the ultimate vanity license plate in cyberspace," Mr. Seiden said.
Recently, turf wars have flared over rights to domain names. MTV: Music Television last month sued Adam Curry, a former host, who claimed the name mtv.com. "This is a trademark issue," said Carol Robinson, an MTV spokeswoman.
Wired, a year-old magazine of computer culture in San Francisco, took the same stance in a dispute with the Women's Wire, an on-line service for women, founded in 1992. The editors of the magazine (domain name: wired.com) felt that Women's Wire domain name (wire.net) was too close for commercial comfort.
 
'This Is Real Estate'
 "The domain name is just a brand extension," explained John Battelle, the managing editor of Wired. "This is real estate."
The dispute was settled last year after the women's on-line service agreed to modify its domain to wwire.net, figuring it could not afford a legal battle. "But we're going to see more and more of this in the future," said Nancy Rhine, a director of Women's Wire.
Cyberspace veterans have found computer networks a powerful tool of freewheeling communication, but also a daunting one. Some people get more than 100 electronic missives a day, so they have developed filtering tactics, like having several electronic mail addresses to separate business contacts, family and friends.
There are also differing schools of thought about giving out network addresses. Some people have them on business cards, others do not.
"It's not on my business card, but I do give it to people I really want to get in contact with," said Richard A. Shaffer of Technologic Partners, a consulting firm in New York.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Time Inc. Shelves a Gay Magazine

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
Time Inc. Ventures, the division of Time Inc. that develops new magazines, has decided not to proceed with Tribe, a publication aimed at gay men and lesbians.
Saying the decision was made for business rather than editorial reasons, company officials said they were too busy with the division's other ventures to devote the necessary energy to the magazine. 
 The decision raises the question of whether a large media company can successfully publish magazines that may draw criticism from its traditional advertisers. But some industry executives say the move may also illustrate the difficulties faced by middle-aged and older executives making decisions about publications devoted to life styles that are often unfamiliar to them.
"Time wants to be part of the generation shift, but the bosses don't know how to address that issue, so when it comes to making tough decisions they don't know how to address them," said a Time Inc. editor who was familiar with the situation.
 
Issue of Economics
 But the company said the decision on Tribe was simply a matter of time and money.
"For us to consider any new business proposition, it does have to be of some scale," said Robert Miller, the president of Time Inc. Ventures. "It's difficult to imagine taking on a magazine that would not make several million dollars annually in profits."
Mr. Miller said he thought Tribe might have a circulation potential of 250,000. However, no existing gay magazine has come near that figure. Out, a two-year-old gay and lesbian life style magazine, reports a circulation of about 100,000, while the 27-year-old Advocate, the nation's oldest news magazine for gay and lesbian readers, says its circulation is 70,000.
"We are discontinuing Tribe because, frankly, our plate is a little too full," Mr. Miller said. "As intrigued as I continue to be with Tribe, we are just flat-out fully occupied pursuing or looking at other ideas that are just a little farther along or projects that have a significantly larger scale as a business."
He denied rumors that there had been pressure to kill the project from the Rev. Donald Wildmon, whose American Family Association has attacked television programs with gay themes. In an interview published Friday in The Washington Times, Mr. Wildmon said that he knew nothing about Tribe and that no letter-writing campaign had been planned.
Mr. Miller said Tribe had been in the earliest stages of consideration. Although he declined to say how much the company had invested in the project, other company officials put the figure at less than $75,000.
 
Attention on Other Projects
 Mr. Miller said current magazine projects at Time Inc. Ventures included Mouth 2 Mouth, Martha Stewart Living and Vibe.
Mouth 2 Mouth, a magazine for teen-agers, published its first test issue in March. Mr. Miller described the results as "terrific," although other people in the company used phrases like "unsure" and "not a slam dunk."
A second issue will go on sale in August, but plans for regular publication are "not a definite go" as of now, Mr. Miller said.
Martha Stewart Living, which started regular publication in 1991 and has soared to a circulation of almost 750,000, is looking into a number of multimedia opportunities. The first of these, a weekly television show, is in its first year. Mr. Miller declined to say whether the magazine had become profitable.
Vibe, an urban culture magazine started in 1992, has had a more difficult time defining itself. It began as a magazine of hip-hop, a type of music that originated in inner-city black neighborhoods and was later embraced by many young white listeners. The magazine has since widened its coverage to include politics and other urban music. It reports a circulation of 200,000.
 
Question of Direction
 The focus of Vibe has been a point of dispute among its staff. What insiders called increasing tensions between its black and white staff members came to a head last month, when, according to published reports, Quincy Jones, the musician and record producer who co-founded the magazine, complained about the proposed June-July cover featuring Madonna because it represented the second month in a row that a white person would be on the cover. (The Beastie Boys had been on the previous cover.) As a result, Jonathan Van Meter, the editor in chief, resigned, saying his editorial control had been compromised.
On Friday, Vibe named Alan Light, the former music editor, as acting editor in chief.
As for Tribe, there may still be a future, according to Maer Roshan, who originally brought the idea for the magazine to Time Inc. Ventures. Mr. Roshan, the former editor in chief of QW, a gay life style magazine that stopped publication in 1992. said last week that he was "still determined to do something with Tribe."
"The gay community needs a magazine like this that is focused on readers rather than advertisers," he said.
"We are living in gritty times and they call for journalism that comes from the soul, rather than articles that consider what Calvin Klein might think."

HEADLINE: R.J. Reynolds Woos Polish Smokers

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WARSAW, June 3

 BODY:
R. J. Reynolds recently opened the first American cigarette manufacturing factory in Eastern Europe, a plant of gleaming glass and green trim set among verdant suburban fields, and said it was doing Poles a favor.
Polish smokers rank among the heaviest smokers in the world. Some surveys show they are the heaviest, preferring unfiltered cigarettes laden with coarse tobacco that gives a pungent aroma and is considered a major cause of death among middle-aged Polish men. 
In a marketing environment free of the antismoking emotion that exists back home, R. J. Reynolds sees itself in a front-line position to persuade Poles to switch to its brands.
"Central Europe is a market of great opportunity and we are able to play a positive role," said Piotr Kwitkowski, a market researcher for R. J. Reynolds in Poland. "We are able to replace something that is very harmful with something that is of better quality. It's obvious that Camel is much less harmful than traditional Polish cigarettes."
Since the collapse of Communism, the major international tobacco companies have been feverishly pursuing the Polish market for an obvious reason: An estimated 90 billion cigarettes are sold yearly in a country of only 38.5 million people. Beyond the Polish market lies easy export access to the heavy smokers in the former Soviet Union.
The World Health Organization estimates that from 1990 to 1992, adult Poles smoked 3,620 cigarettes a year, an increase from 3,400 a decade earlier, making Poles the world's heaviest smokers. Greece and Hungary followed Poland in the W.H.O. survey, with the United States in eighth position, said Dr. J. R. Menchaca, the manager of W.H.O.'s tobacco program. According to the health organization, 42 percent of adult Poles smoked in 1992, up from 40 percent in 1990. By contrast, an estimated 25 to 27 percent of American adults smoke.
W.H.O. estimates that about 80,000 Poles "are killed by tobacco" each year, accounting for one of the highest death rates from smoking in the world, Mr. Menchaca said.
 
Poles Smoke Everywhere
 Surveys show no decline in the number of Polish smokers, although health warnings on cigarette packs have been mandatory since 1992 and health warnings started to appear on print and billboard cigarette advertising this month.
Poles smoke everywhere: walking along the streets, while shopping and even in the bathrooms of public hospitals. The habit is so accepted that Foreign Minister Andrej Olechowski lights up Camels during meetings.
But R. J. Reynolds detects a trend to milder cigarettes, which it believes is a good sign for its business. In the first few months of this year, for example, Poland's cheapest brand, Popularne -- about 25 cents a pack, or a quarter of the price here of Reynolds's Camels -- was replaced by a slightly more expensive local brand, Klubowe, as the best seller.
"Klubowe is also awful but they have a filter," Mr. Kwitowski said. "Reynolds thinks this is a positive trend for them, a very slight shift to a milder cigarette that is not so smelly."
 
A $33 Million Plant
 By opening its own plant at a cost of $33 million, R. J. Reynolds bucked the path that it and the other companies have taken in Eastern Europe and it won an important round against its archrival Philip Morris. In other countries in the region -- Hungary, the Czech Republic, Ukraine and Russia -- the cigarette companies have bought often-rundown plants once owned by the state as the fastest track into the Eastern European markets.
Philip Morris bet on this approach in Poland, and hoped to buy a Polish plant in the southern city of Cracow, where the company has had a licensing agreement to produce Marlboros since 1973. But Philip Morris encountered public and political opposition to selling what was perceived as a "crown jewel" of Polish industry to foreigners.
After four years of negotiation, a letter of intent by Philip Morris and announcements by the Polish Government that Philip Morris would pay more than $200 million for the Cracow plant, there has still been no sale. "We're waiting for the Government to say how it wants to proceed," said Michael Parsons, a spokesman for the company in Lausanne, Switzerland.
 
A Government License
 R. J. Reynolds says it understood early on that, unlike in Ukraine where it bought two fairly antiquated state-run cigarette enterprises, there would be difficulties in buying one of the plants in Poland. "Due to a number of reasons we found we couldn't meet each other," said Piotr Piwkowski, the general manager of the new Polish factory. "We immediately started to go our own way and start from scratch."
In early 1991, R. J. Reynolds got a license from the Ministry of Agriculture to manufacture cigarettes and started to build its 17th wholly owned factory in the world. (The company also produces under license at 23 other factories). Through a Western executive search firm, the company found Mr. Piwkowski, a civil engineer who was the chairman of a Gdansk shipyard, to supervise the construction as well as run the plant.
"The concept was very clear, a huge market of 90 billion sticks," said Mr. Piwkowski, "and considering border taxes, you have to produce locally or you're out of the market."
At the factory in the Warsaw suburb of Piaseczno, R. J. Reynolds now controls the local manufacture of its three leading international brands -- Camel, Winston and Salem -- and has introduced a new local brand, 777, to compete against Popularne and Klubowe. At the opening of the plant, the company noted that not only the size of the market but the "lower cost of production" made Poland an attractive investment.
Mr. Piwkowski acknowledged that the $33 million cost of the factory was "not a lot" and that the wages for skilled workers were "relatively cheap." The plant, which has 250 permanent employees, will have the capacity to produce 12 billion cigarettes within two years, Mr. Piwkowski said. Capacity can grow to 15 billion, he said, which is about half the capacity of the plant in Cracow that Philip Morris wants to acquire.
The heart of the battle will be to increase the share of American-blended cigarettes from the current 8 percent of the total Polish market. "We are interested in addressing the upper end of the price segment," said Thomas E. Marsh, the regional manager for Eastern Europe of R. J. Reynolds. "Our interest is not to increase the per capita smoking but to have the people who are already smoking smoke more of our brands."
Philip Morris's Marlboro remains the most popular American blended cigarette in Poland. R. J. Reynolds estimates that Marlboro accounts for 3 percent of the market and Camel about 2 percent. But with a fairly vigorous advertising campaign dusted off from the United States -- "A Taste for Adventure" with the macho Camel man canoeing and climbing -- brand awareness has come on a par with Marlboro, R. J. Reynolds says.
But because of the limited purchasing power of Polish smokers, it is likely to be a long slog. Paying $1 for a pack of Camels is a lot of money on a monthly average salary of around $200. Tobacco company officials said they were prepared to be patient. It will be a while, they said, before a pack of foreign cigarettes stops being just a status symbol of the well-off or a splurge to make an impression on a weekend date.
In raw numbers, 1.3 billion cigarettes were sold out of the new R. J. Reynolds plant last year, Mr. Piwkowski said. The company hopes to double that number as the plant gets up to speed this year. Marlboro, according to its spokesman, Mr. Parsons, doubled its sales from two billion cigarettes four years ago to four billion last year.
In five years, American-blended cigarettes should account for 13 to 15 percent of the market in Poland.
"It's a growing economy, the standard of living is slightly improving," Mr. Piwkowski said. "But there are other needs, not just smoking a pack of Camel. Maybe improving your standard of living means smoking Camel, but maybe it means traveling to Miami."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
For banks, the bloated balance sheet is becoming undesirable.

BYLINE: By Saul Hansell 

 BODY:
AT lunch in Beverly Hills, Calif., they say you can never be too rich or too thin. In the corporate dining rooms of the nation's banks, the refrain has been you can never have too much capital.
Now, while fat waistlines may not be in fashion, fat balance sheets are becoming passe. 
 It's not that banks want their balance sheets to return to the scrawny waif-like state of the late 1980's, when capital was severely depleted by waves of bad loans to developing countries and real estate ventures. But banks now have more money than they know what to do with, so they are giving some back to shareholders by sharply increasing dividends and repurchasing their own stock.
On Friday, for example, the Chemical Banking Corporation said it would buy back up to 10 million shares, almost 4 percent of those outstanding, in the next year. At today's price, that would mean spending as much as $420 million. Chemical will also redeem $374 million of preferred stock, issuing only about $200 million in new preferred stock at a lower rate.
Other companies, including J.P. Morgan & Company, First Chicago, and Bank of New York are also buying back their shares.
Bank capital is the money supplied by investors and from earnings not paid out as dividends. Since the late 1980's, regulators have required banks to build reserves because the more capital a bank has, the more losses it can absorb before it fails.
Bank capital was drained in 1990 because of bad real estate loans. Since then, banks have raised new capital by stock sales. And as interest rates fell and loan losses receded, bank earnings soared, lifting capital to the highest levels in decades.
Investors, of course, don't want banks to be undercapitalized because it increases the risk of failure. On the other hand, having too much capital dilutes earnings.
Chemical's buyback, for example, will increase its earnings per share by about 2 percent this year, Ronald I. Mandle, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, estimates. "It's not a giant step, but it shows they are interested in enhancing shareholder value," he said.
Moreover, many investors now worry that if banks have too much capital, they will be tempted to spend it unwisely. "By returning their capital to shareholders, banks show they have their best interests in mind and will not do something foolish like making bad loans or paying too much for acquisitions," Mr. Mandle said.
Mr. Mandle recently did a study that looked at 22 banks that made the best use of shareholder capital, based on buyback programs, increased dividends, low prices paid for acquisitions and whether the banks paid for acquisitions with cash rather than stock. The top banks studied were the PNC Bank Corporation, Nationsbank and the First Union Corporation. The worst were Barnett Banks, the Mellon Bank Corporation and the Bank of New York Company. While other factors also play into stock picking, Mr. Mandle says he recommends all three top-ranked banks.
But others see problems in this view of capital.
"Capital is hard to come by, and the banks are squandering it," said Eugene J. Sherman, research director of M. A. Schapiro & Company, a brokerage firm that specializes in banks. Most banks, he said, are buying their stock at well above book value. And the banks are likely to need the capital later to pay for acquisitions and to back loans. "It is a very short-term strategy," Mr. Sherman said.
Peter Tobin, Chemical's chief financial officer, said the company had not lost flexibility because it could easily issue more shares later. Even with the share buyback, he said, the bank is likely to have higher capital a year from now than it does today, though it may consider buying more shares.
In addition, Chemical will be forced to issue more shares later because of employee stock options and possible redemptions of its convertible preferred stock. The program lets the company buy the shares it needs at what it figures is a cheaper price now.
"We think our stock is undervalued now, and there is the potential for a significant increase," Mr. Tobin said. This, he conceded, may well be a self-fulfilling prophecy. "A share buyback signals the market that you think the stock is undervalued," he said.

HEADLINE: New York City Seeks to Sell U.N. Plaza Hotel to Help Close Deficit

BYLINE: By ASHLEY DUNN 

 BODY:
The very thought of checking into a hotel owned by a city government that faces a $2.3 billion deficit might be enough to send some tourists screaming back to Kansas.
Yet New York City has managed to become one of the premier hoteliers in town. For nearly 20 years it has owned the sparkling pair of blue-glass-and-steel towers above the East River known as the United Nations Plaza Hotel. 
 The four-star hotel, which was given to the city, has turned a profit every year of its existence, with the city's share amounting to roughly $1 million.
And now the city wants to sell it.
To help close the deficit, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has proposed putting the hotel on the market for between $70 million and $90 million, for a potential gain of $65 million once debt is paid off.
 
Hurdles Ahead
 But real-estate brokers say this is not the best time to sell, since the market is only beginning to recover from the recession and could generate a higher price in a year or two. The proposal has several other major hurdles to overcome, like winning the blessing of the Internal Revenue Service and a host of city boards.
But city officials are confident. "There's tens of millions to be made, and it really makes sense to sell it," said Lance Carlile, vice president of Manhattan development for the New York City Economic Development Corporation, which is handling the sale. "It's not like it cost the city anything. Most of what we'll get will be profit."
Except for cashing a rent check every month, the city has had little to do with the 428-room hotel, at East 44th Street and First Avenue.
The city owns the land and building, but the hotel is managed by the United Nations Development Corporation, a nonprofit group created by the city and the state to construct and finance buildings for the United Nations. Day-to-day operations are left to the Hyatt International Corporation.
The hotel was built in 1976 as part of a larger project to help meet the demands of the United Nations, which had grown from 51 original missions to more than 120 by the mid-1960's.
 
Solving a Problem
 At the time there was a shortage of office space, and no company seemed willing to build a hotel as far east midtown as the United Nations, said Thomas Appleby, president of the development corporation. The situation had reached the point where the United Nations was considering moving out of New York City.
With about $4 million, the development corporation bought several properties and contracted with the architect Kevin Roche to design a combination office building and hotel, One United Nations Plaza.
But there was a problem. Because the corporation owned the land, it would have to pay real-estate taxes on the development, which would increase rents. It might also insult the United Nations, which does not pay taxes but would be doing so indirectly through higher rents. To solve the problem, the corporation simply gave the whole project to the city, which does not tax its own properties.
The city took ownership of the $35 million development, striking a deal in which the United Nations would pay no taxes but an equal amount in rent.
In 1984, the corporation completed an expansion project, Two United Nations Plaza, and gave the building to the city under a similar agreement.
Under Mr. Giuliani's proposal, most of the development would remain in city hands. Only the hotel, which occupies the top quarter of each tower, and a proportional share of the land underneath would be sold. The office space in the complex would still belong to the city.
 
Advice to Wait
 Franklin Speyer, a senior director with the real-estate firm Cushman & Wakefield Inc., said that if the city were his client, he would recommend waiting another year or two as prices recover from the recession.
He said that from a peak in 1989, prices had dropped by as much as half by mid-1993. But he added that prices had bounced back by up to 20 percent since then, and if the city needed to sell, it would no longer be bailing out at the market low.
"We passed rock bottom a long time ago," Mr. Speyer said. "They shouldn't have any problem with this sale."
Before the city can even put the hotel on the market, the deal must first be reviewed by a variety of city agencies, a process that could take as long as six months. And because the development was built by a nonprofit corporation with tax-exempt bonds, the United Nations Development Corporation needs a ruling from the I.R.S. on whether the sale to a private company would affect earnings of bond holders.
Mr. Carlile of the Economic Development Corporation said he could see no reason why anyone would contest the sale.
"I doubt anyone will notice, except there might be a name change," he said.
