HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Soybean and Grain Prices Drop on Rain in the Midwest

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Soybean and grain prices fell sharply yesterday as weekend showers in the Midwest and forecasts for more rain this week dispelled concern that dry weather could damage crops.
Those declines, along with drops in coffee and lumber prices, helped push the Commodity Research Bureau's index down 3.21 points, to 228.84, its low since May 16. 
 As much as 1.5 inches of rain fell in the western crop region of Nebraska, Kansas and Iowa. More showers were expected by midweek. And up to an inch of rain is forecast to arrive by Thursday in the eastern Corn Belt of Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, according to the Weather Services Corporation.
 
 
'Good Week for Crops'
 "The rainfall should be enough to ease most of the concerns about dry weather," said Mike Palmerino, Weather Services' senior agricultural meteorologist. "This should be a good week for crops in the Midwest."
Soybeans for November delivery, which represent this year's crop, touched their 30-cent daily limit before closing down 28.75 cents at $6.3100 a bushel. July soybeans fell 25.75 cents, to $6.5925 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.
July corn fell as low as $2.6150 before closing at $2.6550 a bushel, down 8 cents. But July wheat gained 1 cent, to $3.3125 a bushel.
On other commodity markets, coffee prices fell to a four-week low amid traders' expectations that supplies would grow as the harvest progresses in Brazil and Colombia, the world's two largest coffee-producing nations.
July coffee fell 5.30 cents, to $1.1925 a pound, at the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.
Traders will begin issuing notices to deliver coffee in two weeks. While delivery notices in May were less than a quarter of their normal size, helping prices to rise to a five-year high, that number is expected to be closer to normal now that the harvest has begun.
 
 
Lumber Prices
 Elsewhere, lumber prices fell amid expectations that higher mortgage interest rates would reduce demand, traders said. Lumber for July delivery fell the $10 trading limit, to $383.30 for 1,000 board feet, at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
"We have not seen much business for about a week and a half now," said Bud Merrill, an analyst with Smith Barney in Portland, Ore.
Cash prices were quoted yesterday at $370 to $375 for 1,000 board feet, down from $375 to $380 quoted on Friday, said Bill O'Neill, chief futures strategist with Merrill Lynch in New York.
The Commerce Department said last week that sales of new single-family homes fell 6.3 percent in April, the first drop in three months, as higher mortgage rates kept buyers away.

HEADLINE: Man Shoots Wife to Death As She Holds Their Infant

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
After weeks of quarreling with his wife, Thomas Rodriguez surprised her yesterday morning at the elevator outside the door of a Bronx apartment and shot her to death as she cradled an infant in her arms, a 3-year-old at her side, the police said.
The woman, Joselina Quezada, dropped the infant and collapsed with four bullets in her body. Mr. Rodriguez then raised his .38-caliber revolver to his temple and killed himself with a single shot. 
 When a neighbor cracked the door of his third-floor apartment to take a look, the police said, the 3-year-old, Jermin Quezada, was holding the gun. "The kid says, 'Papi shot Mami,' " said Sgt. Daniel J. Howell, of the 44th Precinct detective squad.
Neither Jermin nor his 10-month-old brother, Johnson, were injured, the police said.
But all day, as detectives and reporters came and went at the apartment, at 85 McClellan Street in High Bridge, the older child would tug at the pants of whoever would listen and retell in Spanish how his father had killed his mother and then committed suicide.
Only the night before, Ms. Quezada, 23, had gone in tears to a police station house in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, to report that her husband of four years had punched her, pulled her hair and taken her purse on the sidewalk near the hair salon where she worked, at 155th Street and Broadway.
"The cops tried to find him, but they couldn't," said Herminia Quezada, the young woman's mother.
The murder and suicide were precisely the kind of crimes that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had hoped to head off when he announced in April that he was assigning a police officer and detective in every precinct to focus on domestic violence. It was not clear yesterday whether the 34th Precinct, where Ms. Quezada reported the assault by her husband on Sunday, has yet set up a team to deal with domestic violence. But Lieut. James T. Malvey said the police officers who tried to find Mr. Rodriguez had done everything possible.
"It's not a perfect system," he said, "but its far superior to what we had. Rather than referring complaints to the court, we have an aggressive arrest policy. We have detectives go out and look for them."
The 44th Precinct, where the shootings occurred, has a domestic-violence team made up of police officers. Like 11 other precincts in the city, it also has a handful of counselors from Victim Services, a nonprofit social services organization under contract to the city that offers counseling and shelter to victims of domestic abuse. Victim Services also provides counseling to the partner who resorts to violence, according to Maureen Geoglis, the deputy director of the organization's police programs.
The 34th Precinct, where the reported assault took place about 8 P.M. Sunday, shortly after Ms. Quezada got off work, does not have a Victim Services team. But even if it had, it is unlikely that it would have been helpful in this case. Because of financial constraints on the city, Ms. Geoglis said, the counselors work only five days a week, during regular business hours.
"If a report had been filed Sunday evening," Ms. Geoglis said, "we would have attempted to contact the person the following day."
But that would have been too late. Mr. Rodriguez, 24, was crouching in a stairwell, the police said, when his wife and two children left her mother's apartment at 8:15 A.M. yesterday.
The police said that three weeks ago, Mr. Rodriguez, an unemployed furniture mover, had moved out of the apartment he had shared with his wife and children at St. Ann's and 138th Streets in the South Bronx. He had beaten his wife then, the family said, and she was still carrying bruises from that incident on her lower back when she died.
Five days ago, Lieutenant Malvey said, Ms. Quezada was apparently concerned for her safety, and she moved into her mother's apartment with the children.
Sergeant Howell said that after checking with several police precincts and interviewing the family, investigators concluded that Ms. Quezada had not sought police help until Sunday night.
For the elder Mrs. Quezada, who now faces the task of raising her daughter's two young boys, the shootings were tragic in every way. Though the couple's relationship had been stormy, she had thought highly of her daughter's husband, who, like her and her daughter, had come from the Dominican Republic.
"He was a good father," Mrs. Quezada said. "But he was jealous and didn't want her to leave with the children."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Jermin Rodriguez, 3, top left, and his 10-month-old brother, Johnson, watched yesterday as their father killed their mother, Joselina Quezada, right, the police said. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

 BODY:

International
The White House signaled that it was ready to jettison its all-or-nothing, package-deal approach to a trade agreement with Japan and strike whatever arrangements it could get piece by piece, having learned in the last year that it did not have as much economic leverage over Tokyo as it thought. [Page A1.] 
 Institutional investors are beginning to look at South Africa, but their investments are mainly going to big U.S. companies with South African operations whose stocks they once boycotted. [D1.] Pepsi-Cola is returning to South Africa after nine years. [D5.]

Sara Lee is closing plants and cutting its work force by about 8,300 people, or 6 percent, in response to shifting trends in fashion and problems in the women's hosiery business. [D1.]

The Supreme Court agreed to resolve one of the most contentious issues in banking law: whether federally regulated banks can sell annuities, which are usually sold by insurers. [D1.]
U.S. monetary authorities intervened in currency markets on April 29 to support the dollar, the New York Fed said. [D7.]
A Federal judge forcefully rejected subpoenas secured against two House members by Brown & Williamson. [A14.]
Limited logging may resume in the publicly owned forests of the Pacific Northwest, a Federal judge ruled. [A17.]
 
Markets

Bond prices rose again, responding in part to a report that top Fed officials believed inflation was under control and were thus much less likely to push up interest rates soon. [D16.]
Soybean and grain prices fell sharply as rain in the Midwest dispelled concern that dry weather could damage crops. [D18.]
The dollar was little changed against the Japanese yen. [D18.]

HEADLINE: Job Agency Head Resigns After a Report Criticizes Spending

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
The president of the New York State Job Development Authority announced her resignation yesterday, hours after the state Inspector General criticized her for spending about $10,000 in agency money on personal expenses like credit card bills.
The Inspector General, George R. Moresco, also found that the job agency's $99,750-a-year president, Audrey P. Bynoe, had improperly used staff members and equipment for political activities. The inspector general's report said the authority lacked the management checks and balances needed to prevent the kinds of abuses Mr. Moresco said had taken place. 
 Separately, Mr. Moresco said that he was continuing his investigation of the job agency's dealings with the Wall Street firm of W. R. Lazard, the largest minority-owned money-management house. Its founder, Wardell R. Lazard, was found dead of alcohol and cocaine poisoning in a Pittsburgh hotel room last month.
The Manhattan District Attorney's office is also investigating the Lazard firm's work for the agency, which was set up to provide loans and loan guarantees for struggling companies.
 
Acting Head Named
 Ms. Bynoe, who had been president of the job authority since January 1992 and was vice president for six months before that, issued a statement with Vincent Tese, the state director of economic development, in which they both agreed on the need for stricter financial controls at the agency. But Mr. Tese, in an interview later, appeared to be putting distance between himself and Ms. Bynoe, calling the inspector general's report "pretty damaging."
Then, referring to Ms. Bynoe and her lawyer, Victor Kovner, Mr. Tese added, "Unless you can refute all the facts, it's pretty difficult for them to contend with."
Mr. Tese said he had not asked Ms. Bynoe, a former aide to Assemblyman Albert Vann of Brooklyn, to step down. "They pre-empted that question by resigning," he said.
He named Lee Webb, the executive vice president of the state Urban Development Corporation, as acting president of the job agency. He said the Urban Development Corporation's deputy general counsel, Anita Laremont, would replace Kenneth McLaughlin as the general counsel at the Job Development Authority.
The report said the inspector general "could not substantiate" an allegation that Ms. Bynoe might have provided inaccurate information to New York Newsday in response to a Freedom of Information Law request about the agency's salary-advance program. "However," the report said, "Bynoe appears to have furnished misleading information to Newsday" about the agency's payment of her personal expenses.
The inspector general's report said that Mr. McLaughlin provided Newsday with a list that included only one of Ms. Bynoe's salary advances and that his action "could appear to have been misleading."
 
Challenging the Report
 The investigation began after the authority dismissed its treasurer and chief financial officer, James Blaine, last year. He maintained that the dismissal was retaliation for his having brought "questionable financial transactions undertaken or approved by her" to Ms. Bynoe's attention.
Mr. Kovner took issue with what he called "false facts" in the report, challenging the inspector general's finding that Ms. Bynoe had borrowed more than $25,000 from the authority and had repaid all but $177 through payroll deductions. The amount that Ms. Bynoe owed was never more than $8,000 at any one time, Mr. Kovner said. "It was all paid as soon as any indebtedness was made known to her," he said.
The inspector general said Ms. Bynoe was the only job agency employee who used payroll deductions to reimburse the agency for advances against her salary. The inspector general said that in February 1991, when she was the agency's executive vice president, Ms. Bynoe ordered the agency's finance office to deduct $100 from six paychecks to cover a $614.47 car rental expense.
Ms. Bynoe first told the inspector general's investigators that she rented the car while vacationing in Florida. Later, the report said, "she stated that she rented the car in Albany, N.Y., for use during a period of unpaid leave she took to assist the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus."
The report said she received $4,500 from the caucus, including $774.47 for "travel and car rental." The report said that because she received a lump-sum reimbursement, she should have repaid the agency all at once, instead of in installments.

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D. Being Pressed To Change Its Mission

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 5

 BODY:
Long respected as a low-profile "think tank" that monitors and forecasts the economic performance of the industrialized world, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development is under pressure to broaden its horizons by opening its doors to more members and involving itself in shaping global economic policy.
As a result, the organization's annual ministerial meeting, which usually only interests economists, has assumed special importance. At stake when it opens here Tuesday is whether the 25-nation organization can adjust to the changing global economy. 
 In recent years, this economy has changed significantly, with the emergence of fast-growing Asian economies, the adoption of free market systems by the former Soviet bloc, the creation of a single European market and passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement. And these changes now affect the O.E.C.D.
The United States is leading the drive to modernize the Paris-based body, from the largely monitoring role it now fills to one carrying more influence with the making of global economic policy. In an address here on Wednesday, Secretary of State Warren Christopher is expected to detail how the Clinton Administration believes the O.E.C.D. can become more relevant today.
Its readiness to change will become apparent in the coming months in its choice of the organization's next Secretary General. The current office-holder, Jean-Claude Paye, who has already served two five-year terms, is seeking re-election, but the United States feels it is time for new blood.
 
Postwar Roots
 Created in 1948 as the Organization for European Economic Cooperation to help enact the Marshall Plan, the O.E.C.D. assumed its present name and began taking in new non-European members in 1961. But after New Zealand joined in 1973, the "rich man's club" admitted no new member for the next 21 years.
This year, after strong lobbying from the United States, Mexico became its 25th member. But some members like Portugal, Greece and Mexico have lower per-capita income than several Asian countries like South Korea, which now seek a place in the organization.
The O.E.C.D. already considers Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia to be "partners in transition" since, as democracies with market economies, they have met the basic conditions of membership. And, on Wednesday, the "club" will for the first time sign a cooperation agreement with Russia.
Russia will be able to participate in some committees and benefit from the O.E.C.D.'s expertise through regional and country-specific reports. But the new link is also of symbolic importance. For some experts, it was Moscow's decision to withdraw from the Marshall Plan organization that set the stage for the cold war.
"You could say that this agreement closes the final pages of the final chapter of the cold war," an American official said. "Russia is not yet a major world economic player, but it won't be long before it is. We will now be able to see this frontier economy in action."
The United States also hopes to turn the O.E.C.D.'s attention toward the trade issues of the 1990's so that the many economists on its 1,900-member staff can support the work of the World Trade Organization, which will succeed the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade on Jan. 1.
Washington's insistence that the new trade body debate the links between trade and the environment and between trade and labor rights has met strong opposition from many developing countries, notably in Asia, which fear moves toward nontariff protectionism.
By encouraging the O.E.C.D. to study these and other trade-related issues, such as competition and investment, the United States and some European countries hope to develop what one American official called "objective criteria" that could influence the World Trade Organization.
A more immediate problem facing the O.E.C.D. member countries is the unemployment that now affects 35 million of their residents. The problem of joblessness has dominated a series of recent summit meetings of the European Union and the Group of Seven industrialized nations without any solution emerging.
In its own two-year study of the problem, the O.E.C.D. focused primarily on whether high unemployment is structural or cyclical and concluded that it has elements of both conditions. Its 50-page report, "Growth and Employment," is to be presented to economic ministers meeting here on Tuesday.
Many of its ideas seem likely to be addressed to the 12-nation European Union. Western Europe's current 11.2 percent unemployment rate, compared with 6 percent in the United States, is widely attributed to minimum wage laws and generous unemployment and other social benefits that inflate the cost of creating jobs.
"It is much better to have people on a salary, perhaps not a very high one, than to have people unemployed," Mr. Paye said last week.
But the key question this week is whether individual countries will agree to enact recommendations that are often fraught with political risks. And it is here that the O.E.C.D.'s future may be defined. "We want it to address itself more to policy makers and political leaders than to bureaucrats," one American official said.
For this reason, then, the United States believes a "new" O.E.C.D. needs a new leader. And it is backing the candidacy of Donald Johnston, a Canadian who served in Pierre Trudeau's Cabinet and is a former leader of Canada's Liberal Party.
Washington hoped a decision would be made this week, but European governments have asked for more time. France is backing Mr. Paye, whose current term ends on Sept. 30; Britain has put forward the candidacy of Nigel Lawson, a former Chancellor of the Exchequer under Margaret Thatcher, and Germany has proposed its former GATT negotiator, Lawrence Schomerus.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Lawyer Joins Wasserstein; Latin Focus

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

 BODY:
Mario L. Baeza, a Wall Street lawyer with short-lived diplomatic aspirations, switched careers yesterday and joined the Wasserstein Perella Group as a senior executive who will concentrate on building Latin American business for the New York investment bank.
"Every so often the spirit of adventure calls," said Mr. Baeza, who is leaving the law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, where he started 20 years ago after graduating from Harvard Law School. 
 Mr. Baeza, 43, who had been a partner and founder of the firm's 30-member Latin America group, will be president of Wasserstein Perella International, chief executive of the company's Latin American operations and co-head of its operations in Spain and Portugal.
 
More Direct Role in Deals
 In many ways, Mr. Baeza said, his new job will be like his old one, concentrating on developing new business opportunities in Latin America. But, as an investment banker, he said, he will have a more direct role in putting deals together and in following them to conclusion.
"There is a one-step-removed quality to being a lawyer, where your success and what you get paid" are not necessarily functions of whether deals actually close, Mr. Baeza said. "This is going to be different."
One place where Mr. Baeza said he hoped to do a lot of business eventually is Cuba, which is now under an American trade embargo. Mr. Baeza's parents were born in Cuba, and, although he was born in Montclair, N.J., the family moved back to Havana for four years when he was a child. It was his longtime interest in seeing Cuba opened eventually for business opportunities that scuttled his diplomatic dreams last year.
 
Opposition From Anti-Castroites
 Mr. Baeza was scheduled to become Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, the State Department's top Latin American post, in the spring of 1993. At the last minute, the Clinton Administration scratched his name from a list of nominees sent to the Senate after Cuban-American groups and their supporters in Congress protested that Mr. Baeza would not be tough enough toward Cuba's leader, Fidel Castro.
"The whole experience made me take a step back and think about what I was doing," Mr. Baeza said. "I decided maybe it was time for career No. 2."
Barry R. Bryan, Debevoise & Plimpton's presiding partner, said of Mr. Baeza, "His new job is really a perfect fit for his deal-making talents, which he exhibited as a lawyer, and his interests in Latin America."
 
Role in Telmex Deal
 While at the law firm, Mr. Baeza worked on deals that involved Wasserstein Perella. One was the Mexican Government's 1990 sale of control of its national telephone company to an international consortium.
When Mr. Baeza was still a youngster, his family returned to New Jersey, where his father became chairman of the economics, marketing and research department at Seton Hall University. Mr. Baeza was good enough on his high school baseball team to be offered a tryout with an Atlanta Braves farm team but chose instead to go to Cornell University and then Harvard Law School.
He and his wife, Della, also a lawyer, have two daughters and a son.

HEADLINE: Fight Looms Over Curbs On Smoking In New York

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Opening what is likely to be a bitterly fought battle, the tobacco industry officially began its campaign yesterday to challenge a set of proposals that would ban smoking in virtually all public places in New York City.
The City Council's Health Committee opened hearings on the bill with a full day of often-spirited testimony that drew a broad array of people, from anti-smoking advocates and public officials to tobacco industry spokesmen, restaurateurs and cancer victims. 
 The bill, introduced three months ago by Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, has been endorsed in principle by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, backed fully by all five borough presidents and is considered likely to pass in some form.
The bill would force all employers, no matter their size, to confine smoking to enclosed areas with specialized ventilation systems, limiting such rooms to one on each floor of a building. Smoking would also be restricted to separate rooms in pool halls and separate sections of outdoor cafes. It would also be banned in Yankee and Shea Stadiums and in outdoor areas of child-care agencies.
To conduct its campaign, the tobacco industry has hired two veteran lobbyists with close ties to Mr. Vallone: Martin J. McLaughlin, who heads a public-relations and lobbying firm and is a friend of the speaker, and Norman Adler, a consultant and former political adviser to Mr. Vallone. The lobbyists also have close ties with several other Democratic legislators.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Vallone acknowledged his friendship with the two lobbyists, but added that he also has close ties with Joseph W. Cherner, president of Smokefree Educational Services, an anti-smoking advocacy group.
"Lobbyists have the ability to help me to gather information and look at all sides of an issue," Mr. Vallone said. "But I make my own decisions." Of Mr. Adler and Mr. McLaughlin, the speaker said, "They have the same influence that any other lobbyist would have."
While tobacco industry representatives said they expected the bill to pass, they said they hoped at least to weaken or eliminate some proposed restrictions.
"We're trying to go for a defeat of the bill," Thomas Lauria, assistant to the president of the Washington-based Tobacco Institute, said in an interview. "But barring that, we'll go for making it as easy to live with as possible. One thing is for sure: a total ban on smoking is unacceptable to many people, not only in the tobacco industry, but in the hotel and motel industry and even civic groups."
Tobacco industry officials said yesterday that they planned heavy lobbying of Mr. Vallone and individual Council members. They said their strategy centered on two premises: that second-hand smoke is not the hazard that several medical reports say it is, and that the bill would be too costly for small businesses, particularly restaurants.
Leaders of good-government groups said the tobacco industry did not have a history of making large contributions to City Council members. But they said they expected it to be vigilant in lobbying Council members by bringing restaurant and business owners to future hearings.
"The strategy of the tobacco lobby in New York City is no different than their strategy in other parts of the country," said Chris Meyer, a lawyer with the New York Public Interest Research Group, which supports the bill. "It is to hire the best-connected lobbyists to try and influence the best-connected legislators. The strategy is to do private meetings with the leadership and, at some point, bring out the rank and file."
The rank and file in this case means owners of restaurants and hotels, who generally oppose the bill. "About 35 percent of all business travelers and visitors who stay at our hotels are international visitors who are determined smokers," said Joseph Spinnato, president of the Hotel Association of New York City, at the hearing. "As a result, this proposed legislation will unfairly impact on many of our hotels that specifically cater to these travelers."
Some officials of restaurant associations said at the hearing that they objected to a provision in the bill that would require smoking areas to have specially built ventilation equipment. "The bottom line is simply that this legislation would have a serious economic impact on the food-service industry of New York City," said Fred G. Sampson, president of the New York State Restaurant Association, a trade group.

HEADLINE: Signs of Life After Pan Am;
Thousands of Workers Stranded by Airline's Sudden Demise Find Training and Jobs

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
John Wallace remembers the day Pan American World Airways flew for the last time: the Kennedy International Airport maintenance shop where he had worked as a machinist for 24 years was "the quietest thing I've ever seen in my life."
"There was no screaming, no complaining," he said. "We all just got our tools and left." 
 For about 2,500 Pan Am workers who lost their jobs that day -- three weeks before Christmas in 1991 -- the future could not have looked much bleaker. Not only was the New York region, where 85 percent of Pan Am's employees lived, in the midst of its most severe economic downturn since the Great Depression, but the entire airline industry was also experiencing its worst financial turmoil ever. More than a dozen Pan Am workers who lost their jobs committed suicide within months of the shutdown, while many others left the job market altogether.
But most of the other workers have defied the grim expectations and made fresh starts, largely through an unusually successful job-placement program sponsored by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey under a $6 million Federal grant. Roughly three out of four workers who entered the program, called Career Connections, have found employment or entered job retraining, compared with two out of three people in Federal job-placement programs nationwide.
"We learned that one of the most important things we had to offer was simply a place for people to go," said Kenneth Ryan, president of the Employment and Training Institute, which operated Career Connections for former Pan Am employees at Kennedy Airport for two years. "The key was to be there from the beginning, when people were hurting the most."
Amid all the talk of corporate cutbacks and layoffs among middle managers and other white-collar employees, it is easy to forget that by far the largest number of those whose jobs were lost in the last few years wore some kind of uniform to work.
 
Tough Times for Blue-Collar Workers
 Unemployment among semiskilled workers averaged 17 percent in the New York area last year, compared with 5.3 percent among executives and managers. Even among highly skilled manual workers, more than one in eight were jobless.
Pan Am's blue-collar workers had particular reason to be discouraged. They had already agreed to at least two rounds of sharp reductions in pay and benefits to help keep the airline going, to no avail. With little cash and already under bankruptcy protection, the company shut down without warning, offering no severance pay, no unused-vacation pay, and ending paid health coverage that day.
Most of those laid off by Pan Am, once the world's most far-flung airline and the pride of American carriers, had a hard time imagining working anywhere else. While more than 5,000 of its workers were immediately hired by Delta Air Lines, which took over many of Pan Am's routes, at least 2,500 were left out in the cold.
The largest share of the 2,323 participants in Career Connections were mechanics, mostly men in their late 40's or early 50's who had been with the company for 20 years or more. Too young to retire, they were also too old to begin a new career easily. Many former employees, including flight attendants and customer-service agents who faced added obstacles because of their age, had never worked for another company.
They were fortunate, though, because Career Connections got off to a fast start. Rather than waiting until the airline failed, the Port Authority had applied for Federal funds and begun planning the job program several months earlier. The agency's planners knew that even under the company's most optimistic expectations, layoffs would be required.
 
Guidance for 2,200
 By moving before the company shut down on Dec. 4, 1991, Career Connections was able to open its doors less than six weeks later. Counselors, working six days a week, gave initial guidance to 2,200 people by the end of April.
Orientation sessions essentially allowed former workers to express their anger and commiserate with colleagues. The center also provided office space, telephone banks, fax machines, copying services, job fairs and open houses, a reference library, advice on preparing resumes and cover letters, and financial support for retraining. Most important, it offered a sanctuary.
"Going through the training kept me busy, compared to sitting back and thinking about how bad off I was," said Hans Pfeil, a former crew chief in the maintenance shop who was earning $19 an hour, or about $48,000 a year, when Pan Am collapsed. "It kept me out of trouble."
But in many ways both explicit and subtle, Pan Am's former employees were also reminded that their futures rested largely in their own hands. "It took a long time for many of these former employees to act on their own behalf," the final report on the program said.
One drawback of many job programs is that they do not demand enough of the participants, said Mr. Ryan, the head of the program.
"In the past, job programs didn't ask enough," he said. "You want people to feel comfortable coming for help, but in the end they have to shoulder the responsibility themselves."
So with the Pan Am programs, job search training was mandatory, because it forced most people to recognize that they would need to develop new skills to find work in a changing labor market. It also allowed them to express hostility in a safe haven and make mistakes before going on real job interviews.
Some never recovered from the shock of losing their jobs. Several gave up the search, often relying on spouses for income while waiting for their pensions to kick in at age 55.
Many were lucky to find work with other aviation companies. Roughly two out of five of those who found employment were hired within the industry, although some of those later lost their jobs again.
The rest, however, started over.
Mr. Pfeil, 57, had it harder than most. The day Pan Am folded, he was scheduled to fly to his mother's funeral in Germany. He had come to work that morning only to thank his supervisor for writing a letter so he could travel for free. "I never saw so many grown-up people cry," Mr. Pfeil said. "Myself, I didn't have any tears left."
Mr. Pfeil's challenge was to keep his house in Oceanside, L.I. "We cut back on everything else to pay the mortgage," he said. "When we tried to refinance, the bank we had relied on for years refused me three times. I finally found another bank that saved us $300 a month. I moved my I.R.A. to them."
Mr. Pfeil entered a training program to learn how to install and repair air-conditioning and heating systems. That led to a temporary job at $10 an hour, little more than half his previous income. When that ended, Home Depot hired him at roughly the same wage.
Along with more than 1,000 other people, Mr. Pfeil applied for a job to repair buses for the New York City Transit Authority. He was chosen and started work this winter. His pay and benefits are similar to what he earned before. Working a 4 P.M.-to-midnight shift, though, means he sees his family far less.
Still, Mr. Pfeil concluded, "I think I'm one of the lucky ones."
 
New Hope for Flight Attendant
 Helene Ladenheim, a former flight attendant who was 49 when Pan Am failed, has been less fortunate. Multilingual and with wide experience overseas, she initially hoped to continue her work.
"Delta promised to take 2,000 flight attendants," she said, "but they didn't have to follow seniority rules. My interview skills were not so good, and I didn't pass."
Eventually, after more than 20 job interviews, she decided to enter a two-year nurse training program. All except $1,000 of the cost was paid by the Federal grant. Ms. Ladenheim's experience taking care of people in the air, she says, should prove useful in her new career. And after caring for her husband, who died of cancer several years ago, she wants to help others in similar situations.
"I've spent a lot of time in hospitals and most of the doctors were pretty rotten and uncaring," she said. "It made me realize how important it is to have a good nurse."
Ms. Ladenheim, who graduated from nursing school last month, does not have a job yet, though she is hopeful. "The shortage of nurses is not as acute as it used to be," she said.
Mr. Wallace, 48, also wanted to stay in the aviation industry. Despite 24 years' experience as a mechanic, he was not senior enough in his shop to be chosen by Delta to work at its Atlanta operation.
"I had never really looked for a job," said Mr. Wallace, who joined Pan Am right after his military service. "Career Connections showed me how." For a while, he loaded baggage part-time for American Airlines. Finally, he found his current job working as a civilian handling evidence and property at the New York City Police Department auto pound in College Point. At $30,000 a year, it pays about $8,000 less than his old job.
And if the new job disappears?
"One thing I've learned is that I have other skills than being a mechanic," Mr. Wallace said. "So if it happens, it happens. Now I know I can survive the worst."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Officials' Comments Help Push Rates Down

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates moved lower again yesterday, brushing against the bottom of a trading range that has been in place since the beginning of April.
By late in the day, the Treasury's benchmark 6 1/4 percent bonds due in 2023 were offered at a price to yield 7.21 percent, down from 7.27 percent late Friday. It is the lowest yield on the closely watched issue since April 27. 
 Credit market participants attributed the improvement, which came on light trading, to several factors.
Comments from three governors of the Federal Reserve Board provided an initial lift to prices of fixed-income securities, traders said.
The governors were quoted in an article in The New York Times yesterday as saying that based on recent data they had concluded that growth in the economy had eased slightly, and that inflation was under control. Those developments made any further tightening in monetary policy much less likely in coming weeks, the article said.
Aside from the article, traders said the market was also benefiting from a light calendar of new Treasury issues that is scheduled. Periods of heavy supply are usually difficult times, because often prices must be marked down to attract customers. Dealing with new supply would not be a problem for at least the rest of the month, traders said.
 
 
European Markets
 Finally, a number of market participants said they saw investors repatriating money from European debt markets and moving it into the secondary market for Treasury securities. That movement also helped to bolster the dollar on foreign exchange markets.
Despite the extension of the rally, which began last Wednesday, analysts and traders were unwilling to say that an end to the upward movement in interest rates that began in early February is at hand.
"We have had several of these runs, from a top yield of around 7 1/2 percent to a low of around 7.20 percent," said Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg.
He added: "It feels good, but until we make a conclusive breakout this is still a trading range. I think long rates have a good chance of going back under 7 percent in the second half of the year, but the jury is still out."
Investors, as well as the Fed, will be busy sifting through various readings on the economy and inflation over the next several weeks to determine whether recent indications of a cooling are real, or merely an aberration.
"Right now the market is saying the Fed has finished tightening," one trader said. "But if we get strong numbers, we will start to price in additional tightening moves, and the market will get ugly all over again."
But all was calm yesterday, and a number of corporations took advantage of the good conditions to price new debt issues. The strong secondary Treasury market also provided a good backdrop for the Treasury's weekly bill auctions.
At the bill auctions, the Treasury sold its new three-month bills at an average discount rate of 4.15 percent, down from an average rate of 4.23 percent at last week's auction.
Bids on the new six-month bills generated an average discount rate of 4.53 percent, down from 4.67 percent a week ago.
The rates on the three-month and six-month bills are the lowest since the auctions of May 2.
Citicorp led corporate issuers yesterday, as it offered $250 million of 10-year subordinated notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Citicorp Securities Inc.
The notes, which are noncallable for life, were priced at par, or $100, to yield 7 3/4 percent -- 85 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.5 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Prices improved for all maturities in the secondary market for Treasury securities, although longer-dated bonds and notes outperformed intermediate and short-term issues.
By late in the day, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 10215/32 , up 19/32 , to yield 6.90 percent. And the price of the Treasury's 6 3/4 percent five-year notes was up by 14/32 in late trading, to 1013/32 , to yield 6.48 percent.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A New Day Dawns for South African Investment

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Comforted by visions of Nelson Mandela visiting the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, institutional investors are beginning to look at the country they once shunned. But few are pulling out their checkbooks and, so far, the main business beneficiaries of South African political change have been large American companies whose stocks were once boycotted.
The big public pension funds that led the anti-apartheid charge are now free to invest in more than 100 of the largest United States corporations with ties to South Africa. In Michigan, for instance, the $24 billion state employees pension fund no longer faces a ban on more than 40 percent of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- including in-state giants like Ford Motor and General Motors.
 
'Fertile New Fields'
 Barry Stevens, the Michigan system's director of investments, said that the change "opens up fertile new fields" and that "before, we could just invest in teeny parts of the American market." 
 The $37 billion New Jersey state pension fund has just directed more than $500 million to a shopping list that includes General Electric, Du Pont, Time Warner and International Paper. And, in California, the $77 billion California Public Employees Retirement System has just begun to invest in 100 top American companies.
But these same public pension funds that supported economic sanctions are now reluctant to make risky bets about international markets, and little of their money is flowing into South African companies. At the same time, corporate pension plans that never expressed moral qualms about South Africa are showing interest in the Johannesburg exchange and have been seeking advice from stockbrokers and investment consultants.
"South Africa is in everybody's thoughts," said Stephen McCarthy, a portfolio manager at Batterymarch Financial Management. "It's a question of when it's going to start going."
Investors are worried, however, about political instability and potential violence, and that tends to slow the pace of investment. "Only the most sophisticated and adventurous investors will probably venture into South Africa," said Adam Spector, a director at the SEI Corporation, a Wayne, Pa., pension consulting firm.
That theme was echoed at a meeting last week in Atlanta, sponsored by the United States Information Agency, in which both United States business executives and South African officials agreed that the peaceful election and transition was the most important step in reassuring potential foreign investors. And South African officials repeated that business investment, not only buying stocks in South African companies but also setting up business operations there as well, was important to ending South Africa's high unemployment rates.
Allan A. Boesak, minister of economic affairs of the Western Cape provincial government, said: "The two questions are: How does one maintain the level of stability that we have been able to reach and how does the Government evolve as a partner of business from outside?
"You need the kind of investment that will create jobs on a scale large enough to allow for us to work actively at that incredible number of jobless people," Mr. Boesak said.
For stock pickers, the Johannesburg exchange, despite its size, is considered an emerging market and, as such, it competes for capital with fast-growing markets elsewhere. With more than 600 listed stocks, it has a market capitalization of $215 billion. It is the largest emerging market, bigger than those in Mexico, Malaysia, Taiwan, South Korea, China and all of Eastern Europe. Stocks linked to mining make up 30 percent of the exchange -- the best known being DeBeers Consolidated Mines Ltd. and Anglo American.
Investment capital is critical to development to help create jobs and support an educational system. Mr. Mandela, since calling in September for an end to economic sanctions, has expressed clear pro-business views. And African National Congress representatives in the United States have met with institutional investors to spread this message, while acknowledging investor concerns.
"We see that investors have adopted a wait-and-see attitude," said Madala Mthembu, a spokesman for the congress here. They are waiting, he acknowledged, "to see what the politics are and that the country stabilizes," adding, "That is what any sensible investor would do."
Since Mr. Mandela's September statement, a total of 137 state and local governments in the United States have eliminated pension fund restrictions on buying stock in American companies that did business, even tangentially, in South Africa. Forty-two others are in the process of repeal. While it is impossible to determine how much money was withheld, most came at the expense of the 100 or so largest American companies.
 
New Restrictions Replace Old
 But even as these restrictions fall, others remain. Roland Machold, director of investments for the New Jersey state fund, said state law prohibited investments in countries with less than an AA credit rating -- and South Africa is currently unrated.
Besides, global investing is still a new concept to some public plans, where there is a highly conservative investment focus. Such plans may not have tested established markets in Europe or Japan, let alone those in less familiar areas.
But Justin Beckett, president of New Africa Advisers, based in Durham, N.C., said such caution might be misplaced. South African stocks, he said, might well outpace domestic equities in the years ahead.
"If I'm a pension fund manager and I hear that the No. 1 performing stock market is in Johannesburg, I'd better have a good reason for not participating," Mr. Beckett said. He said that worries about social unrest were overblown and that the pre-election violence in South Africa had never affected business.
"No one took over the new Chrysler plant there or the Coca-Cola bottling plant," Mr. Beckett said. "You have riots in Los Angeles and political assassinations in Mexico and no one says to avoid investments there. You have record killings in New York and people don't avoid the New York Stock Exchange."
 
New Codes in the Works
 As investors ponder, the Rev. Leon H. Sullivan, the Philadelphia minister who devised the Sullivan Principles, a code of responsibility for American companies operating under apartheid, is now drafting a social responsibility code for companies that left South Africa and are returning.
In 1985, 267 American companies had South Africa operations. That fell to 104 in 1991 and rebounded this year to 154. Among those returning are Honeywell, I.B.M., Procter & Gamble and Sara Lee, which, with 4,703 employees, is the biggest American employer there.
One leading company returning to South Africa is the H. J. Heinz Company of Pittsburgh.
"We expect to have an investment there within 12 months," said Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, chief executive, at the Atlanta conference. "American business will adopt a quite unheroic pose and it will be one of wait-and-see. I think the omens are good. Many people will wait too long and it will be regrettable if they do."
Mr. Sullivan said he was concerned that "political apartheid is not replaced with economic apartheid" and that American companies act in a socially responsible way to protect equal rights, promote education and provide job training. To this end, he said, has been meeting with big-city mayors, heads of university endowments and black church leaders to persuade companies to sign on to his "new Sullivan Principles."
But the African National Congress fears that Mr. Sullivan's effort may duplicate what the South African Government plans on its own and impose burdens that could discourage foreign business from investing.
"We don't need a code of conduct for American investors and we are afraid it may become a disincentive," Mr. Mthembu of the A.N.C. said. "If he puts this on American companies, it will put them at a disadvantage to Japanese or British businesses. We will have our own laws protecting the employee. We wants business to act in a socially responsible manner. But it is not desirable to put this as a code of conduct."

HEADLINE: High Court to Rule on Bank Annuities Issue

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve one of the most contentious issues in banking law -- whether federally regulated banks can sell annuities, an investment usually sold by insurance companies.
The case is an appeal by the Comptroller of the Currency, Eugene Ludwig, and Nationsbank of North Carolina that the Comptroller authorized in 1990 to act as a sales agent for a variety of annuities. In a ruling last year, the Federal appeals court in New Orleans invalidated, as contrary to Federal law, a 1985 decision by the Comptroller's office that selling annuities was appropriate for national banks as an activity "incidental" to the business of banking. 
 Banks' entry into the multibillion-dollar market for annuities, investments that are attractive to many customers as alternatives to low-interest certificates of deposit, has split the Federal courts and provoked a counterattack from the insurance industry. A lawsuit by a Houston-based insurance company, the Variable Annuity Life Insurance Company, resulted in this case.
Adding to the ferment over the issue, New York State bank regulators have permitted state-chartered banks to sell annuities in a decision that was upheld in March by the state's highest court. About half the banks in New York, including Chemical Bank, have state charters, while other leading banks, including Citibank and Chase Manhattan, are nationally chartered.
The American Bankers Association, the Conference of State Bank Supervisors and the New York Clearing House, representing 11 big commercial banks, all urged the Supreme Court to hear the case. The New York Clearing House said in its brief that the underlying question in the case was "the extent to which national banks may continue to respond to the needs of their customers in the rapidly changing marketplace for financial products."
The economic stakes in the outcome are considerable. In 1992, the last full year for which the Comptroller's office has statistics, banks sold annuities worth $12.2 billion, representing about 20 percent of the national market.
Annuities are similar to individual retirement accounts, which banks offer, because taxes on the interest earned can be deferred until the customer retires. But they are not subject to the $2,000 maximum annual contribution limit on I.R.A.'s.
There are several legal issues in the case, Nationsbank of North Carolina v. the Variable Annuity Life Insurance Company, No. 93-1612.
The first is the degree of deference that Federal courts owe to determinations of administrative agencies like the Comptroller of the Currency. The brief filed for the Comptroller by the Solicitor General, Drew S. Days 3d, argues that the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit failed to give proper deference to the agency's reasonable interpretation of its governing statutes.
 
'Business of Banking'
 Beyond the deference issue, the case involves two Federal banking laws. One, Section 24(7) of the National Bank Act of 1864, permits national banks to engage in activities that are "incidental" to the "business of banking." So one question in the case is whether the Comptroller correctly determined that the sale of annuities came within that grant of authority.
The other question is whether annuities are forms of insurance, as opposed to a noninsurance investment product. The issue is important because of another Federal law, Section 92 of the National Bank Act of 1916, which permits banks in towns of fewer than 5,000 inhabitants to sell a range of insurance products, whether or not they are incidental to banking. Lower courts have interpreted that grant of authority to small-town banks as prohibiting, by implication, other banks from selling insurance products.
In the Comptroller's view, annuities are not insurance at all because they lack the main characteristic of insurance, indemnification against the risk of loss. Annuities are investment contracts, the Comptroller ruled in adopting the challenged policy in 1985.
The appeals court in this case rejected that conclusion, noting that all 50 states regulate annuities under their insurance laws and that the Internal Revenue Code defines insurance companies, in part, as those that issue annuity contracts. The appeals court said that like life insurance, annuities were sold on the basis of actuarial calculations. People buy annuities, the court said, not to insure against the risk of dying prematurely but against the possibility of outliving their resources.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Selling by Japan's Exporters Thwarts Rally in the Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed against the Japanese yen and other leading currencies yesterday amid continuing signs that Japanese exporters were selling the dollar whenever it rallied.
Japanese exporters earn revenues in dollars and other currencies, which they must sell for yen to bring their profits back home. Japan's huge trade surplus with the United States means the country's manufacturers have a large stockpile of dollars to sell. 
 Yesterday, some Japanese exporters responded to Friday's rally in the dollar, which had pushed it to a two-month high, by selling dollars. Concerns about this selling kept the dollar from rising again, traders said.
"Exporters are putting a cap on the dollar's rally," said Joseph Francomano, a trader with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank in New York. "A lot of them like selling at these levels."
The dollar was quoted late yesterday at 105.29 yen, little changed from 105.35 yen on Friday. The dollar eased a fraction to 1.6705 German marks from 1.6707 marks.
 
 
A Ceiling at 107 Yen
 "Many Japanese corporations don't expect the dollar to rise above 107 yen," said Koichi Takenaka, assistant vice president of the Industrial Bank of Japan. For that reason, he said, many are keen to sell dollars at current levels, while others are poised to sell at 105.50 yen to 106 yen.
The rally in the bond market helped the dollar gain last week by convincing many currency traders that international investors were again buying American financial assets.
Bonds rallied again yesterday amid signs that the the Federal Reserve was less likely to move on interest rates in the coming weeks since inflation appeared to be under control.
While stable American interest rates are good for bonds, they can hurt the dollar because German short-term interest rates are still as much as one percentage point higher, making deposits denominated in marks more attractive.
"If the Fed is on hold, the dollar loses one leg of support," said Marc Chandler, director of research at Ezra Zask Associates, a hedge fund with $180 million under management.
Other traders expect the dollar to fall against the yen if tensions between the United States and North Korea abate. The yen has recently been shaken by signs that North Korea is developing nuclear weapons. Investors often turn to the dollar in times of international crisis.
Elsewhere, the Canadian dollar rose to a two-month high against the United States dollar, buoyed by strong demand for Canadian bonds. The Canadian dollar rose to 72.86 United States cents, from 72.60 cents on Friday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Pepsi and South Africa To Get Together Again

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Pepsi-Cola International announced yesterday that it would return to South Africa, nine years after selling its beverage business there in response to international economic sanctions.
In a bid to compete against Coca-Cola, Pepsi has formed a joint bottling venture in which black investors from the United States hold a majority stake, according to the company. 
 "Our commitment is to create the most dynamic and most admired black-managed and black-owned company in South Africa," said Christopher A. Sinclair, president and chief executive of Pepsico Foods and Beverages International. In so doing, he added, Pepsi hopes to "differentiate ourselves from other companies and products."
The major competitor is Coke, which has a near-monopoly of the $1 billion South African beverage market.
"Coca-Cola is seen as part of the old South Africa," said Khehla S. Mthembu, chairman and chief executive of New Age Beverages Ltd., the local bottling joint venture with Pepsi.
 
Coke Disputes Statement
 Polly Howes, a spokeswoman for the Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta, said that Mr. Mthembu's statement was "a blatantly inaccurate portrayal of Coca-Cola in South Africa, obviously made by someone out of touch with the facts or who has a business bias."
She said that Coke sold its South African bottling operations to independent franchises in 1986. Blacks own a majority of one of the companies and two others are public companies in which blacks own stock, she said.
Ms. Howes said that Coca-Cola currently had no employees and no assets in South Africa. "At this point we are continuing to evaluate our options regarding re-entry," she said.
Pepsi-Cola International sold its company-owned bottling operation to a group that included black investors. The operation was later sold again and ceased operations.
In a telephone interview from Johannesburg, Mr. Mthembu, a 40-year-old native black South African, said that Pepsi "will involve black people in a process of empowerment, ranging from ownership and management to community support programs."
Mr. Mthembu said that "we are not going to sell our beverages purely because we are black," adding that the quality of Pepsi-Cola beverages and the qualifications of the management would be the best sales tools.
"This is a demanding business and we will run it professionally," he said. "But people here are calling for black ownership, and we do see New Age Beverages as being a part of that."
 
Revolutionary toTurned Businessman
 Mr. Mthembu described himself as "a former revolutionary" who once spent three years in prison with Nelson Mandela. He turned to the business world in 1986, "when we felt that liberation meant getting the economy in our hands," he said. For the last three years he was managing director of the African General Insurance Company Ltd., the largest black-owned insurance company in South Africa.
The president and chief operating officer of South Africa's Pepsi-Cola venture will be Monwabisi P. Fandeso, 35, a black South African engineer who held executive positions with South African Breweries and National Sorghum Breweries in South Africa.
Twenty-five percent of the Pepsi-Cola joint venture will be owned by Pepsi and 75 percent by Egoli Beverages L.P., a United States-based partnership incorporating black American investors. Egoli was formed by Ian R. Wilson, a white native of South Africa who was once an international manager for the Coca-Cola Company.
One of his partners will be Earl G. Graves, a black American who is chairman and chief executive of the Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company of Washington, and the publisher of Black Enterprise magazine.
New Age will produce and distribute a range of products, including Pepsi-Cola, Diet Pepsi, 7-Up and Mirinda orange beverage.
Initially the new plant, which will be in Johannesburg, will employ 100 to 200 South Africans and sell in the Transvaal province. Pepsico said said the initial sales effort at New Age would be about $100 million over three years.
Pepsi-Cola first entered South Africa in 1948 and when it suspended operations in 1985, it had a 25 percent share of the beverage market, according to Pepsico.

Mthembu, the head of Pepsi's local bottling operation, on Sunday in Johannesburg. (Greg Marinovich/Matrix for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. IS SOFTENING STANCE IN TALKS ON JAPAN TRADE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
Having learned in the last year that it did not have as much economic leverage over Japan as it thought, the Clinton Administration signaled today that it was ready to jettison its all-or-nothing, package-deal approach to a trade agreement with Japan and strike whatever arrangements it could get piece by piece.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, first hinted at the change in remarks to reporters today, and he later elaborated in an interview. Since opening trade talks with Japan last July, the Administration has been pressing Tokyo for a package deal, known as a "framework," that would consist of agreements for opening five priority markets in Japan: automobiles, auto parts, insurance, medical equipment and telecommunications. 
 While the Administration never explicitly ruled out the possibility of accepting deals piece by piece, it has been negotiating them as a package from the start. In February, aides to President Clinton boasted that he could have struck a partial deal with Morihiro Hosokawa, who was Japan's Prime Minister at the time, covering only some of these areas, but that Mr. Clinton rejected that as insufficient.
Now American trade officials say that in the new negotiations, agreements to open Japanese markets in medical equipment, telecommunications equipment and insurance seem within reach, and may be ready for signing at the next summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial countries, set for July 8-10 in Naples.
But, the officials said, the two nations remain sharply divided on how to open Japan's automobile and auto parts markets, and this crucial area will probably take much more time to resolve -- if ever. Two-thirds of the United States' $60 billion trade deficit with Japan comes from autos and auto parts.
In effect, the Administration's posture in the framework negotiations with Japan has gone from "all or nothing" to "take what you can get and deal with the rest later."
In a telephone interview from Paris, where he is participating in a meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Mr. Kantor said: "You have got to be realistic. We can't predict what is going to happen in every area. When you are ready to reach agreement on a particular sector, you should go ahead and finalize that and continue to move forward on the other areas.
 "We are not going to wait to open up everything until we make deals in all sectors. But -- let me be very clear -- we don't intend to stop with just one or two sectors either. We see the framework negotiations as a continuing process."
To show some progress, the Administration is now inclined to close whatever separate deals it can on insurance, telecommunications and medical equipment -- three sectors in which the Japanese Government either controls the market or is the biggest purchaser. It would also continue to negotiate for however long it takes on autos and auto parts; private companies and dealers dominate those Japanese markets and are reluctant to open them to foreigners.
Any market-opening agreements in telecommunications, insurance and medical equipment would undoubtedly benefit American exporters. But without a deal opening Japan's markets in autos and auto parts, these other agreements would probably have a small impact on the nations' huge trade imbalance.
With Mr. Clinton and Prime Minister Tsutomo Hata due to meet in July at the Group of Seven meeting, the Administration appears ready to accept at least a piecemeal deal so that the last year of negotiations will not appear to have been a total waste. Neither American nor Japanese officials want to go into another high-profile Group of Seven meeting with their trade stalemate still simmering, since that could only further roil the financial markets, push down the dollar's value and raise American interest rates.
Mr. Kantor's remarks were the latest in a series of subtle shifts in the Clinton Administration's trade policy toward Japan, as it has learned the hard way that it does not have as much clout with Tokyo as it initially thought and that it is going to have to adjust to that reality.
 The lessons the Administration has learned in the last year of dealing with Tokyo include these:
*Japan, which has had three Prime Ministers in the last 12 months, is going through a period of prolonged internal turmoil, which has left it without a political leadership with enough clout and credibility to strike the sort of far-reaching market-opening agreements that Mr. Clinton came into office demanding.
*Mr. Clinton's get-tough policy toward Japan may have played well on Main Street, but it bombed on Wall Street, where fears of a trade war helped to push down the value of the dollar, drive up American interest rates and generally unnerve the financial markets. The currency and bond markets reacted negatively to the get-tough approach, tying the Administration's hands and forcing it to lower its voice considerably when dealing with Tokyo.
*With the North Korea nuclear standoff heading into a crucial stage, the White House wants to have maximum cooperation with Tokyo, whose support is indispensable if any economic sanctions are to imposed on Pyongyang.
*Within the Clinton Administration, particularly the Treasury Department, there has long been a feeling that the different market-opening agreements the Administration has been seeking from Tokyo were a waste of time and energy. America's Asian and European allies did not support them; nor did the Japan's business community or its public.
What Washington should be focusing on instead, Treasury officials argued, is getting the Japanese Government to come up with a macro-economic stimulus program of tax cuts and Government spending that will spur consumer demand for imports from all sectors of the Japanese economy, be popular with the Japanese public and have the support of American allies from Asia to Europe.
 
 
A Striking Shift
 There is now a strong feeling in some quarters of the Clinton Administration that Washington should get as much as it can from Tokyo on the market-opening agreements, declare victory and focus in the future on the macro-economic side.
This is a striking shift. The framework that Washington and Tokyo agreed on in July for negotiating market-opening agreements stipulated the five areas that were not open to foreign competition as they should be.
In February, after eight months of inconclusive negotiations, the talks were aborted by President Clinton, even though aides told him at the time that they could probably obtain a partial deal covering some of the areas, like medical equipment, but not others, particularly autos and auto parts.
Late last month, the two sides agreed to resume talks after Tokyo explicitly accepted the American demand for numerical indicators and Washington specifically promised not to treat these numerical yardsticks as hard and fast import quotas.

HEADLINE: Albany to Expand Fingerprinting Plan For Welfare Funds

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 6

 BODY:
The Governor and legislative leaders have agreed to expand a contentious program for fingerprinting welfare recipients to a total of 12 counties. But top officials said today that the plan, part of an evolving deal on the state budget, excludes New York City, where two-thirds of the state's welfare recipients live.
Details of the fingerprinting program -- aimed at curbing welfare fraud -- emerged today as negotiators rushed to seal the final details of the roughly $34 billion state budget, which is now more than two months late. Though several important parts of the budget remained unsettled, the package includes more than $450 million in tax cuts, mostly to businesses, and is loaded with election-year spending projects across the state. 
 Although the Legislature is usually loath to increase its own budget in an election year, top officials in both houses said today that the agreement includes a modest increase in the $167 million budget spent on staff, supplies and other expenses. They would not disclose the amount of the increase. New York already has the most expensive legislature in the country.
And while state aid to schools and localities was expected to rise, officials in New York City complained that a bill passed by the Legislature today could open a gaping hole in the city budget.
City officials said they calculated the state budget would mean between $260 million and $300 million in increased state assistance for the city. Their complaint is that the bill would force the city to spend the aid on students rather than using it where the city decided the need was greatest; the officials said that could leave a $70 million gap in the city's budget.
Robert M. Harding, the city's lobbyist in Albany, said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would begin lobbying Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has not taken a position on the bill. "I'm sure we'll start expressing our reservations about this bill to the Governor's people," Mr. Harding said.
 
Assistance to Schools
 The Legislature voted today on two parts of a budget deal that officials said was all but complete: debt service and the $5.7 billion capital spending package. On Tuesday, the State Senate and the Assembly are expected to review other parts of the deal, including state assistance to schools and localities, and lawmakers were standing by in Albany to vote this week on the entire package, which was 67 days late today.
The deal on the fingerprinting program was among the most difficult to reach between the Senate and the Assembly, aides on both sides said. The Republican-controlled Senate, with Mr. Cuomo's support, was pushing for a statewide program, but the Democrats who control the Assembly argued that fingerprinting treats welfare recipients like criminals.
"It's merely a case of political posturing," said Mark A. Dunlea, executive director of Hunger Action Network of New York State, a coalition of soup kitchens and food pantries. "It sells well politically for them to say they are doing something about welfare fraud."
The final deal, scheduled to go before rank-and-file legislators on Tuesday, calls for the program to be expanded in October to 12 counties, including Rockland and Onongada Counties, which were already part of a pilot fingerprinting program. The program would cost roughly $2 million and would be run by each county.
The other counties are Suffolk, Orange, Oneida, Broome, Rensselaer, Niagara, Allegany, Steuben, Dutchess and Oswego. But the program does not include the five counties in New York City, where the greatest number of the state's welfare recipients live and where some advocates of the plan say it would be most useful, in part because there are so many welfare offices.
"We feel finger imaging is a very good way of saving money and we would explore means of doing that," said Cristyne Lategano, press secretary for Mr. Giuliani, who has said he may go forward with the program even without state approval. Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County Executive, has also expressed interest in starting a fingerprinting program.
 
Potential Legal Problem
 But there is a potential legal problem if Mr. Giuliani or other county leaders not in the program decide to initiate fingerprinting.
Opponents contend that fingerprinting amounts to another criterion for welfare, like income, and that the Legislature alone can decide on the criteria. Others argue that a fingerprint is the equivalent of a photograph on a driver's license and does not need legislative approval.
Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat who has opposed fingerprinting, said his chamber agreed to the expansion as a larger, more complete extension of the tests in Rockland and Onondaga Counties, where he said the programs were flawed and did not catch a single welfare cheat. The counties did save money under the program because fewer people applied for benefits, but it was inconclusive whether the fingerprinting was the reason.
 
Cost of Technology
 Mr. Silver said he argued against including New York City in the program because the technology would cost too much for the program he said was untested.
Under the agreement, the program would expire in two years and would be evaluated in an independent study.
The technology for fingerprinting includes an optical scanner tethered to a data bank that can compare a fresh set of prints to thousands of others on file in a matter of minutes. There is no ink: the computer electronically converts a print into a mathematical formula.
Aides said that to appease the Senate, which wanted a more comprehensive program, the deal includes more than $250,000 for enhanced prosecution of welfare cheats in five counties, including New York County (Manhattan), Queens County and Niagara County.
Unlike in past years, the Governor and lawmakers this year have not announced a formal budget deal, and the Legislature is acting on various parts of the budget as negotiations are completed. On Sunday, rank-and-file lawmakers reviewed the capital budget and a tax cut package, which calls for more than $450 million in tax cuts. Those cuts include the phasing out of the surcharge on corporate income taxes, repeal of the state's portion of a tax on luxury hotel rooms and a tax credit for low-income working families.
Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican designee for Governor, said today that he would vote against "the vast majority" of the package, including the tax cuts, and blamed Mr. Cuomo for overspending, though Mr. Pataki's boss in the Senate, the majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, is one of the three architects of the deal.
"It looks like we are going to be spending more than $4 billion more than last year," said Mr. Pataki, who has voted against every budget during his 10 years in the Assembly and Senate. "We continue to spend and tax ourselves into economic uncompetitiveness."
 
Clash With Giuliani
 The fight over aid to New York City schools was in many ways a tangle between Mr. Giuliani and Assembly Democrats, who represent mostly minority neighborhoods and have been upset about the Mayor's cuts in the city budget. The bill passed today requires that the state's five largest cities maintain a steady level of local financing for schools so that the cities cannot use increases in state education aid to offset budget deficits.
Two of Mr. Cuomo's pet projects were scaled down in budget negotiations. A scholarship program for poor college students, for which he had requested $70 million, will be delayed for a year, though $50 million will be set aside for the program for this year's budget. Also, a high school for exceptional math and science students in Albany will be developed without a dormitory, to save $10 million on the $15 million project.
The deal includes repeal of the last tolls on state roads, the 25-cent fees on the Hutchinson and Saw Mill River Parkways, as of Oct. 31. For at least the next eight years, the state will pay for the Westchester County police to continue patrolling the highways.
