HEADLINE: Intractable Pain Of Sickle Cell Begins to Yield

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

 BODY:
THE pain is like no other, its sufferers say, deep, gnawing agony that goes to the bone. Those who have experienced other conditions known for their measure of pain, like cancer, childbirth, arthritis and surgery, almost always say none compares with the torment of sickle cell disease.
The pain of sickle cell is not only intractable but in many cases lifelong. And while many people have heard that the condition is associated with acute suffering, experts say, few have a sense of how bad it can be. 
 Sickle cell disease is an inherited blood disorder that afflicts millions worldwide and tens of thousands in the United States, where it usually takes the form of sickle cell anemia, with varying degrees of severity.
Specialists say pain in general, and sickle cell pain in particular, is not being treated adequately. Concern about unnecessary patient suffering resulted in recent Federal guidelines on treating surgical and cancer pain. Experts say there has also been growing interest in the pain of sickle cell, in part because it takes a unique form and in part because of the increasing realization that most doctors do not know how to deal with it.
"There is not one kind of sickle cell pain, and it can't be treated as such," said Dr. Lennette J. Benjamin, a leading sickle cell pain researcher who is co-director of the Sickle Cell Center at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. "Many of the standard approaches to treating pain do not work well with sickle cell disease. You can't apply any treatment universally to all sickle cell patients."
Sickle cell pain combines chronic suffering with acute, severe attacks, called crises. If not properly treated, experts say, this combined pain causes a buildup of toxic substances that further injure cells, Dr. Benjamin said, causing more pain and inflammation in a cascading action.
While other types of chronic pain, like that associated with rheumatoid arthritis, can last for years, few are coupled with recurring acute episodes, Dr. Benjamin said, and few begin as early as infancy and last for life, as sickle cell pain can.
Not all those with sickle cell disease suffer equally. Studies indicate that more than 50 percent of patients experience significant acute or chronic pain, while nearly 40 percent rarely or never have such episodes. About 20 percent of patients account for 80 percent of hospitalizations for acute painful episodes.
Researchers have recently reported a number of new approaches to treating sickle cell pain, including using high doses of inflammation-fighting steroid drugs and applying epidural injections of local anesthetics into the lower spine, a method also used to control the pain of labor.
 
It Starts With Hemoglobin
 With sickle cell disease, the body produces abnormal forms of hemoglobin, the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout the body. Stress, temperature changes and other factors that are not well understood somehow cause cells containing this hemoglobin to stiffen and distort into odd, prickly shapes, which can clog small blood vessels. These painful occlusions can lead to stroke, damage to bones and internal organs and life-threatening infections.
Dr. George R. Buchanan of the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, who has treated sickle cell patients for more than 20 years, noticed that pain crises include swelling, redness, warmness to the touch and increased white blood cell counts -- typical of an inflammatory response. Exploiting this idea, Dr. Buchanan, Dr. Timothy C. Griffin and others treated 36 children and adolescents undergoing 56 acute pain episodes with doses of a corticosteroid, methylprednisolone, or a placebo.
The researchers found that two doses of the steroid 24 hours apart caused a rapid reduction in pain in several patients and generally shortened hospital stays by a third, although a small number of the children suffered rebound bouts of pain within days after initial improvement. The results, published recently in The New England Journal of Medicine, were encouraging enough for Dr. Buchanan to begin a new study with another steroid, dexamethasone, given in four doses over a 48-hour period. Dr. Buchanan said he hoped this would produce similar positive results without the rebound problem.
In another study, Dr. Myron Yaster and his colleagues at the Pediatric Pain Service at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore found that children who did not respond well to conventional pain therapy during sickle cell crises recovered faster and reported little pain after getting spinal anesthetics. Dr. Yaster said his group has found these epidurals using local anesthetics, like lidocaine, give better relief for almost all kinds of pain than intravenous infusions of narcotics.
 
Relief in 15 Minutes
 In the first application of this technique to sickle cell disease, the researchers said in a report in the February issue of Pediatrics, eight of nine children in severe pain from the chest down reported dramatic relief within 15 minutes of starting the treatment, which took an average of three days.
"Of all the pains we see, the hardest to manage is sickle cell crisis pain," Dr. Yaster said. "So, we are encouraged by these results and have submitted a grant application to study using this technique as first-line therapy."
Sickle cell anemia is most prominent in Africa, but varies widely in incidence throughout the continent. The genetic predisposition toward the disease varies from about 7 percent to 25 percent in West Africa, for example, compared with about 8 percent among black Americans, said Dr. James E. Bowman of the University of Chicago, an expert in the worldwide epidemiology of the disease. Experts say 1 of every 375 to 400 black Americans, more than 60,000 people, is afflicted with sickle cell anemia at birth.
In addition, sickle cell anemia is found in some whites whose ancestors came from the Mediterranean area, as well as among people in India, the Middle East, the Caribbean and Central and South America. The genetic mutations that cause sickle cell arose in many places where malaria was prominent, including the southern Mediterranean and India, because sickle cell disease has a protective effect against malaria, Dr. Bowman said.
Sickle cell patients around the world describe the pain in similar terms. Dr. Barbara S. Shapiro, a specialist at Children's Hospital in Philadelphia, noted that many African tribal names for the disease translate variously as "body chewing" or "body biting," or in the case of "nwiiwii," in the language of the Fanti tribe of Ghana, imitate the screams and moans of victims.
"The thing about sickle cell pain is that it is intense and you never know when it will occur," said Dr. Dorothy C. Moore, a physician and pathologist who has sickle cell disease. "I had my most severe painful episodes when I was younger, but it has evolved into a chronic type of pain that I have just about all the time. It's similar to acute arthritis, but instead of just my joints hurting, the whole bone itself hurts."
 
'A Pulsating Pain'

 
 Dr. Moore, who is 42 and an associate professor of laboratory medicine at the New Jersey College of Medicine in Newark, said she still has acute pain episodes several times a year, mostly involving her lower legs and back. But they occur less frequently than they did in her youth and last only one or two days, instead of five.
"For me, it's a pulsating pain, hard in intensity, that usually occurs in the same spots," she said. "When I feel it coming on, I try to engross myself in my work and ward it off. I don't always succeed."
There is no cure for sickle cell disease, but a few experimental treatments, including the use of drugs like hydroxyurea and butyrate to stimulate production of more beneficial forms of hemoglobin, are beginning to offer the first hopes of attacking the underlying cause of the illness. Most current treatments, like giving patients intravenous fluids, blood transfusions and pain killers, are aimed at relieving symptoms of the disease.
Deaths from sickle cell disease have decreased greatly in the last 20 years, primarily because of early diagnosis and better control over infections that previously killed so many patients, experts said. The vast majority of patients now survive into adulthood and those in their 50's and 60's are becoming common, they said. But older patients develop chronic pain that can damage organs and bones and lead to secondary arthritis.
Dr. Clarice Reid, chief of the Sickle Cell Disease Branch of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, said studies show pain not only affects quality of life, but mortality itself. A 1991 study of more than 3,500 sickle cell patients treated at 23 medical centers pointed out the pain-mortality link, she said. It found that among those with sickle cell who were more than 20 years old, people with high rates of pain episodes -- averaging three or more a year -- tended to die earlier than those with low rates.
"Pain is not just a subjective part of the disease," Dr. Reid said. "It has implications for longevity."
 
Obstacles to Treatment

 
 Part of the problem in dealing with sickle cell pain is societal. Dr. Elliot P. Vichinsky, chief of hemotology-oncology and director of the Sickle Cell Center at Oakland Children's Hospital in Oakland, Calif., said, "Many sickle cell patients do not get good care, both because their pain is not understood and because of social factors, like ethnic bias and economic issues."
Many doctors who see sickle cell pain in emergency rooms or clinics do not understand it because the source of the pain is not always obvious, and most physicians are not trained to deal with severe pain, Dr. Vichinsky said. And since almost all of the patients are black and many are from disadvantaged backgrounds, he said, some doctors without sickle cell experience may suspect that the patient is just trying to get narcotic pain killers to abuse.
"Even when sickle cell disease is diagnosed and doctors know the pain is real, many patients do not get good treatment because there is no simple way to handle it," Dr. Vichinsky said. "Sickle cell patients need an aggressive, multi-disciplinary approach to treatment, but they are often shunted aside to hemotologists outside of major centers who are not geared to take care of them."

HEADLINE: In Budapest, Signs Of a Literary Life After Communism

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, June 6

 BODY:
The Budapest Book Week used to be a worthy event, where Hungary's state-run publishing houses dutifully released art volumes, comradely fiction from the Warsaw Pact countries and, in the 1980's, a smattering of Western titles. Then, after the collapse of Communism, the literary fireworks that everyone anticipated failed to materialize and publishing, afflicted by economic hardship, went into the doldrums.
But at the 65th annual fair, held here last week on graceful Vorosmarty Square in the center of the city, a fresh spirit seemed to dominate, suggesting that new writing was at last emerging in Eastern Europe after a five-year dry spell. 
 Amid the 41 booths, privately owned publishers with lists of contemporary Hungarian writers did brisk business. Some of the state-run publishers offered current fiction alongside their usual fare of picture books. And there was lively interest in the Hungarian translation of "Under the Frog," by Tibor Fischer, a 35-year-old British writer born of Hungarian parents.
"Under the Frog," a comic novel set in Hungary between World War II and the 1956 uprising, was a finalist for Britain's Booker Prize last fall. The novel, published here by Europa, a privatized state firm, has just been released in the United States by the New Press.
 
Period of Despair
 "There was a despair for one or two years after 1989, when writers were submerged in politics every day," said George Bolgar, the new director of Helikon, a venerable Hungarian publishing house that has been losing money but hopes to change this by presenting new writing. "But the best of them have raised the level of writing about contemporary politics. Peter Esterhazy has written articles in daily papers that can be considered as literature but with reference to day-to-day politics."
Mr. Esterhazy, one of only a few contemporary Hungarian writers whose work is translated into English, had a new collection at the fair: "Egy Kekharisnya Feljegyzesey," roughly translated as "Notes From an Intelligent Whore." The pieces, which are both literary and political, make reference to the characters and policies of the right-of-center Government that was elected in Hungary in 1990 and was defeated in elections last month.
Mr. Bolgar, a well-known radio journalist before he joined Helikon recently, said the theme of how a Communist society transforms itself was a compelling one. "To describe how a society collapsed and this new something emerged, and how people lived through this, that is the most intriguing," he said.
Despite the impression in the West that Eastern Europe is making the transition from Communism without much difficulty, the new writing here strikes an opposite and rather mordant chord. Mr. Bolgar, for example, rushed out a collection of pieces by Tivadar Farkashazy, whom he described as a cross between the American columnists Art Buchwald and Dave Barry. Mr. Farkashazy's "I Don't Understand" is a sort of "grotesque chronicle" of the last four years, Mr. Bolgar said.
 
A House Making a Profit
 Abovo, a new publishing house founded in 1991 by Miklos Vamos, a novelist and dramatist, has issued 28 novels and 2 nonfiction books in inexpensive editions designed to sell in the hard economic times. With a Budapest restaurant guide in Hungarian ("Foglatjon Helyet" or "Have a Seat") that has become a solid seller, and with low overhead, the company is making a profit, Mr. Vamos said.
"I hope the big publishing houses go bankrupt as soon as possible," said Mr. Vamos, who helped organize this year's fair and perked it up with outdoor music performances and events for children. "The state grants go to publishers who are the favorite children of the Government. The next Government won't like me because I won't support them either."
His house has made contracts with four highly regarded Hungarian writers: Gyorgy G. Kardos, Gyorgy Spiro, Akos Kertesz and Judit Fenakel.
For the fair, Abovo released a new collection of short stories by Mr. Spiro, the title of which is a play on words that can be roughly translated as "Horroar". These stories are about the "madness" of the last four years, the publisher said. Abovo has also published "Reflections," a first novel by a 30-year-old writer, Zsuzsa Kapecz; it is an abstract tale set in the Hungarian countryside (although the book never specifically mentions Hungary), with thinly veiled characters from the political scene of the last four years.
 
Misjudging of Demand?

 
 One problem for Hungarian writers, whose language is one of the most inaccessible in Europe, is a general lack of translation for Western markets. Hungarian publishers say this is because of a lack of interest. "Usually, Americans just want one author from a country like ours," said Mr. Vamos. The fact that there are two such writers from Hungary, George Konrad and Peter Esterhazy, "makes me very proud," he said.
But Tony Lang, the owner of Bestsellers, an English-language bookshop in Budapest, believes Hungarians are underestimating the demand for English translations of Hungarian literature.
"The publishers here haven't understood how much they can sell of the English version of a Hungarian book," said Mr. Lang, whose store offers a wider range of current American and British books than any other store in Eastern Europe and who recently held a book signing for Mr. Fischer with "Under the Frog."
"There are several thousand English-speaking people here who are always asking for Hungarian books in English," said Mr. Lang. "As well, the publishers could exploit the audience in the United States who are second- and third-generation Hungarians who would prefer to read their Hungarian literature in English. But that takes effort."
Mr. Lang, pointing to a sign of interest in Hungarian writing, said he gets at least five people a day inquiring about English translations of Hungarian poets. So far, he has not been able to come up with a good anthology in English. As for novels by some of Hungary's other established literary writers -- Gyula Krudy, Miklos Meszoly and Ivan Mandy, for instance -- there is nothing in English, Mr. Lang said. "It is a neglected opportunity."

HEADLINE: U.S. Steps Up North Korea Talks And Drafts an Embargo Plan

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 6

 BODY:
The United States intensified consultations here today, seeking to build a coalition in favor of punitive action against North Korea if it continues to defy United Nations nuclear inspectors.
American officials said the United States had drafted a proposed resolution for an economic embargo but had not yet shown the text to other countries. 
 The United States representative, Madeleine K. Albright, met with the South Korean Foreign Minister, Han Sung Joo, and had separate meetings with the representatives of Japan and China. She then met with the four countries that along with the United States are permanent members of the Security Council -- Britain, China, France and Russia. Each permanent member has the power to veto Council decisions.
 
Assistant Secretary Attends
 Also on hand for these meetings was Assistant Secretary of State Robert Gallucci. He has led the unsuccessful American campaign to persuade North Korea to meet its obligations under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty in return for an end to its diplomatic isolation, including better relations with the United States.
After meeting with this month's Council President, Salim bin-Mohammed al-Khussaiby of Oman, Foreign Minister Han indicated that South Korea supported the threat of sanctions against the North, describing a trade embargo as "the most important option we are discussing."
Mr. Han also expressed optimism about China's attitude, despite Beijing's professed opposition to sanctions in the past, saying, "I don't expect China to be standing in the way of trying to solve this issue."
In Washington, the State Department announced that its third-ranking official, Peter Tarnoff, the Under Secretary for Political Affairs, would go to Japan and South Korea this week for further talks with the leaders of those countries.
 
'Corrective Action' Sought
 American officials said the Clinton Administration's immediate goals were first to encourage "corrective action" by North Korea that would allow inspectors of the International Atomic Energy Agency to reconstruct as much as possible of the history of the reactor at its nuclear site at Yongbyon.
The second objective is to prevent any further deterioration in the situation there that would make it harder to discover whether North Korea had secretly removed nuclear explosive from the reactor when it was shut down for a hundred days in 1989.
On Friday, the director of the agency, Hans Blix, told the Security Council that North Korea had dismantled so much of the reactor's core, despite agency protests, that it was impossible for inspectors to tell whether plutonium had been covertly reprocessed from removed fuel rods.
The agency has already established that North Korea secretly manufactured some plutonium in violation of its safeguards agreement with the agency, although it is not known how much.
An agency request to examine two nuclear waste dumps that might throw light on this question was rejected.
When the Security Council has imposed trade sanctions in the past, as it has on Iraq, Yugoslavia and Haiti, the Council has first issued a warning, setting a deadline for compliance with its orders before the embargo goes into force.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Warning From the North
 SEOUL, South Korea, June 6 (Special to The New York Times) -- In one of its most strident and ominous warnings that it would not submit to pressure from the United Nations, North Korea said today that "sanctions mean outright war."
The statement, which was combined with an unusually specific threat against the President of South Korea, Kim Young Sam, was issued by the Committee for Peaceful Unification of the Fatherland, the group in the North Korean Government that oversees inter-Korea affairs.
A North Korean broadcast said that if "Kim Young Sam dares to move toward the road of adventure, this will mean his end."
While American and South Korean officials have grown somewhat inured to North Korea's often-inflated language, the comments today clearly prompted concern, and there were small signs of increased military readiness here. The South Korean Prime Minister, Lee Young Dug, said after a meeting of the heads of various security agencies that "now is the time to prepare the people for a series of contingency steps."
Prime Minister Lee also declared a crackdown on radical students who have supported North Korea, saying the Government would not tolerate "forces trying to wreck our free democratic system."
So far the North appears not to have responded to several openings created by President Clinton, who said over the weekend that he thought a diplomatic solution was still possible if additional North Korean sites were opened to inspectors.

HEADLINE: It's Your Money or Strife in Zaire, Where Corruption Reigns

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire

 BODY:
Traveler to Zaire, beware!
Stepping off the sweltering tarmac at Ndjili, the new arrival becomes a helpless fish in a sea of sharks. 
 Snap! The passport disappears, perhaps taken by the man with some kind of emblem fastened to his lapel by a paper clip. Snip! The luggage goes off in two directions.
The visitor is led into a darkened office for interrogation. The passport magically reappears. But there are problems: Something strange about the visa, perhaps. An ulterior motive for your visit? The questions swirl into a crescendo of accusations.
But perhaps all this can be overlooked. A $50 bill on the table is scooped up like raw bait.
More money is required to locate the suitcases and get through customs and then to pay off the touts and soldiers who cram into the taxi peeling off toward the capital.
The departure is worse, for now the visitor has been here long enough to commit certain offenses. Smuggling? Black market trading? Spying? The interrogation can last an hour or more. It slows to an impasse as the flight is being announced.
The extortion of money from visitors by officials who receive no regular pay is only the most superficial manifestation of a malady that runs deep in Zaire and some other African countries. Corruption is a constant source of conversation, but it is never mentioned in studies by the World Bank or the United Nations.
Unlike eruptions of scandals in, say, Italy or Japan, the corruption here never erupts; it is a constant, diplomats, scholars and Africans themselves say. It runs up and down through the entire country, from the soldier in sunglasses who flags down a motorist to extract a bribe for an imaginary infraction to President Mobutu Sese Seko, who has become one of the world's richest men by plundering Zaire's treasury.
"This isn't just greasing the wheels so that the pie keeps growing. It's an impediment to growth, pure and simple," said an American State Department official.
The gross national product of almost all countries south of the Sahara has been in a decline for over a decade, and while there are many reasons for this, corruption and economic mismanagement rank high among them.
Nigeria, gushing with oil and go-for-broke capitalism, is widely deemed to be the most corrupt country in West Africa. Beginning in the early 1970's -- when 20 million tons of cement was ordered in a kickback scheme that clogged the harbor with sinking freighters -- generations of leaders have enriched themselves.
The Economist magazine estimated in April that about $3 billion -- or 10 percent of the gross domestic product -- "disappeared" out of Nigeria's public accounts in 1992.
If Nigeria is the king of "dash" in West Africa, Zaire is the undisputed champion in central Africa. "Everything is for sale -- anything can be bought in our country," Mr. Mobutu once said.
One former Foreign Minister, Nguza Karl-I-Bond -- who was sentenced to death for treason and fled into exile and is inexplicably back working as a deputy defense minister -- testified in Washington in the 1970's that Mr. Mobutu had stashed away $5 billion.
One Western diplomat said he thinks the president "operates more like a franchise system -- he'll give you the exclusive right to import chickens from Europe or to sell fish to the army or to operate cellular telephones."
Not long ago, Telecel, a largely American-owned company, was granted an exclusive contract to operate a cellular phone system. Then another outfit mysteriously appeared, owned by the son of Bemba Saolona, one of Mr. Mobutu's closest associates. Telecel cables were cut. Then a microwave appeared on a nearby building, jamming its antenna. Local papers call it the "battle of the frequencies," but nobody doubts who is going to win.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise on Fed News, Then Slip

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
For much of yesterday, the stock market rallied as a report that the Federal Reserve Board was unlikely to raise interest rates in the next few weeks sent bond prices higher.
But by the afternoon, stock traders were selling their suddenly more valuable shares as they took profits after having little to show in the trendless market of the last few weeks. The major indexes closed mixed and barely changed. 
 Blue chips like Chevron, General Motors and Sears, Roebuck, as well as health care companies like Abbott Laboratories and oil companies like Mobil all fell. But over-the-counter stocks like Microsoft and US Health Care held on to their gains.
The selling was accelerated late in the day as some computer-guided trading kicked in. Starting at 3:30 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average fell nearly 22 points while the Standard & Poor's 500, starting at 3:15 P.M., fell nearly 3 points.
By the closing gavel, the Dow settled at 3,768.52, down 3.70 points, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 settled at 458.88, down 1.25 points.
Of the major indexes, only the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index kept some gains. In the last half- hour of trading, the Nasdaq fell more than a point, but closed up 1.05 points, to 743.43.
Even a sharp drop in the Commodity Research Bureau index, a proxy for commodities traders' inflation outlook, failed to sustain the rally. It fell 3.21 points, to 228.84, one of the steepest drops this year. Abundant rain in the Midwest over the weekend helped bring down the price of futures contracts for soybeans and related products.
Perhaps unsurprisingly, the number of shares changing hands yesterday remained below average as it has since May 17, when the Fed raised interest rates for the fourth time this year. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled only 259.1 million shares, some 14 percent below this year's average of 300 million shares.
 
Traders Spend Time on Sidelines
 Although Monday is often a below-average day, stock traders have spent a great deal of time on the sidelines in the last few weeks wondering whether the Fed would raise rates soon or hold off consideration of tighter monetary policy until autumn.
Yesterday, The New York Times reported that three of the five sitting Fed governors contend that inflation is under control and that another interest-rate increase unnecessary for now. The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, on which the seven Fed governors serve along with the presidents of five of the 12 the regional Federal Reserve Banks, will meet next month to decide the next move on interest rates. There are two vacancies on the Federal Reserve Board at the moment.
Long-term interest rates, a proxy for bond traders' inflation outlook, fell. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 17/32 , to 888/32 . Its yield, the interest rate a current bond needs to pay to coax new buyers, fell to 7.21 percent from 7.27 percent. Since May 31, in five trading sessions, the bond's yield has fallen 22 basis points. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.17 point, to 254.17, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks 1,320 to 864. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.75 point, to 442.59.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 17 fell, led by Chevron, which fell 1 point, to 87 3/4, following news of cost overruns at a huge Canadian offshore oil project now being built. Chevron is a part-owner of the project.
Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 220 fell, led by Pepsico, which fell 1 3/8, to 34 5/8. A Goldman, Sachs analyst reduced his assessment of Pepsico, but continued to recommend the stock, citing slower-than-expected growth at Taco Bell and other Pepsico restaurants.
Even the most active stock was not all that active. At 4.8 million shares, the most heavily traded stock was Microsoft, which rose 1 5/8, to 54 1/2. It was unclear what news might have affected the stock. The most immediate news was that The Wall Street Journal reported that Justice Department investigators were interviewing Microsoft executives as part of an antitrust investigation.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 8, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about stock market activity on Monday misstated the trading volume of the Microsoft Corporation's shares. A total of 47.8 million Microsoft shares were traded, not 4.8 million shares.

HEADLINE: Stop Benefits for Aliens? It Wouldn't Be That Easy

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, June 7

 BODY:
On a sultry day in July, a 25-year-old woman, Laura C., waded across the Rio Grande, slipped past the Border Patrol in Brownsville, Tex., and boarded a $49 Southwest Airlines flight to Houston.
Hoping for work and a better life, she has instead subsisted on government benefits and become one more straw threatening to break the back of America's uneasy patience with illegal immigrants. 
 With at least four million illegal aliens in the country, politicians from Florida to California have introduced dozens of bills to stop giving them services like education to health care.
Laura C., the unmarried mother of two children with a third on the way when she arrived, reached Houston with no English and no plan beyond her sister's assurance that she could find house-cleaning jobs at $40 a day.
"I had never heard of food stamps; I had never heard of W.I.C.," Laura said, naming the two Federal programs that put $46.50 worth of food on her family's table each week. (She did not want her last name used for fear of being found and deported.)
Most of the benefits are available because Laura's baby boy, Jacobo, born at public expense at Ben Taub General Hospital here five months ago, is an American citizen.
Illegal immigrants are not always a drain on the American economy. Many pay more in direct and indirect taxes than they get in government services. But Laura and her children epitomize the immigrants who angry taxpayers say come here in violation of American law and live off the American safety net.
Nevertheless, it would be extremely difficult, and perhaps even legally impossible, to reduce aid to illegal immigrants significantly. Public schools would have to turn away children, and hospitals would have to refuse treatment to accident victims and pregnant women. Education and emergency medical care represent at least two-thirds of the estimated $7 billion spent each year by all levels of government on illegal immigrants, according to the Center for Immigration Studies, a research group in Washington.
But longstanding Federal and state laws and court rulings require hospitals to provide emergency care for anyone, regardless of immigration status, and the Supreme Court ruled in 1982 that any child on American soil has the right to an education.
Barring catastrophic illness, by far the single largest cost that Laura's family will pose to taxpayers is the education of her three children: Jesus, 5 years old, who registered for kindergarten last week; Nicole, who turns 3 in a few days, and Jacobo.
The Federal, state and local governments pay an average of $4,683 a year for a student in Houston. If Laura's three children go through high school, the bill would come to more than $182,000 in today's dollars.
Nationwide, the cost of educating illegal immigrants is estimated to be at least $3 billion a year -- and $4.5 billion when the American-born children of illegal immigrants are included.
As for health care, many proposals to cut aid would do little more than transfer to local governments the obligations that have been assumed by Federal programs, like Medicaid, which helped to pay for Jacobo's delivery in January.
Welfare, by contrast, is largely unavailable to illegal immigrants, a vast majority of whom work and pay some taxes. Only a small minority receive benefits, generally through relatives who are American citizens.
Laura does not qualify for Aid for Families With Dependent Children, the welfare program that provides cash to recipients. But for now, she and her daughter, Nicole, qualify for $12 a week in food coupons from the Women, Infants and Children program, a supplemental Federal benefit for nursing mothers, who are eligible regardless of citizenship, and for children under 5. Jacobo qualifies for another $8 a week under this program.
Any long-term benefits are likely to come through Jacobo, whose rights to welfare are the same as those of any native-born American.
Politicians who favor deep reductions in all types of aid to illegal immigrants hope to change the rules. Some, like Gov. Pete Wilson of California, have called for a constitutional amendment to take away citizenship rights from the American-born children of illegal aliens. A California ballot initiative would bar illegal immigrants from schools. If approved, the measure is certain to face legal challenges.
There has generally been less pressure for such aggressive action in other parts of the country -- even in places like New York and Texas, which both have large populations of illegal immigrants.
Proponents of the changes say they would discourage people like Laura C. from entering the country. But many experts, and immigrants themselves, say curtailed services would not deter people, because their primary goal is to find a job.
"For those who have come to work -- and believe me, that is most -- it won't matter if you cut the benefits," Laura said. "There may be problems when they come here, they may find work or they may not. Maybe the work will not pay as much as they thought. But they'll come anyway."
Supporters of a crackdown counter that even if the cutoff fails to stem the tide, it is outrageous for taxpayers to bear any burden for those who have entered the country illegally.
"An illegal alien dilutes in part or altogether the legal rights and privileges of a legal citizen," said Representative Lamar Smith of Texas, the chairman of the House Republican Task Force on Immigration.
But many experts warn that unless the measures being proposed succeed in keeping illegal immigrants out altogether, carrying them out could ultimately pose health and safety problems for all Americans.
"Let's suppose we want to really save some money and get tough with all these illegal immigrants," said Prof. Nestor Rodriguez, a sociologist at the University of Houston who has studied immigrants here. "Here is what you would do: Close the doors to the hospitals, even when a woman is coming to give birth. Lock the kids out of school, and tell them they have no future at all. Do not pay for their immunizations. Do not let them use clinics. That is the way to save some really big money. But at what cost later on?"
 Marginal Existence With Much Help
 Laura C. and her family scrape by. It takes her an hour and a half to travel across town by bus to the city-run West End Multi-Service Center, where she picks up $26.50 in food stamps and about $20 in coupons from the Women, Infants and Children program. She also receives a small stipend under the food-stamp program for diapers.
In a cramped room at the welfare center, large posters in English read "Food Affects Our Moods" and "Food Influences Our Appearance."
"I don't even know what they say," Laura said.
The W.I.C. coupons, stamped "least expensive brand required," provide the family with nine gallons of milk a month, four dozen eggs, three pounds of cheese, four bottles of juice, two large boxes of cereal, two pounds of beans, one 18-ounce jar of peanut butter, two pounds of carrots and eight 31/2 -ounce cans of tuna fish.
"Some weeks there isn't enough at the end," Laura said, "but most of the time we can get by."
Laura's older sister arrived here illegally eight years ago and did well enough as a maid to send money to her parents in Veracruz, Mexico.
Unlike her sister, who has no children, Laura said her decision to come here was less a calculated decision than an act of desperation.
None of the three fathers, all in Mexico, have ever seen their children or provided support, she said.
Laura says she expected to work and her sister to help watch the children. She worked briefly cleaning houses for $25 a day and cooking tamales at an outdoor market. But then, she says, she got into a fight with her sister, who demanded that she get an abortion when she was six months' pregnant with Jacobo.
She refused and moved out; she lost both jobs because she had no one to look after the children. One prospective employer told her that if she applied for a job she would be reported to immigration authorities.
Desperate, she turned to a private women's shelter, which set her up in a rent-free one-bedroom apartment near a huge coffee factory in Houston's East End and told her how to apply for government benefits for her children.
Virtually everything in Laura's life is paid with scrip, which includes bus tokens she receives from the women's shelter. The only cash she sees is the occasional quarter or two she gets when she buys groceries.
She has built up the smallest of nest eggs -- $5.64 so far -- to pay for a small birthday party for Nicole this month. Food stamps will not pay for candles, ice cream or a toy.
Laura has used a public hospital once, for Jacobo's birth. The hospital bill for a birth without complications typically costs about $1,100 in Houston. The family has also used a city-financed clinic several times for the children's minor illnesses: a sore throat; a stomach virus.
 
Determined To Stay
 What if all these benefits and services were cut tomorrow?
"I don't think I would leave," Laura said.
She explained the difference between Houston and Matamoros, the Mexican border city she left.
"Here, if you see a child alone in the street without shoes, he is cared for," she said. "Somehow, that child will be cared for. There, no. There, you see children in the street, cleaning shoes, and people pass without seeing them."
Many politicians argue it is precisely this perception that induces people to come.
Representative Smith of Texas has proposed a bill that would cut off all benefits to illegal immigrants except emergency health care and public education. If the measure is enacted, Laura would lose about $12 a week in W.I.C. grocery coupons, and she and the two older children could stand to lose privileges at the city health clinic that receives some Federal money.
But Jacobo, the American-born baby, would retain full rights to welfare and Medicaid. He would continue to qualify for food stamps and his portion of the W.I.C. coupons. When he turns 5, he may qualify for larger welfare assistance.
That entitlement has led some politicians like Governor Wilson of California to call for a constitutional amendment to deny citizenship to the offspring of illegal aliens.
But this would be a difficult, long-term undertaking. Supporters of the California ballot initiative, which would bar illegal immigrants from the public schools, are trying a different legal strategy. If approved, the measure would violate Federal law, flouting the 1982 Supreme Court ruling giving all children in the United States the right to a public education.
But some politicians say the time is ripe for a challenge. The Court, they argue, is more conservative now than it was 12 years ago, and the original ruling resulted from a 5-to-4 split.
The proposals for aid cuts come in tandem with measures for keeping people like Laura out of the country. The California initiative would in some cases require schools and hospitals to report those suspected of being illegal aliens.
But deportation in Laura's case would be fraught with legal tangles, because of her American child.
And immigration officials say that with 2,000 miles of shallow riverbed and desert linking the United States and Mexico, sealing the border will never be feasible.
More than half of all illegal immigrants come from Mexico. Others fly in from Latin America, Asia or Europe, enter the country legally, by air as well as over land, then become illegal when they overstay their visas.
Many experts say that if the North American Free Trade Agreement succeeds in elevating economic conditions in Mexico, the forces that lead people to leave will wane.
In the meantime, the question of what to do with Laura and her family remains. She may get a job; then again, she may not.
"Rationally, we should cut off that woman's benefits and deport her if she's deportable," said Mark W. Davis, a former aide to Governor Wilson and now director of the Pacific Research Institute in San Francisco. "But in both humanitarian and practical terms, we find that extremely difficult to do. Humanitarian, because there are children involved. And practically, it's problematic because she'll be back."

HEADLINE: Political Battle Lines Drawn in California Races for Governor and Senator

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 7

 BODY:
Voting without much enthusiasm and coming up with no surprises, Californians nominated candidates today for this fall's elections for governor and the United States Senate, contests with national political implications.
For governor, Republicans chose the incumbent, Pete Wilson, and Democrats chose Treasurer Kathleen Brown. 
 For Senator, Democrats chose the incumbent, Dianne Feinstein, and Republicans chose Representative Michael Huffington of Santa Barbara.
All were easy winners.
Polls indicate that both fall races will probably be closely contested, with the flagging California economy the main issue, followed by crime, taxes and illegal immigration.
And if the primaries were good indicators, both races will be expensive, with the Huffington-Feinstein contest possibly setting a spending record for Congressional elections.
 
National Implications
 From a national standpoint, both fall contests are of interest for what they might say about Democratic and Republican Presidential prospects in 1996 in the country's most populous and politically powerful state. The Feinstein-Huffington race also will help determine whether Democrats retain control of the Senate and whether the small contingent of women in that body shrinks.
Almost from the start of the primary campaigning, there was no serious doubt about the outcome of today's voting, a factor that state election officials said appeared to have reduced voter turnout to below 40 percent, an unusually low level. The favored candidates spent most of their time campaigning against their presumed fall opponents and ignoring their primary opponents.
In the Republican primary for governor, the struggling California economy had deeply depressed Governor Wilson's job approval ratings. But by promising to be tough on crime and illegal immigration and by speeding aid to the Los Angeles area after the January earthquake, he overcame that serious political minus and handily overwhelmed his only major opponent, Ron Unz, the wealthy owner of a Silicon Valley computer company.
Mr. Unz, a 32-year-old hardline conservative, spent a $1 million of his fortune on a blitz of television ads that were highly critical of the Governor, a 60-year-old moderate conservative. While they did not carry the day for Mr. Unz, they may eventually have the unintended effect of softening up Mr. Wilson a bit for the coming bout with Ms. Brown.
With 10 percent of the state's precincts counted and a solid counting trend established, the Governor was leading Mr. Unz 66 percent to 30 percent.
"We've completed the first step," Mr. Wilson said tonight. "We're going to continue to making the kind of change that is going to make California all that it can be."
 
 
Shift by Brown
 In the Democratic primary for governor, Ms. Brown, a moderate liberal, easily overcame challenges by the State Insurance Commissioner, John Garamendi, and State Senator Tom Hayden, best know as one of the noisiest reformers of the 1960's but lately, at the age of 54, a soft, reasoned voice for change.
Mr. Brown, daughter of former Gov. Edmund G. (Pat) Brown and sister of former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., had problems early on in her primary campaign, sometimes stumbling over questions about issues and at other times delivering speeches that seemed unfocused. But midway through the campaign, she reorganized her staff and her pitch -- she began to promise to create a million jobs in the state -- and thereafter she was never in political danger.
With 10 percent of the state's precincts counted, Ms. Brown had 49 percent of the votes, compared with 34 percent for Mr. Garamendi and 11 percent for Mr. Hayden.
"Not bad for a woman, a Democrat and a Brown," Ms. Brown said. Pre-primary polls in which voters were asked about a possible Brown-Wilson fall matchup showed Governor Wilson pulling slightly ahead with Ms. Brown after trailing her by 15 points or so throughout most of the year.
In today's Senate primaries, Ms. Feinstein, a 60-year-old moderate liberal, faced no major opponent in the Democratic contest. She first went to Washington two years ago but faces re-election this year rather than in 1998 because she was sent to serve out the unexpired term of Mr. Wilson, who returned early to California to become Governor.
Ms. Feinstein was not available for comment; her spokesmen said she was in Washington, where the Senate had just returned from the Memorial Day recess.
In the Republican primary, Mr. Huffington easily out ran his major opponents, former Representative William E. Dannemeyer, a 64-year-old hard-right conservative from Orange County.
With 11 percent of the state's precincts reporting, Mr. Huffington had 55 percent of the vote, compared with 28 percent for Mr. Dannemeyer.
"This is the Dianne Feinstein retirement committee," Mr. Huffington told cheering supporters tonight. "Feinstein says government is her life. Maybe it's time for her to get a life." Mr. Huffington's primary campaign was notable in that he poured $6.5 million of his $75 million oil fortune into a television blitz aimed almost entirely at attacking Ms. Feinstein. Seldom has so much been spent so early and so quickly.
But the spending paid off, making Mr. Huffington's name a household word with voters outside his home district, most of whom previously knew little or nothing about him.
Ms. Feinstein began to counter with her own ad campaign a few days ago.

HEADLINE: Largesse, Even Late

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 7

 BODY:
In a $34 billion state budget with a $1.5 billion surplus to spread about like election-year tonic, it would be misleading to suggest there were winners and losers. More to the point, there were winners and lesser winners.
A vast majority of the state's 718 school districts will receive an increase in school aid. Seventeen towns will get new sports stadiums. Most corporations will pay lower corporate income taxes, and an influential few will receive reductions beyond that. And every county will benefit from $9.6 billion in road and bridge work over the next four years. 
 A newly found prosperity is making this budget largesse possible. What better times did not make possible was a timely budget, which had been due April 1. If nothing else, the stalemate that made this budget more than two months late will only reinforce the perception that the Governor and Legislature find consensus hard to reach. In the past, they have blamed their late budgets -- there have been 10 in a row now -- on the political difficulties of cutting programs. This year's revived economy made such excuses obsolete.
"When it comes to making a budget in New York, it seems as difficult to increase spending as it is to cut it," said Cynthia B. Green, deputy research director for the Citizens Budget Commission, a private advocacy group supported by businesses.
 
The Politics of Spring
 To Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the 211 members of the State Legislature, the politically attractive content of this budget seemed to justify the posturing, stalling and political jockeying that filled the final days of budget negotiations. And for good reason: all are up for re-election this fall and all face voters grown testy after five years of recession, rising property taxes and bad-news budgets that cut popular programs.
"The budget process was hijacked by the politics of spring, meaning positioning for the November election," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University.
The many news releases this week spoke volumes of Mr. Cuomo's and lawmakers' admiration for their handiwork. The Republicans who control the Senate issued a 10-page scorecard showing how, in their view, they had one-upped Mr. Cuomo in winning $1.7 billion in business-tax cuts.
In more subdued but no less self-congratulatory tones, the Democratic-led Assembly praised the budget as providing low-cost health insurance and tax credits to the working poor.
 
'Brimming With Good News'
 And not to be outdone, Mr. Cuomo offered a 23-page release detailing how $9.6 billion will be spent in every corner of the state, from a new science library in New York City to landfill improvements in Clinton County to repairs to Buffalo's downtown music hall.
"This need not have been late, but it is arriving brimming with good news and evidence of our strong recovery," said Mr. Cuomo, who is facing perhaps his toughest campaign.
What the news releases shared beyond their air of satisfaction was a willingness to ignore the anxiety and problems created because the budget was 68 days late.
During that time, school and local officials could not plan their budgets because they did not know how much state aid to expect. Scores of state road projects were postponed and may now be finished late. Nonprofit agencies with state contracts had to take out loans to cover payrolls.
And the Legislature now has only three weeks in its session to deal with several major issues, including legalizing gambling, controlling medical malpractice costs and disposing of low-level radioactive waste.
 
No Towers, Just Hurdles
 Outside the Statehouse, there were plenty of critics willing to splash cold water on the celebration inside. Advocates for the poor said the budget did not restore money for social service programs that underwent deep cuts during the recession. Anti-tax groups said the tax cuts did not go far enough, while labor groups said they went too far. And environmentalists said the budget provided the bare minimum to protect open spaces and to clean up landfills.
This year there were no towering issues that prevented the final agreement, just numerous hurdles, which, once surmounted, were replaced by new ones. One week they fought over the size of the surplus: was it $500 million or a billion? Another week they bickered over $3 million in drug treatment programs for convicts. And for over a month they battled over whether New York City should receive 35.16 percent or 34.67 percent of the state's $9 billion in aid to local schools, a difference worth more than $40 million.
The frustratingly slow pace of talks inspired a bevy of theories. Some Democrats suggested that the Republican Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, wanted to delay the budget beyond the Republican convention in May so he could penalize legislators who supported the gubernatorial candidacy of Senator George E. Pataki.
 
Concessions by Cuomo
 The Republicans theorized that Mr. Cuomo was holding up the budget so that he could attack the Legislature for overspending. And Mr. Cuomo completed the circle by accusing the lawmakers of stalling to squeeze more concessions from him.
In the end, Mr. Cuomo did have to give up things to break the deadlock.
The final agreement included most of the projects sought by lawmakers, including $24 million for a Nassau County aquatic center that the Governor had called a Taj Mahal.
He had called a Senate Republican proposal that would increase health care costs by $145 million "a tax hike," then agreed to a one-year version worth $95 million.
And he had fought hard for two educational programs -- a boarding school for gifted science and math students and scholarships for needy college students -- only to allow Republican critics to delay the scholarships and to curtail the boarding school proposal. Just last month, Mr. Cuomo had described the two programs as deal-breakers: so important that he would not sign any budget that did not include them.
But even if Mr. Cuomo lost on some fronts, he can now travel the campaign trail claiming credit for tax cuts and programs that he did not necessarily initiate and may have even criticized.
So, too, the same Republicans who accused Mr. Cuomo of being a tax-and-spend liberal can be expected to praise school aid and road projects in their districts.
"This was like a Valentine's Day card in June," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat. "You're glad to get it; you just ask why it's so late."

HEADLINE: Governments Are Joining Haiti Force

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Administration officials say they have enlisted about a dozen countries to take part in a United Nations task force of more than 3,000 soldiers and civilians who would maintain order and strengthen democratic institutions after the Haitian military leaders cede power, whether voluntarily or through military intervention.
In recent days, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and William H. Gray 3d, the special adviser on Haiti, have asked countries throughout the Western Hemisphere to join the force, which is aimed at insuring the safe return of Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 
 The Administration's effort to line up broad participation is part of its stepped-up campaign to heighten political, economic and psychological pressure on Haiti's military leaders, who seized power in September 1991 and so far have been reluctant to give it up.
 
Quicker U.S. Exit
 For the Clinton Administration, one obvious benefit of a large United Nations mission is that if the United States invades Haiti to oust its military leaders, sending in the mission afterward would allow Washington to withdraw many of its troops quickly.
American officials declined to name the countries that have agreed to take part in the task force -- officially called the United Nations Mission on Haiti -- but officials in other countries said Canada, Venezuela and Argentina had agreed to contribute personnel.
"What if the coup leaders step down next week as a result of the economic sanctions?" Mr. Gray said in a telephone interview. "Who maintains order? Who protects the international relief organizations and embassies there? Who's there to protect the return of President Aristide and to insure his safety? You will need the U.N. mission right away."
Many nations in the Hemisphere oppose military intervention, and American officials recognize that the Administration could point to a broad-based United Nations mission as an international imprimatur for such intervention.
 
Some Oppose Invasion
 According to one official, several countries have said they would not participate in the United Nations mission if Haiti's military is forced out through military intervention.
Administration officials said the task force would be vital for maintaining safety and order to allow Father Aristide to return to Haiti should Haiti's military leaders step down because of pressures from the trade embargo.
"If the military leaves in a week or two, you would probably want the U.N. mission there before Aristide returns," Mr. Gray said. "It would assure law and order. It would make sure there was no retribution and could prevent another coup. If you have a power vacuum anything could happen. You could potentially have another level of military rise up and say, 'We're taking over.' "
Some Administration officials predict that it will take months for the embargo to work, while others say that only military intervention will succeed in forcing out the Haitian military. American officials say they are not asking other countries to contribute troops to an invasion.
 
U.S. Fears Anarchy
 American officials fear an embarrassing wave of anarchy and retribution between the time the military leaders leave and the time Father Aristide returns, either from international pressure or an invasion. With Haiti's military and police force expected to be in wholesale disarray, American officials see the United Nations mission serving as the beat cops until a government is running smoothly.
One senior American official said the United Nations mission would leave Haiti in early 1996, at the earliest, after presidential elections scheduled for December 1995.
In feverish diplomacy over the last week, the United States has persuaded other countries to back a task force that would be far larger and have far greater responsibilities than one set up last July as part of the Governors Island agreement. In that accord, the Haitian military agreed to turn over power to Father Aristide, but it later refused to honor that commitment.
The United Nations mission established under that agreement was to include about 800 soldiers and civilians and to concentrate on retraining Haiti's military and police force, who have a long history of repression and opposition to democracy.
 
A Protection Mission
 Mr. Gray said that the expanded, reconfigured task force not only would do such training, but that it would also be responsible for law enforcement and for protecting embassies, elected officials, human rights monitors and international relief organizations.
At a meeting today in Belem, Brazil, of the foreign ministers of the Organization of American States, the ministers called for enlarging the United Nations mission. They also backed an American-led call to ban all commercial flights to and from Haiti and to cut off financial transactions with Haiti.
Administration officials said today that President Clinton would announce unilateral action within a few days to ban flights and financial transactions between Haiti and the United States.
"It will take six months for Haiti's upper classes to be bitten" by the tougher United Nations sanctions approved last month, said a senior Administration official. "What you have to do is ratchet it up real quick so they feel the bite, so they can't keep their money in foreign banks or enjoy flying around in American planes."
Buoyed by the Dominican Republic's new efforts to clamp down on smuggling to Haiti, Administration officials have voiced increased confidence in recent days that the embargo might force Haiti's military from power.
Some Haiti specialists say the Administration adopted a more upbeat posture on the embargo after officials concluded that their privately stated pessimism about the sanctions was reinforcing the military's commitment to stay in power.
Dennis Boxx, a Defense Department spokesman, said today that a small number of American troops might soon go to the Dominican Republic to help provide "technical support" to fight smuggling to Haiti.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A group praying yesterday at the Port-au-Prince Cathedral for democracy for Haiti. Demonstrators urged the return of the exiled President. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: North Korea Said to Have A-Bomb Fuel

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
North Korea could process the fuel it recently removed from its Yongbyon reactor by the end of the year and produce enough plutonium for four or five nuclear bombs, Administration officials said today.
The speed with which North Korea could reportedly break the remaining constraints on its nuclear program has raised the stakes for Washington's push to block that program. It has also become a key consideration in deliberations over what economic sanctions to seek and when to impose them. 
 The crisis was caused by North Korea's refusal to allow international inspectors to determine how much plutonium was diverted when North Korea first shut down its reactor in 1989.
But while Washington and its allies have been frustrated by North Korea's destruction of evidence of its past plutonium production, North Korea's nuclear program is also poised to leap forward.
 
A Surprising Efficiency
 Already the pace of the program has become a major worry for Washington. The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that there is a better than even chance that North Korea has produced one or two nuclear bombs. But the production of additional plutonium would expand North Korea's nuclear potential and yield surplus bomb material to sell to other nations, officials say.
North Korea took a step toward expanding its bomb material when it shut down the five-megawatt reactor at Yongbyon in mid-April.
Administration officials were caught off guard by the decision to shut down the reactor, and surprised by the speed with which North Korea unloaded its spent fuel.
Officials initially thought it would take two or three months to remove the 8,000 rods of spent fuel, assuming that North Korea only had one machine to remove the rods. But North Korea has two machines.
 
Time May Be Growing Short
 So far North Korea has kept the rods in a cooling pond under the eyes of international monitors and special cameras operated by the International Atomic Energy Agency.
But Administration officials are worried that North Korea will use its growing dispute with the inspectors as a pretext to repudiate the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, abandon all controls on its nuclear program and produce more bomb-grade material.
If North Korea decided to reprocess more plutonium, it is positioned to move ahead quickly. A rule of thumb is that to avoid exposing workers to excessive radiation, technicians should wait 80 days after shutting down a reactor before taking rods to a reprocessing plant. Thus if North Korea follows these safety guidelines, it may begin reprocessing fuel in a matter of weeks.
An Administration expert said that if North Korea used one reprocessing line, it could produce enough plutonium for four or five bombs by the end of the year. And the North Koreans have been working to build a second line.
 
Analyzing the Schedule
 How long it would take North Korea to make bombs with the new supply of plutonium is unclear. Administration officials say their "worst case" estimate is that some new bombs might be produced by the end of the year; some officials speculate that it could take many months or even years.
Adding to Washington's concern, North Korea is also building a second, larger reactor. Defense Secretary William J. Perry has said the reactor will be completed in a few years and could produce material for 10 to 12 bombs a year.
North Korea's nuclear potential is an important consideration in the Administration's deliberations over economic sanctions.
Some experts say the speed with which North Korea can move forward on the nuclear front and its potential sales of bomb-grade material mean that Washington and its allies may not have time to gradually tighten sanctions. If sanctions are imposed, they say, it is important that they hurt the North Korean economy, and thus make clear to North Korea's leaders that they will pay a heavy price for their nuclear program.
 
Past the Threshold
 But other officials worry that tough sanctions may give North Korea a excuse to reject the nonproliferation treaty altogether and produce more plutonium. They say maintaining constraints on North Korea's future production is more important than resolving the mystery of how much plutonium may have been diverted in the past.
The prospects for a compromise look dimmer than ever. Yun Ho Jin, North Korea's representative to the International Atomic Energy Agency, said today that the North would never allow inspectors to visit two nuclear-waste sites to try to determine how much plutonium might have been diverted in past years.
And Hans Blix, the head of the United Nations agency, said it was not clear that such visits would suffice now that North Korea has destroyed other evidence of its past production.

HEADLINE: Iran Accuses U.S. of Reneging on Hostage Deal

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, June 7

 BODY:
President Hashemi Rafsanjani accused the United States today of reneging on secret assurances that Iranian assets frozen by the United States would be freed in exchange for Iranian mediation to gain the release of American hostages in Lebanon.
It was the first time since the Iran-contra arms-for-hostages affair of the Reagan Administration that a senior Iranian official had asserted that an American-Iranian deal had been reached for the release of Western hostages in Lebanon. 
 "We have ample reason to distrust the Americans," Mr. Rafsanjani said at a news conference in Teheran today. "The U.N. Secretary General had told us that if we use our contacts to free Americans and other Western hostages in Lebanon, the United States would release our assets. In this one instance, the Americans could have demonstrated their goodwill. But in effect, they did not even live up to the promises of the Secretary General."
Mr. Rafsanjani gave no details of the assurances from the United Nations. But he was apparently referring to Javier Perez de Cuellar, who traveled to Iran twice in 1990 and 1991 as United Nations Secretary General. Militant Lebanese groups released 10 Western hostages in late 1991.
In November 1991, the United States and Iran reached an agreement under which the United States returned $278 million for military claims by Iran, and the Bush Administration issued a statement clearing Iran of involvement in the bombing of a jetliner over Scotland in 1988, in which 270 people were killed.
Reacting to Mr. Rafsanjani's remarks today, a State Department official said: "It's not the first time the Iranians have given the impression that it's a one-sided thing about unfreezing assets. The whole issue is part of a long, drawn-out process that is before the International Court of Justice in The Hague. That process is continuing."
Iran claims that more than $11 billion of its assets were frozen by the United States in 1979 when Washington broke off relations with Teheran, but United States officials estimate the value of the assets at $1 billion.
Last year, the Clinton Administration called Iran "an international outlaw" and vowed to use economic pressure to try to persuade Teheran to change its policies. Trade between the United States and Iran increased 14-fold between 1989 and 1992, according to State Department figures.
Mr. Rafsanjani said today that Iran had no intention of suspending trade with the United States. American oil companies are the biggest buyers of Iranian oil.

HEADLINE: Alternative Sites for Yankee Stadium Are Studied

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
City and state officials have begun examining sites other than the South Bronx as a home for a new Yankee Stadium, at the request of team officials who say fans are staying away from home games because of concerns about safety in that neighborhood.
Officials said last night that 8 to 10 sites in all 5 boroughs are under study, including the rail yards on the West Side of Manhattan, where Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had earlier proposed building a stadium over the tracks. 
 The Yankees' lease on the current Yankee Stadium, which is owned by the city, is due to expire in 2002. For more than a year, the team and its principal owner, George Steinbrenner, have engaged in on-again, off-again discussions with city officials over the team's plans for the future.
Now, even as the Yankees are having their best season on the field in years, team officials have complained to the city that attendance is woefully low, and that they believe it is linked to perceptions about crime in the area. Yankee officials have also informed the Giuliani administration that they have recently renewed negotiations with New Jersey officials about moving to the Meadowlands sports complex.
"Both of us, the city and the state, have made clear that our very strong preference is for them to stay in the Bronx," said John Dyson, New York City's Deputy Mayor for economic development. "On the other hand, in light of their request, while we don't want to lose them from the Bronx, we don't want to lose them from New York City, and we don't want to lose them from New York State."
Mr. Dyson said he did not believe that team officials were determined to leave the South Bronx, but said that "since they only get to make this decision every 30 years" they thought it prudent to consider other locations. Yankee officials could not be reached last night.
Even as the city and state search for alternative sites, the officials are also continuing to plan a renovation of the current stadium. Vincent Tese, the chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, which is a partner with the city in the Yankees project, said he still believed a compelling case could be made for keeping the Yankees in the Bronx.
"We think it's important to the economy of the Bronx," he said. "We think it's also a historic place. We think we can make a statement in the Bronx that will satisfy the Yankees and the community."
John Lawn, the Yankees' vice president for operations, requested the search for alternative sites in a May 11 letter to city officials. In his letter, Mr. Lawn said the Yankees -- with the best record in the American League -- rank 8th in the American League and 17th in the major leagues in terms of home attendance. The letter also says that attendance at Yankee Stadium is 30 percent higher for day games than for night games.
That disparity, Mr. Lawn said in his letter, "suggests the perceptions about security may be a critical factor in decisions to attend a game at Yankee Stadium."
Attendance has increased this year over last year, however. Through the first 31 home games last season the Yankees drew 681,539 fans, an average of 21,985. Through 31 dates this season they have drawn 800,177, an average of 25,812.
City and state officials contend that the crime around Yankee Stadium during games is very low because of a 80-member police detail that patrols the area when the team is in town. But both Mr. Dyson and Mr. Tese acknowledge that the perception of crime is a real issue that must be dealt with.
"If you're going to get the fans, you have to answer their concerns," Mr. Dyson said.
The request from the Yankees came as the city and the state were planning a renovation of Yankee Stadium that was designed to address safety concerns. The stadium renovation, estimated to cost $250 million, was expected to include indoor parking for 12,000 to 15,000 cars and a Metro-North station in the stadium area, to allow fans to go to games without having to set foot in the streets of the South Bronx.
Mr. Dyson also said city and state officials have been considering coupling the stadium renovation with a renewal effort in the neighborhood, both to benefit residents there and to ease the fears of Yankee fans. The Giuliani administration has included Yankee Stadium in the city's application for designation as a Federal Empowerment Zone, which would allow that area to share in a $100 million economic development grant.
Mr. Dyson said he believed it would be difficult to find a suitable alternative site in the city. He said a stadium site must be at least 30 acres, geologically sound for building, accessible and free from environmental problems that would be expensive to remedy.
In addition to the Manhattan rail yards site, officials said, areas under consideration include Ferry Point in the Bronx, the Charleston section of Staten Island, a tract on 207th Street in Manhattan, Coney Island, the Brooklyn Marine Terminal, the old Flushing Airport in Queens and Phelham Bay Park in the Bronx.
