HEADLINE: Clinton in Normandy: Hands Across a Generation

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 7

 BODY:
It was the soldiers whom people will long remember. Mostly brittle old men now, no longer the lusty youngsters who "saved the world," they were touching in their simple eloquence, heartbreaking in their heartache for their lost comrades.
Like the old men of the Grand Army of the Republic, veterans of Bull Run and Vicksburg and Antietam who lived through the direst days of their century, the survivors of the first momentous hours on the Calvados coast half a century ago have become icons for today, the symbols of courage and conviction that democracies crave. 
 Lincoln at Gettysburg said the world would "little note nor long remember" what he said there, dedicating a cemetery for the fallen in the most awful battle in America's most awful war. What he meant was that no words, not even his, had power adequate to the task of memorializing the deeds of those whose graves lay around him.
President Clinton succeeded in his D-Day speeches not because he made speeches worthy of comparison with Lincoln's or perhaps even with Ronald Reagan's "These are the boys of Pointe du Hoc . . ." of 10 years ago. He succeeded because with the help of many others he managed to keep attention focused on the veterans, not on himself and his problems.
 
A Plea to the Young
 Fully aware that their hour on the world's stage is nearing its end, many of them appealed earnestly to those they will leave behind, denizens of a world that sometimes has a lot of trouble telling right from wrong, to remember the values that inspired the heroism of their international band of brothers in Operation Overlord.
Amid the barbed wire and the artillery craters of Pointe du Hoc, a former Ranger, Richard Hathaway, said on Monday:
"Nations can and should unite to form the strongest possible bonds, devoted to all mankind so that they may enjoy freedom from oppression, freedom from fear, freedom from want, freedom of expression and freedom of religion. We leave this to you, for only by this can you and your descendants enjoy a free society of all mankind, devoid of such destructive forces as were exhibited here."
Many of the veterans fear that the young, President Clinton perhaps included, are all too prone to turn away from trouble abroad. So they were pleased with the repect that he bestowed on them and their ideas, not only by coming but also by urging members of his generation to learn the lessons of their struggle and sacrifice.
"It's an honor," Mr. Clinton said to almost every one of the hundreds of World War II veterans he met during his European tour.
 
Evocative Ceremonies
 For one aging onlooker at least, the ceremonies were most evocative. The old planes, the parachutes descending again near Ste.-Mere-Eglise, on whose church steeple Pvt. John Steele dangled for hours before being cut down, the coffin-shaped boats back at Omaha Beach, the stories the veterans told -- all rekindled the emotions stirred by the broadcasts of George Hicks, the radio networks' pool man on a ship out in the English Channel on June 6, 1944.
With very nearly every American household tuned in, with the big naval guns drumming behind him, Hicks reported the thrilling news: "The landing craft have been disembarked from their mother ships and are moving in irregular lines toward the horizon of France. All over the surface of the sea they can be seen cutting and zigzagging and heading toward the ribbon of land that's the coast of Normandy."
Fifty years later, the politicians did their part, secular priests in a secular age, in the solemn rites commemorating the D-Day landings. President Clinton found a few eloquent phrases for the preliminary ceremonies, then produced a gem of a speech late in the day for the main event at the American cemetery above Omaha Beach.
It would have been unseemly for anything to outshine the ordinary men who discovered such extraordinary things within themselves in the storms of fire they found on Normandy's cliffs and beaches.
"For a few days," said Lane Kirkland, the head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., who was a merchant seaman in World War II, "the spirit of World War II lived again. I tried to give a tip to a cabdriver in London, and he refused to take it. 'No,' he told me, 'You saved us.' "
 
'Didn't Disgrace Himself'
 Called upon by the workings of the calendar to lead what will probably be the last ceremonies on such a vast scale, the President began with three strikes against him, but he refused to accept that he was already out. He is the first President since the World War II to have played no military role. He avoided the draft in Vietnam. He had a tough act to follow in Mr. Reagan, one of the great orchestrators of national emotion, a master of nostalgia and the might-have-been.
"He didn't disgrace himself, and that's what counts," said a senior American official in Europe. "If he had seemed callow, or ill informed, or lacking in respect, if he had grandstanded, that would have been terrible for him and the country.
"As it was, he gained some respect from the older generation, I think, by showing them the deference they deserve and insisting everywhere that their experience shows us where we ought to go. I doubt that that struck much of a chord with the younger generations, but that's not his doing."
Mr. Clinton will return to the United States after meetings and speeches in Paris today and a return to Oxford on Wednesday that is sure to revive talk of his antiwar sentiments during his days as a student there. It seems likely that in domestic terms he has been neither strengthened nor weakened by this second European tour of his 16-month-old Administration.
 
Clinton's Burdens
 No one can convincingly suggest any longer that the big ceremonial moments are beyond Mr. Clinton. He demonstrated that he can put aside his compulsively, sometimes exuberantly informal style for occasions requiring dignity and restraint. If his youth and inexperience sometimes deny his words the weight he would like them to carry, if the imagery he and his aides choose often seems forced or corny, he has shown himself capable of addressing complex issues involving many countries with varied interests and histories.
But health care is still in trouble, the more so with the indictment of Representative Dan Rostenkowski; the Democrats are still back on their heels in electoral politics, having lost almost every election before the off-year balloting in November, and the civil lawsuit brought against Mr. Clinton by Paula Corbin Jones still throws a long, foreboding shadow.
If he passed the test in the ceremonies in Britain and France, the President came a cropper, to a degree, in Italy. He felt that he had to honor the veterans of the "forgotten campaign" to liberate Rome as well as those who served in northern Europe, his aides reported, but in Italy itself and much of the rest of Europe he was seen as simultaneously celebrating the defeat of Fascism and condoning the entry of its offspring, the neo-Fascist National Alliance, into the new Italian Government.
 
On the Agenda
 What the Europeans wonder about is his strategic sense. It was clear, a top French politician said today, that Mr. Clinton was having more trouble than he should in balancing economic and political considerations, as on China, and in deciding where and in what kinds of situations American strength and prestige should be committed.
The President will be back on the Continent this month for the annual meeting of the seven biggest industrial powers, a meeting, this time in Naples, that will focus more than ever before on question of trade, now seen as the key to the domestic economic problems of the big nations.
After that, Mr. Clinton is to meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, also in Italy, and then will spend about 36 hours in Bonn and Berlin. In Berlin, he will hold a meeting in the Reichstag, walk through the Brandenburg Gate and ceremonially disband the Berlin Brigade -- powerful symbols of the end of Berlin's time as a ward of the West and its central new role in a unified Germany.
Those will be important days for Mr. Clinton and for his country, for it is trade, not war, and Germany and Russia, not so much Britain and France, that hold the key to future relations between the United States and Europe.

HEADLINE: Israel and Jordan Make Progress in Talks

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Israel and Jordan agreed today on moves to prepare for peace, including establishment of a cross-border park and construction of a road linking both countries to Egypt.
"The accomplishments of this session have surpassed expectations," said the Jordanian Ambassador, Fayez Tarawneh. 
 Among the accords after two days of talks were an agreement in principle on building a road to link Aqaba and Eilat, the Jordanian and Israeli Red Sea ports, with each other and with Egypt, and a plan to set up a commission on boundaries, water, energy and the environment, some of the most difficult issues. Talks on these matters are to be moved to Israel and Jordan in July.
The two sides also decided to draft an outline of future trade and economic relations and to invite Palestinians to discuss cooperation in trade, finance and banking.
The two sides agreed that the United States would consolidate Jordanian and Israeli plans on development of the Jordan Valley into one master plan. The border runs through the valley.
They also agreed to designate one official from each side to coordinate on a "trans-boundary cultural heritage park" in the Jordan Valley.

HEADLINE: Fingerprinting For Welfare Is Defended

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani vowed yesterday to move ahead with a plan to fingerprint welfare recipients, despite an agreement between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Legislature that would exclude New York City from a pilot program involving 12 counties.
Mr. Giuliani, who says such a system would reduce welfare fraud, maintained that fingerprinting did not amount to a change in welfare eligibility standards and therefore did not need state approval. 
 "Finger or hand imaging is a form of identification," he said at a news conference. "It is not another requirement. It isn't saying that you have to be of a certain age, that you have to live in a certain area or that you have to be of a certain income level."
But the Mayor's determination to move ahead seemed likely to result in a court challenge. Patricia Lynch, a spokeswoman for Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, said Mr. Silver, the Manhattan Democrat, who has opposed fingerprinting, did not believe the city could act on its own.
 
Challenge Is Possible
 Although Mr. Cuomo has expressed his support in the past for a statewide fingerprinting program, he left open the possibility of challenging local governments that decide to start programs of their own without state authorization. Anne W. Crowley, the Governor's press secretary, said last night that he would have to study the "legal implications" of such a move.
Mr. Giuliani first endorsed fingerprinting of welfare recipients when he announced his financial plan in February, arguing that it would reduce fraud and perhaps build more political support for welfare by insuring that only the needy were receiving compensation.
He has projected in his own budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 that the city could save $7 million by using fingerprinting to root out fraud in the home relief program, which provides welfare benefits to more than 304,000 people in New York City, many of them single adults. The projected savings would grow to more than $60 million in the next fiscal year, when the program could be fully in place.
To expand the program to the city's full welfare caseload of more than one million, the city would need Federal approval similar to that granted to California. Mr. Giuliani has said he will apply for such a waiver.
The Mayor said yesterday he was exploring the possibility of working with Nassau, Suffolk or Westchester Counties to put the fingerprinting program in place. "We are looking at three or four different ways to do that which may include doing it with at least one other, possibly two other counties," he said, but did not specify further. Suffolk is one of the 12 counties selected by the Governor and the Legislature to test fingerprinting during the next two years.
An aide to Mr. Giuliani said the city was looking to join other counties because there could be "economies of scale" if the electronic equipment needed for fingerprinting was leased or purchased in conjunction with other counties. The aide did not put a cost figure on the machinery.
David Vieser, a spokesman for the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, said Nassau also intended to move ahead with fingerprinting despite its exclusion from the state program and would welcome the city's participation "because it would be more effective if we had a finger imaging process on both sides of the county."
He said Nassau was beginning negotiations this week to lease equipment from the vendor that would be used by Suffolk County.
The technology for fingerprinting includes an optical scanner connected to a data bank that can compare a set of prints to thousands of others on file in minutes. There is no ink: the computer electronically converts a print into a mathematical formula.
Fingerprinting of welfare recipients, which Democrats have argued equates the needy with criminals, has been a partisan issue in Albany, sharply dividing the Republican-controlled State Senate from Democrats who run the Assembly.
As a compromise, Mr. Silver agreed in budget negotiations to expand a test of fingerprinting underway in Rockland and Onondaga Counties to 10 more counties. The program would expire in two years and then be evaluated.
Mr. Silver said he argued against including New York City, which has two-thirds of the state's welfare recipients, because the equipment would cost too much to be used on a trial basis in a program he considered untested.

HEADLINE: The Tug of Memory, the Call of Home;
With Apartheid's End, South African Emigres Wrestle With Options

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I.

 BODY:
Courtly and silver-haired, Dr. Philip Lanzkowski is a prominent physician, chief of staff of a children's hospital here. But there is one corner of his life he has not always felt comfortable confiding: his origins in South Africa.
"The politics was embarrassing to me," he said. "At times I was ashamed to mention to people that I'd been a South African." 
 But that is changing. The end of apartheid and the election of a democratic, multiracial government are subtly transforming the lives of the roughly 100,000 emigres in the United States, 70 percent of whom are white, and the 25,000 who live in the New York metropolitan region. For one thing, they have shed their defensiveness.
 
A Burden Lifted
 "I feel like I've been freed of the burden of defending or answering to people about South Africa," said Dr. Lanzkowski, who left his country because he did not want to raise children under apartheid.
Many expatriates have also begun to let themselves feel the pull towards the bronze mountains and wild seas of home. A few are even contemplating returning, though such notions are made risky by South Africa's uncertain future and are complicated by the presence of American spouses, children and careers.
"I'm finding that for the first time since I left I can allow myself to love South Africa again," said Brian M. Rom, who runs a software company for institutional investors.
 
Embracing Home
 Having despaired of seeing any change in its political system, Mr. Rom, a 46-year-old white South African, all but abandoned the idea of even visiting the country again. But suddenly he is flirting with the prospect of retirement one day to his boyhood turf in the province of Natal.
It is impossible to say how many others are making similar plans. The South African consulate in New York said no figures were available on the number of expatriates who are returning, because native South Africans do not need any special papers to move back.
Many emigres say Americans fail to appreciate that emigres could have despised South Africa's racist government, but still have felt bound up with the land of their birth and its people.
Of course, some emigrants were comfortable with apartheid, or turned a blind eye, and left for practical reasons. They could not see a future in South Africa, either because of its economic ostracism by other nations or because they thought a black government would strip away white privilege.
Whatever their motives for coming, the emigres have been forced to wrestle with their souls -- and options -- once again.
Although Sikhulu Shange, who is black, left his country 30 years ago to wage an exile's struggle against apartheid and intended to return when apartheid was overcome, he now has anchors here: his music store on 125th Street in Harlem, and three grown daughters and three grandchildren who were raised in New York City. So Mr. Shange will proceed cautiously, exploring the possibility of opening a music outlet in South Africa while keeping his Harlem store to train both Americans and Africans in retailing.
"I have lived with my brothers and sisters in the diaspora for a long time and it is not very difficult for me to survive," he said. "But home is home. I long for it. I want to go back to the land where I was born and be a father and grandfather who's able to come up with the answers when everyone runs short."
John Baskind, a white specialist in political advertising, fled South Africa 13 years ago to avoid service in an army enforcing apartheid, and joined the African National Congress here. Now he too is thinking of returning. He wants to be part of the new South Africa and to reacquaint himself with the things he never stopped pining for.
 
Earth, Trees and Memory
 "It's the little things like the smell of the dust, the red earth, the green trees and my grandfather's grave in Johannesburg," said Mr. Baskind, who grew up in a farming village north of Johannesburg. "I was born in the bush and grew up in the bush, and those are one's most powerful memories."
For longtime opponents of apartheid, there is a bitterness along with the intoxication of recent weeks -- the anger of knowing that if South Africa's transformation had happened a generation ago, they would have been spared the anguish of tearing themselves from their country.
"My parents were deprived of their children and grandchildren," said Dr. Lanzkowski, the 62-year-old chief of staff of Schneider Children's Hospital at Long Island Jewish Medical Center. "Here people were looking at me as the oppressor, but I left because I was a victim. What did I need to be an American for?"
South Africans started coming here in significant numbers three decades ago for many reasons.
"I was raised to leave that country," said Danny Abelson, a 43-year-old advertising executive who came to study at the University of Pennsylvania. "Like many white liberals I was raised with the disorienting feeling that we were good people living in a bad system."
It is difficult to find a white South African here who will admit to condoning apartheid, though some will say so privately.
"We sucked in racism with our mother's milk," said one suburban businessman who spoke only on condition of anonymity. "As bad as things were for blacks, we learned to accept that blacks weren't quite human. Of course, I've heard more racism in this country than I ever heard in South Africa. The difference is it isn't officially sanctioned."
 
Migratory Habits
 Afrikaners, the whites whose Dutch ancestors began settling in the country more than three centuries ago and whose leaders imposed apartheid in 1948, seldom emigrated because they overwhelmingly supported the government or had few connections abroad. Far more prevalent among the emigres have been descendants of the English who colonized South Africa or the Jews who migrated to South Africa in the late 19th century to flee the Russian pogroms and army. These groups were more likely to oppose apartheid and found it easier to transplant themselves.
Although many expatriates came with a cushion of affluence, most still found the passage traumatic. They had to requalify for professional licenses or start businesses while mourning the loss of their land and the distance from relatives.
Most have navigated the transition well, consular officials say. They now live in New York suburbs like Westchester, Fairfield and Bergen Counties, and the suburbs of Boston, Houston or San Diego that in many cases resemble the neighborhoods of their childhood: overwhelmingly white and prosperous with emerald lawns and household help. Yet most say they have never felt quite American.
"I still feel very connected to South Africa," said Beryl Bresgi, a librarian in Teaneck, N.J. "This is still a foreign country for me."
Mr. Baskind says he feels more African than European or American. Africans, black and white, are far more accepting of other people and less cynical, he said. They have a more elastic sense of time, and are more gregarious, he said. Indeed, Mr. Baskind argued, there is far more similarity between black and white South Africans than between black South Africans and black Americans or white South Africans and white Americans.
A handful of South Africans have made it their business to work with their fellow emigres. Ash Caplan came here from Cape Town in 1986 and, using his brother-in-law's garage, started making biltong, the dried beef jerky that South Africans gnaw on as a snack. Now he owns a mail-order business in Wilton, Conn., that furnishes South Africans with chutneys, fish paste and the sausage known as boerewors.
Three years ago, Larry Shore, a bearded 42-year-old professor of communications at Hunter College who fled to avoid serving in the army, formed the Organization of South African-Americans and Canadians, and it now has a data base listing 800 expatriates. The group's principal purpose is to provide expertise and money to a post-apartheid society, for such needs as training rural nurses and financing rural schools.
Still, now is a time of celebration. Last Saturday, the organization invited emigres to a party at Hunter College to toast South Africa's new government.
"I'd like to take my American wife to see South Africa," said Mr. Shore, who long avoided going back. "I want to show her what a beautiful country it is, and now I want to show her what a remarkable country it is, that it has been able to come through this when many other countries would have collapsed."

HEADLINE: A Big Gain In Consumer Borrowing

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Consumers borrowed $8.9 billion more in installment loans than they paid off in April, raising credit-card use by a record amount, the Federal Reserve reported today. It was the biggest overall rise in more than nine years.
The surprisingly vigorous gain in borrowing, which was on top of a $1 billion upward revision for March, was generally considered to be a sign of continued confidence by households in their ability to handle new debt and not as a sign that they were pressed for cash and forced to borrow. Installment loans include credit-card debt, automobile loans and other personal loans. 
 "Consumers feel better about the economy and their financial position," said Allen Sinai, chief economist for Lehman Brothers Global Economics in New York.
But other factors may also have played a role, analysts said. Some of the borrowing boom probably reflected April 15 income tax payments, which included sizable increases for the well-to-do this year. The April borrowing may also have been swollen by Easter-related purchases in late March that were not immediately posted.
It was also possible, but difficult to demonstrate, that a portion of the jump reflected distress -- borrowing on high-interest credit cards by consumers who had no other choice.
 
Sign of Economic Growth
 But Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities, said he would be surprised if such pressure had arisen so suddenly. He attributed the increase mainly to general economic vigor. "Private credit demands are picking up and we're in the phase of the expansion when that should be happening," he said.
Revolving, or credit-card, credit jumped $5 billion in April after rising a modest $1.4 billion in March, the report showed.
Automobile credit slowed to a gain of $2.8 billion, from $3.8 billion in March, consistent with previously issued data on sales.
Home equity and other borrowing secured by real estate is not included in these figures, providing one reason for analysts' interpretive caution. Another is that credit cards are increasingly used for convenience rather than because of a real need to borrow -- and the figures are further muddied by developments like the awarding of frequent-flier miles for credit-card use.
Mr. Sinai said a recent study he conducted showed that a surprisingly large proportion of households with incomes of at least $75,000 a year kept credit-card balances even though they could have avoided them.
 
An 11-Month Climb
 April was the 11th consecutive month of expanding installment credit, but the streak would have stretched back to the immediate aftermath of the 1990-91 recession had it not been for a statistically aberrant decline last May.
The rise in total installment debt in April was at an annual rate of 13.2 percent, with automobile credit expanding at an 11.9 percent pace, revolving credit at 20.7 percent and other credit at 5.5 percent, the Fed also reported.
The $8.9 billion surge for the month compared with a revised March advance of $8.4 billion, up from the $7.4 billion originally estimated.
The Federal Reserve also said the average interest rate for a 48-month new-car loan was 7.76 percent in May, up from 7.54 percent in February. During the same three-month period, rates on 24-month personal loans rose to 12.96 percent, from 12.89 percent, while credit-card rates rose to 16.15 percent, from 16.06 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 12.61 in Lackluster Trading

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed down slightly yesterday, following the falling bond market, as traders posted the 11th consecutive day of below-average trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange.
Blue chips like Caterpillar and the Aluminum Company of America, cellular telephone companies like Airtouch Communications and regional banks like Banc One all fell, as did Nasdaq stocks like Microsoft and Cisco Systems. 
 Traders seemed to lack a compelling reason to bid stock prices higher. "The market is, if you will, tired," said William N. Allyn, director of listed equity trading at Jefferies & Company. "The good news about a growing economy, low inflation and strong first-quarter earnings is out of the way, and the market is looking for something else."
 
 
Taking Cues From Bonds
 Mr. Allyn said that for the next few weeks, traders were likely to bid stock prices up and down slightly, following trends in the bond market. But the stock market will be essentially lackluster until some earnings or other surprise next month prompts a rally, he said.
Yesterday, long-term interest rates rose, raising borrowing costs for corporations and hurting stocks. Ending a four-session rally, the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.26 percent, from 7.21 percent the day before.
Futures contracts for commodities, a proxy for the inflation outlook of commodities traders, moved up slightly. The Commodity Research Bureau index rose 0.12 point, to 228.96, after falling for three consecutive sessions. The price outlook for copper, coffee and sugar rose moderately, almost outweighed by declines in cattle, lumber and pork bellies.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.61 points, to 3,755.91, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 0.67 point, to 458.21. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 4.13 points, to 739.30.
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was again less than normal, with 234.7 million shares changing hands, about 21 percent less than the average of 297 million shares this year.
The Sprint Corporation, frustrated about failed merger talks with Electronic Data Systems, said yesterday that it was considering selling minority stakes of Sprint to the two largest European telephone companies, France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom.
The move would strengthen Sprint's presence in the European market, which will begin to resemble that of the United States when major government-owned carriers like France Telecom become privatized in the next few years. Shares of Sprint rose 1 3/8, to 39 3/8.
 
 
Equitable's Real Estate Plans
 The Equitable Companies said it planned to expand its real estate operations by providing $1 billion in hotel financing. Equitable stock fell 1/4, to 22 1/4.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.47 point, to 253.70, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining stocks, 902 to 1,190. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.10 point, to 442.49.
Of the 30 components of the Dow industrial average, 14 fell. The declining components were led by Caterpillar, which fell 2 1/4, to 106, on no apparent news.
Of the 500 components that make up the S.& P. 500, 247 fell, led by the Harris Corporation, the electronics, communications and office equipment company. Its stock fell 1/8, to 48 3/4.
Microsoft, the software giant, was again the most active stock at 10.4 million shares, after Monday's one-day Nasdaq record of 47.8 million shares. Microsoft was included in the S.& P. 500 yesterday, but it stock fell 7/8, to 53 5/8.
The second-most-active stock, at 4.4 million shares, was Chrysler, which fell 7/8, to 45 1/2.

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D. Suggests Ways to Fight Unemployment

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 7

 BODY:
Confident that the industrialized world is pulling out of recession, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development today urged that advanced nations introduce new flexibility to their labor markets to combat stubbornly high levels of unemployment.
In doing so, the organization, based in Paris, identified the most politically explosive question facing many Western European governments: how to reduce "structural" unemployment without eroding living standards and slashing welfare and other social benefits? 
 A report to the opening session of the organization's annual ministerial meeting said that with 35 million people now out of work in its 25 member countries, unemployment "is probably the most widely feared phenomenon of our times." And it warned, "It brings with it unraveling of the social fabric, including a loss of authority of the democratic system."
 
Low Pay, but More Jobs

 
 The report, which is based on a two-year study, noted that the crisis was most severe in the 12 nations of the European Union, where unemployment now averages 11.7 percent, in part because of the high cost of creating jobs. In contrast, it said, the United States has far lower unemployment -- now 6 percent -- but many more low-skill jobs paying low wages.
Attending the meeting, Robert B. Reich, the United States Secretary of Labor, said the United States had been a "job machine," creating three million new jobs in the last 16 months.
"The problem is that most are low-wage jobs," Mr. Reich told reporters after today's session. "The long-term trend is toward a widening gap between the top and the bottom of the income ladder."
The O.E.C.D., which monitors economic trends and policy for the wealthier industrialized countries, said the problem of joblessness would not be eliminated simply through an economic recovery. Rather, it noted, additional measures would be needed to attack structural unemployment.
As distinct from cyclical unemployment, which rises and falls with economic activity, structural unemployment reflects an economy's failure to adjust to automation, other new technologies, and changes in the global economy, including intensified competition.
 
Labor Policies Addressed

 
 Some of the organization's recommendations are fairly general, such as urging governments to seek sustainable growth, to promote new technology, to improve job training programs and to help the creation of new businesses.
But other recommendations deal directly with the labor market and are certain to be controversial. These include: adopting flexible working times, such as part-time work or early retirement; discouraging minimum wages or at least linking them to age and region; permitting job-creation programs at below-average wage levels; making it easier for employers to dismiss staff, and linking unemployment benefits to a continued search for work.
This afternoon, ministers endorsed "the main conclusions" of the report, but with a caveat. They agreed to enact its recommendations "within the context of their particular economic circumstances," a clear sign that some governments are fearful of tampering with social rights.
"A further cut in benefits or assistance cannot be considered a political option in my opinion," Austria's Labor Minister, Josef Hesoun, told the meeting. Belgium's Finance Minister, Philippe Maystadt, said some of the O.E.C.D.'s recommendations risked "provoking social breakdown."
But Hans Christopherson, the European Union's economics commissioner, suggested that European governments had little choice. Asked if they had the courage to slash benefits, he retorted, "Do they have the guts to live with 12, 15, 18 percent unemployment?"
 
'A Third Way'

 
 Mr. Reich said developed nations appeared to face the choice between creating new jobs and preserving a social safety net, but he argued that the Clinton Administration believed there was "a third way" that would both increase the number of new jobs and raise wage levels.
The Labor Secretary said this approach was based on three principles: improving the quality of the work force through education and training; adapting the labor market to economic changes by, for example, aiding the movement of workers between industries, and moving from social safety nets to "springboards to employment."
"The longer people are out of work, the harder it is to find a job," he said.
The United States Treasury Secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, who is also attending the meeting, focused his attention on the need to bolster new growth in the global economy. "Japan and Europe must strengthen their recoveries," he said. "And it will take more than interest cuts or fiscal support for recovery. It will require structural reforms."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Prices Fall Steeply Amid fears of Oversupply

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices posted their largest decline in more than two months yesterday amid traders' concerns that gasoline supplies are rising and that a United Nations oil embargo against Iraq could move a step closer to ending.
On other commodity markets, copper and soybeans rose while lumber prices fell. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 0.12 point, to 228.96. 
 Gasoline supplies appear more than ample, analysts said. Refiners operated at 95.3 percent of capacity in the week ended May 27, up from 94.1 percent the week before, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Meanwhile, Iraq hinted that it might be moving closer to recognizing Kuwait as a sovereign state, which it must do before the August 1990 ban by the United Nations on Iraqi crude oil exports is lifted.
 
July Crude Falls 36 Cents
 At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for July delivery dropped to $17.63 a barrel before rebounding to settle at $17.75 a barrel, down 36 cents. July unleaded gasoline fell 1.53 cents, to 51.35 cents a gallon, its fourth straight decline. July heating oil fell for the fifth day, losing 1.09 cents, to 46.47 cents a gallon.
The petroleum institute's weekly report on gasoline and crude stocks, released after the close of trading, showed crude stocks fell by about 4.4 million barrels, or 1.3 percent, while gasoline stocks rose by about 1 million barrels. Refinery utilization was little changed, at 95.1 percent.
"It's going to be real tough for crude to hold up if gas falls any further," said William Brown, president of W. H. Brown & Company consultants in New York.
Elsewhere, copper prices rose to an 18-month high amid perceptions that stockpiles will fall as Europe's economy gains strength. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, July copper surged 4.75 cents, to $1.0645 a pound, its highest since January 1993.
Western Germany's economy, Europe's largest, grew by five-tenths of 1 percent in the first three months of the year from the previous quarter, and rose 2.1 percent compared with a year ago.
Meanwhile, copper stockpiles in London Metal Exchange warehouses dropped almost 40 percent so far this year. Since Friday, copper stocks declined 3,700 metric tons, to 379,050 tons, a 14-month low.
"It's very much the demand side of the market" pushing copper higher, Michael Frawley, an analyst with Dean Witter in New York, said. "Demand is broad-based in Europe. I think people have failed to recognize that demand is not coming just from the U.S."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Decline In a 'Healthy Setback'

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell yesterday for the first time in five sessions even though there are increasing expectations that interest rates are headed lower this summer.
The bond market's decline was "a little healthy setback," said Bill Feezer, co-head of United States Government bond trading at Sanwa Securities (USA). The market had advanced 2.6 percent between May 31 and Monday. 
 Late yesterday, the Treasury's 30-year bond was down 12/32 of a point, or $3.75 per $1,000 bond. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.26 percent, from 7.21 percent on Monday.
The bond market's promising outlook derives mostly from evidence that the economy is not growing fast enough to generate a surge in inflation, traders and money managers said.
"People are more comfortable with the inflation scenario, more comfortable with the idea of a slowdown in demand" in consumer spending, Mr. Feezer said.
 
Late Selloff in Dollar Helps
 A late selloff in the dollar helped push bonds lower. The dollar fell 1.12 Japanese yen, to 104.17 yen, after the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said the United States was prepared to use trade laws to force Japan to open its markets. That threat caught many currency traders off guard, since it contrasted sharply with what had seemed a more conciliatory American stance toward Japan in recent weeks.
The dollar's decline in turn unnerved bond traders. "Ultimately, a weaker dollar is inflationary," said William Shea, head United States bond trader at the Nikko Securities Company International.
The two-year Treasury note's yield was unchanged at 5.76 percent. The note yielded 150 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, less than the 30-year bond, up four basis points from Monday.
As evidence mounts that the economy's growth rate is slowing, Treasury bond yields could fall to 7 percent or lower by the second half of the year, investors said.
"I figure the inflation rate won't be as onerous as people think it will be," said Warren Schmalenberger, director of fixed-income investments at Transamerica Fund Management, a Houston firm with $2.25 billion in bond mutual funds. "I am optimistic on bonds. I think that yields are going to come down."
The Federal Reserve has raised the rate on overnight bank lending rates four times this year. Now the central bank is inclined to watch how much growth slows, Mr. Schmalenberger said. "I think they pause here for the foreseeable future," he said.
So long as the Fed is not raising rates, bond yields are likely to fall, he said.
Meantime, inflation is not likely to accelerate because the Fed -- and the bond market -- will not let it, Mr. Schmalenberger said. This built-in brake on inflation will help drive yields down. Inflation erodes the value of fixed-income securities such as bonds.
"When you have a Fed that is concerned, and a market that's concerned, they will raise rates to where the economy slows" and inflation subsides, Mr. Schmalenberger said.
So far this year, 30-year Treasury bond yields have fluctuated between 7.66 percent, an 18-month high, and 6.30 percent, set before the Fed began raising rates in February. The record low yield is 5.77 percent, reached on Oct. 15.
Meantime, there is little evidence that the inflation rate is about to accelerate. Consumer prices rose 2.4 percent in the 12 months ended in April, down from 2.7 percent last year.
 
Some Traders Still Bearish
 Still, some traders remain bearish on the bond market. "Another two and a half points up doesn't change the trend," said Chris Madell, a trader at First Chicago Capital Markets. The four-day rally amounts to "false euphoria in a bear market, which is not to say we can't go higher near term."
But, he added, "I don't trust this thing for one second. I could be wrong, but if it's over, it will be one of the shortest bear markets in history."
Treasury bonds began falling in Asia in tandem with a rout in Japanese bonds. Declines there later spread to European bond markets.
Japanese Government bonds plunged as much as one point amid press reports that the Bank of Japan will end its monthlong policy of keeping money rates near historic lows. A Bank of Japan official denied the reports.
British bonds also fell one point amid expectations that European economies are rebounding.
Among other Treasury securities, the three-month bill fell two basis points to a discount rate of 4.11 percent. The six-month bill fell four basis points to a discount rate of 4.47 percent. And the one-year bill fell one basis point, to a discount rate of 4.86 percent.
The yield on three-year note rose to 6.09 percent from 6.07 percent. The yield on the five-year note rose to 6.51 percent from 6.49 percent. And the yield on the 10-year note rose to 6.94 percent from 6.90 percent.

HEADLINE: A Deal With Russia on Uranium Draws Protest From U.S. Industry

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
An unusual trade agreement in which the United States has tried to cement good relations with Russia and stabilize the Yeltsin Government is under siege. The uproar is a lesson in what happens when noble foreign-policy goals clash with rigid trade laws that were constructed to protect American industry.
The agreement, signed in March, allowed the Russians to export to the United States far more uranium fuel for nuclear power plants at a far lower price than would normally be allowed under American trade laws. At the same time it required that the Russians pay American uranium producers a subsidy to compensate for the falling price caused by the exports. 
 The deal has been praised by Jan Kalicki, the Commerce Department's ombudsman for trade with the Russian Federation, as "a model for future commercial relationships." But now it is bringing howls of protest from competing uranium exporters, notably Canada, Australia and Kazakhstan. And last week it was challenged in court by a coalition of American uranium producers and their union, who fear that most of the gravy will go not to them but to a single American company run by a wheeling-dealing Denver entrepreneur who helped frame the agreement.
What's more, Justice Department officials have raised eyebrows by refusing to declare in advance that sales will be legal under the antitrust laws. And many economists see the deal as a worrisome precedent in trading with the former socialist countries. "It's driving the Russians back to state control" by obligating uranium producers in Russia to negotiate export deals as a cartel, said Gary Hufbauer of the Institute for International Economics.
The Soviet Union began exporting uranium in large quantities in the late 1980's to help prop up its failing economy. In 1991 a handful of American producers of uranium and the labor union that represented their workers complained that the former Communist country was "dumping" uranium -- selling below the cost of production.
In October 1992 the Bush Administration negotiated a settlement with Russia and five other former Soviet republics that tied future sales of uranium in the United States to a sliding price scale: No uranium, beyond deliveries promised in earlier contracts, was to be sold unless the price of world market uranium reached $13 a pound. The $13 was far below the price that prevailed through most of the 1980's and roughly the cost of production for the most efficient American mines.
But contrary to expectations, that $13 threshold was never reached in 1993, so the former Soviet republics were not able to export uranium to the United States legally. And by late 1993 the beleaguered Yeltsin Government was pressing for a more liberal deal. The Russians even suggested that a failure to resolve the dumping case would threaten fulfillment of a separate agreement to sell to the United States 550 tons of highly enriched uranium, enough to make thousands of nuclear warheads, people close to the negotiations said.
 
Foreign Policy Goals
 When foreigners flood the American market with cheap commodities, Washington usually punishes the offenders with tariffs, or forces them to negotiate temporary import quotas. But when vital foreign policy goals, like stabilizing Russia, conflicted with American trade laws, the Commerce Department decided to turn the trade laws on their head.
With prodding from the State Department, Joseph Spetrini, then the Acting Deputy Secretary of Commerce, accepted radically different terms -- terms initially suggested by lawyers working for a trading and producing conglomerate, Concord, run by a Denver entrepreneur, Oren Benton. The conglomerate has worked closely with Russian uranium interests since Russia began exporting the commodity in 1988.
This amended agreement, signed in March, gave the Russians the right to export up to 42 million pounds to America over the next decade, roughly one-tenth of expected consumption by nuclear power plants. But there are strings: Every pound of Russian uranium must be matched with a newly mined pound of American uranium, and the blend must be sold to utilities for at least the prevailing market price.
The deal has another provision to accommodate the American producers. In effect, said Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University, the Russians are obligated to pay American producers not the prevailing market price -- what utilities pay for the uranium -- but rather what American producers would charge to supply the fuel. Say the utilities are paying $10 a pound, and the American producers want to charge $13. The utilities would pay $20 for the two-pound blend. The Russians would then pay the American producers $13 for their half of the blend, and keep the remaining $7.
 
Kazakh Treatment Cited
 But the arrangement seemed to meet Russia's demands, if not that of the other former Soviet republics. "I personally am disappointed and embarrassed by the way the United States has treated Kazakhstan," said Thomas Wilner, a lawyer at the firm of Shearman & Sterling, which represents the Kazakh Government.
Other unhappy parties are various uranium-exporting nations. Australia has protested to the Commerce Department, arguing that it violates America's obligations to trade fairly under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a 109-nation group that oversees world trade. And Jean Dominique Ierachi, a spokesman for Canada's Ministry of External Affairs, said "the agreement is inconsistent with Nafta," the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Professor Bhagwati, a former adviser to the staff of GATT, said both countries had a case. "It's a backdoor subsidy for domestic uranium," he asserted.
The Justice Department has also reacted coolly. While Homer Moyer Jr., a partner in Miller, Chevalier, a law firm in Washington that represents Concord, argues that "there will be more competition in the uranium market with the agreement than without it," others worry that the matching requirement is an invitation to price collusion. "There are antitrust risks," said Diane Wood, a Deputy Assistant Attorney General. "We're monitoring the situation."
 
No Deals Struck
 So far, there has been nothing to monitor. In spite of the prospect of obtaining above-market prices, no American company has struck a matching deal with the Russians. Indeed, the reaction from domestic producers not associated with Concord has ranged from suspicious to overtly hostile.
Daniel Einbund, a vice president of a consulting firm called New York Nuclear, wondered whether the Russians were really in a position to offer matching terms that any American producer could accept. With the market price now around $9 a pound, the Russians would have to agree to settle for just $6 or $7. "How low will they go?" he asks.
Then, too, there is the problem of trust. A contract with a private uranium producer in Canada can be enforced in American and Canadian courts. Deals with Russia, which has neither assets to seize in America nor a reliable system to adjudicate disputes with foreigners, is a different matter.
Another troubling issue has been raised by economists, who say the arrangement just doesn't make sense. Indeed, it is against American interests to treat former socialist economies in transition as if nothing had changed, they say.
The initial assessment of dumping against the former Soviet republics was made under Commerce Department rules for "nonmarket economies," where local prices are assumed to offer no clue to actual production costs. That, Mr. Hufbauer said, gave the Commerce Department broad discretion to estimate that the republics' costs were extremely high and that therefore very high dumping penalties were called for -- not surprising from a Government agency that sees itself primarily as a protector of American industry.
 
Negative Effects Seen
 By effectively forcing the former Soviet republics to negotiate national quotas, said Thomas Neff, a political scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Washington is reinforcing the bureaucrats' control over production decisions -- "the very thing we are trying to change."
Professor Neff said the amended pact with the Russians not only drove control toward the old guard but encouraged Russia to export large quantities of uranium at very low prices. That may keep Russian miners employed, but it will also make the mines dependent on continuing Government subsidies to stay afloat. "We are encouraging inefficient production," he said.

HEADLINE: A Giant Restrained;
Superpower Obligations and Huge Deficits Tie U.S. Hands in Trade Talks With Japan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
A top American trade official argues that the Japanese always have an edge in their negotiations with the United States for one simple reason: they get to practice "commerce," while the American side always has to practice "diplomacy."
Commerce is the art of the deal. It is practiced with a narrow lens, focused on one's own profits and competitive advantage. Diplomacy is the art of compromise. It is practiced with a wide-angle lens, focused on what is good not only for the nation's economy, but also for its global relationships. Commerce is about going for the jugular. Diplomacy is about holding hands. 
 These differences come to mind these days as the Clinton Administration lowers its expectations in its negotiations with Japan, from the pugnacious tone and policies with which it initially confronted Tokyo to the almost resigned "let's take what we can get and move on" approach now being pursued.
The "framework" negotiations, in which the Administration was looking for a package deal to open Japan's markets in automobiles, auto parts, telecommunications, medical equipment and insurance, will now be pursued piece by piece. Deals will be cut where they can be made, when they can be made. It is certainly better than nothing, but clearly not all that was hoped for.
Why the change? Because the United States simply does not have the influence to demand more. In effect, America cannot practice commerce with Japan. The giant has been "Gulliverized," tied down by two sets of ropes. One is the responsibilities that come from being an economic and political superpower, and the other is the limitations that come from having run up such huge Federal deficits and trade deficits over the years. Foreigners, particularly the Japanese, now hold billions of American dollars, greatly inhibiting what Washington can do to them.
In its heart, the Clinton Administration would love to go for Tokyo's jugular with the same single-mindedness with which Japan pursues its economic interests. But the United States' superpower legacy and its huge debt now make that virtually impossible. In the end, Washington seems doomed to diplomacy.
"We are still the country responsible for the global financial system, which we basically set up, and for global security," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "It is a real constraint. Although Japan has the second-largest economy in the world, it has no such legacy. It has a much more national and regional focus and does not tend to worry about the implications for the global system."
Consider the last few months: When the Japanese dragged their feet in negotiations and the United States tried to punish them by pushing up the value of the yen -- so that all of Japan's exports would be more expensive -- world financial markets panicked and drove down the dollar even further, forcing Washington to back off. When the Japanese dragged their feet in negotiations and the American trade team wanted to play hardball, foreign policy advisers whispered in the President's ear that he could not afford a confrontation with Tokyo now, when its support was so crucial as Washington tried to deal with North Korea's nuclear threat.
 
 
Big Weapon: Treasury Notes
 When the Japanese dragged their feet and the United States threatened bilateral trade sanctions on Tokyo, Europeans and Asians howled that Washington was breaking the rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and undermining the global trading system it helped to establish. When the United States let the dollar fall to make exports to Japan cheaper, the Japanese started selling the billions of dollars of Treasury notes they had bought to help finance the American deficit, which forced up interest rates in this country.
And that is a real constraint. Put simply, the American economy now spends more than it can finance through domestic savings. To keep the economy growing, the United States must attract foreign savings from countries like Japan; otherwise the American economy will slow down. If Japanese investors are frightened by either the prospect of a trade war or a devaluing American currency, they will be less willing to buy the bonds, stocks and Treasury instruments that fuel the American economy. America can no longer have growth and a real get-tough Japan policy at the same time.
"It is our net debtor status, and our current account deficit, that imposes an inherent limitation on our freedom of action in international trade policy" vis-a-vis Japan, said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
In other words, every time the Administration tries to bring leverage to bear on Japan, either the global interests of the United States or its global economic exposure forces Washington to hold back. Whenever the Clinton Administration tries to exercise pressure by pulling one lever or another, that lever comes off in its hand.
 
 
 
Possible Approaches
 What to do? Some argue that Washington should abandon the rancorous and energy-consuming effort to open specific Japanese markets and simply focus on getting Japan to stimulate its economy with tax cuts and Government spending, which would spur consumer demand for imports across the board. That is a less confrontational approach, and there are allies for it in Japan.
Others, like Joe Massey, a former top Bush Administration trade official, argue for shifting the emphasis in negotiations away from the Japanese Government, where little leverage can be brought to bear, to negotiating instead directly with Japanese businesses. Individually, they are much more vulnerable to American threats, from anti-dumping suits to antitrust suits.
"What we need to do is shift our focus to the Japanese private-sector companies which are the actual marketplace for our goods," Mr. Massey said. "The formal Government barriers are not that important any more. It is the informal barriers that are important -- the relationships between Japanese suppliers -- and we have to break into that."

HEADLINE: Speaker Vallone's Opportunity

 BODY:
The New York City Council has no more vehement champion than Peter Vallone, its Speaker since 1986. He never hesitates to point out that the revised City Charter has given the Council more muscle. Now -- city budget time -- is his moment to prove it.
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's budget for the year that starts July 1 heads the Council's agenda. At issue is his proposal for deep cuts in social service agency funds, while he refuses to seek similar cuts in the police and fire departments. 
 As a Democratic Council member from a middle-class district in Queens, Mr. Vallone says his ideology and the Republican Mayor's are not very different. But as Speaker, he is leader of the entire Council and represents a broader constituency.
Budget negotiations are under way, aimed toward passage in the next few weeks. These negotiations have extra significance in establishing the Council's authority because this budget is a new Mayor's first thrust, and because the Council, with a heavily Democratic majority, faces a Republican Mayor for the first time.
Mainstream Democrats are furious, and properly so, over proposed social service cuts, particularly in services for children and teen-agers, while Mr. Giuliani's political backers in the uniformed forces are left untouched. Balance is essential. There must be belt-tightening everywhere, including social services, but also including safe, reasonable economies in the police and fire departments.
The Mayor insists the uniformed forces cannot be cut because the state aid for their agencies sets specific requirements, including a specific head count for police. Here lies the Speaker's opportunity to exercise the power he claims for the Council.
Mr. Vallone strongly supported the state legislation that pays for more city police and firefighters. But the legislation has a basic flaw; it focuses on total numbers of uniformed personnel, whether they are deskbound or out on the street.
The Mayor and Council should look instead to patrol strength. Analyses by the Citizens Budget Commission, a private group, have shown that enforcement can be strengthened while hiring fewer new police officers -- for example, by hiring lower-paid civilians to handle duties that do not require a uniformed officer.
Reduction in the uniformed force would require an O.K. from Albany. Mr. Giuliani shows no inclination to seek it, and his people say the Legislature would not approve if he did. But nothing ventured, nothing gained.
Mr. Vallone has undisputed control over the members of the Council's Democratic majority. If he opts for a showdown with the Mayor on the police-fire issue, he and the Council might prevail. If he chooses instead to let members just tinker with projects that please their constituents, he will lessen the Council's clout.

HEADLINE: In America;
The Job-Killer Policy

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
To anyone who has grown up with the deeply American belief that the best way to get ahead is to roll up your sleeves and get to work, it must seem peculiar that the Clinton Administration has adopted a policy that deliberately puts a brake on the economy, and thus on the number of Americans who can work.
The Administration, genuflecting before the Federal Reserve, is now more concerned with inflation than with the chronically high unemployment that is eroding the promise of the American dream for millions of men and women. 
 But what inflation? Nobody can find the inflation. Having run from so many other battles, the Administration is now engaged in a fight to the death with a phantom. It's a fight that pleases the wealthy but has painful consequences for ordinary working men and women, and for the poor.
Stephen Blackwell, a supervisor with the State Department of Labor in New York, mentioned the discouragement he continues to see in the faces of the working poor as they sign up for unemployment benefits and job search assistance. "We hear that things are getting better," said Mr. Blackwell, "but our gut reaction is that things haven't substantially improved."
Mr. Blackwell has worked in the same Manhattan office for 30 years and knows many of the clients personally. "You now see people accepting jobs that pay much less than jobs they would have accepted years ago. At some point it gets to be an emotional thing for me. I see people that I've known for years who are now struggling; people who are hard workers just like me, maybe harder."
The decision to sacrifice the livelihoods of real people to placate the evil spirit of inflation has enormous consequences, most of them bad. A lack of meaningful work is at the core of nearly all the social problems plaguing the country. You cannot gather up the pieces and begin to repair the damage we have done to families without finding a way to create many more jobs. You cannot achieve meaningful welfare reform, or universal health coverage, without a growing market for labor. And you sure can't make any real headway on crime without putting vast numbers of young people to work.
But we are not moving in that direction. The outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas reported yesterday that work-force reductions through May were running 18 percent ahead of the first five months of 1993. While there are jobs being created (many of them temporary or part time), corporate downsizing continues at a rapid, perhaps record-breaking rate. There are vast regions of the work force that have yet to be reached by the economic recovery, and they won't be reached as long as the brakes are kept on expansion.
Joseph Kneafsey, who manages Mr. Blackwell's office, says he is seeing professionals who are "a job away" from their specialties. An example would be a senior programmer who loses a job, cannot find other work in the field, manages to land a job as a bookkeeper, and then loses that job.
Mr. Kneafsey was asked, in light of official statistics showing decreasing unemployment, if he was seeing any improvement at all. After a long pause he replied, "Very limited."
If the country is not yet strong enough economically to have nearly full employment for the middle class, how will it be possible to get decent jobs to the working poor, and beyond them to the hard-core unemployed?
"You can't at this level of growth in the economy," said Jeff Faux, president of the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. In Mr. Faux's view, the argument that you have to sacrifice jobs to keep inflation under control is a specious one, given current economic conditions.
Mr. Faux noted that over the last 80 years, the period for which price indices are available, the United States has never experienced runaway inflation that resulted from a peacetime economy surging out of control. "In our actual experience," he said, "the dreaded wage-price spiral has only occurred when markets have been suddenly jolted by war or supply shocks, such as occurred with the oil embargoes."
The inflation rate is a shade under 3 percent, yet the Federal Reserve remains mesmerized. As for out-of-work Americans -- well, too bad about them.

HEADLINE: Foreign Policy: A Fresh Start

 BODY:
The long D-Day weekend celebrating unity of purpose, commemorating individual acts of bravery and recalling the eventual triumph of good over evil lifted spirits on both sides of the Atlantic and allowed President Clinton to float, at least momentarily, above the foreign policy frustrations that have plagued his first 17 months.
If only today's foreign policy agenda lent itself to such clarity and back-to-the-wall heroism. But the challenges of 1994 are less cataclysmic -- and far more ambiguous -- than those of 1944. And when the President tried, in his speech to the French National Assembly yesterday, to summon some of that D-Day spirit to address present European challenges, the exercise looked strained. 
 The goals Mr. Clinton articulated were worthy: expand democracy, integrate the economies of Eastern and Western Europe, develop a system of cooperative security with the former Warsaw Pact, try to contain and calm the Bosnian conflict. But where the weekend's commemorative speeches rang with purpose and personal engagement, yesterday's policy address had all the passion of a political science text.
Yet Mr. Clinton still has a rare chance to refocus his Administration's foreign policy, clarifying America's role in the world and improving day-to-day execution. The President's careful preparations for this trip and his immersion in recent European history have given him new confidence in foreign affairs and perhaps a new appreciation of its significance for his Presidency. And his creditable performance has won respect at home and abroad. It is a valuable moment in his Presidency, a chance for a fresh foreign policy start. He should make the most of it.
One lesson the President seems to have learned recently is that a big power like the United States cannot easily abstain from major global crises. Given America's global engagement during the half-century from Pearl Harbor to the collapse of the Soviet Union, even a decision not to intervene in a place like Bosnia becomes a form of intervention.
Yet Mr. Clinton has always understood that Washington cannot continue to assume all the global responsibilities that came with the cold war. Rightly, he wants his Presidency to be known for its domestic accomplishments. Belatedly, he is coming to understand that a reputation for foreign policy fecklessness can undermine domestic credibility.
Mr. Clinton's biggest problem has been the unresolved conflict between a globalist rhetorical agenda that seems to invite U.S. involvement everywhere and day-to-day decision-making that seems to permit it nowhere. Compounding this has been the President's reluctance to appear personally engaged in his own Administration's foreign policy.
Mr. Clinton succeeded so well in Europe this week because he finally did step into the role of national leader and Commander in Chief. He needs to build on that success by speaking out more often and more effectively on foreign policy issues, abandoning academic abstractions for the kind of strong personal imagery he used in the cemeteries and battle sites of Europe.
And he needs to close the gap between rhetoric and practice by making firm choices among competing priorities.
In an era of reduced danger, no abstract set of rules can determine when the U.S. should involve its forces in a foreign crisis. Washington should not try to manage the world. It should be clear about the differences between localized crises, however intense, and strategic challenges, like the future of Russia, China and Mexico. It should mainly look out for American interests, including the defense of allies and the promotion of American values.
Presidents rarely get the chance to change course in foreign policy without a disastrous loss of credibility. Mr. Clinton has such a chance now.

HEADLINE: Australia Doesn't Wink at East Timor Abuses

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Timorous on Timor," your egregious May 24 editorial, gravely misrepresents Australia's position on East Timor. Although Australia has recognized the sovereign authority of Indonesia over East Timor since February 1979, our public concerns and representations over violations of human rights in the region are well-documented. Recognition of Indonesia's sovereign authority in no way implies approval of the circumstances of the Indonesian acquisition of East Timor. 
 Far from "meekly refusing to challenge Indonesia" as you state, Australia raises its concerns with the Indonesian Government with committed persistence. We have been unswerving in our call for a process of reconciliation in East Timor, which would involve economic development sensitive to the needs of the East Timorese and a major reduction in military presence. This is understood by the Indonesians.
Australia supported the 1993 resolution of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights critical of the human rights situation in East Timor. This year Australia joined the commission's consensus adoption of the chairman's statement on human rights in East Timor.
On a practical level, Australian diplomats, official delegations (some parliamentary) and journalists visit East Timor regularly, and the issue stays prominent in Australia.
Despite difficulties and obstructions, Australia delivers development assistance specifically to East Timor, including funds to improve water supplies and sanitation, donations to the United Nations Children's Fund project and the Red Cross.
Your bizarre suggestion that Australian diplomats avoid using the words East Timor for fear of offending Indonesia is simply fanciful. We use the terminology "East Timor" bilaterally and in global forums, as anyone who follows the debate would know. I might note that your own editorial languished under a headline in which the "East" had been lost from Timor.
 
DON RUSSELL
Ambassador of Australia to the U.S.
Washington, May 27, 1994

HEADLINE: The Trouble With a Bull Run Theme Park

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire betrays misunderstanding in "Third Manassas" (column, May 26) of opposition to Disney's proposed development in Virginia. The issue is the site, in some of America's most beautiful and historic countryside. Opponents would welcome the theme park closer to Washington, where it could be served by public transportation, thus eliminating the air pollution of adding 77,000 car trips a day to a gridlocked Interstate 66. 
 A site closer to Washington would also provide jobs to people who need them. The unemployment rate in rural Prince William County has been less than 3 percent for a decade, a figure most public officials can only dream about. The Washington unemployed figure is much higher.
Historians don't really care if Disney is interested in American history. The issue is, rather, should Disney create massive urban sprawl with a megadevelopment in rural Virginia and desecrate historic Civil War battlefields -- battlefields where thousands of Americans died in our bloodiest conflict and which are the legacy of all Americans.
The sprawl, air pollution, traffic congestion and water pollution the development will generate throughout Northern Virginia, the District and the Maryland suburbs are unwelcome to most residents, not just the historians and other "elites" Mr. Safire sneers at.
 
ARLIE SCHARDT
Executive Director
Environmental Media Services
Washington, May 31, 1994

HEADLINE: IN PERFORMANCE;
THEATER

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:

Variations on Odysseus In a Play From Britain
Ohio Theater
"Waiting at the Water's Edge," a play by Lucinda Coxon, both celebrates and demands patience. This fablelike tale is as fat, leisurely and dense with social detail as a novel from the early 20th century, the period in which it is set. 
 Indeed, the British play initially seems as conventional as an Edwardian slice-of-life series on PBS, as it carefully sets up the contrasting characters of Vi (Isabel Keating), a restive miner's daughter, and the more domestic Su (Patricia Scanlon), both servants to an isolated, imperious woman (Sharon Laughlin) in coastal Wales.
For a while, all goes according to class-conscious British formula: Su wrestles with the humiliations of a maid's life; Vi begins a relationship with her employer's brow-beaten son, Will (gracefully played by Simon Brooking). When a violent accident forces Vi to escape to Canada disguised as a man, the play shifts disjunctively from naturalism to magical realism. And Vi, aided by a ghost, metamorphoses into a tyrannical mining executive.
Vi and Su suggest variations on Odysseus and Penelope: the nomadic adventurer and the virtuous woman who waits. In making both characters female, Ms. Coxon ingeniously subverts myth to explore economic and sexual identity. But she is more skilled in establishing themes than in working them out. The drama's second act is often ungainly and reductionist, particularly in unfolding the social motives of Vi's revenge.
Nela Wagman's efficient, simple staging, ballasted by lucid performances, doesn't transcend the play's limitations. But it highlights Ms. Coxon's undeniable gifts for building narrative and, in examining forms of loneliness and ambition, for fluidly forging connections between social cause and emotional effect.
The play, a Watermark Theater production, is at the Ohio Theater, 66 Wooster Street, SoHo. BEN BRANTLEY

GRAPHIC: Photo: Simon Brooking, left, and Isabel Keating in a scene from Lucinda Coxon's new play, "Waiting at the Water's Edge," a Watermark Theater production at the Ohio Theater in SoHo. It is directed by Nela Wagman. (Peter Cook/"Waiting at the Water's Edge")
