HEADLINE: LEADERS IN ALBANY FINALLY ANNOUNCE A BUDGET ACCORD

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 7

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders said tonight that they had finally cobbled together the last details of the $34 billion state budget in a deal that reflected both the revival of New York State's fiscal health and the political needs of a difficult election year.
Sixty-eight days after the legal deadline passed, Mr. Cuomo and the leaders of the State Senate and the Assembly had reached agreement on one last issue: exactly how much the state would increase assistance to schools and local governments. Lawmakers returned to the session late tonight to begin debating the package, and were expected to finish voting early Wednesday. 
 "Frankly I think it's done," Mr. Cuomo said after he and legislative leaders resolved a dispute today over $30 million that had threatened to delay the budget further.
Final numbers were not available, but the budget, leavened with a $1.5 billion surplus, was expected to contain the largest spending increase since the recession, which hit New York State especially hard, began five years ago.
The budget was also a candidly political document, spreading road projects and sports arena repairs around the state and increasing school assistance to virtually all 718 school districts this election year. [News analysis, page B4.]
Lawmakers had already reviewed agreements on tax cuts, fingerprinting for welfare recipients and capital spending. Today they reviewed agreements on local spending, a limited state takeover of county governments' Medicaid costs and a plan to reorganize, and in some ways restrict, how the state borrows and plans for expensive capital projects.
Local governments would receive a total increase of $147 million this year in aid for health care costs for the poor, educating disabled students and other unrestricted aid. For all types of aid, New York City would receive significantly more than the $275 million that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani requested to help close a projected $2.3 billion budget gap.
Estimates of the city's share varied from about $300 million to $418 million. Robert M. Harding, the city's lobbyist in Albany, called the estimates "good news."
"From everything we're been told by the leaders, this budget will give us in excess of $275 million," he said.
But Mr. Giuliani said today at City Hall, before the budget numbers were released, that the outcome for the city was still uncertain because of a bill the Legislature passed on Monday requiring the city to spend a set amount of state aid on students, not on balancing its budget.
"Essentially, what this law does is memorialize the present way in which the money is being allocated in the school system, which is really terrible," he said.
Legislative aides, however, gave the bill a dim chance for survival, and Mr. Cuomo has yet to say whether he will sign the bill into law.
School districts would receive $550 million in added aid for the coming school year, a 6 percent increase to a total of $9.68 billion. Of that total, New York City would receive an increase of $265 million in the coming school year, an increase of about 8 percent, to a total of $3.38 billion.
The budget's outlines were disclosed days ago. But the Legislature was prepared to vote on the final plan only hours after details were disclosed on $150 million in so-called legislative initiatives and member items, virtually closing off public scrutiny of those most sensitive projects. That spending goes to pet local projects of individual legislators, and one-third of the spending is never itemized in the final budget.
Only one budget fight has dragged on longer: in 1991 the Legislature adopted its final plan on July 4.
 
Praise From Cuomo
 Mr. Cuomo praised the final deal, which more than doubled the $210 million in tax cuts he proposed in January, saying it showed a state on its way to economic strength. "It is clear that we have resumed the voyage toward a stronger and better New York," he said.
The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, sought to take credit tonight for the tax cuts, mostly for businesses, projected to be worth between $450 million and $476 million this year and $1.7 billion when fully in effect.
"The tax cut package in this budget is the blueprint for a new beginning and partnership with the business community and the renewal of our commitment to provide jobs and a better future for all New Yorkers," Mr. Marino said in a statement.
Aside from state assistance to schools and local governments, the leaders announced agreement on a debt reform proposal today that was praised by both State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and the Citizens Budget Commission, a private advocacy group supported by businesses.
The bill, pushed strongly by Mr. Cuomo as a way to improve the state's low bond ratings, would end almost all forms of backdoor borrowing -- essentially loans that the state takes out without voter approval.
Under existing law, all state borrowing is supposed to be approved by voter referendum, but in fact lawmakers have resorted to a variety of techniques to avoid such public scrutiny. In 1990, for example, the state transferred ownership of Attica state prison to a public authority as collateral for a $200 million bond issue.
 
A Set Percentage
 The new bill would for the first time allow the Legislature to approve bond issues directly, without a voter referendum, but would limit such borrowing to a set percentage tied to the total personal income of the state's residents. It would also require the Governor to submit a detailed list of expected capital projects and their costs each year.
The bill was introduced as a constitutional amendment and requires the approval of two consecutively elected legislatures, followed by voter approval.
"The state has relied on expensive and unacceptable backdoor financing and fiscal gimmicks for too long," said Mr. McCall, who helped draft the package. The bill, he said, "will bring real change to the process."
On one major issue, the cost of the Medicaid program of health care for the poor, the new budget included some modest help to local governments, which have been complaining loudly about high costs. Mayor Giuliani and county leaders lobbied heavily for the state to take over their share of the costs, but in the end the budget called for a two-year plan for the state to assume a fraction of the counties' $3.2 billion share of the $22 billion program.
This year the budget calls for an increase of $48.9 million to local governments to pay for long-term and managed care costs. New York City's share would be $31.5 million, and roughly double the sum next year. The state already pays about 80 percent of the local share of these costs.
The state currently pays 34 percent of the total Medicaid program, or $7.5 billion, and the Federal Government picks up the rest, or $14.5 billion.
 
'Underlying Problem'
 While grateful for any extra aid, John R. Zagame, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties, likened the deal to "rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic."
"Never has so much time been wasted by so many on so little without addressing the most pressing, critical, underlying problem the state faces -- which is how to address out-of-control Medicaid costs," he said.
The state will also pick up $118 million over two years for a program that prepares handicapped preschoolers to attend regular classes. The state will ultimately pay for 39 percent. New York City's share would be $12.6 million this year.
Two other items related to medical care were included, both of which became the source of fierce haggling near the end of the negotiations.
The Assembly won a program to expand a health insurance program to an additional 24,000 children of low-income parents not eligible for Medicaid. The program currently covers children 12 years of age and under. With the new plan, it would include 13-year-olds this year and 14-year-olds next year. This year the plan would cost an additional $5 million.
 
Help for Hospitals
 The Senate won a program to assist hospitals by allowing them to increase the rate they charge to insurers in a one-year aid package worth $95 million. The package, which would cost the state $13.8 million, would benefit virtually all of the state's 268 hospitals.
The state's legislative budget, which pays for staff, supplies and other expenses, was set to increase about 5.8 percent over last year for a total of $177 million.
And closing a long chapter of lobbying from Brooklyn, the budget also provides $1.3 million to change Medgar Evers College from a two-year to a four-year institution. The change would take place July 1.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 10, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Wednesday with articles about the New York State budget misstated the date when the legislature finished approving the budget for the 1994 fiscal year. It was June 8, not June 7.
